āaqu(i).Comment: The literal sense of this is "to water-enter", Z hasthe reflex of AH instead of Ā-TL, but the sense isof Ā-TL, and Z has AH for Ā-TL elsewhere.

āc.Comment: This is the preterit agentive form derived from theexistential verb Ā.  It contrasts in vowel lengthwith AC, the preterit form of AQU(I) "to enter".

ācachiquihu(i)-tl.Spanish: canasto hecho de can9as (M), jiŸcara para tortillas(X)
ācachiquihu(i)-tl.Comment: The initial vowel is not marked long in theattestation.

acachtopahuiā.English: to be the first to do s.t.
acachtopahuiā.Spanish: soy el primero que hago algo (C for first pers. sg.)

ācāhual-li.English: large, dry leaves for lighting ovens
ācāhual-li.Spanish: yerbas secas y grandes para encender hornos (M)
ācāhual-li.Comment: The second vowel is attested long only once, butit should be long if the literal sense is"s.t. dehydrated".

ācāhuatōtō-tl.English: small yellow or blue bird with gray on the back
ācāhuatōtō-tl.Spanish: paŸjaro (chico, amarillo o azul con gris sobre laespalda) (T)

ācalaquiā.Spanish: se bucea (de bucear), se mete en el agua (Z), meteralgo debajo del agua, o hundirlo (M)

ācal-li.Comment: The literal sense of this is "water-house".

acāloah.English: a type of lizard that bites
acāloah.Spanish: un animal que muerde--parecido a la largatija (Z)
acāloah.Comment: Z provides a picture which appears to be of a gilamonster.  The final H is uncharacteristic of nativeNahuatl but is common to vowel-final loanwords.

ācamāya.Comment: The attestation on Zp.139 has an uncharacteristicfinal H as does ACĀLOAH.

ācapah-tli.Spanish: planta medicinal semejante en las hojas al raŸbano
ācapah-tli.Comment: The initial vowel is not marked long in theattestation.

ācapech-tli.Comment: Z fails to mark the initial vowel long.

acatto.Comment: Cf.98r gives YACATTO as a variant.

acattopa.Comment: Cf.98r gives YACATTOPA as a variant.

ācax(i)-tl.Spanish: alberca (M), pileta para tomar agua los animales (X)
ācax(i)-tl.Comment: X fails to mark the initial vowel long.

ach.Spanish: part. que ordinariamente indica duda y a vecesequivale a una negacioŸn (S)
ach.Comment: Cf.125v gives ACHAH as a variant.  Zp.139 givesACHA = ĀCHĀ as variants.

āchcāuh-tli.Spanish: primogeŸnito, hermano mayor de alguien, el jefe dealguien (S)
āchcāuh-tli.Comment: This seems to be related to ACHTO "first", but thereis a vowel-length discrepancy.

achchica.Comment: This is commonly written with only a single CH.  Ofsix attestations in C, one has a marked long vowel inthe second syllable.

achcōl-li.Spanish: bisabuelo (M for achtontli, which is in appositionwith ACHCŌL-LI in B)
achcōl-li.Comment: All the attestations are possessed plurals withreduplication of the CŌL element: COHCŌL.  Twoattestations have the first element with aspecifically marked short vowel, two with aspecifically marked long vowel.  In the paired formACHTŌN-TLI, Bf.6v, the vowel of the first elementis specifically marked short.  This is inconsistentwith the first element of ĀCHCĀUH-TLI "elderbrother", which is without exception marked long, butit agrees with ACHTO "first".  X appears to havereanalyzed the plural as a singular and dropped ACH.

achi.Spanish: un poco, o poca cosa, o en alguna manera (M)
achi.Comment: This appears to be an element in constructions whereit has the contrary sense of "a lot, more, verymuch", as in ACHIPA "always", ACHICUAL-LI "better".See the note with ACHĪC.  In some, but not all,constructions this has a final glottal stop, ACHIH.

achīc.Spanish: hay diferencia entre una persona, o cosa, y otra (C)
achīc.Comment: This comparative ACHĪC may be related in some way tothe contradictory "more" sense of ACHI.

achihtzinca.Spanish: un poco de intervalo, o espacio de tiempo (M)

āchīhual-li.Spanish: agua que se ocupa para moler (T)

āchīhuiā.English: to wash one's hands while grinding maize
āchīhuiā.Spanish: se lava las manos (mujer cuando muele) (T)

āchīhuīlō.Comment: In the attestation of this on Tp.164 the vowel of thesecond syllable is incorrectly marked short.

āchio-tl.English: a tree (Bixa orellana) from the seeds of which ismade a paste used as a seasoning and for coloringthings orange
āchio-tl.Spanish: bija, fruto empleado en el ten9ido (S), achiote,fruto y aŸrbol conocido (R)
āchio-tl.Comment: This is attested in R without diacritics.  X has-TLI, implying a glottal stop at the end of the stem,but in general Nahuatl has -TL with this item.

ach-tli.Comment: This seems to be related to XINĀCH-TLI "seed", butthere is a vowel-length discrepancy.  It also seemsto be related to the HUACH element of AYOHHUACH-TLI"squash seed".  It contrasts in vowel length withĀCH-TLI "elder brother".

āch-tli.English: elder brother (from the point of view of a youngersister)
āch-tli.Spanish: hermano mayor de la hermana menor (C)
āch-tli.Comment: This seems to be related to ACHTO "first", but thereis a vowel-length discrepancy.  It contrasts invowel length with ACH-TLI "seed".

achtopahuiā.English: to take the lead in some matter
achtopahuiā.Spanish: guiar en alguna cosa o ser el primero en hacerla (R)

ācōcīl-in.Comment: R provides the characteristic -IN absolutive suffix ofsmall animates.

ācocoā.English: for a plant to suffer from overwatering

acocoh-tli.English: acocote, name of several different squash plants
acocoh-tli.Spanish: dos plantas medicinales semejante la una al nardo (R)

ācōlhuah.Spanish: fuerte, es tambieŸn nombre de nacioŸn (R)

ācōlō-tl.Comment: The literal sense of this is "water-scorpion", as inthe Spanish gloss.

āconi.Comment: This form appears to be peculiar to Z.

ācui.Comment: Z has the reflex of AH rather than Ā-TL, but thesense demands the latter.

acxoya-tl.English: branches used in penitential offerings; fir
acxoya-tl.Spanish: planta cuyas hojas eran utilizadas por los sacerdotespara recoger la sangre que se sacaban por penitencia(S)

ah-.Spanish: negacioŸn, usado en comp. por amo, no (S)

ahachi.Comment: T gives this bound with ZAN, ZANAHACHI.  It ispossible that this is a case of distributivereduplication rather than negation in view of the"more, very much" sense of ACHI in some otherconstructions.

ahahcui.English: to rise up; to raise s.t. up
ahahcui.Spanish: se levanta (Z); lo levanta, lo alza, lo eleva (Z)
ahahcui.Comment: The sense of this suggests that it is a reduplicatedform related to AHCOCU(I).

ahāhuiā.Comment: This implies *ĀHUIĀ, of which this would be thereduplicated form.  This contrasts with AHĀHUIY(A)"to take pleasure".

ahāhuiy(a).Comment: This contrasts with AHĀHUIĀ "to moisten s.t."

ahalac-tli.English: alache, a fibrous, slippery plant (Sida rhombifolia)

ahāmāxēhu(i).Spanish: se escalda (de comezoŸn), se pone blanquizca (lamano, etc.), se esponja (frijol, etc.), se enlama (T)

ahaquiā.Comment: This distributive form contrasts with AHĀQUIĀ "tomoisten s.t."

ahāquiā.Comment: This contrasts with AHAQUIĀ "to insert s.t.repeatedly".

ahātēm(i).English: to fill up with water, to flood

ahātocō.English: for things to be carried away by water
ahātocō.Comment: This is derived from the nonactive form of the verb.

ahātōltic.Spanish: cosa muy blanda, como higo muy maduro, etc. (M),aguado, magullado (T)
ahātōltic.Comment: T does not mark the vowel of the second syllablelong.

ahcazomō.Comment: In one of two attestations R gives this with aglottal stop in the third syllable, but infour attestations in C there is no glottal stopindicated.

ahchīuhcāyō-tl.Comment: The vowel of the second syllable is not markedlong in either attestation.  C gives AHIUHCĀYŌ-TLas a synonym of this.

ahci.English: to catch s.t. with the hand, to reach for and takes.t.
ahci.Spanish: alcanzar con la mano a donde estaŸ la cosa (M)
ahci.Comment: T has lost the internal glottal stop.  A lexicalizedreflexive form of this conveys a sense of wholenessor completeness, as in MAHXĪTIĀ "to cause s.t.to become complete".  M has synonymous maxiltiaand also macic "s.t. whole", which can bind withverbs to mean "completely".

ahcicācaqu(i).Spanish: comprender o alcanzar a saber enteramente la cosao el negocio (M)

ahcicāitta.English: to perceive s.t., to know s.t. well
ahcicāitta.Spanish: advertir, conocer bien (R), ver algo perfectamente(M)

ahcicāmat(i).English: to master s.t., to understand s.t. completely

ahcocu(i).English: to rise up; to raise s.t. up
ahcocu(i).Spanish: levantarse de suelo, o empinarse el caballo, orevolar el ave, o batir las alas cuando quiere volar(M), alzar o levantar algo en alto (M)

ahcol-li.Comment: This invites analysis as a derivation from *CŌL"something twisted, bent", but there is a differencein vowel length.

ahcoltehtequ(i).English: to cut oneself in the shoulder

ahcoman(a).English: to get worked up, to become disturbed; to disturbothers
ahcoman(a).Spanish: alborotarse, o turbarse (M), alborotar a los otros(M)

ahcoquetz(a).English: to build up s.t.; to raise the bidding at an auction
ahcoquetz(a).Spanish: aumentar o doblar el trabajo a otros, o pujar enalmoneda (M), erigir, alivar (R)

ahcual-li.Comment: The literal sense is "s.t. not good".

ahhua.English: to scold s.o., to quarrel with s.o., to irritate s.o.

ahhuach-tli.Comment: This is implied by the many compounds ofof which it is an element.

ahhua-tl.Comment: M puts the definition of this together with thedefinition of ĀHUA-TL "oak" and ĀHUĀ-TL, a type ofcaterpillar.

ahhuayohua.Comment: In both attestations Z marks the final vowel long,which is unlikely in terms of Nahuatl verbmorphology.

ahhuayohualiz-tli.Comment: Z marks the vowel of the fourth syllablelong in both attestations.

ahhuel.Spanish: no poder, no ser posible (R), imposible,absolutamente no (S)

ahhuiāc.Spanish: cosa suave y olorosa, o cosa gustosa (M)

ahhuiācāyō-tl.Spanish: suavidad o fragrancia, o olor de cosa sabrosa ygustosa (M)

ahhuiāliz-tli.Spanish: suavidad de olor, o de cosa gustosa y sabrosa (M)

ahhuiāya.Spanish: tener o dar de siŸ buen olor (M)

ahhuīc.English: here and there, back and forth
ahhuīc.Spanish: a una parte y a otra (M)
ahhuīc.Comment: C contrasts this with ĀHUĪC "toward the water".

ahhuīcpa.English: from one side to another, from one place to another
ahhuīcpa.Spanish: de un lado y de otro, de un lugar a otro (S)

ahiuhcāyō-tl.Comment: C gives AHCHĪUHCĀYŌ-TL as a synonym of this.

ahman(a).English: to get worked up, to be discontent
ahman(a).Comment: This contrasts with ĀMAN(A) "for water to becontained".

ahmō.Comment: T and Z have lost the internal glottal stop, and thisis true for most Nahuatl outside the Valley ofMexico, but although AHMŌ and also AHHUEL(I) aregenerally attested in modern Nahuatl without it,other forms with the negative prefix AH- generallyretain some reflex of the glottal stop.

ahmōcual-li.Spanish: mal, malo, mala, no es bueno (T)
ahmōcual-li.Comment: More common in older texts is the shorter formAHCUAL-LI, but AHMŌCUAL-LI appears in P as wellas in the modern sources.

ahmohuiā.Spanish: enjabonarse, lavarse la cabeza con jaboŸn (S)
ahmohuiā.Comment: This is apparently derived from AHMŌL-LI "soap" withloss of L and vowel shortening.  Although T, Z,and R all attest L-loss, Mhas amolhuia with the L, both reflexive andtransitive, with the sense of "to wash with soap".

ahmōl-li.Spanish: raiŸz conocida que sirve de jaboŸn (R)
ahmōl-li.Comment: In the derived form AHMOHUIĀ the vowel of thesecond syllable is short, and the L is lost.

ahmōquēn.Spanish: carencia de turbacioŸn, pena, y cuidado (C)
ahmōquēn.Comment: In M this does not appear as a separate entry but aspart of three phrases.  The literal sense is "in nomanner".

ahpān(a).English: to gird oneself, to be dressed
ahpān(a).Spanish: arrearse o cen9irse con manta de algodoŸn, o con otracosa semejante (M)

ahpāzhuēhuēn.Comment: T does not have the reflex of a long vowel in thefinal syllable, but in HUĒHUĒNTŌN and HUĒHUĒNTZIN"old man" it is long.  T forms the pluralof this item by adding the plural form ofthe compounding element -TŌN.

ahpāz-tli.Spanish: lebrillo, o barren9oŸn grande de barro (M)

ahpilōl-li.Spanish: jarro de barro (M), el caŸntaro de la mano (C)
ahpilōl-li.Comment: Ā "water" rather than AH is to be expected for thefirst element if this is literally "liquid-pourer",but the attestation clearly indicates a glottal stop.

ahpōchquiyāhuayohcān.Comment: In B this refers to the land of the dead.

ahquetz(a).English: to raise one's head; to rear up; to be upside down
ahquetz(a).Spanish: levantar o alzar la cabeza (M), se lo empina (T),boca arriba (T)
ahquetz(a).Comment: M combines the definitions of AHQUETZ(A) withĀQUETZ(A) "to beat liquid (such as chocolate) into afoam".  In principle, the sense of "to lift up thehead" could be derived from Ā-TL's "crown of thehead" sense, but C specifically contrasts AHQUETZ(A)with ĀQUETZ(A).

ahquetztitlahcal(i).Spanish: lo tumba boca arriba, lo tira boca arriba (T)

ahquimahmatqui.Spanish: el necio (C), desalin9ado, torpe, que no hace cosabien hecha (M for aquimamati)

ahtēl.Spanish: pero, y en forma interrogativĀ no es evidente?  (S)

ahtlāca-tl.Spanish: no hombre, o tan mal hombre, que no se merece sellame hombre (C)
ahtlāca-tl.Comment: M combines in a single entry this and ĀTLAHCA-TL"sailor, fisherman".  They both contrast with C'sĀTLĀCA-TL "person made of water".

ahtlapal-li.Spanish: ala de ave, o hoja de aŸrbol, o de yerba (M)

ahtle(h).Comment: The final glottal stop drops when followed by a wordbeginning with a vowel.

ahtlehpiyaliz-tli.Comment: R does not indicate the glottal stopof the second syllable.

ahtlehtiliā.English: to ruin, to destroy s.o., s.t.
ahtlehtiliā.Spanish: deshacer o apocar a otros (M), aniquilar alguna cosao tornarla a nada (R)
ahtlehtiliā.Comment: R does not indicate the glottal stop of thesecond syllable.

ahtlehtiy(a).English: to come to nothing, to be ruined
ahtlehtiy(a).Comment: -IY(A) verbs generally have an alternation offinal-syllable vowel length yielding ĪX inthe preterit, although it is not attested forthis item.  The glottal stop of the second syllable is alsonot attested.

āhuaca-tl.Spanish: fruta conocida, o el campan9oŸn (M), ahuacate, frutaconocida (R)

āhuah.English: s.o. who possesses, has control over water
āhuah.Comment: This is generally found in the phrase ĀHUAHTEPĒHUAH "resident of a town" from ĀLTEPĒ-TL"town".

āhuahuetz(i).Spanish: se baja la mollera (y se enferma) (T)
āhuahuetz(i).Comment: This involves the less common "crown of the head"sense of Ā-TL.

āhuatilān(a).English: to jerk, shake, beat s.o.'s head
āhuatilān(a).Comment: This involves the less common "crown of the head"sense of Ā-TL.

āhua-tl.Comment: Z marks the vowel of the second syllable long, but Cspecifically marks it short and contrasts it withĀHUĀ-TL "caterpillar".  M combines the definitionsof these two in a single entry along with thedefinition of AHHUA-TL "thorn".

āhuā-tl.Comment: M combines in a single entry the definition of thiswith those of ĀHUA-TL "oak" and AHHUA-TL "thorn".

āhuatzetzeloā.English: to jerk, shake, beat s.o.'s head
āhuatzetzeloā.Comment: This involves the less common "crown of the head"sense of Ā-TL.

āhuēhuē-tl.Spanish: cipreŸs diŸstico, vulg. cipreŸs calvo ... jefe,sen9or (S)
āhuēhuē-tl.Comment: This also appears in R but without diacritics.  Accordingto R three different types of cypress share this name.

āhuēlic.Comment: One would expect the reflex of AH rather than Ā anda literal meaning of "not-tasty".  The singleattestation has Ā, however.  Possibly the sense is"water-flavored", hence "tasteless".

āhuīc.Comment: This contrasts with AHHUĪC "here and there, back andforth".

āhuilnem(i).English: to go about playing and wasting time

āhuilpoloā.Spanish: ser proŸdigo y destruidor de la hacienda (M forreduplicated auilpopoloa)

āhuilquīxtiā.English: to diminish oneself by misuse of office or property;to sell one's belongings to raise cash
āhuilquīxtiā.Spanish: infamarse o apocarse (M), lo saca (de la casa) paravenderlo aunque sea barato para tener dinero (T)

āhuiltiā.English: to waste time; to entertain s.o.
āhuiltiā.Spanish: pasar tiempo (M), dar placer a otro con alguŸn juegoregocijado, o retozar a alguna persona (M)

āhuiy(a).Spanish: tener lo necesario y estar contento (M)
āhuiy(a).Comment: C attests the preterit twice, once with the vowellong and once with it unmarked for length.  Elsewherethe lengthening of this vowel in the preterit ofverbs ending in IY(A) is well attested.  Derivationsfrom ĀHUIY(A) have the somewhat divergent senses of"contentment, happiness" and "self-indulgence, loosebehavior, waste".

ahxiliā.English: to get to know s.t. entirely; to stalk s.t., s.o.for s.o.
ahxiliā.Spanish: alcanzar a saber algo enteramente (M), montear, ocazar para otro (M)

ahxiltiā.English: to make s.t. up, to complete s.t.; to see s.o. tohis place
ahxiltiā.Spanish: suplir, o an9adir lo que falta (M), acompan9ar oseguir a otro hasta su posada (M), hacer que lleguealgo a alguna parte (M)

ahxītiā.Comment: The vowel of the second syllable should be long bygeneral rule and is consistently long in C, but it isshort in T and twice specifically in B, although Balso has it specifically marked long.

aīc.Comment: The first element of this is from the negativeparticle AH- and is often written AY.

aihhuachmōl-li.English: a stew prepared with squash seeds, ground corn,chili, and achiote

aihhuach-tli.Comment: The IH sequence of the first syllable is open toquestion, and X has HUĒX for HUACH.  It is probablythe same element as in AYOHHUACH-TLI and related toACH-TLI "seed".

āīxco.English: on the surface of the water
āīxco.Comment: This seems to be synonymous with ĀTLĪXCO.

alactic.Comment: Although Z gives this with a long vowel in the secondsyllable, attestations of related items in T have ashort vowel.  Related derived forms with -HUA havethe vowel long by a general lengthening rule.

alāhuac.Spanish: lo mismo es que alactic (cosa deleznable) (M)

alaxoā.Spanish: lo afina, lo lima, lo pule, lo alisa (Z)

alaztic.Spanish: lo mismo es que alactic (cosa deleznable) (M)
alaztic.Comment: Zp.140 has ALĀXTIC, which is probably the same withthe vowel length of the second syllable in error,since the corresponding vowel of Z's ALAXOĀ isshort.

āltepē-tl.Comment: The literal sense of this is "water-hill", those twoelements being fundamental necessities for acommunity.  When possessed, the elements of thecompound generally separate, with the possessiveprefix attaching to each one, -ĀUH -TEPĒUH.

āltiā.Spanish: ban9arse (M), ban9ar a otro, o hacer mercedes elmercader rico, o sacrificar y matar esclavos ante losidolos, o ofrecer ornamentos al templo o iglesia (M)

āltzapo-tl.English: type of sapota, the fruit of which has a narcoticeffect (Lucuma salicifolia)

āmāc.English: at the edge of the water
āmāc.Comment: C contrasts this with ĀMAC (synonymous with ĀMAPAN)"on paper".

āmachīltiā.Spanish: lo riega demasiado, le dilata el riego (T)

āmacuahu(i)-tl.English: fig tree (the inner bark of which is used inpapermaking)

āmahuiā.Comment: R fails to mark the initial vowel long.

āman.Comment: This is peculiar to X, where it is abundantlyattested.  In phrases it can have the sense"immediately, right away".

āman(a).English: for water to be contained, as in a tub or broadvessel
āman(a).Spanish: tener agua en lebrillo o cosa ancha (C)
āman(a).Comment: This contrasts with AHMAN(A) "to get worked up, tobe discontent"

āmanal-li.Comment: This also appears in R but with the initialvowel unmarked for length.  X has ĀMAN-TLI.

āmantēca-tl.Comment: This originally referred specifically tofeatherworkers.  In T it has the special sense of"healer, curandero", while R glosses it as"interlocutor, speaker".

āmantēcayō-tl.Spanish: arte de oficial mecaŸnico, o cosa que pertenece a ladicha arte (M)

āman-tli.Comment: X fails to mark the initial vowel long.

āmapōhu(a).English: to read (from a book or text)

āmapōhualiz-tli.Comment: This is in a construction meaning "to know how toread".

āma-tl.Spanish: papel (M), papel, carta, etc. (S), papel o libro (C)

āmaxcuitl(a)-tl.Comment: T has the reflex of a short A in the second syllable.X fails to mark the initial vowel long and has Ōfor A in the second syllable.  M has amaxac "delta".

amehhuān.Comment: This has a longer form AMEHHUĀNTIN.  T and Z haveabsorbed the article IN into the pronoun: NAMEHHUĀN

āmēyalco.Comment: This is a locative meaning literally "at the spring".

āmēyal-li.Spanish: fuente de agua (M), pozo, fuente, manantial (Z)
āmēyal-li.Comment: Z has a shortened variant: ĀMĒL.

āmīl-li.Comment: This is only attested in a compound and lacksdiacritics, but it is a transparent derivation.

āmīltoma-tl.Comment: The attestation lacks diacritics, but the derivationis transparent.

āmīn-tli.Comment: M has amina "to suffer indigestion from drinkingwater after eating raw vegetables".

āmiqu(i).Spanish: tener sed, o morir de sed (M)
āmiqu(i).Comment: M also has an entry amiqui "s.t. immortal" fromthe negative prefix AH- and MICQUI, the agentive nounderived from MIQU(I) "to die".  There is a contrastbetween ĀMIQU(I) "to be thirsty" and AHMICQUI "s.t.that does not die".  X has reduplicated ĀMĪMIQU(I).

āmiquiliz-tli.Comment: M combines in a single entry this sense and that ofAHMIQUILIZ-TLI "immortality".

āmoxpōhu(a).English: to read (from a book or text)
āmoxpōhu(a).Spanish: leer libro, o relatar el proceso (M)

āmoxpōuhqui.Comment: M has amoxpoani with the same sense.

ān(a).English: to take hold of, seize s.t., s.o.

āneloā.Comment: R reduplicates the initial syllable of NELOĀ andfails to mark the Ā long.

ānticah.English: to be at a certain distance
ānticah.Spanish: estar algo lejos el lugar, o haber buen trecho hastaeŸl (M for achica onantica)
ānticah.Comment: This progressive form is built from the stem and theverb CĀ linked by the ligature -TI-.  CĀ is apreterit-as-present verb with alternate preteritsingular forms CAH = CATQUI.  *ĀN or *ĀM, themain verb stem here, is otherwise unattested.  It isalways prefixed with the directional ON- to yield thealternate forms ONĀNTICAH = ONĀNCATQUI.

antlein.Comment: This is a reduction of AHMŌ TLEIN.  The word-finalN is dropped in T.

aoc.Comment: This is a reduction of AH-OC and is often writtenAYOC.

aocāc.English: there is no longer anyone; the person in question isno longer here
aocāc.Spanish: ya no estaŸ aquiŸ, o ya no parece (M)

āocoxōchi-tl.English: a plant the foliage of which grows all to one side
āocoxōchi-tl.Spanish: cierta planta cuyos ramos se extienden solamentehacia una parte (R)

aoctle(h).Spanish: nada ... ya no hay nada, no maŸs (S)
aoctle(h).Comment: The final H drops when followed by a word beginningwith a vowel.

āocuil-in.Spanish: animal que nada en el agua (Z)
āocuil-in.Comment: The literal sense of this is "water-worm".

āpachoā.English: to inundate s.t., to soak s.t.
āpachoā.Spanish: echar algo en mojo, o regar la hortaliza (M)

āpach-tli.English: roe, insect lavae, or plant that grows in water,marsh hay
āpach-tli.Spanish: ovas que se criŸan dentro del agua (M), planta quecrece dentro del riŸo, heno (T)

āpanō.English: to cross, ford a body of water
āpanō.Spanish: pasar a la otra parte del riŸo o del mar (M)

āpan-tli.Spanish: acequia de agua (M), barranca, riŸo (T), zanja (T)
āpan-tli.Comment: R's gloss of this as "bridge" probably represents adifferent derivation from Ā-TL and PANŌ.  In oneattestation T has a long vowel in the second syllable.

āpītz(a).Spanish: tener caŸmaras (M), hace del excusado, depone (T)

āpitzac-tli.Comment: The vowel of the second syllable should be short butis marked long in two of the four attestations.

āpītzalpah-tli.Spanish: camotillo, planta conocida.  Item otras tres plantasmedicinales (R)
āpītzalpah-tli.Comment: R fails to mark the vowels of the first two syllableslong, but T has them long in the verb ĀPĪTZ(A) "tohave diarrhea".

āpīz-tli.Comment: In T the vowel of the second syllable is short.

āpōc-tli.English: water vapor; rain squall with wind
āpōc-tli.Spanish: exhalacioŸn, vapor de agua (S), llueve con viento (T)

āquetz(a).English: to beat water into a foam
āquetz(a).Spanish: colgar el agua, como lo hace quien hace cacao, paraque haga espuma (C)
āquetz(a).Comment: C contrasts this with AHQUETZ(A) "to rise up, to turnupside down".

aqu(i).Comment: In the phrase AQUI IN TŌNATIUH the sense is "for thesun to set".  AQU(I) has two alternative nonactiveforms, ACOHUA and AQUĪHUA, the second of which itapparently shares with AQUIĀ.  AQUĪHUA is givenwith AQU(I) on Tp.108 and with AQUIĀ on Tp.140.The preterit form of this verb contrasts in vowellength with ĀC "(one) who; who?"

aquiā.English: to adjust to s.t., to fit s.t.; to cause s.t. to beinserted, to plant s.t.
aquiā.Spanish: trasponer aŸrboles, hincar estacas, o meter algo enagujero (M)
aquiā.Comment: This apparently shares one alternative nonactiveform, AQUĪHUA, with AQU(I).

āquiā.English: to get dressed; to do up a garment

aquīl-li.Comment: S has the verb aquili with the sense of burnishings.t. or applying rouge.

āquin.Spanish: quieŸn, o a quieŸn?  (M), alguien, quien, alguno (T)

āquīxtiā.Spanish: enjaguar la ropa despueŸs de lavada (M)

ātecax(i)-tl.English: container in which mud is mixed

āteconxōchi-tl.English: flower of the guaje vine (Lagenaria siceraria,Lagenaria leucantha), the fruits of which are madeinto water containers
āteconxōchi-tl.Comment: X does not mark the first vowel long.

atemiā.English: to delouse oneself; to delouse s.o.

atem(i)-tl.Comment: Z has a long initial vowel, while X hasthe variant form ATIN-TLI.

ātēn-tli.English: edge of a body of water
ātēn-tli.Spanish: ribera de riŸo o de mar (M)

ātēquiā.English: to water or sprinkle water on s.t., s.o.
ātēquiā.Spanish: regar (M), mojar a otro echaŸndole agua (M)

āte-tl.Comment: The literal sense of this is "water-stone".

ātexā-tl.Comment: T has O for Ā in the second syllable.

ātēzca-tl.English: surface of a body of water
ātēzca-tl.Spanish: charco de agua, o nivel para nivelar agua (M), el mar(T)

ātic.Spanish: cosa derretida, o cosa rala, o cosa trasparente comocristal, etc. (M)

ātiy(a).Spanish: derretirse o regalarse algo, o pararse ralo loespeso, o alegrarse mucho (M)
ātiy(a).Comment: This has the vowel length alternation in thepreterit characteristic of verbs in IY(A).

ā-tl.English: water, liquid; crown of the head
ā-tl.Spanish: agua, orines, guerra, o la mollera de la cabeza (M)
ā-tl.Comment: In T there has been a confusion of the possessed formof Ā-TL "water" with Spanish agua, and thisconfusion has spread to the "crown of the head"sense, leading to a possessed form -ĀHUA and threederived verbs incorporating ĀHUA, namelyĀHUAHUETZ(I), ĀHUATILĀN(A), and ĀHUATZETZELOĀ.

ātlāca-tl.Comment: C does not write this out but describes it in proseas contrasting with ĀTLAHCA-TL "sailor, fisherman"by lack of the internal glottal stop.  It alsocontrasts with AHTLĀCA-TL "bad person".

ātlacco.English: at the place of a gully or stream

ātlacomōl-li.Comment: Z has E for A in the second syllable.

ātlacoxōniā.English: to beat water with one's hand
ātlacoxōniā.Spanish: hace sonar el agua con la mano (T)

ātlacui.Spanish: sacar agua de pozo o de jaguey (M)

ātlahca-tl.English: one who dwells in the water; fisherman
ātlahca-tl.Spanish: el que vive en el agua, y el pescador (C)
ātlahca-tl.Comment: M combines the definition of this and of AHTLĀCA-TL"inhuman person" in a single entry.  They bothcontrast with C's ĀTLĀCA-TL "person made of water".R does not indicate the internal glottal stop.

ātlahu(i)-tl.Comment: The more common form is ĀTLAUH-TLI.

ātlapēch-tli.Comment: This is attested with a long vowel in the thirdsyllable despite its apparent affinity to TLAPECH-TLI"bed" which consistently has a short vowel across allsources including T.

ātlatlācatzīca-tl.Comment: M has atlatlacamani "to bring on a storm ortorment".  Possibly T is characteristically lackinga glottal stop, and the first element of this compoundshould be ĀTLAH and have to do with an abundanceof water.

ātlatzcuepōniā.English: to beat water with one's hand
ātlatzcuepōniā.Spanish: hace sonar el agua con la mano (T)

ātlauh-tli.Comment: X does not mark the first vowel long.

ātlīxco.English: Atlixco (literally "surface of a body of water")
ātlīxco.Spanish: encima del agua, o en la superficie (M)

ātōl-li.English: atole, a drink made from cornstarch
ātōl-li.Spanish: papilla de maiŸz <atole˛ de la cual haciŸan granconsumo los indiŸgenas preparaŸndola de muy diversasmaneras (S)

ātōnahuiz-tli.Comment: R has this as the name of an insect.

ātōyāhuiā.English: to throw oneself in the river; to throw s.o. ors.t. in the river
ātōyāhuiā.Spanish: echarse en el riŸo (M), echar a otro en el riŸo(M), echar cualquier cosa el riŸo abajo (M)

ātzin-tli.English: a bit of water, polite way of referring to a beverage

ātzītzicāz-tli.Spanish: chichicastle (yerba) (Z), cierta plarta semejante ala ortiga (R)
ātzītzicāz-tli.Comment: X has ĀCHICĀL-IN "nettle", which appears to berelated.  This appears in R without diacritics.

ātzōtzocol-li.Comment: M has atzotzocolli referring to young men's longside locks of hair.  The Z attestation lacks anabsolutive suffix.

ātzoyōn(i).Spanish: se consume (el agua) por tanto hervir (T)

āuh.Spanish: pues (C), pues, queŸ hay?  queŸ se hace?  (M)
āuh.Comment: C contrasts AUH and ĀUH.  ĀUH and itsreverential form ĀUHTZIN convey approval.

āxāyac(a)-tl.English: a type of water insect, the eggs of which serve asfoodstuff
āxāyac(a)-tl.Spanish: masca palustre de cuyos huevos se hace el ahuauhtli(R)
āxāyac(a)-tl.Comment: This is used as a personal name and as such generallytakes the honorific suffix -TZIN.

āxcāco.Comment: This appears to be a locative with -C(O).

āxcāhuah.English: a person with many possessions, s.o. wealthy
āxcāhuah.Spanish: duen9o de algo, o rico y proŸspero (M)

āxcā(i)-tl.Comment: This is often found in the phrase -ĀXCĀ -TLATQUI(both elements possessed) referring to s.o.'s.property.

āxcāmpa.Spanish: luego, desde luego, o con tiempo (M)

āxcātiā.English: to appropriate to oneself; to give possession ofs.t. to s.o.
āxcātiā.Spanish: aplicar, o apropiar para siŸ alguna cosa (M), dar laposesioŸn de alguna cosa a otro (M)

āxihu(i)-tl.Comment: R glosses this as "an herb" rather than a tree andfails to mark the initial vowel long.

āxil-li.Comment: Because of the general reduction of geminate tosingle L in Z and the tendency to loss of final N(general to T but not to Z), it is possible that theabsolutive form of this is ĀXIL-IN.

āx-in.English: insect that secretes a substance used medicinally,and that substance itself
āx-in.Spanish: cierto ungu ento de esta tierra (M), la grosura deciertos gusanos que se emplea uŸtilmente en lamedicina (R)
āx-in.Comment: R fails to mark the initial vowel long, while Thas a stem-final A in the absolutive form which isabsent in the plural form.

āxīx(a).English: to urinate or to have diarrhea

āxīxpah-tli.English: medicinal plant for treating urinary disorders

āxōchi-tl.Comment: X does not mark the first vowel long.  R hasaxochiatl also referring to a water plant.

āxōlō-tl.Spanish: batracio con branquias persistentes ... losmexicanos lo utilizaban y lo utilizan todaviŸa comoalimento (S), ajolote, pez conocido de cuatro pies,que menstrua como las mujeres (R)

āxoxoctzin.English: a type of bird with green plumage

āxoxōhuīl-li.Spanish: abismo de agua profunda (M), playa, agua verde (Z)
āxoxōhuīl-li.Comment: For M this refers to water so deep it appearsblue green, while Z uses it for water that turns to lightgreen as it grows shallower and the bottom begins toshow through.

aya.Comment: R consistently has a final glottal stop in this item.

āyacachcuahu(i)-tl.Spanish: caoba (Z), planta de hojas como las del algodoŸn (R)
āyacachcuahu(i)-tl.Comment: R has X for CH and does not mark the initial vowel long.

āyacach-tli.Spanish: sonajas hechas a manera de dormideras (M)
āyacach-tli.Comment: The Bf.10v attestation is at variance in its vowellength pattern from all the other attestations, whichare consistent across C,T,Z.  R and X have thevariant ĀYACAX-TLI.

ayacān.Spanish: aun en ninguna parte o lugar (M)

āyāhuiā.English: to toss s.t. in a blanket

āyahu(i)-tl.Spanish: niebla, neblina, o nube del ojo (M)
āyahu(i)-tl.Comment: This has an interesting similarity to QUIYAHU(I)-TL"rainstorm".

āyā-tl.Spanish: manta delgada de algodoŸn, o de maguey (M)

āyātlaquēn-tli.Comment: The literal sense of this is "ayate-garment".

āyauhcōzamālōtōnamēyohtimani.Spanish: estaŸ resplandeciendo a manera del arco iris (C)

āyāxcān.Spanish: con dificultad, o apenas (M), algo despacio, y conflema (C)

āy(i).Comment: This verb can also be used intransitively.TLA-ĀY(I) with the indefinite object prefix means"to cultivate land".

āyīltiā.Comment: T attests this with a long vowel in the secondsyllable, although by general rule it should beshort.

āyoh.Spanish: cosa aguada, como vino o miel, etc. (M)
āyoh.Comment: C gives this twice with the absolutive suffix -TLIand contrasts it with AYOH-TLI "squash".

ayohhuachmōl-li.English: green mole, a sauce made from ground squash seeds

ayohhuach-tli.Comment: The HUACH element of this seems to correspond to thefree form ACH-TLI "seed".  X has HUĒX in placeof HUACH.

āyōhuiā.English: to warm s.t. with the breath
āyōhuiā.Spanish: calentar algo con el huelgo, o echar el huelgo (M),le sopla como cuando uno calienta sus manos ... (T)
āyōhuiā.Comment: This appears to be related to IHĪYŌ-TL "breath" insome idiosyncratic way.

āyōtiā.English: to irrigate s.t., to sprinkle water on s.t.

āyōtōch-in.Spanish: armadillo (Z), cuadruŸpedo; especie de lagartocubierto de escamas (S)
āyōtōch-in.Comment: If this means literally "turtle-rabbit", as it seemsto, the vowel of the second syllable should be long,but in the attestations it is not so marked.  R hasthe absolutive suffix -TLI rather than -IN.

āyōtzīncuep(a).Spanish: voltear o trepar al modo de espan9a (M)

āzaca.Spanish: acarrear agua, o ser azacani y aguador (M)

āzcacuahu(i)-tl.English: a type of tree that serves as a host for a species ofant that makes its nest within it (Cordia alliodora,Cordia gerascanthus, Cerdana alliodora)

āzcacualoā.Comment: The first vowel is not marked long in theattestation, but the sense suggests that it isderived from ĀZCA-TL.

āzcapōtzal-li.Comment: C has TZ where B and R have Z.

āzcaxōchi-tl.English: a type of flowering plant associated with ants, oneof several different plants known as "lirio".
āzcaxōchi-tl.Comment: X does not mark the first vowel as long, andR has no diacritics at all, but this is atransparent compound.

āzolōn(i).English: for a blister to form, for water to bubble up

āzolōniā.Comment: In the single attestation, the vowel length values ofthe stem are reversed, with the vowel of ZO markedlong and those of the adjacent syllables not markedfor length.  Since this is certainly a derivationfrom ĀZOLŌNI, the attestation is clearly in error.

ca.Spanish: porque. conjuncioŸn para dar razon de algo (M), pueses (C), ya, cierto, doŸnde, porque, por queŸ, puestoque (S)
ca.Comment: Corresponding to the English construction "as for(s.t.)," followed by a clause, Nahuatl has "(s.t.),CA" followed by the relevant clause.  C gives theexample inŌn calli, ca amo te mocal "as forthat house, it is not yours".  The CA is notobligatory to the construction; its presence conveysemphasis.  CA also combines as initial element withother particles and particle clusters; CA AHMŌ(emphatic negation), CA HUEL OC "todaviŸa", CA NEL"porque", CA NEL NOZO "porque" (emphatic), CA YE"ya", CA ZAN "sino que", etc.  The emphatic force ofCA is often negligible.

-ca.Comment: This binds to nouns with the ligature -TI-.  The -CAof NECHCA "from here to there", ACHIHTŌNCA "a shorttime", and similar forms seems to be a differentcliticizing particle that does not implyinstrumentality and does not require -TI-.

-cā-.Grammar: a linking element traditionally known as a ligature
-cā-.Comment: This serves to bind one verb in its preterit form toa second verb.  This medial -CĀ- and the final -QUIof the class of derived nouns known as preteritagentives appear to be derived from the same source.The sense of the construction is that the second verbis performed in the manner of one who is or doeswhatever the first verb signifies; CUALĀN(I) "tobecome angry", (I)TTA "to see s.t." ˛ CUALĀNCĀITTA"to look upon s.t. angrily".  Preterit agentivenouns have -CĀ- in derivations; TLAHTOHQUI "ruler"(< TLAHTOĀ "to speak, to give orders"),TLAHTOHCĀYŌ-TL "kingdom".  -CĀ- also links nounsderived with the possessor suffixes -EH and -HUAH toother elements; CALEH "householder", CĀHU(A) "togive s.t. up" ˛ CALEHCĀCĀHU(A) "to turn overstewardship of a household to s.o.".

cā.Grammar: preterit-as-present verb; pret: CAH = CATQUI, pret.pl: CATEH
cā.Comment: Since the preterit of this verb is used for thepresent tense, past tense is expressed with thepluperfect form CATCA.  It is suppletive with theverb YE, which is used for the future, theimperative, and the optative.  The nonactive YELOHUAis built on the YE verb.  The sense of CĀ incontext is generally locative or existential.  Inequational sentences CĀ and YE are used only asvehicles for overt tense marking other than simplepresent or unspecified time; otherwise they areomitted from the sentence.

caca.Comment: No absolutive suffix is attested.  T has this with-TŌN, and X has it with -TZIN.

cacahuaca.English: to be indisposed, disordered, feverish; to shine, toglare
cacahuaca.Spanish: tener gran destemplanza y calor en el cuerpo (M),brilla ... resplandece (Z)

cacahuanān-tli.English: tree planted to give shade to coffee bean shrubs
cacahuanān-tli.Spanish: aŸrbol que se planta en las sementeras de cacao parahacerle sombra (R)
cacahuanān-tli.Comment: R fails to mark the vowel of the fourth syllable long.

cacahua-tl.English: cacao, chocolate bean; shell, hard outer covering
cacahua-tl.Comment: In Nahuatl the word for "peanut" is specificallyTLĀLCACAHUA-TL < TLĀL-LI "earth", CACAHUA-TL.

cacalaca.Spanish: sonar el cascabel, o la vasija de barro que tienedentro pedrezuelas, o el cacao dan9ado cuando locuentan, o echan en el suelo, o cosa semejante (M),suena (Z)

cācalāch-in.Comment: X has CALĀCH-IN, pl: -MEH, apparently an apocopatedform, with the same sense.  CĀCALĀCH-IN has adifferent vowel length pattern from the verbCACALACA "to rattle" and the associated nounCACALACH-TLI, which might otherwise be taken to berelated in sense.

cacalachtic.Comment: One of the two attestations has the vowel of thesecond syllable long.  In two related forms, CACALTIC"thin, gaunt" and CACALCUI "to become thin", Z doesnot have a long vowel in the second syllable.

cacalach-tli.Spanish: cascabel de barro (M), sonaja (T), su cascabel (deviŸbora) (T)

cācalāchtōtō-tl.Comment: In Spanish this is known as a wasp (eating) bird, butin Nahuatl it is a cockroach bird.

cacalatz(a).English: to cause s.t. to make a rattling noise
cacalatz(a).Spanish: hacer ruido revolviendo jiŸcaras, o nueces, o cosassemejantes; o abriendo y cerrando cajas, cajones, opuertas y ventanas (M)

cacalcui.English: to become thin, to lose weight

cācālōxōchi-tl.Spanish: flor de singular fragrancia que se da en racimos, enciertos aŸrboles de tierra caliente (R), flor delcuervo, cacalosuchil (X)
cācālōxōchi-tl.Comment: X does not mark the first vowel long, and R has nodiacritics at all for this item, but the Spanish nameleaves no doubt about the derivation.

cacama-tl.English: secondary ears of maize that form at the base of theprimary ear
cacama-tl.Spanish: mazorcas pequen9as de maiŸz, que nacen cabe lamazorca mayor (M), jilote (T)

cacapaca.Spanish: sonar las chinelas o alcorques cuando andan con ellas(M)

cacapatz(a).English: to cause s.t. to make a slapping noise
cacapatz(a).Spanish: hacer ruido con los pantuflos, o chinelas cuandoandan (M)
cacapatz(a).Comment: Because of the hand slapping that goes into it, thiscan be used to refer to tortilla-making.  Z has whatappears to be this verb compounded with HUETZ(I)meaning "to fall very hard".  In one attestation thevowels of the first two syllables are marked long,and in the other they are not.

cācāx-tli.Spanish: escalerillas de tablas para llevar algo a cuestas eltameme (M)

cacchīhu(a).Comment: None of the attestations has the second vowel markedlong, but the compound is transparent.

cachopīn.Comment: This is thought to be a Nahuatl word derived fromCAC-TLI "shoe" and CHOPĪNIĀ "to pick at s.t.", butthis attestation is in a modern source, where itcould be a loanword or a back loan.  The term appearsas early as the first half of the 18th century inNahuatl texts.

cacti.Comment: This is the first element of the common verbCACTIMAN(I) "to be quiet, empty, deserted" and M'scactiuetzi "to fall quiet".  The -TI- of thecompound forms seems to be the -TI- "ligature" thatbinds together verb stems, which makes the free formCACTI appear anomalous.  Aside from this singleattestation, the initial element does not occurindependently.

cactiā.English: to put on one's shoes; to put shoes on s.o.
cactiā.Spanish: calzarse los zapatos, o cacles (M), calzar zapatos aotro (M)

cactihuetz(i).Spanish: hacer bonanza despueŸs de la tormenta, y aclarar eltiempo (M)
cactihuetz(i).Comment: This is not directly attested in the sources for thisdictionary, but its component parts are attested.

cactiman(i).English: for there to be silence, stillness, absence ofactivity; for the weather to be fair
cactiman(i).Spanish: casa desamparada que se no habita, o hacer bonanza ybuen tiempo, o haber silencio un poco de tiempo, oestar la ciudad asolada de repente y destruiŸda (M)
cactiman(i).Comment: The initial element of this construction isrestricted in occurrence.  M has it in cactiuetzi"to fall quiet", and T has CACTI "to moderate".

cahcāhu(a).English: to give up, to lose; to set s.t., s.o. loose, tofree s.o., s.t.
cahcāhu(a).Spanish: dejarse o apartarse muchas veces los casados, opasarse los unos a los otros los que caminan, o losque trabajan y cavan la tierra a destajo (M),callarse (X), lo abandona, le permite, le da libertad(T)

cahcapollah.English: place where there are cherry orchards
cahcapollah.Comment: This is given by C as the plural of CAPOLLAH "cherryorchard".  Strictly speaking, it is the reduplicatedstem of CAPOL-IN "cherry tree" bound to -TLAH "placewhere the relevant thing is found in abundance".

cahcatza.Spanish: atar fuertemente alguna cosa, o embutir o recalcaralgo (M)

cahcayāhu(a).Spanish: burlar o escarnecer de otro, o engan9arle (M)
cahcayāhu(a).Comment: M gives this as reflexive and in construction withTĒCA "with regard to s.o.", but T, Z, and X treat itas a simple transitive verb.

cahtzō-tl.Comment: Z marks the second vowel long in one attestation andnot in the other.  This appears in R withoutdiacritics.

cāhu(a).English: to leave, abandon, relinquish s.t., s.o.
cāhu(a).Spanish: dejar algo, o llevar alguna cosa a otra parte (M),dejar o desamparar a otro, o exceder y sobrepujar alos otros (M)

cahuāctic.Comment: Although Z marks the vowel of the second syllablelong in both attestations, the expected form would bea short vowel.

cāhual-li.English: one who is left behind, widow, widower
cāhual-li.Comment: This is attested as a free form in X and Z and isabundantly attested in compounds across sources.

cāhualtiā.English: to restrain oneself; to restrain, prohibit s.o.
cāhualtiā.Spanish: irse a la mano o abstenerse de algo (M), vedar aotro, o irle a la mano (M)

cahuān(i).Comment: Two of these attestations are in the constructionCAHUĀNTOC < CAHUĀN(I) bound to thepreterit-as-present verb O with the -TI- ligature.

cahuāntiā.Spanish: lo enciende, lo calienta, hace lumbre (Z)
cahuāntiā.Comment: In one of the two attestations the vowel of the firstsyllable is marked long, but it is not in the otheror in related forms.

cahuīx-in.Comment: In Campeche CAHUĪX without the absolutive suffix isused as the name for the female grackle.

calacohuayān.Spanish: puerta o entrada para entrar o salir (M)
calacohuayān.Comment: X has CALAQUIYĀN, derived from the active form ofthe verb CALAQU(I) and apparently synonymous.

calāmpa.Comment: In one of the two attestations the vowels of bothsyllables are marked long; in the other only thesecond is.

calān.Comment: In two of six attestations Z marks the vowel of thefirst syllable long.  This is possibly derived fromCAL-LI and -TLĀN with degemination of medial LLresulting from LTL assimilation.

calān(i).Spanish: reten9ir el metal (M), hacer ruido cosas como nueces,jiŸcaras, cosas de madera (C)

calaqu(i).Spanish: entrar o meterse en alguna parte (M)
calaqu(i).Comment: CALAQU(I) has essentially the same sense as AQU(I)and appears to be derived from that verb and CAL-LI"house".  This would mean literally "to house-fit, tohouse-enter".  The construction has been lexicalizedto the point that the CAL element contributes nothingliteral to the construction as a whole.

calaquiā.English: to enter into s.t. such as employment; to close s.t.up inside s.t.
calaquiā.Spanish: entrar con otro asoldada (M), meter o encerrar trigoo cosas semejantes en casa (M), meter dentro (C)

calca-tl.Comment: C equates CALQUI, CALCA-TL, and CHĀNEH in sense.

calchīhu(a).Comment: M has calchiualiztli "repairs made to a house".

calcuāco.English: at the peak of the house
calcuāco.Spanish: encima de la casa, azotea, teco, tejado (Z)
calcuāco.Comment: The expected form would be CALCUĀC.

calīcampa.Comment: Z also has a shortened form CALĪCAN.

calihtic.Spanish: hacia dentro de casa (M for caliticpa), dentro decasa (C)

cal-li.Comment: M combines the definitions of CAL-LI and CĀL-LI"tongs" in a single entry.  R has CAL-LI and CĀL-LIas separate entries but with the vowel length valuesreversed.

cāl-li.Spanish: tenazuelas de palo o de can9a para comer maiŸztostado en el rescoldo (M)
cāl-li.Comment: This contrasts with CAL-LI "house".  M combines thetwo in a single entry.  R contrasts them but has thevowel length values reversed.

calmecac.English: name of one of the academies of precolumbian Mexico
calmecac.Spanish: $una de las academias precolumbinas, donde estudiabanlos nobles)

calnēnepaniuhqui.English: a house of more than two stories

calnepaniuhqui.Comment: M has calnepanolli for "story of a house".

calpixqui.Spanish: mayordomo (M), el mayordomo, el que guarda las cosasde casa (C)

calqui.Comment: C equates CALQUI, CALCA-TL, and CHĀNEH in sense.

caltech.English: next to a house, to one side

caltechoā.English: to separate, to draw aside; to set s.t. to one side
caltechoā.Spanish: se echa a un lado, se aparta, se ladea (T),lo echa a un lado, lo aparta, lo pone aparte (T)

caltech-tli.English: wall of a house; walkway along the side of a house

caltēn-tli.English: corridor, walkway along the side of a house
caltēn-tli.Spanish: la acera de la pared de las casas (M), cerca de lapuerta (Z)

caltetzon-tli.Spanish: cimiento de casa, hasta medio estado de pared (M)

caltiā.English: to build a house for oneself or s.o. else
caltiā.Spanish: hacer o edificar casa para siŸ (M), edificar casa aotro (M)

-camac.English: place where there is an abundance of s.t.
-camac.Comment: This is attested only for T, where it is compoundedwith CUAHU(I)-TL "tree", OHUA-TL "cane", XĀL-LI"sand" and other such nouns.  It seems to besynonymous with -TLAH, which also occurs in T, sothat there are doublets--TECAMAC, TETLAH "pedregal(field of volcanic stones)"; CUAUHZĀHUACAMAC,CUAUHZĀHUATLAH "place where many casaguate treesgrow".  In one pair of variants T gives -CAMAC with anabsolutive suffix, TLAHZOLCAMAC, TLAHZOLCAMAC-TLI"dump, trash heap".

camacāhu(a).English: to let s.t. fall from the mouth
camacāhu(a).Spanish: soltaŸrsele alguna palabra, la cual no quisiera haberdicho (M), lo suelta de la boca, lo deja caer de laboca (T)

camachaloā.Comment: Both Z and X give this with a long vowel in CHAL, butin the abundant attestations of CAMACHAL-LIelsewhere, the vowel is short.

camactic.English: s.t. fresh, like a newly harvested crop
camactic.Spanish: cosa tierna y reciente, como la mazorca de maiŸzantes que estaŸ del todo sazonada y seca (M), entreverde y seco, estaŸ huŸmedo, estaŸ recieŸn cortado(frijol, mazorca, etc.) (T)

camac-tli.Spanish: boca (X), su boca (T for possessed form)
camac-tli.Comment: C gives -CAMAC as an alternative possessed form forCAM(A)-TL.  The locative -CAMAC has the sense "placewhere there is an abundance of s.t."

camacui.English: to take s.t. in the mouth

camāhu(a).Spanish: pararse el maiŸz sarazo, o casi del todo sarazonado(M)

camāhuac.English: s.t. that has achieved ripeness; a ripe ear of corn
camāhuac.Spanish: cosa saraza (M), mazorca fresca (pero demasiado durapara comer como elote) (T)

camahuāqu(i).English: for the mouth to be dry

camanālihtoā.Comment: One of the two attestations has the second vowelmarked long as well as the third one, but in relatedforms it is not long.

camanāl-li.English: boast, joke; s.o. who jests, jokester
camanāl-li.Spanish: chufa, o burla de palabras (M), charlador (Z)

camapihpī.English: to shave one's own beard or s.o. else's
camapihpī.Spanish: rasura la barba (T), le rasura la barba (T)

camapīnāhua.English: to be bashful in speech or eating habits
camapīnāhua.Spanish: se avergu enza en comer, en hablar, etc. (T)
camapīnāhua.Comment: T forms the preterit as CAMAPĪNĀUH, but elsewherePĪNĀHUA forms its preterit by adding -C.

camapināuhqui.English: s.o. bashful in speech or eating habits
camapināuhqui.Spanish: vergonzoso en hablar, en comer, etc. (T)

camapiy(a).English: to hold s.t. in one's mouth

camatelicza.English: to kick s.o. in the mouth

camatepāchoā.English: to get one's mouth bruised; to bruise s.o. on themouth
camatepāchoā.Spanish: se machuca la boca (T), le machuca la boca (T)

cam(a)-tl.Comment: Cf.82v gives -CAMAC as an alternative possessed form.

camatotōncāpah-tli.Spanish: planta medicinal y bella de hojas casi perfectamenteredondas (R)
camatotōncāpah-tli.Comment: The single attestation does not mark the vowels ofthe fourth and fifth syllables long.

camatoxcoā.Spanish: dice una cosa cuando no iba a decirla (T)

camoh-tli.Spanish: batata, raiŸz comestible (M), camote, raiŸzcomestible bien conocida (R)

cāmpa.Spanish: a doŸnde, o a queŸ parte, o por doŸnde?  adverbiopara preguntar (M)
cāmpa.Comment: CĀMPA can be used without a strictly interrogativesense; ZĀ ZAN CĀMPA means "just anywhere", and Tgives the meaning of CĀMPA ZĀ as "very distant".

campaxoā.English: to nip at s.t. or s.o., to swallow s.t. withoutchewing
campaxoā.Spanish: morder a alguien sin llevarse el pedazo (S), comerapriesa, tragando sin mascar (C)

-cān.Spanish: posp. que indica el lugar, el tiempo, la parte (S)
-cān.Comment: This is a common element of placenames.  It bindswith the preterit stem of verbs, with possessorderivations in -EH and -HUAH, and with numbers, aswell as being an element of NICĀN "here" and ONCĀN"there".

canactic.Spanish: cosa delgada, como tabla, estera, lienzo, o cosassemejantes llanas (M), delgado (Z)
canactic.Comment: In one attestation Z marks the vowel of the firstsyllable long, but it should not be.

canah.Comment: In spite of the obvious relationship of CANAH andCĀN, they differ in vowel length.  This same patternis true of ĀC "who", ACAH "someone" and ĪC "when",ICAH "sometimes".

canahpa.Spanish: en alguna parte (M), hacia alguna parte, o de algunaparte (C)

canāhu(a).English: to make s.t. thin and flat
canāhu(a).Spanish: adelgazar tablas, o piedras anchas o la losa cuandola hace, etc. (M)

canāhuac.Spanish: cosa delgada ... lienzo, o manta delgada de algodoŸn(M)

canauh-tli.Comment: The attestations are written without diacritics;it is possible that one or both vowels are long.

canel.Spanish: pues es asiŸ, o pues asiŸ es (M)

cānin.English: where?  to where?  from where?; somewhere, anywhere
cānin.Spanish: doŸnde, de doŸnde, a doŸnde, por doŸnde (C),cualquier lugar, donde quiera (T)

cānmach.Comment: C also has emphatic CĀNINMACH with the same sense.

capān(i).English: to make a cracking or slapping noise
capān(i).Spanish: crujir, o restallar las coyunturas de los dedoscuando los estiran (M), el ruido que se hace con lapalma de la mano, o el ruido del crujir de los dedos,o el de los zapatos, y chinelas (C)

capāniā.English: to cause s.t. to make a creaking or slapping sound

capolcuahu(i)-tl.Comment: R has capolquauhtli, but for "tree" R has the standardCUAHU(I)-TL.

capol-in.Spanish: cerezo, el aŸrbol, o la fruta del (M)

capotzēhu(i).Comment: M has caputzaui with the same sense.

capotztic.Spanish: cosa negra (M), negro, prieto, tringuen9o, moreno (T)

caquītiā.English: to get other people to listen to s.t., to announce,tell s.t. to s.o.
caquītiā.Spanish: dar relacioŸn de algo a otros, o notificarles algo(M)

caquizti.English: to sound, to be heard clearly
caquizti.Spanish: sonar, o oiŸrse bien el que habla, o cuenta (M)

caquiztiliā.Spanish: exponer, declarar, atestigar, comentar, interpretar,anotar, explicar una cosa (S)

cātlehhuā-tl.Spanish: cuaŸl de ellos?  preguntado (M), queŸ?  adjectivo dela misma significacioŸn de tlein (R)
cātlehhuā-tl.Comment: This has a short form CĀTLEH.  The -HUĀ-TL elementis that which is also found in the long forms of thepersonal pronouns.

catzāhua.Comment: M gives CATZĀUH as an alternative preterit for thisintransitive verb as well as for its transitivecounterpart.

catzāhu(a).English: to get oneself dirty; to get s.o. dirty

catzāhuac.Comment: catzactic is to be found in M with the same sensebut is not attested in the sources for thisdictionary.

cātzān(a).English: to stretch out one's arms and legs

cāuhtēhu(a).English: to make one's will; to stop and remain somewhere; toleave, relinquish or abandon s.t.
cāuhtēhu(a).Spanish: testar, hacer testamento, o detenerse y quedarse enalguŸn lugar (M), dejar a otro, o a otra cosa, e irseluego a alguna parte (M)

caxaltic.English: s.t. loose, weak, lacking in substance
caxaltic.Comment: One of the three attestations has the vowel of thesecond syllable marked long.

caxān(i).English: to loosen, slacken; to lose courage
caxān(i).Spanish: aflojarse lo atado (M), se ablanda, se suaviza, seafloja (T)

caxāniā.English: to relapse into sickness; to loosen, unstring s.t.
caxāniā.Spanish: recaer el enfermo (M), aflojar lo atado, o desarmarla ballestra, y aflojar el arco (M)

caxānqui.English: s.t. mild, weak, lacking in substance, loose
caxānqui.Spanish: cosa floja o mal atada (M), blando, suave, flojo,suelta (tierra), tierno (T)

caxeh.English: one who possesses a bowl, vessel
caxeh.Spanish: duen9o, y poseedor de la cosa ... escudilla, ocajete (C)
caxeh.Comment: C and R give this and CAXHUAH as synonymous.

caxhuah.English: one who possesses a bowl, vessel
caxhuah.Spanish: duen9o, y poseedor de la cosa ... escudilla, ocajete (C)
caxhuah.Comment: C and R give this and CAXEH as synonymous.

cax(i)-tl.Comment: There is a printing error in M.  This item appears ascaxtil but is alphabetized for caxitl.  T hasCAX-TLI as well as CAX(I)-TL.

cax-tli.Comment: In T this short variant of CAX(I)-TL has thespecialized gloss "cup for drinking alcohol".

cayahcihu(i).Comment: The single attestation in T does not have an internalglottal stop, but in view of the tendency in T tolose such glottal stops, this is a plausiblederivation from (I)HCIHU(I).  Compare TEOHCIHU(I) "tobe hungry".  The first element may be related to M'scacayactic "s.t. thin, with respect to a cloak orblanket".  This appears to be synonymous withCANĀHU(I).

cayāhu(a).English: to blunder; to deceive s.o., to mock s.o.
cayāhu(a).Spanish: engan9arse a siŸ mismo, equivocarse ... burlarse,reiŸrse de alguien (S)
cayāhu(a).Comment: S and C treat this as a reflexive verb with theobject of the deception expressed in contruction with-CA.  C cites in noca timocayĀhua "with respect tome you practice deception".  T and Z treat it as asimple transitive verb.  The reduplicated formCAHCAYĀHU(A) is more common.

cē.Comment: The related bound form -CĒL has a long vowel, butCEM has a short one.  The plural CĒMEH has the sense"one of several".  As an example C gives cĒmetehuĀntin "one of us", cĒmeazcihua "one ofyou women" (Cf.85v).

ceccān.Spanish: en cierta parte, o en una parte (M)

cecec.Comment: This is abundantly attested in Z and consistently withthe vowel of the second syllable long, but as a reduplicatedform of CEC-TLI, it should have a short vowel.

cēcecni.English: here and there, in several different places

cececpah-tli.English: cecepacle, a plant used in treating dysentery, gallbladder complaints, and sores

cēcecu(i).Comment: This apparently forms its preterit in the same manneras AHCOCU(I); namely the final vowel and also thelabialization of CU are lost.  The delabialization isanalogous to that of M in word-final position,yielding N.

ceceliā.Spanish: lo hace en friŸo, lo refresca (Z)
ceceliā.Comment: In both attestations Z has a long vowel in the secondsyllable, but in the related form TLACECELTIĀ, T hasshort vowels.

cēcem.Spanish: cada uno sendos, o a cada uno sendos, o a cada uno deellos (M)
cēcem.Comment: CEHCEM with glottal stop reduplication also occurs,and both CĒCEM and CEHCEM are attested withexpressions of time and period.  The final nasalconsonant delabializes word-finally, CĒCEN.

cēcempōhual-li.English: by twenties, twenty apiece, in lots of twenty
cēcempōhual-li.Spanish: de veinte en veinte, o cada uno veinte (M)

cēcente-tl.Spanish: cada uno sendos, o a cada uno sendos, o a cada uno delos (M)

cēcentlapal.English: each person or thing on one side
cēcentlapal.Spanish: cada persona, o cosa del un lado (C)

cecēpahtic.English: s.t. very cold, s.t. that gives one the chills
cecēpahtic.Spanish: cosa muy friŸa ... cosa muy espantable (M)
cecēpahtic.Comment: The long vowel of the second syllable is questionable.

cecepoca.English: to get numb, to have goose bumps
cecepoca.Spanish: se entume (T), carne de gallina (aplicado a la pielhumana) (Z)
cecepoca.Comment: M has cecepoctic "s.t. asleep or benumbed".  Thisseems to include CE-TL "ice" as an element in itsderivation.

cēcexxiuhtica.Spanish: cada an9o, o de an9o a an9o (M)
cēcexxiuhtica.Comment: Although all attestations are printed with a singlex, the ones in C are in a section of examplesformed with CĒCEM.  The M assimilates to X bygeneral rule to give the sequence XX.

cecni.Spanish: en otra parte o lugar, o en cierta parte, o por siŸaparte (M)

cēco.Comment: Of nine attestations in Z, four have the vowel of thefirst syllable marked long.  In principle, this couldbe a reduction of CECCO analogous to CECCĀN andCECNI, but it also seems to be an acceptableconstruction of CĒ "one" plus the locative -C(O).

cectiā.English: to catch a cold; to cool off

cec-tli.Comment: This is found as a free form only in Z, where onceout of four times it is given with a long vowel.  Zalso gives it in some compounds with a long vowel.CEC is abundantly attested in the other sources as anelement of compounds, always with a short vowel.

cecu(i).English: to be cold; to have chills
cecu(i).Comment: According to M, the preterit of this form loses thefinal vowel, but the resulting final consonant doesnot delabialize, yielding CEUC, butT gives as thepreterit of CECU(I) a reduplicated form CEHCECwith delabialization.

ceh.Grammar: reduction of the particle sequence ZO (Y)EH,typically as the last elements of a particle clustersuch as ZĀCEH "once and for all", AHNOCEH "orperhaps", etc.

cehcecuiliz-ti.Comment: This is given without an absolutive suffix in bothattestations.

cehcēliā.English: to cool off; to cool s.t. off
cehcēliā.Spanish: enfriar cosas calientes (M), se resfriŸa (T), lorefresca, lo resfriŸa (T)
cehcēliā.Comment: This contrasts with the reduplicated form of CELIĀglossed by M as "to enjoy oneself".

cehceltiā.Comment: M gives the corresponding applicative cecelia, usedreflexively as "to amuse oneself".

cehcem.Comment: Both CEHCEM and CĒCEM occur with expressions of timeor period.  The nasal consonant delabializesword-finally, CEHCEN.

cehcenmētztica.Spanish: cada mes, o de mes a mes (M)
cehcenmētztica.Comment: These attestations lack long-vowel marking in MĒTZ.C writes nm as though a word boundary intervenesbetween CEHCEM and MĒTZ.  R has this withoutdiacritics but writes mm.

cehcēpanoā.English: to unite, to put s.t. together
cehcēpanoā.Spanish: ayuntar o recoger razones en favor de alguŸn negocio(M), juntar (R)
cehcēpanoā.Comment: R indicates the glottal stop but fails to mark thevowel of the second syllable long.

cehuapāhu(a).Spanish: aterirse, o pararse yerto de friŸo (M)

cehuetzilizpan.English: in winter, at the time of cold and ice
cehuetzilizpan.Spanish: en tiempo de friŸos y hielos (C)

cēhu(i).English: to calm down, to take a rest, to cool off
cēhu(i).Spanish: aplacarse el airado, o apagarse el fuego o amatarsela vela, o enfriarse la cosa caliente (M), parar,descansar (C)

cēhuiā.English: to rest oneself; to get someone else to rest, torelieve s.o.
cēhuiā.Spanish: descansar (M), descansar a otro, ayudaŸndole a llevarla carga, o aplacar el enojado (M)

cēhuilōni.Comment: In all three attestations, Z fails to mark the vowelof the second syllable long.  This would be correctif the noun is derived from CĒHU(I) rather thanCĒHUIĀ.

-cēl.Comment: When bound with a possessive prefix, this means"oneself alone"; NOCĒL "I alone", TŌCELTIN "wealone".  It can also be incorporated into verbs toconvey exclusivity.  Z has the variant form CELTI.

*cel.Grammar: This is an element meaning "fresh, green".  It canalso refer to heat, since Nahuatl's use of "green" asan intensifier for heat is analogous to the use of"blue" and "white" in English.  It is only attestedbound, but Z has the form CELTZIN, which implies afree form.  Z has the vowel marked long, but inrelated forms it is consistently short.

celiā.Spanish: hospedar a otro (M), recibir alguna cosa (M)
celiā.Comment: With the nonspecific object prefix TLA- thisspecifically means "to take communion".

celic.Comment: In addition to CELIC, Z also has CELQUI with thesense of "fresh".

-celicā.Comment: M has celica as a free form with the sense"freshly".  The final vowel is shortened word-finallybut appears long in CELICĀYŌ-TL.

celicpah-tli.Spanish: cierta planta medicinal cuyas hojas son como las dela ortiga (R)

celiy(a).English: to catch fire; for plants to sprout, to blossom
celiy(a).Spanish: prender, brotar, o reton9ecer la planta (M)

celticāyō-tl.English: the delicacy of s.t. fresh and green
celticāyō-tl.Spanish: ternura de cosa reciente, fresca, y verde (M)

cem.Spanish: enteramente, o del todo, o juntamente (M)
cem.Comment: Generally speaking CĒ is the free form meaning"one" and CEM is the corresponding bound form.  Inword-final position the M delabializes, yielding CEN.Within a compound the M assimilates to adjacentnonlabial consonants.  Before vowels and labialconsonants CEM retains its underlying form.  In therelated forms CĒ and -CĒL the M is missing and thevowel is long.  Z consistently has CĒM where theother sources have CEM.

cemahcicāpohpohtiā.English: to pay back, to even the score
cemahcicāpohpohtiā.Spanish: recompensar algo copiosamente (M for nonreduplicatedverb stem), igualar (R)

cemahciticah.Comment: R glosses this as "spirit", i.e. that which iscomplete and perfect.

cemān(a).Comment: This contrasts with CEMMAN(A) "to sprinkle,scatter, disseminate s.t.". Neither has the sense ofM's cemana "to carry s.t. on to the end, topersevere in s.t.".

cemanāhua-tl.Comment: The vowel length pattern and absence of locative -C< -C(O), cf. TLĀLTICPAC-TLI "the earth", are evidenceagainst a derivation involving CEM "entirely" andĀNĀHUAC < Ā-TL "water" and NĀHUAC "adjacent to".A reasonable derivation would be from thenonactive form of M's cemana "to continue s.t. onto the end, to persevere in s.t."  In this case, thesingle M would probably result from a reduction ofMM.

cemēlleh.Spanish: falta de union, y de paz (C)
cemēlleh.Comment: This appears to have negative polarity.  S givesa positive sense of con alegriŸa, tranquilidad forthis without negation, but there are no nonnegativeconstructions attested in the sources for thisdictionary.

cemi.English: once and for all, ultimately; always
cemi.Spanish: finalmente, una sola vez, de repente (S), siempre(T), muy (Z)
cemi.Comment: In Z, which has the variant forms CEMI = CIMI, thishas come to be a general intensifier meaning "very"or "very much".

cemihcacāyōlīhuayān.Comment: In the single attestation the medial vowel of thesequence YŌLĪHUA is not marked long, but it shouldbe by general rule.

cemilhuitiā.English: to pass a whole day somewhere, for s.t. to take up awhole day
cemilhuitiā.Spanish: tardar, o estar todo el diŸa en alguna parte (M), lohace todo el diŸa, pasa todo el diŸa hacieŸndole (T)

cemitta.English: to stare at s.o., to pay close attention to s.t.
cemitta.Spanish: mirar a otro de hito en hito (M), estar muy atento, oabsorto en alguŸn negocio (M), lo fija, lo admira, lehace caso, lo mira (Z)
cemitta.Comment: In the single attestation, the initial vowel ismarked long, and the M appears as n, but thederivation is transparent, and the sense iscompatible with the entry in M.

cemizti-tl.English: the distance from the tip of the thumb to the tip ofthe forefinger, a small amount

cemmāctiā.Comment: The geminate MM is not attested.

cemman(a).English: to sprinkle, scatter, disseminate s.t. (other than liquid)
cemman(a).Spanish: esparcir, derramar, o echar algo por el suelo (M), lo riega(cosa seca), lo esparce, lo tira (T)
cemman(a).Comment: T reduces the MM sequence to M.  This contrastswith CEMĀN(A) "to resell, exchange, barter s.t."

cemman(i).English: to fall, to spill, to spread out, to scatter
cemman(i).Spanish: descarriarse, o aventarse el ganado, o apartarse losque estaban juntos, yeŸndose cada uno por su parte, ocosas sencillas, o cosas que estan llanas e iguales(M), cae, derrama (T)
cemman(i).Comment: The attestation is written with a single medial m,but M has it double.

cemmaniyān.Spanish: de todo en todo, o ultimadamente (M), enteramente,formalmente, finalmente, perpetuamente (S)
cemmaniyān.Comment: C consistently writes the MM sequence as nm.M's cemana "to continue s.t. on to the end, topersevere in s.t." must be related to this bydegemination of MM.

cemmat(i).English: to pay close attention to s.t.; to agree about s.t.
cemmat(i).Spanish: estar muy atento a alguŸn negocio, sin divertirse aotro (M), estaŸn de acuerdo (Z)
cemmat(i).Comment: Both attestation have n for M and have the vowel ofthe first syllable marked long, but the derivation istransparent.

cempōhual-li.Comment: In the vigesimal counting system twenty is one fullcount.

cempōhualxōchi-tl.Spanish: flor que llaman de muertos, y otros, clavel grande deindias (R), caleŸndula, flor de muerto, zempasuchil(T)
cempōhualxōchi-tl.Comment: None of the many attestations marks the vowel of thesecond syllable long, but the compound is transparent.

cencah.Spanish: muy o mucho, o cosa estable que no se muda (M)

cencāhu(a).English: to prepare, get ready; to ready s.t., to prepare s.t.
cencāhu(a).Spanish: aparejarse, apercibirse, disponer, ataviarse, oaderezarse (M), aparejar algo asiŸ (M)

cencaqu(i).English: to take heed; to take s.o.'s advice, to admire s.o.
cencaqu(i).Spanish: escarmentar (M), corregirse, escuchar, seguirfielmente los consejos (S), lo admira (Z)
cencaqu(i).Comment: In both attestations the initial vowel is markedlong, although the derivation appears to be from CEM.In general Z has CĒM where the other sources haveCEM.

cenchichiliā.English: (for one's heart) to grow permanently embittered
cenchichiliā.Comment: All attestations are in the constructionQUICENCHICHILIĀ ĪYŌLLŌ.

centetiliā.English: to join together, to become one
centetiliā.Spanish: juntar diversas cosas en uno (M), se junta, se haceuno (T), lo junta (T)
centetiliā.Comment: T has CENTI for CENTE, while Z lacks the TEaltogether.

cente-tl.Comment: T has a variant CENTI-TL.  Numbers suffixed withTE-TL, which literally means "stone", are used forenumerating objects more or less arbitrarily assignedfor the purpose of counting to the class of rock-likeor lump-like things.  Among other things, the classincludes eggs, tamales, fruits, and beans.

centlachiy(a).Comment: The alternative preterits given here are based onCHIY(A).

centlahcol.English: a half, a portion of s.t.
centlahcol.Spanish: la mitad de algo (M), mitad, fraccioŸn, porcioŸn deuna cosa (S), la mitad (C)
centlahcol.Comment: C fails to indicate the glottal stop, but it isattested in R.

centlāliā.English: to gather people or things together in one place
centlāliā.Spanish: ayuntar, congregar, o acaudillar gente (M), allegar,recoger, o amontonar algo (M)

centlaman-tli.Spanish: una cosa, un negocio, o una parte, o un par (M)
centlaman-tli.Comment: Numbers suffixed with -TLAMAN-TLI are used inenumerating objects more or less arbitrarily assignedto a class of flat objects including, among otherthings, shoes, sheets of paper, and dishes, as wellas more abstract items such as speeches and pieces ofadvice.

centlani.Spanish: abismo, cosa muy honda o pielago (M), en el abismo,en lo maŸs profundo (C)

centlapal.Spanish: de un lado, o del un lado (M)

cen-tli.Spanish: mazorca de maiŸz curada y seca (M)
cen-tli.Comment: C, Z, and X have the variant form CIN-TLI.  R and Thave CEN-TLI, and M gives both forms.

centoca.English: to omit nothing, to continue s.t., to pursue s.t.
centoca.Spanish: no dejar nada, o comprar todo cuanto se vende (M), locontinuŸa, permanece (Z)
centoca.Comment: The Z sense of this follows from the literal sensesof CEM "entirely" and TOCA "to follow s.t." Thiscontrasts with CENTŌCA "to plant things together".

centōca.Comment: This contrasts with CENTOCA "to continue, pursues.t."

centzacu(a).English: to pay a penalty for all of one's offense

centzontlahtōleh.Spanish: paŸjaro que canta mucho (M), ave celebrada por suadmirable canto (R)
centzontlahtōleh.Comment: R has both the full form and the shortened formCENTZONTLEH.

centzon-tli.English: four hundred; a bunch of grass
centzon-tli.Spanish: cuatrocientos, o una mata de hortaliza o de yerba (M)
centzon-tli.Comment: The representation of the unit four hundred in thevigesimal counting system by a bunch of grass isprobably a metaphor for a large and more or lessuncountable quantity.  TZON-TLI literally refers tothe hairs on the head, which would embody much thesame notion.

cenyā.Spanish: ir el canto bien concertado y ordenado (M)

cenyohual.Spanish: toda la noche, o en toda la noche, o una noche

cēpa.Comment: Sources other than Z have CEPPA.

cēpan.Spanish: juntamente, o en compan9iŸa (M), significasimultaneidad o concomitancia (R)
cēpan.Comment: This is abundantly attested in B and C with the firstvowel marked long.  B also has two attestations inwhich the vowel is specifically marked short.  CĒPANcan be incorporated into verbs to convey the sense ofsimultaneity.  T has CĒPAYEHU(I) "to be the sameage" which seems to be derived from CĒPAN.  TheYEHU(I) element suggests a derivation from the verbYĀ, but it has regular rather than suppletivecausative and nonactive forms.  R has CEHCĒPANOĀ"to unite things".

cepayahu(i)-tl.Comment: M also has the associated verb cepayahui "to snow".The possessed form of the noun is not attested, butby analogy with QUIYAHU(I)-TL, -CEPAYAUH is to beexpected.

cepōhua.English: for a part of one's body to be numb from cold or lackof circulation
cepōhua.Spanish: estar yerto y aterido de mucho friŸo, o estarentumecido alguŸn miembro del cuerpo, o adormecido(M)
cepōhua.Comment: M has two entries for cepoa.  The first is thisitem, and the second, meaning to scrub s.t. andforming its preterit by final vowel loss, is notattested in the sources for this dictionary.

cepōhuiā.Comment: T has contrasting CEPŌHUIĀ and CEPŌHUIY(A).

cepōhuiy(a).Comment: This intransitive form contrasts with transitiveCEPŌHUIĀ.

ceppa.Comment: Z consistently has CĒPA where the other sources haveCEPPA.

cequi.Spanish: algo, o alguna parte de lo que estaba entero (M),algunos, o los unos (M for cequintin)
cequi.Comment: The long vowel of the second syllable in plural formsis abundantly attested in B and C.  The long vowelof the final syllable of the longer plural formis given here by analogy with plurals of otherquantifiers.  It is not directly attested as long.

cētica.Spanish: un (C), con ninguno (C for negated form)
cētica.Comment: M and C both give examples with CŌHU(A) "to buy s.t."where CĒTICA means "one real's worth".

cētiliā.Spanish: hacerse muchos una cosa, o unirse por la viŸa deamistad (M), casar los novios, o conchabar yconformar a los desconformes (M), hacer de algunascosas una, juntaŸndolas (M)

ce-tl.Comment: In compounds the element CEC is generally foundinstead of CE, but the free form CEC-TLI is attestedonly in Z, which lacks CE-TL.

-cēuhyān.Spanish: lugar donde remansan, y reposan las aguas (C inconstruction with Ā-TL)

cēxiuhtiā.English: to be at a place for a year, to pass a year somewhere
cēxiuhtiā.Spanish: estar o tardar un an9o en alguŸn lugar (M)
cēxiuhtiā.Comment: C has cĒcexiuhtica in a section of derivationswith CĒCEM.  The NX sequence assimilates to XX andis printed in C as a single x.  The item hereappears to be derived not from CEM but from CĒ,hence the long vowel and the genuinely short X.

cey(a).Comment: This has a variant form CIY(A).

ciacatitlan.Comment: T has the reflex of CĒYEC corresponding toCIAC.

ciac(a)-tl.Comment: Because the sequence is internal, it is impossible todetermine if it should be IA or IYA.

ciacatlan.Comment: This appears to be a truncation of CIACATITLAN"flank" with a specialized meaning.  T hasCĒYEC corresponding to CIAC.

ciahu(i).English: to attain s.t. by labor and fatigue
ciahu(i).Spanish: adquirir con trabajo lo necesario a la vida (M)

ciahuiztica.Spanish: con mi fatiga (C for possessed form)
ciahuiztica.Comment: This pairs with the instrumental formTLATEQUIPANŌLIZTICA (both elements in possessed form)to form a construction with the sense of the Englishphrase "by the sweat of one's brow".

ciammictiā.Spanish: cansar, fatigar o acosar a otro (M)
ciammictiā.Comment: One of the attestations has the variant spellingCIANMICTIĀ.

ciammiqu(i).Comment: C gives the variant spelling CIANMIQU(I)

ciauhquetz(a).Comment: The sense of this does not follow literally from itscomponent elements.

ciauhtlāz(a).English: to rest from labor and fatigue

cicuil-li.Comment: T has E for I in the first syllable.

cih-tli.Comment: C twice gives the reduplicated form CĪCIHTIN for theplural of this, making it distinct in the plural fromCIH-TLI "grandmother", but he also once glosses thesingular form as both "hare" and "grandmother" andgives the plural as CIHTIN.  X has CIHTIN for theplural of this item, which is not homophonous withthe X word for "grandmother".

cihuācōā-tl.English: title of a high Aztec office
cihuācōā-tl.Spanish: magistrado supremo que juzgaba en uŸltimo instancia ycuyo poder igualaba casi siempre el del soberano, porcuya razoŸn ha sido equiparado a un virrey olugarteniente (S)
cihuācōā-tl.Comment: The single attestation is in the honorific formCIHUĀCŌĀTZIN-TLI.  The literal sense is "femalesnake".

cihuāmōn-tli.Spanish: nuera, mujer de su hijo (M), novia (T)
cihuāmōn-tli.Comment: In T the possessed form has the sense"daughter-in-law", but the unpossessed form isglossed as "girlfriend, fianceŸe".

-cihuānacayō.Comment: M has ciuanacayo "weak, effeminate man", whichprobably represents CIHUĀNACAYOH.  S gives thiswith an absolutive suffix, but C has it only inpossessed form.

cihuāpah-tli.English: name applied to several medicinal plants used toinduce contractions during childbirth (Montanoatomentosa, Montanoa grandiflora, Eriocoma floribunda)
cihuāpah-tli.Spanish: nombre de cinco o seis plantas medicinales (R)

-cihuāpoh-tli.Spanish: usado en comp. nociuapo una mujer como yo, micompan9era, mi pariente; teciuapo la acompan9ante,la hermana, la pariente de alguien (S)
-cihuāpoh-tli.Comment: S gives this with an absolutive suffix, but it is notso attested in the sources for this dictionary.

cihuātēuc-tli.Spanish: ama o sen9ora de esclavos (M), su patrona (Z forpossessed form)

cihuā-tl.Comment: T has the variant ZOHUA-TL, which is also in M inaddition to CIHUĀ-TL.  Besides the difference ofvowel in the first syllable, there seems to be avowel length discrepancy in the second syllablebetween CIHUĀ-TL and ZOHUA-TL.  In compounds Z dropsthe vowel of the first syllable.  When honorific-TZIN is added to the possessed form of CIHUĀ-TL, aglottal stop intervenes between the two elements,ĪCIHUĀHUAHTZIN "his wife (H)".  This is true ofseveral other expressions of kinship relationship aswell.

-cihuāyō.Spanish: secrecioŸn de los oŸrganos sexuales de la mujer (Sfor cihuaayotl)
-cihuāyō.Comment: S gives this with a double vowel medially and anabsolutive suffix and analyzes it as a compound ofCIHUĀ-TL and ĀYŌ-TL, but C has this in a sectionwith -OQUICHYŌ "semen", both apparently inalienablypossessed forms of the corresponding nouns, althoughit is not impossible that -YOH is intended.  M alsohas cihuayotl "vulva".

cihuāyō-tl.Spanish: la madre do concibe la mujer (M), matriz, vulva (S)

cimapah-tli.English: medicinal plant of the bean family the root of whichcan be used to induce vomiting

cima-tl.English: a plant (Desmodium amplifolium) the well-cooked rootof which is used to season stews
cima-tl.Spanish: cierta raiŸz de yerba (M), planta cuya raiŸz se usaen guisados (S)

cin-tli.Spanish: mazorcas de maiŸz secas y curadas
cin-tli.Comment: Z consistently has the stem vowel long, but it isconsistently short elsewhere.

cītlalcuitl(a)-tl.Spanish: la suciedad de estrella, gusanos en la tierra (Z)
cītlalcuitl(a)-tl.Comment: Obsidian is known in Spanish in some areas by theapparent loan translation caca de estrella, but anotherexplanation of Z's rather opaque gloss is the beliefreported in the Florentine Codex that falling starsturn into worms that invade animals (Bk.7,p.13).

cītlallohtihca.Spanish: estaŸ en pie lleno de estrellas (C)

ciyāhu(a).English: to soak s.t., to water s.t.
ciyāhu(a).Spanish: remojar algo, o regar la hortaliza (M)
ciyāhu(a).Comment: By analogy with the nouns ĀYAHU(I)-TL "cloud",CEPAYAHU(I)-TL "snow", and QUIYAHU(I)-TL"rainstorm", one would expect a short A in thesecond syllable, but T has the reflex of Ā.

ciyaltiā.English: to lure, captivate s.o., to cause s.o. to give in,to consent to s.t.
ciyaltiā.Spanish: atraer a otro hacieŸndole querer algo (M)

-ciyaya.Spanish: la voluntad con que uno consiente (C)

-c(o).Grammar: locative suffix; with stems ending in vowels this hasthe form -C
-c(o).Comment: -C(O) is a suffix which attaches tonouns.  It does not take the possessive prefixesas postpositions do.  To indicate motion in thedirection indicated by -C(O), -PA is suffixed to givethe sequence -COPA.

-co.English: to come to do the action indicated by the verb towhich it is attached
-co.Comment: This does not take the tense suffixes; it issuppletive with -QUĪHU(I) for the future tense.

cōā-tl.Spanish: culebra, mellizo, o lombriz de estoŸmago (M)
cōā-tl.Comment: This has two distinct senses, the concrete "snake"and an abstract one involving reciprocity.  Thislatter use is involved in the use of CŌĀ-TL to mean"twin", in the expression of a host-and-guestrelationship in CŌĀNŌTZ(A), and in coatequitl"communal work" (which is not attested in the sourcesfor this dictionary but is transparently a compoundof CŌĀ-TL and TEQUI-TL "work").  There is nophonological contrast corresponding to the twodifferent uses of CŌĀ-TL.  Possibly the reciprocalsense derives from some belief about snakes.Otherwise there are two homophonous lexical items.Because the sequence is internal, it is impossible todetermine if it should be ŌĀ or ŌHUĀ.

cōātlīchān.Spanish: casa de la culebra (C), pueblo del estado deAcolhuacan (S)
cōātlīchān.Comment: The literal sense of this is "serpent's home".
