cochcāhu(a).English: to oversleep; to steal away from s.o. who issleeping; to neglect to do s.t. because one has beenasleep
cochcāhu(a).Spanish: duerme demasiado (Z), dejar durmiendo a otro e irse(M), dejar de hacer algo por se haber dormido (M)

cochcamachaloā.Comment: X has this in reduplicated form.

cochcamacoyāhu(i).Comment: M has camacoyauac "person with a large mouth".

cochcāyōtiā.English: to eat supper; to serve supper to others
cochcāyōtiā.Spanish: cenar (M), dar de cenar a otro (M)

cochcāyō-tl.Comment: This is conventionally paired with NĒUHCĀYŌ-TL"breakfast", both in possessed form, to mean one'sdaily sustenance.

cochhuiā.English: to have intercourse with a woman who is asleep, torock s.o. in one's arms
cochhuiā.Spanish: hacerlo a la mujer que estaŸ durmiendo (M), lo meceen los brazos (T)

cochihtlēhua.English: for s.o. who has been sleeping to leap out of bed
cochihtlēhua.Spanish: saltar de la cama con presteza el que estabadurmiendo (M)
cochihtlēhua.Comment: B has this as a transitive verb "to route s.o. outof bed" and has as the final element -ĒHU(A),forming preterit -ĒUH.

cochīhuani.English: s.t. to aid in sleeping, poppies
cochīhuani.Spanish: instrumento para dormir, como las adormideras (C)

cochīhuayān.Spanish: dormitorio, mesoŸn, celda, o caŸmara para dormir (M)

cochihzoloā.English: to lose sleep over s.t.; to prevent s.o. fromsleeping
cochihzoloā.Spanish: desuela (Z), quitar el suen9o a otro (M)
cochihzoloā.Comment: In one of the two attestations in Z the glottal stopis missing and the preceding vowel is marked long.In the other the glottal stop is also missing, butthe vowel is short.

cochiliz-tli.Comment: One of the Z attestations has the vowel of the thirdsyllable long, and the other has the vowels of boththe second and third syllables long, but neithersyllable should contain long vowels.

cochītiā.English: to put s.o. up for the night; to put s.o. to sleep
cochītiā.Spanish: dar posada a otro albergaŸndolo, o hacer dormir aalguno (M)

-cochiyān.Comment: S gives this with a -TLI absolutive suffix, but it isonly attested in possessed form.

cochiznequ(i).English: to be sleepy, to want to go to sleep
cochiznequ(i).Comment: Z has the vowel of the second syllable long in bothattestations, but it should be short.

cochīz-tli.Comment: This is a shortened form of COCHILIZ-TLI withcompensatory lengthening of I due to loss offollowing LI indicated only in the attestationin B.

cochmahmauhtiā.English: to have a nightmare, to be frightened in one's sleep

cochpachihu(i).English: to have had a good sleep

cochtlachiy(a).English: to waken and go back to sleep repeatedly
cochtlachiy(a).Spanish: recuerda, se despierta y vuelve a dormir repetidasveces (T)
cochtlachiy(a).Comment: M has the noun cochtlachializtli "conception,vision between dreams".  Although T only indicatesthat the preterit is formed with X, this undoubtedlyundergoes the same potential vowel lengthening beforethe X as CHIY(A) does.  The alternative preteritsgiven here are based on CHIY(A).  T only gives thefinal X.

cochtlamelāhu(a).Comment: T has TLACOCHMELĀHU(A) "to be sleeping soundly".

cochtlapechtepehxihuiā.English: to fall out of bed in one's sleep

cochtoc.Comment: C has a reduplicated plural form of this which may bedistributive.

cocoā.English: to be sick, to hurt; to hurt s.o.
cocoā.Spanish: estar enfermo (M), escocerme o dolerme alguna partedel cuerpo (M for first pers. sg. object), lastimar aotro (M)
cocoā.Comment: The sense of "to be sick" may arise from confusionwith COCOY(A), or it may derive from the shared senseof pain.

cococ.Spanish: cosa que quema y abrasa la boca, asiŸ como el ajiŸ opimienta, etc. (M)
cococ.Comment: C specifically gives both vowels short and contraststhis with COCŌC "affliction".  But only the singleattestation in C is in accord with this contrast.All the other attestations have a long vowel in thesecond syllable.  Z has a derived noun COCŌYĀLIZ"piquancy" which is deviant as a derivation fromeither COCOĀ or COCOY(A).

cocōc.Spanish: afligido, atormentado, maltratado; dolor, pena,afliccioŸn, trabajo, etc. (S), afliccioŸn y trabajo(C)
cocōc.Comment: This is conventionally paired with TEOHPŌUHQUI withthe whole construction having the sense of"affliction".

cocōca-tl.Spanish: hacienda o sustenacioŸn de la vida (M)
cocōca-tl.Comment: In the single attestation this appears with -TZIN andan intervening glottal stop which makes the basiclength of the vowel of the last syllableunrecoverable;  it may be Ā.  This contrasts withCOCOCĀ-TL "brandy, rum".

cōcohpātzmictiā.English: to kill s.o. by pressing the neck, to hang s.o.
cōcohpātzmictiā.Spanish: le aprieta el pescuezo hasta matarlo, lo ahorca (T)
cōcohpātzmictiā.Comment: T consistently has the reflex of CŌCŌ for CŌCOH.

cōcohpozāhu(i).English: for the throat, neck to swell
cōcohpozāhu(i).Comment: T consistently has the reflex of CŌCŌ for CŌCOH.

cōcohtlan.Spanish: su garganta, su cuello (T for possessed form)
cōcohtlan.Comment: T consistently has the reflex of CŌCŌ for CŌCOH.X has the variant form CŌCOHTITLAN, of which thismay be a shortened form.

cōcoh-tli.Comment: R attests the stem-final glottal stop and absolutivesuffix, while T's and X's CŌCOTETZIN lacks the glottal stop,but attests the long vowel in the first syllable.This is apparently homophonous with CŌCOH-TLI"throat".  For a similar case, see COPĀCTECOLŌ-TL.

cocōlhuiā.Spanish: entortar algo a otro, o lastimarle, o maltratarlealgo (M)
cocōlhuiā.Comment: The T attestations are specifically given asderivations from COCOĀ, and neither they nor the Cattestations have a long vowel in the secondsyllable.

cocoliā.English: to hate s.o., to wish s.o. ill
cocoliā.Spanish: aborrecer o querer mal a otro (M)

cocomoca.English: to crackle, to make a sound like a roaring fire

cocomotz(a).English: for a baby to make a smacking noise nursing at thebreast; to make a clamour, clatter with one's feet
cocomotz(a).Spanish: paladear el nin9o cuando mama (M), hacer estruendocon los pies (M)

cōconēchihchīhu(a).English: to make an effigy of s.o.

cōconē-tl.Comment: Following Spanish, X has extended the sense of thisto "wrist", but T and Z have not.

cōconēyoh.Comment: The final glottal stop is not attested.  It ishypothesized here for the sense of "somethingembodying embroidery".  The "embroidery" senseassociated with CŌCONĒ-TL is opaque.

cocoquil(i)-tl.English: quausoncle, an edible plant (Chenopodium bonushenricus, Chenopodium nuttalli)
cocoquil(i)-tl.Comment: Because of the minimal attestation, the first elementof this is unidentifiable.

cocotoca.Spanish: quebrarse o despedazarse el hilo, la manta, oromperse la red, etc. (M)

cōcotōn(a).English: to cut, tear s.t. up, to pinch, squeeze, wound s.t.
cōcotōn(a).Spanish: desmenuzar o despedazar pan o cosa semejante (M),pellizcar a otro (M)

cocototz(a).English: to cause s.t. to be cut up, torn into pieces
cocototz(a).Spanish: cortar algo muy menudo, o hacerlo pedazos (M)

cocototzahu(i).Spanish: tullirse (M), se endurece, se entiesa, se dobla (T)

cocotzalhuiā.Comment: This derived applicative form has either lost asyllable or replaced T with C.

cocotzin.Comment: This appears once in a string of epithets all ofwhich are glossed as "hija miŸa" and once unglossedin a command.  S has COCO glossed as "sirvienta" andwith the possessed form -COCOUH.

cocoxcānehnequ(i).Spanish: me finjo enfermo (R for first person)

cocoxoca.Spanish: zonglotear o bazucar la vasija, o sonar el huevomenguado (M), brota (agua) (Z)
cocoxoca.Comment: In one of the Z attestations the vowel of the thirdsyllable is marked long, but this is contrary to thegeneral patterning of verbs of this type.

cocoxotz(a).English: to cause s.t. to make a sloshing noise
cocoxotz(a).Spanish: agitar una vasija, unos huevos, etc. (S)

cōcōyehualoā.Comment: The derivation of this is opaque.  Despite theabsence of L, the sense seems to call for CŌL "s.t.twisted" as an element.  The second element isprobably YAHUALOĀ "to go around s.t." with T'scharacteristic substitution of E for A.

cohcōl-li.Spanish: uno que tiene los pies torcidos y no puede andar (T)
cohcōl-li.Comment: The single attestation is in honorific form,COHCŌLTZIN.

cohcotōn(a).English: to pluck, shred, crumble s.t.; to cut, pinch, wounds.o.
cohcotōn(a).Spanish: desmenuzar o despedazar pan o cosa semejante (M),pellizcar a otro (M)

*cōl.Comment: This is found only as an element of derivations, notin absolutive form.  It is not clear whether it isderivationally related to CŌL-LI "grandfather" orjust homophonous with it.

cōlhuiā.English: to skirt s.t., s.o.; to avoid s.t., s.o. bypassingto one side
cōlhuiā.Spanish: llevar a otro por rodeos a alguna parte, o rodear porno pasar por donde estaŸ alguno (M)

cōlihu(i).Comment: This is only attested in the construction CŌLIUHTOC.In one attestation Z marks no vowels long and in theother both the first and second.

cōl-li.Comment: This is rarely attested in nonpossessed form.  Thepossessed plural is abundantly attested in B, alwaysin reduplicated form, -COHCOLHUĀN.  Sincereduplication in plural formation involves longvowels rather than short vowel and glottal stop, theforms in B may be distributive.  In X and in oneattestation in B the reduplicated form has a singularsense and appears without the plural suffix.

cōloā.English: to twist, to change direction; to bend, fold s.t.; todetour around s.t.
cōloā.Spanish: entortarse, o encorvarse, o rodear caminando (M),encorvar o entortar algo, o rodear yendo camino (M)

cōltiā.English: to offer intoxicating drink to s.o.
cōltiā.Comment: The literal sense of this is "to twist s.o."

comāl-li.Spanish: comal adonde cuecen tortillas de maiŸz, etc., o elbazo (M)

com(a)-tl.Comment: This occurs mainly in the constructions TECOM(A)-TL"clay pot" and CUEZCOM(A)-TL "corn crib".  C hasmocontzin with the same sense as TZONTECOM(A)-TL"brain pan".  The related free form is CŌM(I)-TL,which differs from COM(A)-TL in vowel length in theinitial syllable as well as in quality of the finalvowel.

cōm(i)-tl.Comment: X has a variant CŌN-TLI.  There is a related formCOM(A)-TL that differs in final vowel and also invowel length in the initial syllable and which occursin some but not all compounds with the same sense asCŌM(I)-TL.

comōl-li.Comment: This is implied by ĀCOMŌL-LI and TLACOMŌL-LI andin turn implies COMŌLIHU(I) "to become gullied" andCOMŌLOĀ "to create gullies", both in M.

comōn(i).Spanish: encenderse y echar llama el fuego (M), hacer ruidoalguna cosa pesada que cae, como piedra (C), suena(Z)

comōniā.English: for a crowd to become inflamed, aroused
comōniā.Comment: This is implied by the reduplicated formCOHCOMŌNIĀ.

cōnchili.Comment: The plural form is based on an absolutiveless noun.Both *CŌNCHIL-IN and *CŌNCHIL-LI would fail to givea vowel before the plural suffix.  In either case theexpected plural form would be *CŌNCHILTIN, possibly*CŌNCHILMEH.  However, there are attested plurals inI-MEH for other words that take the -IN absolutivesuffix, and this is the regular plural formation ofsuch words in X.  This implies a loss of final N fromthe absolutive suffix and reanalysis of the remainingvowel as part of the stem.

copāctecolō-tl.Comment: X also uses COPĀC-TLI alone to mean "sparrowhawk",although the literal sense is "palate" or "throat".

copalxoco-tl.Spanish: cierto aŸrbol resinoso, fructiŸfero, medicinal y debuena madera (R), ciruela berraca (X)
copalxoco-tl.Comment: X is missing the internal L.

copīn(a).English: for s.t. to pull itself loose; to pull s.t. out, to removes.t. from a mold, to copy s.t.
copīn(a).Spanish: se arranca (T), sacar una cosa de otra, o por otra, osacar algo con molde asiŸ como adobes o vasos (M),lo arranca (T)

copīn(i).English: for s.t. to pull loose, get out, come unstuck
copīn(i).Comment: This is abundantly attested but only in T and Z.

copīniā.English: for s.t. to pull itself loose

copitztic.Comment: In one of the two attestations the vowel of thesecond syllable is marked long.  This may be relatedto COPĪN(A) and COPĪN(I), because they areassociated with the sense of "mold", hence s.t. verytight.  M has copichtic "s.t. pried out".

cotoctic.Spanish: cosa que le falta algo o alguŸn pedazo (M)

cotōn(a).English: to cut s.t., to break s.t. off, to wound s.o.
cotōn(a).Spanish: cortar o despedazar algo, o coger la fruta del aŸrbolcon la mano, o coger espigas, o abreviar algo (M),pellizcar (M)

cotōn(i).English: for a cord, thread, or rope to snap
cotōn(i).Spanish: quebrarse la cuerda o el hilo, soga, etc. (M)

cototzoā.English: to squat down, for s.t. to shorten, shrink; tolengthen or shorten s.t.
cototzoā.Spanish: ponerse de cuclillas, encogerse o encaramarse (M),encoger la costura (M)
cototzoā.Comment: This is related by metathesis to synonymous TOCOTZOĀ.

cototztlāliā.Spanish: ponerse de cuclillas, encogerse o encaramarse (M)
cototztlāliā.Comment: This is related by metathesis to synonymousTOCOTZTLĀLIĀ.

cōtz-tli.Comment: This also appears in three attestations in T with thegloss "la piel" instead of "el pie", and the gloss isrepeated on the Spanish-to-Nahuatl side of T.  It iseither a mistake or a confusion with CUETLAX-TLI"skin, leather".

coxōn(i).English: for a hollow vessel to make a sloshing sound

coyāhu(a).English: to extend s.t., to enlarge a hole, to peel staffs
coyāhu(a).Spanish: ensanchar alguŸn agujero, o descortezar varas (M)

coyāhuac.Spanish: cosa ancha, asiŸ como can9o de agua o ventana, etc.(M)

coyoctic.Comment: T and X have the variant COYACTIC.

coyol-li.Comment: M also gives "fishing rod" as a sense for this, butit is unattested in the sources for this dictionaryand may differ in vowel length.

coyolxōchi-tl.Spanish: cierta planta medicinal de bellas flores (R)
coyolxōchi-tl.Comment: Spanish names for this are granadita and flor desonaja.

coyōn(i).English: for s.t. to get full of holes

coyōniā.English: to perforate s.t., to make holes in s.t.

coyōtoma-tl.English: a plant of the verbena family with bitter roots(Vitex mollis)

cōzca-tl.Spanish: joya, piedra preciosa labrada de forma redonda, ocuenta para rezar (M), collar, gargantilla (Z)
cōzca-tl.Comment: This contrasts in vowel length with COZTIC "yellow,golden".  X has a variant CŌZ-TLI.

cōzol-li.Comment: B gives only the first vowel long.  Of the twoattestations in Z, one has both vowels marked long,the other neither.  Z also has a part-Spanishconstruction meaning "net, sling" which seems toinclude this element.

coztic.Comment: The COZ of this appears as an element in somecompounds.

cozticpah-tli.English: name given to two medicinal plants
cozticpah-tli.Spanish: nombre de dos plantas medicinales de las cuales launa es semejante al adianto (R)

cōz-tli.Comment: This contrasts in vowel length with COZ from COZTIC"yellow, golden".

chachacuaca.English: to sprinkle, for mud to splatter
chachacuaca.Spanish: salpicar el lodo, andando por lodazales (M), salpica(Z)
chachacuaca.Comment: This is synonymous with CHACHAPACA, and they probablyshare a common source with substitution of one labialconsonant for another.

chachalaca.English: to chatter, especially for birds to do so
chachalaca.Spanish: parlar mucho, o gorjear las aves (M)
chachalaca.Comment: Z has CHACHALĀCAH as a noun for the birds known inSpanish as chachalacas (Ortalis vetula, Ortaliscinereiceps) That this is a back loan from MexicanSpanish is shown by the lengthening of the stressedvowel and by the word-final glottal stop, both ofwhich are characteristic of Spanish loans intoNahuatl.  M has chachalatli "a type of bird",complete with absolutive suffix.

chāchalān(i).English: to make a hubbub, create an uproar
chāchalān(i).Comment: M has only the transitive verb chachalania with thesense of to mix things up, to disturb people.

chachalatz(a).Spanish: se dice del que causa este ruido (C for CHACHALACA)

chachāntic.Comment: M has chamactic "s.t. thick and swollen or s.t.massive like thick wool".

chachapaca.English: for rain to patter down in big drops, to sprinkle
chachapaca.Spanish: cuando las pellas son muchas (C), caer grandes gotas,llover (S), salpica, rocia (Z)
chachapaca.Comment: In one of the attestations in Z the vowel of thethird syllable is marked long, but it should beshort.

chachapān(i).English: for rain to sprinkle, patter in large drops

chachapatz(a).English: to make s.t. splash, spatter, get spotted
chachapatz(a).Spanish: chapotear por lodazales (M), patalear en el barro,salpicar, manchar algo (S)

chacha-tl.Comment: This is only attested in the compound ĀCACHACHA-TL,of which M has what appears to be a shortened formacachatl.

chāchicte-tl.English: a good luck stone known as a "corn kernel"
chāchicte-tl.Spanish: piedra de buena suerte, "el corazoŸn de maiŸz" (T)
chāchicte-tl.Comment: T has the variant CHĀCHTE-TL.  The first element isnowhere else attested.

chacuān(i).English: for s.t. to get spattered, soaked
chacuān(i).Spanish: mojarse mucho la ropa o cosa asiŸ (M)

-chahchān.Comment: C gives this possessed reduplicated form of CHĀN-TLI"home" as an example of the distributive, "each tohis own home".

chāhu(a).English: s.o. in an irregular, nonlegitimate relationship,s.o. likely to arouse jealousy, mistress
chāhu(a).Comment: S gives chauatl, but since this only appears incompounds and in possessed form, the absolutivesuffix is unattested.  T has the pejorativediminutive CHĀHUATŌN.  M has compounds of CHĀHU(A)with COCOY(A) "for a woman to be miserable on accountof her husband's mistress, or to be gravely ill",with NE-COCOY(A) "to be possessed by evil", withCONĒ-TL and PIL-LI "stepchild", and with NĀN-TLI"stepmother".

chāhuiz-tli.English: chahuistle, a blight especially affecting wheat

chalān(i).English: for s.t. such as a pot or copper pot to crack or forsuch vessels to make a noise together; for a song orinstrument to be out of tune
chalān(i).Spanish: cascarse la vasija de barro, o de cobre, odesentonarse el canto, o el instrumento musical (M)
chalān(i).Comment: Z gives escurre as a gloss for this, apparently inthe sense of trickling or dripping from a crack.

chālchihu(i)-tl.Spanish: esmeralda basta (M), esmeralda en bruto, perla,piedra preciosa verde (S)

chālchiuhtēuh.English: in the manner of precious green stones

chāliā.English: to inaugurate s.t., to handle s.t. for the firsttime

chamāhu(a).English: to brag, to be arrogant; to enhance s.o.'s reputation,to flatter s.o.
chamāhu(a).Spanish: se enorgullece, jacta (T), lo afama (T), lisonjear(M)
chamāhu(a).Comment: M also has this as an intransitive verb with thegloss "for a child to grow or for maize or cacao toripen".  The common sense is of inflation, swellingup.

chamāhuac.Spanish: cosa gorda y crecida, o cosa vasta como lana gruesa(M), grueso (... maiŸz, frijol, etc.) (T)
chamāhuac.Comment: M gives this as synonymous with chamactic.  Z hasthe variant CHACHĀNTIC.

-chān.Comment: This must be possessed; unlike a postposition, itcannot bind with another noun to the exclusion of apossessive prefix.  Z gives ĪCHĀMPA with thestative gloss "his vicinity", but the suffixed -PAshould convey a directional sense.  When thehonorific -TZIN is bound to -CHĀN, then locative-C(O) is suffixed to the whole construction,ĪCHĀNTZINCO "at his home (H)".

chāneh.Spanish: el que tiene casa (C), los naturales (C for plural),habitante (Z)

chānti.English: to live, to take root in a place, to settle

chāntiā.English: to live, to reside in a place
chāntiā.Spanish: vivir o morar en alguŸn lugar (M)

chān-tli.Spanish: la casa (C), casa, habitacioŸn, residencia, paiŸs,patria, etc.  (S)
chān-tli.Comment: This contrasts with CAL-LI as English homecontrasts with house.  CAL-LI refers to thephysical structure, while CHĀN-TLI implies a human,social connection with a location.

chapān(i).English: for there to be a slapping sound like falling doughor wet clay
chapān(i).Spanish: mojarse mucho, o caer en tierra la masa, el lodo ocosas semejantes (M), el ruido del barro y masa, quecae en el suelo (C)

chapāniā.English: to cause s.t. wet and flexible to slap to the ground
chapāniā.Spanish: echar en el suelo o por ahiŸ lodo, masa, o cosasemejante (M)
chapāniā.Comment: M gives the preterit of this as chapan, but T givesCHAPĀNIH as it should be.

chapol-in.Comment: Z consistently gives the vowel of the second syllableas long, but T has a short vowel.

chapopoh-tli.Spanish: especie de betuŸn oloroso que se usaban comoincienso; las mujeres se lavaban los dientes con eŸl(S), chapapote (Z)
chapopoh-tli.Comment: Z gives the vowel of the first syllable as long, butthe other sources do not.

chayāhu(a).English: to scatter, pour, sprinkle s.t. down
chayāhu(a).Spanish: esparcir o derramar por el suelo trigo o cosasemejante (M), lo tira, lo derrama, lo esparce, loriega (T)

chayāhu(i).English: for s.t. to spill, sprinkle down; for snow to fall
chayāhu(i).Spanish: echarse asiŸ trigo, o caer nieve (M)

chayoh-tli.Spanish: fruta como calabacilla espinosa por encima o comoerizo (M)

chicactic.English: s.t. robust, strong, powerful; s.o. who hasattained old age
chicactic.Spanish: cosa recia y fuerte, o persona anciana (M)

chicāhu(a).English: to strengthen, fortify, animate s.t., s.o.
chicāhu(a).Spanish: fortalecer o guarnecer algo, y esforzar y animar (M),esforzar a otro (M)
chicāhu(a).Comment: There is also an intransitive verb of the same form.Z gives the additional sense of "to ferment s.t.".

chicāhuac.English: s.t. strong, robust, powerful; s.o. who hasattained old age
chicāhuac.Spanish: cosa recia o fuerte, o persona anciana (M)

chicāhualiz-tli.Spanish: fortaleza o firmeza o esfuerzo y animosidad (M)

chicāhualtiā.English: to make s.t. grow strong, ripen

chicāhuiliā.English: to hasten work, to push work to the point ofexhaustion

chīchī.Comment: C contrasts this with CHICHI "dog", CHIHCHI "saliva",and the verb CHIHCHI "to mend, patch s.t.". T and Zgive both vowels as long, but T has the vowel of thesecond syllable short in three attestations of thederived form meaning "breast".  X has CHĪCHĪ as atransitive verb "to suckle s.t." and does not markthe vowel of the second syllable long.

chichi.Comment: This is commonly used with the diminutive compoundingelement -TŌN.  Since CHICHI is an absolutivelessnoun, the compound is also absolutiveless,CHICHITŌN.  CHICHI contrasts with CHĪCHĪ "tosuckle" and CHIHCHI "saliva".

chichic.Comment: Z and X have the vowel of the second syllable long,and so does one attestation from T, although anotherin T has it specifically marked short.  This reflectsthe variation of vowel length in verbs ending in-IY(A), which are attested in the preterit as both-IX and -ĪX.

chichica-tl.Comment: In one attestation Z has an internal geminate CCwhich is probably a typographical error.  In both ofthe attestations in Z the vowel of the secondsyllable is given as long.

chīchicāuhcānehnequ(i).English: to gather strength to do s.t.
chīchicāuhcānehnequ(i).Spanish: hace fuerza (aunque esteŸ deŸbil) para una cosa (T)
chīchicāuhcānehnequ(i).Comment: In these attestations the vowel of the secondsyllable is given as long.  This is also true of theitem as it appears in a gloss on theSpanish-to-Nahuatl side of T.  This must be an error,since this is a derivation from CHICĀHU(A).

chichiccuahu(i)-tl.English: a tree from the barkof which quinine is extracted
chichiccuahu(i)-tl.Comment: Another name for this plant is CHICHICTLACŌ-TL.

chīchico.English: from one side to the other repeatedly

chīchicohōme.Spanish: de siete en siete, o a cada uno siete (M)
chīchicohōme.Comment: In this item there are two reduplications.

chichictlacō-tl.English: a tree from the barkof which quinine is extracted
chichictlacō-tl.Comment: This plant is also known as CHICHICCUAHU(I)-TL.

chīchicuacem.Spanish: de seis en seis, o cada uno seis (M)
chīchicuacem.Comment: This is in a compound.  There is a macron over thevowel of the last syllable, but this is an error,because C has the nonreduplicated form immediatelyabove without a macron.  The final M delabializes toN before nonlabial consonants and in word-finalposition.

chīchicuehēy(i).Spanish: de ocho en ocho, o cada uno ocho (M)
chīchicuehēy(i).Comment: In this item there are two reduplications.

chichicuep(a).English: to turn s.o. into a dog
chichicuep(a).Spanish: os vuelve como perros (C for second pers. pluralobject)

chīchihcōloā.English: to move like a snake, to weave from side to side

chīchihcōltic.Comment: Z gives both this and CHIHCHIHCŌLTIC with the samegloss.

chīchīhual-li.Spanish: teta (M), su chiche, su pecho (de mujer) (T)
chīchīhual-li.Comment: A single attestation in B has the vowel of the secondsyllable long as it should be if CHĪCHĪ is thecorrect form of the verb, but T has this vowelconsistently short.  In X the vowels of the first twosyllables are unmarked for length and that of thethird is marked long.

chīchīhualtecom(a)-tl.Spanish: su ubre (vaca) (T), mujer de grandes tetas (M)

chīchīlāzca-tl.English: a type of large red ant

chīchīlēhu(i).Comment: Because the vowel of the third syllable is long, thisseems to be constructed on the verb -ĒHU(I) ratherthan to be a simple case of substitution of E for I.

chichiliā.English: to make s.t. or s.o. bitter
chichiliā.Comment: in construction with "one's heart" as direct object,this has the sense of "to grow angry".

chīchīlihu(i).Comment: This implies the transitive verb CHĪCHĪLOĀ "tomake s.t. red", which is in M but is not directlyattested in the sources for this dictionary.  T and Zhave CHĪCHĪLĒHU(I).

chīchīlticcihuāpah-tli.Comment: The literal sense of this is "red female-medicine".

chīchīlticcuahu(i)-tl.English: candlewood, a spiny red-flowering bush (Fouquieriasplendens, Fouquieria formosa)

chīchīltzapo-tl.Comment: In all three attestations Z fails to mark the vowelof the first syllable long.

chīchīmēcapah-tli.Spanish: planta medicinal muy ceŸlebre, pero demasiadamenteactiva (R)
chīchīmēcapah-tli.Comment: R does not mark the vowels of the first threesyllables long.  An alternative analysis is acompound of CHICHI "dog", MECA-TL "vine", PAH-TLI"medicine".

chīchīmēca-tl.English: Chichimec, a person from one of the indigenous groupsof northern Mexico considered barbarians byNahuatl-speakers.
chīchīmēca-tl.Comment: Used as a modifier this has both a negative"barbarous" sense and a positive "noble savage"sense.  By its vowel length pattern it is clearly notderived from the words for "dog", "rags, patches", or"bitter".  It is possibly derivationally related toCHĪCHĪ "to suckle".

chīchīmēcayō-tl.English: s.t. partaking of the nature of the Chichimecs

chichīn(a).English: to soak s.t. up, to suck s.t. in, to smoke s.t.
chichīn(a).Spanish: chupar algo, o tomar sahumerio de olores con can9as(M), rezumarse la vasija embebieŸndose en ella alguŸnlicor ... lo mismo se dice de la esponja o de cosasemejante que embebe en siŸ alguŸn licor (M)

chichinaca.Spanish: escocer la llaga (M), tener dolor, pena o afliccioŸn(M)

chichinatz(a).English: to cause s.o. to suffer pain

chichinoā.English: to scorch, burn oneself; to scorch, burn s.t.
chichinoā.Spanish: chamuscarse, o quemarse (M), chamuscar o quemar aotro (M)

chichipahtic.Comment: In one of the two attestations the vowel of thesecond syllable is marked long.  R has relatedCUAUHCHICHICPAH-TLI with the internal C which ismissing in this item.

chichipitz(a).English: to sprinkle s.t., to cause s.t. to drip
chichipitz(a).Spanish: derramar algo a gotas en abundancia (C)

chichiquil-li.English: crest; guiding feathers on a spear, vane
chichiquil-li.Comment: The two attestations are in compounds meaning "spine"and "cock's crest".

chichitoca.Spanish: saltar muchas chispas, etc. (C), centellear,crepitar, estallar (S)

chichitotz(a).English: to cause s.t. to sparkle, crackle, explode
chichitotz(a).Spanish: hacer saltar las astillas, chispas, etc. (C)

chichiy(a).Comment: The alternating vowel length in the preterit is notattested but is based on analogy with other verbs inIY(A).

chichizāyōl-in.Spanish: mosca que se para en el aire volando (T)
chichizāyōl-in.Comment: The literal sense of this is "dog-fly".

chīch-tli.English: owl; a type of whistle; sorcerer
chīch-tli.Spanish: lechuza, o pito que tan9en los muchachos (M), brujo,bruja (T)

chicoihtoā.English: to speak ill of s.o., to slander s.o.
chicoihtoā.Spanish: murmurar o decir mal de otro (M)

chicōmepa.Comment: In the single attestation there is the reflex of aglottal stop preceding the -PA.

chicopetōn(i).English: for s.t. to be out of line, protruding sideways
chicopetōn(i).Spanish: se desconcierta uno, y se sale a un lado (C)

chicoquīz(a).English: to move aside; to fall from virtue; to surpass,exceed
chicoquīz(a).Spanish: se sale a un lado (C), apartarse de la virtud (M),sobresale (T)

chicotiya.English: for s.t. to tilt sideways, turn to one side

chicotlahtoā.English: to rave, to blaspheme, to speak cagily
chicotlahtoā.Spanish: desvariar el enfermo, o blasfemar el blasfemo, ohablar cautelosamente (M)
chicotlahtoā.Comment: The literal sense of this is to speak in a less thanforthright manner.  T has CUA for CO.

chicuacē.Comment: X has CHICUACEN as the free form.

chicuaceppa.Comment: M forms this from CHICUACEM- with assimilation of Mto P, but T forms it from CHICUACĒ.

chīcuah-tli.Comment: In the attestation in T the vowel of the firstsyllable is specifically marked short, but C marks itlong.

chīcuahtōtō-tl.English: a bird that resembles a barn owl
chīcuahtōtō-tl.Spanish: cierta ave semejante a la lechuza (R)

chicuēxcān.Spanish: en ocho partes u ocho raciones (M)

chicuēxpa.Comment: M forms this with the regular compounding form ofCHICUĒY(I).  T has two variants.  In one the finalstem vowel is retained and the reflex of a glottalstop intervenes between stem and -PA.  The othervariant is like M's but with the X weakened before-PA.

chihchi.Comment: C contrasts this with CHICHI "dog" and CHĪCHĪ "tosuckle".  It is homophonous with the stem ofCHIHCHI-TL "saliva".

chihchihcōltic.Comment: Z gives both this and CHĪCHIHCŌLTIC with the samegloss.

chihchihcop(i).Comment: In T this has characteristically lost an internalglottal stop.  It is to be found in thenonreduplicated form CHIHCOPILIĀ, also in T.

chihchīhu(a).English: to adorn, dress oneself, to get ready; to adorn, dresss.o., to adorn, embellish s.t.
chihchīhu(a).Spanish: aderezarse, componerse, o ataviarse (M), aderezar deesta manera otro (M), aderezar alguna cosa (M)
chihchīhu(a).Comment: This contrasts with M's chichiua "nursemaid", whichis derived from CHĪCHĪ "to suckle".

chihchīmolōn(i).English: for s.t. to burst open while boiling
chihchīmolōn(i).Spanish: se revienta (p.ej. papa, frijol, nixtamal, etc.,hirviendo, etc.)

chihcōloā.English: to twist, to move in a serpentine manner; to twists.t.
chihcōloā.Comment: This is abundantly attested but only in Z.  In thedirect attestations of the verb and in the derivationCHIHCŌLTIC there is inconsistency, but overall thispattern holds, contrasting with CHICO "to the side"and incorporating CŌL "turn, curve".

chihcōltic.Spanish: cosa tuerta como garabato (M), torcido, chueco,desparejo, de lado (Z)

chihcopiliā.English: to wink at s.o., to catch s.o.'s eye
chihcopiliā.Spanish: hace sen9as con los ojos, le parpadea (T)

chīhu(a).English: to make, do s.t.; to engender, beget s.o.
chīhu(a).Comment: The reflexive use of this has the lexicalized sense"to happen".

chīhuiā.Comment: This is attested twice in the compound PAHCHĪHUIĀused reflexively "to avail oneself of medicine".

chilacayoh-tli.English: a type of soft squash (Cucurbita filicifolia)

chīlatlāhuic.English: a type of mild chili pepper
chīlatlāhuic.Comment: Because of the characteristic reduction in T, theintervocalic L may represent a geminate.  Possiblythe second element is related to TLĀHUIĀ and hasto do with redness.

chīlchō-tl.Comment: It would make sense for the second element of this tobe XŌ, referring to greenness, but M and Z agree onCH rather than X.

chīlhuāc.Comment: M has chiluacmulli "sauce or stew seasoned withsmoked chilies".

chīlhuiā.English: to season s.t. with chili peppers

chīliā.Comment: T gives this as the applicative form of CHIY(A).  Itis noteworthy that the vowel of the first syllable islong in the absence of YA.

chīllacuēchōl-li.English: sauce, paste of ingredients very finely groundtogether
chīllacuēchōl-li.Comment: Z does not give the absolutive suffix.

chīl-li.Spanish: ajiŸ, o pimienta de las indias (M)
chīl-li.Comment: In compounds CHĪL- often conveys the sense "red".

chīllōtiā.English: to season s.t. with chili peppers
chīllōtiā.Spanish: lechar ajiŸ en alguŸn manjar o guisado (M)

chīlpach.English: profusion or scattering of chili peppers
chīlpach.Comment: Z uses the element PACH without an absolutive suffixin this and in TOMAPACH with the sense of"profusion", possibly "waste".  It may be related toPACH-TLI "moss".

chīlpah-tli.Spanish: cierta planta medicinal y lactifera, cuya leche esvenenosa (R)
chīlpah-tli.Comment: R fails to mark the vowel of the initial syllablelong.

chīlpopō-tl.English: a type of leguminous plant (Parosela diffusa)

chīltecpin.English: a tiny, very hot chili pepper pod known in Spanish aschiltipiquiŸn
chīltecpin.Comment: In the plural the final N may assimilate to the M ofthe plural suffix.

chīltlemōlloh.English: soup or stew seasoned with chili peppers
chīltlemōlloh.Comment: The more usual Spanish form of this is clemole.

chīmal-li.Spanish: rodela, adarga paveŸs, o cosa semejante (M), escudo(Z)

chīmalquīza-tl.English: piece of gypsum, plaster of Paris
chīmalquīza-tl.Comment: The derivation of this is opaque.

chīmaltiā.English: to shield oneself; to use s.t. or s.o. as a shield
chīmaltiā.Spanish: hacer rodela para siŸ, o guarecerse con ella del soly del agua (M), te tomo por mi escudo, me sirves deescudo (C for first pers. sg. subject, second pers.sg. object)

chinām(i)-tl.English: fence of cane or cornstalks, an area so enclosed, orthe canes or stalks themselves
chinām(i)-tl.Spanish: seto o cerca de can9as (M), can9uela de maiŸz,chinaŸmil (T)
chinām(i)-tl.Comment: Z has the variant CHINĀN-TLI with the sense"pyramid", while X has it with the sense "hovel".  Italso is a term of social organization referring to aunit closely equivalent to a calpolli.  The senseall share to some degree is "enclosure".

chināncal-li.English: house or enclosure built of cane or cornstalks

-chinānyō.English: the stalks (of a canebrake or cornfield)

chinoā.Comment: All attestations are of the prefixed stem(I)HCHINOĀ.  In fact, since as an intransitive verbthis must always take an object prefix, and since insuch cases the (I)H element is only detectable insources that indicate glottal stop, it is possiblethat (I)HCHINOĀ also underlies M's entry chinoa.

chipactic.Spanish: blanco, limpio, gu ero, huero, rubio (T)
chipactic.Comment: Z has the variant CHIPACTZIN.  M has chipaccalticwith the same sense.  Both are virtually synonymouswith CHIPĀHUAC.

chipāhua.English: for s.t. to become clean, pure
chipāhua.Spanish: pararse limpio, o pararse clara el agua turbia, opurificarse algo (M)
chipāhua.Comment: This contrasts in the preterit form with thecorresponding transitive verb.  T has theintransitive form CHIPĀHU(I).

chipāhu(a).English: to purify oneself; to purify s.t.,s.o.
chipāhu(a).Spanish: alimpiarse o purificarse (M), alimpiar o purificar aotro (M), alimpiar, purificar, o afinar algo (M)
chipāhu(a).Comment: This contrasts in the preterit with intransitiveCHIPĀHUA.

chipāhualiz-tli.Spanish: limpieza, hermosura, y lindeza, o claridad de agua noturbia (M)

chipāhu(i).Comment: This is a variant intransitive verb form with thesame sense as intransitive CHIPĀHUA and contrastingwith transitive CHIPĀHU(A).

chipīn(i).Comment: T has a variant TLACHIPĪN(I) with the same gloss.  Mhas a corresponding transitive verb chipinia "toscatter s.t. in droplets".

chiquilēuhtzahtzi.Comment: M has chiquilitzatzi with the same sense.

chiquilīch-tli.Comment: The Z form of this item appears to retain a relic ofthe -IN absolutive suffix, while M has the -TLIabsolutive.

chītah-tli.Spanish: redecilla para llevar de comer por el camino (M),hamaca, cuna (T)

chitōn(i).English: for sparks, chips to fly; for a story to be told inan animated manner; for a fire to flare and sparkle
chitōn(i).Spanish: saltar el astilla, o la cuenta cuando la quierenensartar, o centellear la lumbre o el fuego (M),bota, tira, salta (T)

chiucnāuhcān.Spanish: en nueve partes, o nueve raciones (M)

chīuhqui.English: s.o. in authority, s.o. with power
chīuhqui.Comment: This item is abundantly attested with an incorporatedobject, for example CACCHĪUHQUI "shoemaker", butonly in Z does it appear as a free form.

chixcācah.Spanish: tener confianza, o esperar alguŸn beneficio (M)
chixcācah.Comment: One of the B attestations has a long vowel in thefirst syllable which reflects the general variationof preterit CHIX = CHĪX.

chiy(a).Comment: This has a variant with E for A.  The preterit showsan alternation in vowel length characteristic ofverbs in IY(A).

chiyāhua.Comment: This contrasts in the preterit with transitiveCHIYĀHU(A).

chiyāhu(a).Comment: This contrasts in the preterit with the correspondingintransitive verb form.

chiyāhuac.Comment: Z has the shortened form CHĀHUAC.

chiyāhualtiā.Comment: Z has the shortened form CHĀHUALTIĀ.  Bothattestations give the vowel of the second syllable aslong, but it should probably be short.

chiyāhuiz-tli.Spanish: humor (M), enfermedad de planta (T), gordura, grasa(X)
chiyāhuiz-tli.Comment: Z has the shortened form CHĀHUIZ-TLI.

chiyan-tli.English: chia, a plant (Salvia chian) from the seed of whichoil is pressed; the seed is also used in making arefreshing beverage
chiyan-tli.Spanish: chiŸa, semilla comuŸn en MeŸxico de que hacen bebidasfrescas y sacan un buen aceite (R)
chiyan-tli.Comment: M has chia and chian without an absolutivesuffix.  From the single attestation it is notpossible to establish beyond doubt that there is anintervocalic Y or that both vowels are short.

chōca.English: to weep, cry, howl, to utter one's characteristicsound
chōca.Spanish: llorar, balar la oveja, bramar el leoŸn o el toro,cantar el buho o las otras aves (M)

chōchōca.English: to go on crying, to weep repeatedly

chochopoca.Comment: T has TZOTZOPOCA with the closely related sense of"for s.t. to bubble as it ferments".  M haschochopoca with a different sense "to itch, to havea rash".

chocolātic.English: s.t. the color of chocolate, dark brown

chocolā-tl.Spanish: alimento hecho con almendras de cacao y semillas delaŸrbol llamado pochotl, en partes iguales (S),chocolate (R)
chocolā-tl.Comment: This is not attested in M, B, or C, but it isattested in R as well as in the modern sources.Possibly the initial element is related to M'sxocolia "to make s.t. bitter or sour" and to XOCOC"s.t. sour".  The substitution of CH for X is notuncommon.

chōcuetlān.Comment: In one attestation the vowel of the first syllable ismarked long, and in the other it is unmarked.

chohchoc.Comment: The literal sense of the Spanish gloss is "muleteerbird".  Since neither attestation marks the vowel ofthe second syllable long, there does not seem to be aconnection with CHŌCA "to cry".

choloā.English: to flee; to run swiftly, to leap along
choloā.Spanish: huir, saltar, o ausentarse, o saltar o chorrear elagua (M)

cholōltiā.English: to throw oneself into flight; to make s.o. flee
cholōltiā.Spanish: echar a huir (M), hacer huir a otro (M)

chopīniā.English: to pick at s.t., to prick s.o.
chopīniā.Spanish: picar la viŸbora, o comer el paŸjaro (M)
chopīniā.Comment: This is only indirectly and weakly attested inCACHOPĪN, but synonymous TZOPĪNIĀ iswell attested.

chōquiliz-tli.English: tears, weeping, cries, howls, the characteristicsound of an animal
chōquiliz-tli.Spanish: lloro o llanto, balido de oveja, bramido de leoŸn ootro, aullido de perro o de lobo, o canto de buho yde las otras aves (M)
chōquiliz-tli.Comment: This is attested across sources, including C.Z gives CHŌCALIZ-TLI and CHŌQUILIZ-TLI together assynonyms.  CHŌQUIZ-TLI is also synonymous.

chōquizhuēhuetzca.English: to laugh with tears in one's eyes

chōquiztiliā.English: to make s.o. feel pain (about spendng money)
chōquiztiliā.Comment: This draws its sense from the T sense of "miser" forthe related noun.

chōquiz-tli.English: tears, weeping, cries, howls, the characteristicsound of an animal
chōquiz-tli.Comment: According to M and C, this is synonymous withCHŌQUILIZ-TLI, of which, in fact, it is a shortenedform.  T glosses it as a as a substantive "amiserable person, s.o. indigent, a miser".

cuā.Spanish: comer algo (M), morder o comer a otro (M)
cuā.Comment: T has a short final vowel in derived forms whereother sources have a long one.  But across sourcesCUĀ appears in some derived forms with a shortvowel where a long one is to be expected.

cuāātēquiā.English: to sprinkle water on one's head, to wash one's head,to receive baptism; to wash s.o.'s head, to baptizes.o.
cuāātēquiā.Spanish: echar agua sobre la cabeza, o lavaŸrsela, obautizarse (M), lavar a otro la cabeza de estamanera (M), lo bautiza (T)
cuāātēquiā.Comment: M has almost identical glosses for CUĀTĒQUIĀ,which results from the compression of the twoadjacent long vowels into one.

cuacemman(a).English: for s.t. to spill, scatter, sprinkle; to spill,scatter, sprinkle s.t. (other than liquid)
cuacemman(a).Spanish: se derrama, se esparce, se riega (cosa seca) (T), loderrama, lo esparce, lo riega (T)
cuacemman(a).Comment: Intransitive CUACEMMAN(I) has the same sense asCUACEMMAN(A) used reflexively.

cuacemman(i).English: for s.t. (other than liquid) to scatter

cuāchcal-li.Spanish: pabelloŸn, cielo de cama, paramento, o tienda demantas enceradas (M)

cuāch-tli.Comment: This is attested indirectly in CUĀCHPĀM(I)-TL andCUĀCHCALTŌPĪL-LI.

cuacuā.English: to chew or gnaw at s.t.
cuacuā.Spanish: mascar pan, carne, etc., o roer el ratoŸn papel,manta, etc. (C)
cuacuā.Comment: This contrasts with CUAHCUĀ "to snap, nip at s.t."M combines both senses in a single entry with thegloss "to nip s.t. or for a sheep to ruminate".

cuācuahueh.English: ox, cow, bull, or other horned animal
cuācuahueh.Spanish: toro, o animal que tiene cuernos (M)
cuācuahueh.Comment: Z has a -MEH plural, implying that this has beenlexicalized and is not recognized as a derivationwith the possessor suffix -EH, which forms its pluralas -EHQUEH.

cuācuahuehcāhuah.Spanish: sen9or de los que tienen cuernos ... el sen9or deeŸste ganado mayor (C)

cuācuahuehhuah.Spanish: sen9or de los que tienen cuernos ... el duen9o deeŸste ganado mayor (C)
cuācuahuehhuah.Comment: C gives this as an alternative to the longer formCUĀCUAHUEHCĀHUAH.

cuācuahu(i)-tl.Comment: The literal sense of this is "head-tree".

cuacualaca.English: to make a thundering sound or a sound like waterboiling in a pot or boiling over
cuacualaca.Spanish: tronar o hacer ruido lo que hierve en la olla aborbollones (M)

cuacualatz(a).English: to cause s.t. to make a thundering sound or a soundlike water boiling over
cuacualatz(a).Spanish: levantar semejante ruido (C referring back toCUACUALACA)
cuacualatz(a).Comment: According to C this item was little used.

cuacualō.Comment: By general rule this should be CUACUĀLŌ, but itis attested in T with the reflex of short A inthe second syllable (p.180).

cuācuauhchōca.Comment: CUĀCUAUH here is apparently a truncation ofCUĀCUAHUEH "animal with horns".

cuācuauhconē-tl.Comment: CUĀCUAH here is apparently a truncation ofCUĀCUAHUEH "animal with horns".

cuācuauhnac(a)-tl.Comment: CUĀCUAUH here is apparently a truncation ofCUĀCUAHUEH "animal with horns".

cuācuauhpixqui.Spanish: boyerizo o vaquero (M), pastor de ganado de bueyes (T)
cuācuauhpixqui.Comment: In M the UHP sequence assimilates to PP.

cuācuauhpiy(a).Comment: CUĀCUAUH here is apparently a truncation ofCUĀCUAHUEH "animal with horns".  The long-vowelvariant preterit form is not directly attestedbut is established for component PIY(A).

cuācuauhtzon-tli.Comment: CUĀCUAHUEH here is apparently a truncation ofCUĀCUAHUEH "animal with horns".

cuāēhuayō-tl.Spanish: el cuero de la cabeza (M), su cuero cabelludo (T forpossessed form), su caspa (Z for possessed form)

cuahcuā.English: to snap, nip at s.t.; for stock to graze
cuahcuā.Spanish: dar bocados o dentelladas a otro (M), pacer el ganado(M)
cuahcuā.Comment: M combines this item with CUACUĀ in a single entrywith the gloss "to nip s.t. or for a sheep toruminate".

cuahcua.English: for s.t. (such as rheumatism) to cause s.o. pain
cuahcua.Comment: This appears nearly synonymous with CUAHCUĀ in thesense of causing a gnawing pain, but this item has ashort vowel in the last syllable, and the preterit isdistinct from that of CUĀ.

cuahcuacuā.Spanish: mascar el enfermo lo que no puede tragar, o el sanolo que estaŸ ... duro (C)

cuahcuacuahtiman(i).English: for things to be scraping against each other
cuahcuacuahtiman(i).Spanish: se estaŸn rascando los unos a los otros (C)
cuahcuacuahtiman(i).Comment: According to C this can refer to a dog biting atfleas, horses scratching each other, and the like.

cuahcuahu(i).English: to be a woodcutter, to cut, gather firewood

cuahcuauhti.Spanish: envararse o pararse yerto (M), se cansa (T)
cuahcuauhti.Comment: For the gloss M refers from quaquauhti toquaquappitzaui but the latter does not occur in M,and the gloss is to be found with unreduplicatedquappitzaui.

cuahcuauhtic.Spanish: personas ya adultas, altas o largas (M for plural),grande, fuerte, adulto (S)

cuahnāmiqu(i).English: to oppose, contradict, attack, resist s.o., to meets.o. head on
cuahnāmiqu(i).Spanish: le opone, le contradice, le afrente, le ataca, leasalta, lo resiste (T), unirse, hablando de dosextremos (S)

cuāhuīhuīca.English: to nod, to shake one's head

cuahuinenetzin.English: a type of insect, possibly the walking stick (Aplopusmayeri)
cuahuinenetzin.Comment: This appears to have CUAHU(I)-TL "wood" and NENE-TL"image" as constituent elements.

cuāhuītequ(i).English: to strike one's head; to beat s.o. on the head
cuāhuītequ(i).Spanish: se pega en la cabeza (T), le pega en la cabeza (T)
cuāhuītequ(i).Comment: M combines this in a single entry withCUAUHHUĪTEQU(I) "to strike s.t. with a stick, towork land with a hoe, stick".

cuāihuintic.Comment: Z lacks the final -C, although it is present in Z'sĪXHUINTIC.  Z consistently has the vowel of HUINmarked long although it is consistently shortelsewhere.

cuāilpiā.English: to receive confirmation (in the church); to bindone's head; to bind s.o.'s head
cuāilpiā.Spanish: atarse la frente, ... recibir la confirmacioŸn (S),se confirma (en la iglesia); se amarra la cabeza (T),le amarra la cabeza (T)

cuā(i)-tl.Spanish: extremidad de algo, o la cabeza ... lo alto de ellacomo es la superficie del casco, veŸrtice (M)
cuā(i)-tl.Comment: In the derived form CUAHNĀMIQU(I), this has thealternate stem form CUAH-, making it analogous toMĀ(I)-TL = MAH.

cuāītztiliā.English: for one's head to get chilled

cuāīxhuintiā.Comment: Z consistently marks the vowel of -HUIN- long, butelsewhere it is short.

cuāiztay(a).English: for one's hair to be turning gray
cuāiztay(a).Spanish: encanecer o tornarse cana de la cabeza (M)

cualāncānahuatiā.English: to give an order to s.o. angrily

cualān(i).Spanish: enojarme (M for first pers. sg. subject)

cualānqui.Comment: This follows from CUALĀN(I) but is attested in thesources for this dictionary only as the first elementin CUALĀNCĀNAHUATIĀ and CUALĀNCĀQUIQUINACA.In the form CUALĀNCĀ- it is the first element inseveral more verbs in M.

cualāntiā.English: for s.o. to get angry, peevish; to anger, irritates.o.
cualāntiā.Spanish: enojar a otro (M), se enoja (T), le hace enojar, lecausa molestia, lo enoja, lo ofende, le provoca (T)

cualcān.English: a good place or proper time
cualcān.Spanish: lugar abrigado y decente, o buen tiempo, o a buentiempo y sazoŸn (M)

cualitta.Spanish: parecerme bien, o agradarme alguna persona (M forfirst pers. sg. subject), le gusta, le agrada, leparece, le tiene carin9o (T)

cual-li.Comment: In the modern Nahuatl of Morelos and Tlaxcala theSpanish phrase estaŸ bien has been translated asCUAL-LI CAH, and this has been lexicalized so thatthe stress may fall on -LI.

cualnēc(i).Comment: In M this is given only as a substantive qualneci"s.t. fine-looking, beautiful".

-cualnēzcā.Spanish: tu buen parecer, tu hermosura (C for second personsingular possessor)

cualnēzcāyō-tl.Spanish: belleza, gracia, elegancia (S), tu buen parecer, tuhermosura (C for possessed form)

cualō.Comment: The expected form would be CUĀLŌ.

cuālōhua.English: for an eclipse to take place
cuālōhua.Comment: This appears to be derived from the nonactive form ofCUĀ "to eat s.t."  In two related derived forms Thas CUALO with short vowels in place of CUĀLŌ.

cualomētz-tli.Comment: T also has MĒTZCUALO with the same sense.  If thisis derived from the nonactive stem of CUĀ "to eats.t.", the vowel of the second syllable correspondsto a long vowel in the verb form, but this vowelshortens word-finally, and the compound may be basedon the short form.

cualquetz(a).Spanish: lo estima, lo recomienda, lo alaba, lo afama (Z)

cualtiy(a).Spanish: restaurarse y hacerse bueno lo que estaba dan9ado (M)

cualtzin.Spanish: bonito, hermoso, fino, lindo, puro, precioso (Z)

cuāman(a).English: to lie to s.o., to deceive s.o.

cuāmātl(a)-tl.Spanish: albanega o cofia de red (M), gorro (T)

cuāmelāhu(a).English: to straighten, raise the head; to brush s.o.'s hair
cuāmelāhu(a).Spanish: se endereza la cabeza; le endereza la cabeza (T), locepilla (Z)

cuāmomotzoā.English: to depilate s.o., to pluck the hairs from s.o.'s head
cuāmomotzoā.Spanish: mesar a otro (M), arrancar los cabellos a alguien (S)

cuāmōtla.English: to throw s.t. at s.o.'s head

cuānaca.Comment: With the absolutive suffix, CUĀNACA-TL refersliterally to the comb of a chicken.  Theabsolutiveless form refers to the animal itself.  Rhas final glottal stop.

cuānacayō-tl.Spanish: la carne del casco de la cabeza (M), su cresta (Z forpossessed form, referring to chicken's comb)

cuanhuācqui.Spanish: deŸbil, debilitado, enclenque, delgado (S), delgado,flaco, (animal u hombre) (T)
cuanhuācqui.Comment: T has lost the internal N.

cuanhuāqu(i).Spanish: estar deŸbil, enclenque, delgado, seco (M), seadelgaza, se enflaquece (T)
cuanhuāqu(i).Comment: T has lost the internal N.  M has CUANHUĀQU(I), theassociated noun CUANHUĀCQUI, and also CUANHUĀTZ(A)"to make s.o. get thin, weak", but only in theSpanish-to-Nahuatl side, associated with theverb enflaquecer.  They aresynonymous with HUĀQU(I), HUĀCQUI, and HUĀTZ(A)respectively.

cuāpatlachoā.English: for one's head to get crushed; to crush s.o.'s head
cuāpatlachoā.Spanish: se aplasta la cabeza (T), le aplasta la cabeza (T)

cuāpetzoā.English: to cut the hair very short, to shave the scalp
cuāpetzoā.Spanish: se corta el pelo muy corto, se alisa el pelo (T), lecorta el pelo muy corto, le alisa el cabello (T)

cuāpihpī.English: to cut one's hair; to cut s.o.'s hair
cuāpihpī.Spanish: se corta el pelo (T), le corta el pelo (T)

cuāpīloā.English: to taper s.t. to a point by twisting and drawing itout
cuāpīloā.Spanish: le adelgazo la punta, torcieŸndole (C for firstpers. sg. subject)

cuāpintic.English: s.t. pointed or drawn out at the ends

cuāpīpinoā.English: to draw s.t. out into a point, to taper s.t.

cuātenextic.Comment: In one of the attestations Z mistakenly marks thevowel of the second syllable long.

cuātenex-tli.English: dandruff, crust, scabs on the scalp

cuātepēhu(i).Spanish: es calvo, se le cae el cabello (T)

cuātepoltic.English: s.t. abbreviated at the top, lacking its top
cuātepoltic.Spanish: sin sombrero, aŸrbol sin follage, cosa que no tienepunta (T)

cuātlapān(a).English: for one's head to break, be crushed; to smash, crushs.o.'s head
cuātlapān(a).Spanish: quebrarse o quebrantarse la cabeza (M), quebrantar aotro la cabeza (M)

cuātlapech-tli.Comment: In one of the two attestations Z mistakenly marks thevowel of PECH long.

cuātlapolōliz-tli.Comment: The second element is a shortened form ofTLAPOLŌLTILIZ-TLI.

-cuātlayōlloh.English: the crown of one's head, the top of a tree
-cuātlayōlloh.Spanish: su coronilla; la punta de su cabeza, la punta delaŸrbol (T)

cuātōhuitztic.Comment: M has the synonymous reflexive verbs tohuitzoa andtonhuitzoa "to rise, to lift oneself up".

cuātzetzeloā.Spanish: sacude la cabeza (T), lo menea (la cabeza) (Z)

cuātzonāhuiā.Spanish: se lava la cabeza con agua (T)

cuātzon-tli.English: head hair (as contrasted with body hair)
cuātzon-tli.Spanish: cabellos, o pelos de la cabeza (M)
cuātzon-tli.Comment: This is attested as an element of the constructionCUĀTZONĀHUIĀ.

cuauhāyacach-tli.Comment: Z also has ĀYACACHCUAHU(I)-TL with the same meaning.In one attestation Z incorrectly marks the vowel ofCUAUH long.

cuauhayoh-tli.English: a type of squash used in making mole

cuauhcal-li.Spanish: jaula grande de palo, a donde estaban los presos porsus delitos (M)

cuauhcalpixqui.Spanish: los que le guardaban (C for plural)

cuauhcamac.Spanish: lugar de aŸrboles, arboledo, bosque, selva (T)
cuauhcamac.Comment: M has quauhcamac with the sense of "fissure orknothole in wood".

cuauhcamoh-tli.English: cassava, a woody root used in making tapioca andcassava flour (manioc)

cuauhcuēch-tli.Spanish: basura de palos, que trae la creciente, viruta,aserriŸn (T)

cuauhhuauhcal-li.Comment: Z has characteristic CUO for CUAUH.  M hasquauacalli and quauhacalli, both meaning ameasure for grain, and also quauacal referring to aperson with a narrow head.  These are probablyCUAUHĀCAL-LI and CUĀHUACAL respectively, and notsynonymous with this item.  A more common synonymousform is CUAUHCAL-LI.

cuauhhuexō-tl.English: tree which produces pods of seeds in an edible pulp(Inga jinicuil)

cuauhhuiā.English: to hit s.o., s.t. with a stick
cuauhhuiā.Spanish: le pega con palo, le da una paliza (T)

cuauhhuītequ(i).English: to beat s.t., s.o. with a stick; to break largeclumps of earth into small clumps by beating with ahoe, stick
cuauhhuītequ(i).Spanish: dar de palos a otro, o herirle en la cabeza con palo,o desboronar terrones con azadoŸn o con palo (M)
cuauhhuītequ(i).Comment: This is attested in its constituent parts in thesources for this dictionary.  M combines the sensesof this and of CUĀHUĪTEQU(I) in the first part ofthe gloss reproduced here.

cuauhhuīztic.Comment: The second element is probably HUITZ "thorn" inspite of the Z for TZ and the discrepancy in vowellength.

cuauhmāpan.Comment: This is based on a compound of CUAHU(I)-TL "tree" andMĀ(I)-TL "hand" referring to the outspread branchesof the crown of the tree.  MĀ(I)-TL by itself isused to mean "branch" as well as "hand".

cuauhmāyahuīllah.English: place where trees have been felled

cuauhmeca-tl.English: Mexican creeper (Antigonon leptopus), hairbrush vine(Combretum farinosum), sarsaparilla;vine or ivy in general

cuauhmōchi-tl.Comment: This is only attested in compounds; the absolutivesuffix is attested in the work on Mexican naturalhistory by Francisco HernaŸndez.  T has CUE for CUAUH.

cuauhneloā.English: for s.t. to be stirred; to stir s.t. (with a stick)

cuauhnenecuil-li.English: tree which produces pods of seeds in an edible pulp(Inga jinicuil)
cuauhnenecuil-li.Comment: M has the reflexive verb nenecuiloa "to staggeraround".

cuauhnepantlah.English: in the middle of the forest
cuauhnepantlah.Spanish: en el medio de los aŸrboles de bosque (C)

cuauhpach-tli.Spanish: moho, musgo, paxtle (Z), paxtle de aŸrboles (Z)

cuauhpampiloā.English: to hang s.t. in a tree

cuauhpilcaticah.English: to be hanging from a tree
cuauhpilcaticah.Lexical Reference: see CUAHU(I)-TL, PILCA, the verb CĀ

cuauhpitzāhu(i).English: to get hard, tough; to get thin
cuauhpitzāhu(i).Spanish: envararse o pararse yerto (M), endurece (tortilla, carne),se adelgaza, se enflaquece (T)
cuauhpitzāhu(i).Comment: In this compound T has a short vowel in the thirdsyllable coresponding to the long vowel of the freeform.  M also has a variant of this in which thesequence UHP assimilates to PP.

cuauhpitzoā.English: for s.o. to become stiff, to become stiff, tobe steadfast; to stiffen s.o.'s resolve, to gives.o. courage
cuauhpitzoā.Spanish: pararse yerto como palo (M), le da valor (parahacer o no hacer una cosa (T)
cuauhpitzoā.Comment: The sequence UHP can assimilate to PP, as itdoes in M.

cuauhpitztic.English: s.o. or s.t. thin, tough, stiff
cuauhpitztic.Spanish: delgado (animal u hombre), duro, macizo, tieso,paraliŸtico (T)

cuauhquequēx.Comment: Despite the discrepancy in vowel length, the secondelement appears to be related to QUEQUEXQUIYA "tohave an itch", possibly "to scratch" or "tobe eaten away".

cuauhtema.Grammar: Z has this as both transitive and intransitive.
cuauhtema.English: to beat s.o. with a stick
cuauhtema.Spanish: le pega (Z), le da una paliza, le aporrea (con palo)(Z)
cuauhtema.Comment: M has quauhtema "to roof a house with wood; toboard, plank, floor a house", which is clearlyderived from TĒM(A) "to fill up", while none of theZ attestations have the vowel of TE long.  The verbTEM(A) "to take a sweat bath" has a short vowel andrefers to an activity involving beating oneself withleafy branches.  Since Z never drops the stem vowelin verbs of this type, it cannot be determinedwhether the preterit of this would be -TEN, as in thecase of TEM(A).

cuauhtēn-tli.English: edge of the woods, stump or trunk of a tree
cuauhtēn-tli.Spanish: halda o orilla de monte (M), tronco (Z)

cuauhtepehxihuiā.English: to fall from a tree; to throw s.t. or s.o. down from atree
cuauhtepehxihuiā.Spanish: se derrumba del aŸrbol (T), lo derrumba del aŸrbol(T)

cuauhtētequ(i).English: to trim the branches off a tree

cuauhtic.English: s.o. tall, s.t. long or s.o. tired and stiff
cuauhtic.Spanish: hombre alto de cuerpo, o de gran estatura (M), cosalarga como palo o aŸrbol (C), cansado (Z)
cuauhtic.Comment: Height and stiffness are both attributes of trees,hence the distinct senses of this.

cuauhtitlan.Spanish: nombre de otro pueblo, y significa junto al aŸrbol oarboleda (C)

cuauhtlāca-tl.Comment: C contrasts this with CUAUHTLAHCA-TL "highlander,mountain dweller, savage".

cuauhtlahca-tl.Comment: C contrasts this with CUAUHTLĀCA-TL "man of wood".

cuauhtlahocuil-in.English: wild animal (as contrasted with a domestic animal)

cuauhtlahquit-tli.Comment: In one of the attestations the reflex of the glottalstop is printed as g.

cuāuhtlān.Comment: Although T loses word-final -N, the remaining reflexof the long vowel in -TLĀN aids in distinguishingthis from CUAUHTLAH.  T gives variants with a shortvowel and a long vowel in the initial syllable buttreats the long-vowel variant as basic, taking thisto be derived from CUĀUH-TLI "eagle", notCUAHU(I)-TL "tree".

cuauhtlapan-tli.Spanish: arbolado, casa en el campo hecha de ramitas delaŸrbol, enramada, tapanco (T)

cuauhtlehcō.English: to climb up in a tree
cuauhtlehcō.Spanish: gatear, trepar, subir por el aŸrbol (M)

cuauhtōc-tli.English: stake, forked stick set in the ground
cuauhtōc-tli.Spanish: aŸrbol o estaca para plantar (M), horcoŸn, horqueta(T)
cuauhtōc-tli.Comment: In one attestation Z fails to mark the vowel of thesecond syllable long.

cuauhtōpīl-li.Spanish: cruz floreada (que usan en el casamiento) (T)

cuauhtōtol-in.English: crested guan, a bird somewhat pheasant-like inappearance (Penelope purpurascens)

cuauhtzālan-tli.Comment: M has quauhtzalan as a locative "among trees".

cuauhtzapo-tl.English: annona, a plant that produces a fruit with sweet pulpand black seeds (Annona glabra)

cuauhtzīca-tl.English: type of ant that lives in trees
cuauhtzīca-tl.Spanish: hormiga (las que habitan en el aŸrbol) (T)

cuauhtzic-tli.Spanish: injerto del aŸrbol, goma del aŸrbol (T)

cuauhtzictōtō-tl.English: a type of oriole that eats sap
cuauhtzictōtō-tl.Spanish: calandria (paŸjaro que come goma de los aŸrboles),avispero (T)

cuauhtzontecopīn(a).English: to uproot trunks of trees, to pull out stumps

cuauhtzonte-tl.English: trunk or stump of a tree, a piece of a timber or a beam
cuauhtzonte-tl.Spanish: tronco de aŸrbol o de madera (M), pedazo de palo o deviga (T)

cuauhxāyac(a)-tl.English: a type of wasp, hornet that builds a large nest
cuauhxāyac(a)-tl.Spanish: avispa de campo (en los aŸrboles), mascaroŸn (panalgrande) (T)

cuauhxihu(i)-tl.English: fronds, branches of trees; a type of palm tree

cuauhxīlō-tl.English: tropical tree and its edible fruit (Parmentieraedulis)

cuauhxīm(a).English: to do carpentry, to work wood

cuauhxīnqui.English: carpenter, sawyer, s.o. who saws wood

cuauhyoh.Comment: There is inconsistency across attestations; in twothe vowel of -YOH is mistakenly marked long.

cuauhzāhuacamac.English: place where there are many casaguate trees

cuauhzāhua-tl.English: casaguate, a tree popularly believed to be poisonousto people and animals (Ipomoea murucoides, Ipomoeaarborescens)
cuauhzāhua-tl.Comment: This may ultimately be derived from CUAHU(I)-TL"tree" and ZAHUA-TL "pox, rash, disease", despite thedescrepancy in vowel length.  T has lost the finallabial consonant of the first syllable.

cuauhzāhuatlah.English: place where there are many casaguate trees

cuāxahxamāniliā.English: to shatter s.o.'s head to pieces
cuāxahxamāniliā.Spanish: se la hizo pedazos (la cabeza) (C for past tense)

cuāxamāniā.English: for one's head to break; to break s.o.'s head
cuāxamāniā.Spanish: quebrantarse o quebrarse la cabeza (M), quebrantar lacabeza a otro (M)
cuāxamāniā.Comment: This is indirectly attested in CUĀXAMĀNILIĀ.

cuāxamāniliā.Spanish: le quebroŸ la cabeza (C for past tense)

cuāxaxamatz(a).Spanish: desmenuzoŸ la cabeza (C for past tense)

cuaxeloā.English: for animals and the like to scatter, separate; toscatter trash, manure, corn, etc.
cuaxeloā.Spanish: se riegan, se desperdigan (animal, etc.) (T), loriega (basura, abono, maiŸz, etc.), lo desperdiga, loalborota, lo frota (T)
cuaxeloā.Comment: This contrasts with CUĀXELOĀ in the same source,but what the first element is, if not CUĀ(I)-TL, isnot clear.  It would appear to be the same asthe first element in CUACEMMAN(A).

cuāxeloā.English: to spill out (as from of an overflowing sack); to pour theexcess of s.t. out
cuāxeloā.Spanish: se quita (p.ej. de un costal que tiene demasiado,etc.) (T), lo quita, lo riega, lo saca (lo que sobradel maiŸz, etc., del bote, costal, etc.) (T)
cuāxeloā.Comment: This is abundantly attested and within T contrastswith CUAXELOĀ "to scatter s.t."

cuāxēpohhuiā.English: to lie to s.o., to deceive s.o.
cuāxēpohhuiā.Comment: This opaque construction may incorporate the Spanishword sebo "tallow" and have some literal sense ofdripping candle-wax on s.o.'s head.

cuāxīcal-li.Spanish: casco de la cabeza, o calavera (M)

cuāyecachoā.Comment: The second element here may be derived from YAC(A)-TL"nose, ridge, summit" or may conceivably be areduction of ĀYACACHOĀ "to play the rattle",namely, for one's head to bob up and down likea rattle.

cuāyetic.English: s.o. with his head hanging, drooping, a treedrooping with heavy fruit, or a wilted plant
cuāyetic.Spanish: se cuelga (la cabeza o la punta) (por tener muchafruta, o por estar marchitada) (T)

cuāyōlcueptoc.Comment: This appears just once in Z and seems to be a variantof CUĀYŌLQUEPTOC, with more standard CUEP(A) forZ's characteristic QUEP(A).

cuāyōlloh-tli.English: the crown of one's head, the crown of atree, treetop
cuāyōlloh-tli.Spanish: la coronilla, o el medio de la cabeza (M), sucoronilla, la punta del aŸrbol (T)
cuāyōlloh-tli.Comment: The attestation is a locative derivation that seemsto be built on YŌLLŌ-TL rather than YŌLLOH-TLI, asin M.

cuechāhu(a).Comment: This is indirectly attested in CUECHĀHUAC,CUECHĀHUALIZ-TLI, and CUECHĀHUALLŌ-TL

cuechāhu(i).English: to get moist, damp, wet through

cuechaquiā.English: to twist, sprain a body part
cuechaquiā.Spanish: se tuerce (mano, pie, etc.) (T), le lastima el pie(al otro) (T for (I)CXICUECHAQUIĀ)
cuechaquiā.Comment: This is abundantly attested, but only in T.

cuēchoā.English: to get ground up, ground to powder; to grind s.t.fine
cuēchoā.Spanish: se muele (T), hen9ir la masa, o moler mucho algunacosa (M)

*cuēch-tli.Comment: This is the second element of CALCUĒCH-TLI "soot"and CUAUHCUĒCH-TLI "sawdust" and apparently means"residue".  It contrasts in meaning and possibly inphonological form with M's cuechtli which refers toa type of snail or spiral shell.

cuēc-tli.Comment: Although this is suggestive of CUETLĀCH-TLI "wolf",there is a vowel-length discrepancy.

cuēcuēlihu(i).Spanish: entortarse o torcerse (M for unreduplicated form), setuerce, es flexible (T)
cuēcuēlihu(i).Comment: M has this in unreduplicated form only, with the samesense as T.  This intransitive verb is synonymouswith the reflexive verb CUĒCUĒLOĀ.

cuēcuēloā.Comment: M has cuecuel as an element in compounds having todo with twisting.

cuēcuep(a).Comment: This contrasts in T with CUĒCUĒP(A) "to turn s.t.over repeatedly".

cuēcuēp(a).English: to turn s.t. over repeatedly, to plow land
cuēcuēp(a).Spanish: volver muchas veces alguna cosa lo de arriba abajo, oprobar y experimentar alguna cosa, o ser vario en loque dice (M), lo barbecha (prepara terreno para lasiembra) (T)
cuēcuēp(a).Comment: In sense this appears to be the reduplicated form ofCUEP(A) "to turn", in which the vowel of the secondsyllable should be short.  In T this contrasts withCUĒCUEP(A) "to be disturbed, upset".

cuecuepoca.English: for many flowers to bloom at once, to break out in arash
cuecuepoca.Spanish: brotar las flores o cosa semejante, o sarpullirse(M), brotar muchas flores juntas (C)

cuecuepotz(a).English: to cause many flowers to bloom at once
cuecuepotz(a).Spanish: hacer que brotan las flores, etc. (C)

cuecuetlaca.English: for a fire to make a loud noise; to shake, tremble
cuecuetlaca.Spanish: hacer mucho ruido la llama (M), estremece, tiembla(T)

cuecuetlatz(a).English: to shake s.t., make s.t. tremble; to brandish aspear
cuecuetlatz(a).Spanish: lo estremece (T), blandear lanza o cosa asiŸ (M)

cuēcuetlaxtic.Comment: In the Spanish-to-Nahuatl side, T has the reflex ofCUĒCUETLAXTIC, while the Nahuatl-to-Spanish side hasa variant form with I for E in the first twosyllables.  Z does not mark the vowel of the firstsyllable long.

cuehchahuiā.English: to go over s.t. without stepping on it
cuehchahuiā.Spanish: pasa sobre eŸl sin que pisa (T)
cuehchahuiā.Comment: This has the same gloss as CUEHCHOLHUIĀ.

cuehcholhuiā.English: to go over s.t. without stepping on it
cuehcholhuiā.Spanish: pasa sobre una cosa sin pisar en ella (T)
cuehcholhuiā.Comment: M has cuecxolhuia, cueacxolhuia, andcuencholhuia all with the sense of jumping over aditch or something of the sort.

cuehcihu(i).Comment: T has lost the internal glottal stop.

cuehciuhqui.Comment: In the B attestation the sense seems to be"disobediant".

cuehcuelpachtic.Comment: M has cuecuelpachoa "to double over or fold s.t.repeatedly"

cuehmolīhuic.Comment: Both attestations mark the vowel of the thirdsyllable long.  This implies intransitiveCUEHMOLIHU(I) corresponding to transitive CUEHMOLOĀ,but the I should be short.

cuehmolīuhtoc.Comment: All attestations mark the vowel of the third syllablelong.  This implies intransitive CUEHMOLIHU(I)corresponding to transitive CUEHMOLOĀ, but the Ishould be short.

cuehmoloā.English: to become disturbed, worried, upset; to bother,upset, disturb s.o.
cuehmoloā.Spanish: se preocupa, se turba, se trastorna (Z), lo molesta,lo alborota, lo trastorna, lo distrae (Z)
cuehmoloā.Comment: This is abundantly attested, but only in Z.

cuehzoā.English: to be disturbed, bothered; to disturb, bother s.o.

cuē(i)-tl.Spanish: faya, faldelliŸn, faldillas, o naguas (M), falda,chincuete, vestido (T)
cuē(i)-tl.Comment: Since despite a vowel length discrepancy -CUEXĀNCO"lap" is clearly related, it is possible that thisshould be CUĒY(I)-TL, with the Y appearing as X inthe derivation.

cuēlihu(i).Comment: This is attested in the sources for this dictionaryonly in the reduplicated form CUĒCUĒLIHU(I).

cuēloā.Comment: CUĒLOĀ and CUELPACHOĀ appear to be synonymous inspite of the vowel length discrepancy attested in T.

cuelpachihu(i).Comment: This intransitive verb is synonymous with the verbCUELPACHOĀ used reflexively.

cuelpachoā.English: to bend, fold over; to bend s.t., to fold s.t. over
cuelpachoā.Spanish: se dobla (T), doblar o plegar mantas o cosa semejante(M)

cuem(i)-tl.English: field, cultivated land; furrow, soil turned up with ahoe or plow
cuem(i)-tl.Spanish: heredad, tierra labrada, o camelloŸn (M), surco (T)

cuemōchi-tl.Comment: This is a variant of CUAUHMŌCHI-TL.

cuemōn(i).English: for a fire to flame, blaze up; to have a fever
cuemōn(i).Spanish: flameŸa mucho, arde mucho (la flama), tiene el cuerpocalenturiento (T)

cuentlāliā.English: to become furrowed; to plow, turn up furrows

cuep(a).English: to turn, to turn back, to turn into something, tobecome s.t.; to turn s.t., to return s.t.
cuep(a).Spanish: volverme de donde iba, o volverme de lado, o de laotra parte (M for first pers. sg. subject), volver aotro del camino (M), volver algo, o dar razon de siŸ,o excusarse (M)
cuep(a).Comment: In T the stem of this verb has the form CUEC- beforeTZ and TL; MO-CUEC-TZINOĀ, TLACUEC-TLI.  Z has avariant form QUEP(A).

cuepiliā.English: to vomit; to return s.t. to s.o., to restore s.o.else's property
cuepiliā.Spanish: vomita, lo devuelve (T), vengarse o restituir loajeno (M)

cuepōncāyō-tl.Spanish: abrimiento de flor, o el acto de brotar la dicha flor(M), el abrirse de las flores (C)

cuepōn(i).English: to shine, glow; for flowers to burst into bloom; fors.t. to burst, explode
cuepōn(i).Spanish: dar estallido el huevo o la castan9a cuando la asan,o abrirse y abrotar la flor o la rosa, o resplandeceralguna cosa (M)
cuepōn(i).Comment: Nahuatl also has XŌTLA, which associates bloomingwith bursting into flame.

cuepōniā.English: to cause s.t. to make a thundering sound
cuepōniā.Comment: This is abundantly attested, but only in T.

cuētiā.English: to get dressed, to put on a skirt
cuētiā.Spanish: se viste, se pone el chincuete (T)
cuētiā.Comment: S gives a different gloss for this "to be a person ofrank", but derives it from CUĒ(I)-TL nonetheless.  Zhas the variant CUĒITIĀ

cuetlāch-tli.Comment: C fails to mark the vowel of the first syllable longin the reduplicated plural form.  This also appearsin P, but the long vowel is not marked there either.

cuetlahu(i).Spanish: mustiarse, ajarse, debilitarse, decaer (S), marchita... se desmaya ... se debilita (Z)

cuetlahuiy(a).Comment: This is indirectly attested in CUETLAHU(I).

cuetlān(i).English: to abate; to flicker, to tremble
cuetlān(i).Spanish: mitigarse, o aflojarse la enfermedad, o amansarse elviento recio, o arder el fuego echando de siŸ granllama (M), se mueve, tiembla (T)

cuetlāniā.English: for s.t. to collapse; to break s.t. up, disjoint,dislocate s.t.
cuetlāniā.Spanish: se cae (de debilidad, etc.) (T), quebrar palos, ocosas largas (M), lo disloca (Z)

cuetlaxcōl-li.Comment: Z also has CUITLAXCOL-LI "intestines", shared with T.The two items differ in the vowel length of the thirdsyllable.  The variation CUETLAX-TLI = CUITLAX-TLI iscommon across Nahuatl dialects.

cuetlaxhuiā.English: to cover or bind s.t. with cured leather
cuetlaxhuiā.Spanish: encorar algo con cuero adobado (M), lo pega con cuero(Z)
cuetlaxhuiā.Comment: The Z attestations are in intransitive form withoutan object suffix

cuetlaxoā.English: to be weak, faint, swooning; to cause s.o. to beweak, faint, swooning
cuetlaxoā.Spanish: desmayarse, o amortecerse de tristeza (M), desmayarsea otro (M)

cuetlaxtic.Spanish: suelta (que no tiene fuerza) (T referring to acrippled hand)

cuetlax-tli.Comment: T has I for E in the initial syllable, which is acommon variation for this item.

cuetzpal-in.Comment: S also gives the alternate absolutive formCUETZPAL-LI.  X has QUETZPAL-IN.  T also thealternates CUETZPAL-IN, HUETZPAL-IN, andHUĒHUETZPAL-IN and gives reduplicated plural formswith both long and short vowels in the initialsyllable.

-cuexānco.Spanish: su regazo (Z for third pers. sg. possessor)

cuexān-tli.Spanish: haldas para llevar en ellas algo (M)
cuexān-tli.Comment: This appears to be related to CUĒ(I)-TL "skirt", butthe vowel is not marked long in X and also is not somarked in Z's attestations of -CUEXĀNCO.  In B'sattestations of -CUEXĀNCO, the vowel is specificallymarked short.

cueya-tl.Comment: M also has the variant form cuiyatl.

cuēyeh.English: s.o. who possesses a skirt, woman
cuēyeh.Spanish: mujer que tiene o lleva faldas (S)

cueza.Comment: S has cuecuec˛o "to put together, baste, make aprovisional seam in s.t."  In spite of the similarityto coser, this does not have the characteristicstructure of a Spanish loanword in Nahuatl.

cuezcom(a)-tl.Spanish: troja o alfoliŸ de pan (M), cozcomate, troje, granero(T)

cui.Spanish: tomar algo, o tener parte el hombre con la mujer (M)
cui.Comment: For all sources, with the exception of T, this verbconsistently has a long stem vowel before theapplicative and causative suffixes, but the vowel isnever marked long before preterit -C.

cuīca.Spanish: cantar el cantor, o chirriar las aves (M)

cuīcatiā.English: to sing; to make music for others

cuīca-tl.Comment: This is conventionally paired with XŌCHI-TL"flower" to refer to poetry.

cuicuinaca.English: to make a low sound in the throat; for a person tohum or a dog to growl

cuīcuitlahuiltiā.Spanish: aconsejar, convencer, obligar a alguien, seducir,violar (S)

cuīcuītzca-tl.Comment: Z has the variant CUICUĪTZCĀNI, once with thevowels of the second and third syllable marked longand once with no vowels marked long.

cuihcui.English: to get ready, to be prepared; to take s.t. away, towork wood or stone by chipping off the surface, toclean up a surface
cuihcui.Spanish: se dispone ... se prepara (Z), lo trae (T), labropiedra o madera, como hace el escultor (C for firstpers. sg. subject), entallar en madera, o alimpiar elsuelo quitando lo que echan de la mesa (M)
cuihcui.Comment: With reference to sculpting and cleaning, theindefinite object prefix TLA- may be absorbed intothe stem.  M also gives cuicui with a gloss aboutcopulation, but there is no way to know if the formhas short vowel, long vowel, or vowel-plus-glottalstop reduplication.

cuihcuīliā.English: to hold out against entreaties or advances, to resist
cuihcuīliā.Spanish: hacerse de rogar, o negar el deŸbito la mujer, oresistir (M)
cuihcuīliā.Comment: This appears to be the applicative form of CUIHCUI,but the sense is not clearly derived in that way.

cuihcuiltic.Comment: Z marks the vowels of the first and second syllableslong in one attestation and those of the second andthird syllables long in the other, but none should belong.

cuīhua.Comment: For CUI, but not for compounded or reduplicated formswith CUI, T has the nonactive form CŌHUA, or becauseof potential ambiguity of the notation, possiblyCOHUA.

cuīliā.English: to take s.t. for oneself; to take s.t. for or froms.o.
cuīliā.Spanish: tomar algo para siŸ, sin que nadie se lo de (M),tomar algo a otro (M)
cuīliā.Comment: The applicative form of CUI consistently has a longvowel preceding the applicative suffix in all sourcesbut T, where the vowel is specifically marked short.

cuiltōnoā.English: to be wealthy and happy; to live happily and enjoys.t.; to enrich s.o.
cuiltōnoā.Spanish: abundar en hacienda o gozarse mucho (M), fruir ygozar de algo (M), enriquecer a otro (M)

cuinatz(a).English: to cause s.t. to creak, resound

cuitcōā-tl.Comment: The first element is a reduction of CUITL(A)-TL.  Zhas T for TL.  In other dialects the expected formwould be CUITLACŌĀ-TL.

cuitcotoltic.Comment: Z gives an abbreviated alternate form CUITCOLTIC.The first element is a reduction of CUITL(A)-TL.  Inother dialects, the expected form would beCUITLACOTOCTIC.

cuītiā.English: to acknowledgeone's failings, to be called s.t.; to name s.o.
cuītiā.Spanish: conocer o confesar a otro por sen9or, o conocer eldelito que cometioŸ (M), se llama, es llamado (T), lollama (T)
cuītiā.Comment: This is an element of two compounds; YŌLCUĪTIĀ"to make confession, to confess s.o." and ĪXCUĪTIĀ"to reproach, blame s.o."

cuitihuetz(i).English: to turn back or retreat quickly; to take s.t.quickly, to snatch s.t., to assault s.t.
cuitihuetz(i).Spanish: tornar, o volver sobre siŸ, o espantarse el trueno ode cosa semejante (M), tomar o arrebatar algo depriesa (M), apechugar o arremeter contra alguno (M)

cuitlachapān(i).English: for a pustule or boil to throb

cuitlacoch-in.English: an ear of maize infected with a fungus that turns thekernels dark gray and deforms them, edible andconsidered a delicacy
cuitlacoch-in.Spanish: mazorca de maiŸz degenerada y diferente de las otras(M)

cuitlacuahu(i)-tl.English: night jasmine, a tree with flowers that are fragrantby night (Cestrum nocturnum, Cestrum lanatum)

cuitlacuep(a).Comment: Z has this with QUEP(A) for CUEP(A).

cuitlahuiā.English: to invite oneself to a feast or gathering, to beresponsible for s.o., s.t.; to care for, raise s.o.;to fertilize the soil with manure
cuitlahuiā.Spanish: convidarse en convite (M), tener cuidado o cargo dealgo (M), tener cuidado de otros (M), estercolar latierra (M)
cuitlahuiā.Comment: Simple transitive CUITLAHUIĀ is derived fromCUITL(A)-TL "excrement" and -HUIĀ.  When this hasthe sense of "to care for s.o., s.t.", it is a doubleobject verb requiring both a transitive and areflexive prefix.

cuitlahuīltiā.English: to oblige s.o. to do s.t., to make s.o. responsiblefor s.t.
cuitlahuīltiā.Spanish: provocar o constren9ir a otro para que haga algo (M)

cuitlālōlō.Comment: In both attestations the vowels of all syllablesbeyond the first are marked long.

-cuitlapan.Spanish: a las espaldas (C), mi trasera, y tras de miŸ, a misespaldas (C for first pers. sg. possessor)

cuitlapanhuiā.English: to carry s.t. on one's back; to bring up the rear
cuitlapanhuiā.Spanish: se cargaba (C for imperfect reflexive), ser traserocaminando con otros, o en la virtud (M)

cuitlapantzotzon(a).English: for people to clap each other on the back whileembracing
cuitlapantzotzon(a).Spanish: se dan papachos (palmadas) en la espalda al abrazarse(T)

cuitlapanxīlō-tl.Spanish: su espina dorsal, su espinazo (T for third personpossessor)

cuitlapāyo-tl.Comment: M has payatl "a small woolly caterpillar", andelsewhere T has PĀYĀ-TL "moyote, flying beetle".The O here seems idiosyncratic.

cuitlapil-li.Spanish: cola o rabo de animal o de ave (M)
cuitlapil-li.Comment: This is frequently attested in B with the vowel ofthe last syllable specifically marked short, but alsotwice with the vowel marked long, both times beforethe plural suffix -HUĀN.  It is marked short in Tbut long in Z.  See the discussion under PIL-LI.

cuitlaquīz(a).Spanish: sale con fuerza, con rapidez (p.ej. agua) (T)

cuitl(a)-tl.Spanish: mierda (M), excremento, fiemo, inmundicia, residuo;llaga, tumor, absceso (S)
cuitl(a)-tl.Comment: By extension this has the sense of "back, rump,behind" in compounds.

cuitlatzīca-tl.English: a type of ant associated with excrement

cuitlaxcol-li.Comment: The second element seems related to CŌLOĀ "tocurve, twist" in spite of the vowel-lengthdiscrepancy.

cuitlaxihu(i).English: to get loose, to go weak
cuitlaxihu(i).Spanish: se suelta (el pie, la mano, etc.), se debilita (T)
cuitlaxihu(i).Comment: This is a variant of CUETLAXIHU(I), which is also inT.

cuitlaxōchi-tl.Comment: This is not directly attested in the sources for thisdictionary, but its component parts are.  The nameprobably refers to the growth of the plant on dungheaps.

cuitlāzca-tl.English: a type of ant associated with excrement
cuitlāzca-tl.Comment: In the Nahuatl-to-Spanish side this isidentified as "hormiga pepehua", but it is glossed as"hormiga de mierda" in the other side of thedictionary.

cuix.Grammar: introductory particle for questions which can beappropriately answered with "yes" or "no".
cuix.Comment: T and Z have the variant form COX.
