cuīx-in.Comment: X also has what appears to be the reflex ofCUAUHHUĪX-IN < CUAHU(I)-TL and HUĪX-IN and meaning"lizard".

ecahuīllah.English: a shadowed place, place in the shade

ecahuīl-li.Comment: This is abundantly attested in Z, where three of nineattestations mark the vowel of the second syllablelong, although it probably should be short.  On the otherhand, Z fails to mark the vowel of the third syllablelong, but it is long in T's synonymous TLAECAHUĪLLŌ-TL.internal glottal stop in the synonymous EHCAUHYŌ-TL,and there should probably be one here as well.

echīchīlē-tl.Comment: In one of the rare inconsistencies in T, the entry onthe Nahuatl-to-Spanish side has the vowels of thesecond and third syllables marked short, while theSpanish-to-Nahuatl side correctly has them long.

ecuetlax-tli.Comment: The Z attestation lacks an absolutive suffix.

-eh.Comment: Added to nouns this means "possessor of" the word inquestion.  It is only added to noun stems endingin consonants; for stems ending in vowels -HUAH isused instead.  -HUAH is also used with someconsonant stems, yielding pairs such asZĀYŌLEH = ZĀYŌLHUAH "one who has flies".

ehcamalacō-tl.Comment: The first element of this seems to have lost asyllable, and the final syllable has the reflex of Ōinstead of expected A.

ehcauhtiliā.Comment: It seems plausible to relate this in sense to theEHCAUHYŌ-TL, referring to shadows and light,insubstantial things.  It is opposite in sense fromETIY(A) "to be heavy".

ehēca.English: to blow lightly, for there to be a breeze, to bewindy
ehēca.Comment: A unreduplicated verb stem related to this is to beexpected, but none is attested.  This verb and therelated noun have identical stems.  R has a shortvowel and glottal stop in the second syllable inplace of a long vowel, EHEHCA.

ehēcacōā-tl.English: a type of venomous snake noted for its swiftness
ehēcacōā-tl.Spanish: cierto serpiente venenosa y muy ligera (R)
ehēcacōā-tl.Comment: There is disagreement about whether this is aconstrictor or a pit viper.  SahaguŸn and Clavijeroboth believe it is called a "wind serpent" because ofits swiftness, but it is also more directly associatedwith wind.  M has the phrase eecacoayo mixtli"storm cloud with whirlwind", and T hasEHQUETZALCŌĀ-TL, "whirlwind".

ehēcahuilō.English: a child possessed by evil spirits
ehēcahuilō.Spanish: nin9o que le cogen los malos espiŸritus (T)
ehēcahuilō.Comment: This is attested without an absolutive suffix andappears to be a substantive use of the nonactive formof a verb derived from EHĒCA-TL "evil spirit" and-HUIĀ.  If this is the case, the vowel of the fourthsyllable should be long.  Possibly this should beEHĒCAHUĪLLŌ-TL.

ehēcamōtla.English: to bewitch someone; to make spirits visible

ehēcapah-tli.Comment: Possibly this is wild senna (Casia laevigata), aplant used medicinally to relieve the symptoms ofsyphilis.  R has EH instead of Ē in the second syllable.

ehēca-tl.Spanish: viento, o aire (M), aire, viento; espiŸritu malo,malos aires (T)
ehēca-tl.Comment: B, C, and T agree in the glottal stop and vowellength pattern, although it is slightly obscured in Tby initial glide formation and the ambiguity in T ofYE and Ē.  Z does not mark the vowel of the secondsyllable long.  R has a short vowel and a glottalstop in the second syllable in place of a long vowel,EHEHCA-TL.  This is clearly related to IHĪYŌ-TL"breath", and some dialects of Nahuatl have A for E.Since intervocalic glottal stops only arise inNahuatl through reduplication of vowel-initial stems,this must be derived from *ĒCA-TL, but theunreduplicated form is unattested in the sources forthis dictionary.

ehēhuīta.English: to consider s.t. unimportant, to deprecate s.o.,s.t.
ehēhuīta.Spanish: no importa, lo achica, lo apoca, no le da importancia(Z)
ehēhuīta.Comment: In two of four attestations the vowel of the secondsyllable is marked long, and in three the vowel ofthe third is so marked.  Because Z lacks the lateralrelease of TL, it is ambiguous whether the lastsyllable is TA or TLA.

ehquetzalcōā-tl.Comment: This seems to have lost two syllables.  CompareEHCAMALACŌ-TL.

ēhua.English: to depart, to rise to go
ēhua.Comment: Intransitive ĒHUA and transitive ĒHU(A) aredistinguished in the preterit as ĒHUAC and ĒUHrespectively.

ēhu(a).English: to get up, to get out of bed; to raise s.o. or s.t.
ēhu(a).Spanish: levantarse de dormir, o de donde estaŸ echado (M),levantar al que estaŸ echado (M)
ēhu(a).Comment: Transitive ĒHU(A) and intransitive ĒHUA aredistinguished in the preterit as ĒUH and ĒHUACrespectively.

ēhuaticah.Comment: ĒHUA here and in some derived forms means "seated",which is just the opposite of its reflexive sense of"to get up".  X has ĒHUATOC with the same sense.

ēhua-tl.Spanish: cuero por curtir, o mondadura y caŸscara de fruta (M)
ēhua-tl.Comment: There is ambiguity in T between initial E and Ē.  Ofnine attestations in Z, four have the vowel of thefirst syllable marked long.

ēhuayō-tl.Spanish: pellejo, y caŸscara, o mondadura de fruta (M)

-ēhu(i).English: to turn out in a particular manner, to become
-ēhu(i).Comment: This is attested in T and Z.  It corresponds to theintransitive verb ĒHUA, which also appears incompounds.  Both correspond to transitive ĒHU(A).

-ēhuiltihticah.Comment: This takes the reflexive prefixes and serves as thehonorific of ĒHUATICAH.

ēhuitiquetz(a).English: to put s.t. to rights; to raise and straighten s.t. bentor out of place
ēhuitiquetz(a).Spanish: lo endereza, levanta una cosa que estaŸ doblada(nin9o dormido, vela, planta, etc. (T)

ēlcihcihu(i).Comment: Z has YŌLNEHCIHU(I) with the same sense.

ēlcīm(a).Spanish: atravesaŸrseme el bocado en los gaznates (M)

ēlcīmiā.Comment: This is a variant of ĒLCĪM(A).  X has TZ for C.

ēlēhuiā.Spanish: desear o codiciar algo (M), codiciar a alguna persona(M)
ēlēhuiā.Comment: This is attested three times in C with a long vowelin the initial syllable.  Elsewhere in C and withoutexception in B the vowel is not marked long.  In Tand Z there is short E.  T has an intensifier meaning"great, very" which may be derived from this.  Itwould correspond to a canonical form LALEHUIZ, butsince Nahuatl morpheme structure excludes initial L,the one in this item must result from vowel loss orbe excrescent.

ēlēhuīlōni.Spanish: cosa deseable (M), persona o cosa deseable (C)

ēlhuēhuetzca.English: to laugh with the mouth closed
ēlhuēhuetzca.Spanish: se riŸe con la boca cerrada (T)
ēlhuēhuetzca.Comment: The T form is ambiguous between EL and ĒL, but thesense seems to call for ĒL with its broad referenceto internal organs and strong emotion.

-ēllelahci.Grammar: verb that takes possessive rather than subjectprefixes
-ēllelahci.Spanish: recibir o tener mucha pena y afliccioŸn (M)
-ēllelahci.Comment: The first element of this is apparently anincorporated noun which is necessarily possessed withthe possessive prefix expressing the person andnumber of the subject; "he suffers" is expressed asĪĒLLELAHCI.

ēllelquīxtiā.English: to relax, to enjoy oneself; to entertain s.o., makes.o. relax

ēllelquīz(a).English: to relax and enjoy oneself; to suffer
ēllelquīz(a).Spanish: recrearse, espaciarse o desenfadarse, y recibir otener gran afliccioŸn (M)
ēllelquīz(a).Comment: This verb has two completely contradictory senses,although both involve feelings manifesting themselvesor being drawn forth.

ēl-li.Comment: In compounds this has a broader sense of "internalorgans" and is also associated with emotions,especially strong or unpleasant ones.

ēlmīmiquini.Comment: M has elmimicqui with the same sense.

ēlōtic.English: s.t. the color of fresh young maize

ēlō-tl.English: ear of fresh young maize with the kernels alreadyformed, corn on the cob
ēlō-tl.Spanish: mazorca de maiŸz verde, que tiene ya cuajados losgranos (M)
ēlō-tl.Comment: The first vowel is long in Z and ambiguous in T.There are no attestations in B or C.  ĒLŌ-TLcontrasts with XĪLŌ-TL, which is the still-soft,semi-formed green ear.

ēlōtzon-tli.Comment: This contrasts with ĒLTZON-TLI "a turkey's chesttassel".

ēltlapech-tli.English: protector for a chest-strap or tumpline
ēltlapech-tli.Spanish: protector para la correa o mecapale (Z)

ēltlatlac(i).Spanish: tose a propoŸsito para que le vea el otro (T)

ēltzon-tli.English: the beard of a turkey, the tassel of hair-likefeathers that grow from a turkey's chest

emōl-li.Spanish: guisado de frijoles, o de habas (M)

epa-tl.Spanish: cierto animalejo que hiede mucho (M), zorrillo(T,Z,X)

ēpatzac-tli.Comment: This is apparently not derived from E-TL, as Sthought it to be.

epazō-tl.English: epazote, a type of seasoning herb (Chenopodiumambrosiodes)
epazō-tl.Spanish: yerba buena de estaŸ Nueva Espan9a (M)
epazō-tl.Comment: T has absolutive -TLI, implying a variant with astem-final glottal stop.

ēquimi-tl.Comment: In one of two attestations Z marks the vowel of thefirst syllable long, but since the tree produces podsof bean-shaped seeds, the first element isundoubtedly E-TL.

etiy(a).Comment: Like other verbs in IY(A), this probably hasalternate preterit forms with long and short vowels.

e-tl.Comment: The common variant YE-TL is caused by regular glideformation affecting word-initial E in certaindialects, of which T and X are two.

etlah.Spanish: heredad de frijoles, o habas (M), frijolar (Z)

eucxoā.Comment: X lacks the labiality of the final consonant of theinitial syllable.

ēuhtēhua.Spanish: partirse con aceleramiento y corriendo para algunaparte (M), sale ... se va (Z)
ēuhtēhua.Comment: This consists of two instances of the verb ĒHUAjoined by the -TI- ligature.  Such constructions arenot incongruous in Nahuatl.

ēxcāmpa.Spanish: de tres, o a tres partes (C)
ēxcāmpa.Comment: This also has a variant form YĒXCĀMPA.

ēxcān.Comment: This also has a variant form YĒXCĀN.

-ēxcānixti.English: in all three parts of s.t.

exixitamal-li.Comment: In two of three attestations Z marks the vowel of thefirst syllable long.

exōyamān-tli.Comment: The literal sense of this is "soft green bean".

ēxpa.Comment: This single attested form does not have the firstvowel marked long, but ĒX "three" is attestedabundantly elsewhere.

exquiquil(i)-tl.Comment: This may be a back formation from Spanishexquite < ĪZQUI-TL "popcorn", often used todescribe plants with clusters of white flowers.This plant may be Colocasia mafaffa, one of agroup of plants from the roots of which an ediblestarch can be extracted.

ēy(i).Comment: A variant form is YĒY(I).  The internal Y revealsitself in forms like YĒXCĀN, where it undergoesspirantization, Y ˛ X.  In other compounds this hasthe form Ē- with no final consonant.

ezcuahu(i)-tl.English: medicinal plant, the bark of which produces a red dye(Jatropha spatulata)

ezhuiā.English: to bloody oneself; to bloody s.o., s.t.

ezpah-tli.English: medicinal plant, the bark of which produces a red dye(Jatropha spatulata)
ezpah-tli.Spanish: cierto arbusto medicinal, que destila por incisioŸnun licor como sangre (R)

ezquīz(a).Spanish: tener su costumbre la mujer (M), sale sangre, sangra,se desangra (T)

eztlatla.English: for a blood blister to form

ez-tli.Comment: The ZY sequence of the possessed form commonlyassimilates to ZZ.

ezzoh.Comment: In Z the ZY sequence fails to assimilate to ZZ.

-ezzohcāpohtzin.Comment: This is said of Christ in an affirmation that he isflesh of our flesh, blood of our blood.

huach-tli.Comment: This appears to be a variant form of ACH-TLI "seed".It is attested as a free form in X, and elsewhere itappears in AYOHHUACH-TLI and AIHHUACH-TLI, bothmeaning "squash seed".  X has E, marked long in oneset of attestations and not in the other, for A.

huāctzin.English: a large bird with a distinctive call known in Spanishas paŸjaro vaquero (Herpetotheres cochinans)
huāctzin.Spanish: cierta ave canora, grande como la gallina; estambieŸn nombre de otra ave de la misma magnitud,pero no canora (R) huaco (X)

huahhualtz(a).Comment: One of the attestations has a glottal stop at the endof the first syllable, and the other does not.  Thiswould appear to be a mistake in diacritics, with thesimple short vowel reduplication being the intendedone.  There is a related verb HUAHHUANOĀ, however,which is attested in T with a glottal stop.

huahuan(a).English: to scratch, scrape s.t., to incise lines on s.t.
huahuan(a).Spanish: escarbar o hacer rayas en la tierra, reglar papel,trazar o dibujar algo (M), lo raspa (T)
huahuan(a).Comment: Z has a long vowel in the second syllable and in oneattestation has the reflex of a glottal stop at theend of the first syllable.  X consistently has a longvowel in the second syllable, while T consistentlyhas a short one.

huāhuā-tl.English: type of caterpillar also known as chinahuate

huālaquiliā.English: to be capable of doing s.t.
huālaquiliā.Spanish: tiene capaz hacer, les cabe a todos (Z)

huālcah.Comment: This is generally preceded by OC "yet", although itis once attested in C without.  C gives the literalsense of the phrase "to be in this direction, to bemore this way, to be more".

huālcui.Comment: With the third pers. singular object prefix, Zalternatively has QUIHUĀLCUI orshortens the sequence C-HUĀL to CUĀL.

huālēhu(a).English: to come from somewhere, to come forth, to flee
huālēhu(a).Spanish: venimos (C for first pers. plural subject), sale, seviene de alliŸ para acaŸ (T), huir (S)
huālēhu(a).Comment: T has an idiosyncratic short vowel in HUĀL-.

huālhuīca.English: to come, to arrive, to reach a place; to bring s.t.
huālhuīca.Comment: T has the common variant form HUALĪCA.

huālitta.Spanish: me ha visitado (C for first pers. sg. object)

huāllā.Comment: This is a compound of HUĀL- and the verb YĀ, butthe HUĀL- has been absorbed into the stem so that noother prefixes can intervene, and there isassimilation of the Y to preceding L.  The YĀelement behaves like free YĀ, being suppletive withHU(I).  The present singular form is HUĀLLAUH, andthe present plural is HUĀLHUIH.

huālquīz(a).English: to emerge, to come hither out of some place
huālquīz(a).Spanish: salir de lo profundo del agua asiŸ (M), salir haciaacaŸ (M)

huāltohtoca.English: to come following after s.o., to drive s.o. away

-huāmpoh.Spanish: ser uno de la misma naturaleza, estado, o condicioŸnque otro (C), nuestro pariente (S)

-huān.Spanish: junto y en compan9iŸa de otro (C)
-huān.Comment: T has lost the final N by general rule, and the vowelhas shortened in word-final position.  T and Z useHUĀN without a possessive prefix to mean "and",contrasting with ĪHUĀN "with him = her = it".

huānti.Comment: With the third pers. singular object prefix Zalternatively has QUIHUĀNTI orshortens the sequence C-HUĀNTI to CUĀNTI.

-huānyōlqui.Spanish: pariente cercano, unido por la sangre (S)
-huānyōlqui.Comment: S has an alternate form without the N.  This almostalways appears in plural possessed form, "one'srelatives".  Only the -HUĀN is actually bound withthe possessive, so no plural possessive suffixappears after YŌLQUI.

huapāhu(a).English: to grow up, to gain in strength; to raise children
huapāhu(a).Spanish: crecer en edad, o esforzarse y animarse (M), criarnin9os, o esforzar y animar a otro (M)
huapāhu(a).Comment: T has the variant form HUEPĀHU(A).  M also hasintransitive HUAPĀHUA, preterit HUAPĀHUAC, "tobecome hard, stiff, numb".

huapal-li.Comment: In three of five attestations Z marks the vowel ofthe first syllable long.  T has the variant formHUEPAL(I)-TL.

huāqu(i).Spanish: secarse, enjugarse al sol, mermar las cosas liŸquidaso pararse flaco (M)

huātz(a).English: to get dried out; to dry s.t.
huātz(a).Spanish: enjugarse (M), secar o enflaquecer a otro (M),enjugar o secar algo (M)
huātz(a).Comment: In T the vowel of the first syllable is consistentlyshort, while in Z it is long.  In one of threeattestations in C it is marked long.

huauhcal-li.Comment: This is a variant of CUAUHCAL-LI.

huāuhquil(i)-tl.English: wild amaranth, greens which are boiled andeaten as a vegetable
huāuhquil(i)-tl.Comment: In the Z attestation the vowel is not marked long.

huāuh-tli.Spanish: bledos (M), huatle, una semilla que comen tostada (Z)
huāuh-tli.Comment: Only in X is the vowel of the stem marked long.

huāx-in.English: large tropical tree that produces edible pods (Leucaenadiversifolia, Crescentia alata)
huāx-in.Spanish: cierto aŸrbol que da unas como algarrobascomestibles, de tierra caliente (C), guaje (T)
huāx-in.Comment: In C, Z, and X the vowel of the stem is long.  In Tit is consistently short.

huāxpītz-tli.English: dried seed of the guaje tree

huāxyō-tl.Comment: This appears in C as an example of derivation with-YŌ.  The base is HUĀX-IN "guaje", and no gloss isgiven for the derived form.  The sense would beapproximately "essence of guaje".

huechiliā.Comment: This is an applicative form of HUETZ(I) only usedbound to the verb CUI by the ligature -TI-.

huecpal-li.Comment: T also has synonymous HUEHCOL-LI.  M has huictliwith the same sense.

huehcacayō-tl.English: s.t. brought from afar; s.o. who has come fromafar, wanderer
huehcacayō-tl.Spanish: cosa que se trae de acarreo (M), peregrino (Z)

huehcāhu(a).English: to retain s.t. for a long time, to detain s.o. fora long time, to postpone doing s.t.
huehcāhu(a).Spanish: detener largo tiempo alguna cosa ajena, no latornando con tiempo a su duen9o, o diferir y dilataralguŸn negocio (M), detener por largo espacio a otro(M), diferir o dilatar algo, o tardarse en hacer algo(M)

huehcāhua.English: to attain great age or to remain for a long time inone place
huehcāhua.Spanish: tener mucha edad o detenerse y tardar en alguŸn lugar(M)

huehcāhu(i).Comment: This is synonymous with intransitive HUEHCĀHUA.

huehcāhuīltiā.Comment: A short vowel in the third syllable is to beexpected, but it is attested long in T.

huehcaitta.Comment: This also appears in P with the glottal stop marked.

huehcapahuiā.English: to keep one's distance from s.t., s.o.
huehcapahuiā.Spanish: seguir a otro de lejos (M), apartarse de algo (R)

huehcapan.Comment: The general loss of word-final N makes thishomophonous with HUEHCAPA in T.

huehcapanihu(i).English: to gain honor and high estate
huehcapanihu(i).Spanish: subir o crecer en honor, dignidad y estado (M)

huehcapaniuhqui.English: s.o. of honor and high estate
huehcapaniuhqui.Spanish: ensalzado y sublimado en honra y estado (M)
huehcapaniuhqui.Comment: This implies HUEHCAPANIHU(I).  HUEHCAPANIUHQUI alsoappears in P with the glottal stop marked.

huehcapanoā.English: to rise up, to become enlarged; to raise, enlarges.t.
huehcapanoā.Spanish: ensalzarse o agrandecerse (M), sublimar y engrandecera otro (M)

huehcatlan.Spanish: cosa honda y profunda (M), hondo, abismo, profundo(Z)
huehcatlan.Comment: Although Z marks the vowel of the last syllablelong, X does not.  In T the vowel is short,and the final N is missing.  Although the N ispresent in HUEHCATLANOĀ, as attested in T, thevowel before it is still short.

huehcatlantlāliā.Comment: The N of the third syllable is missing in T.

huehcatlāz(a).English: to withdraw; to defer, postpone s.t.
huehcatlāz(a).Spanish: ponerse lejos (R), diferir, aplazar, dejar para maŸstarde (S)

huehcāuh.Comment: This occurs frequently in the phrases YE HUEHCĀUH"long ago", OC HUEHCĀUH "a long time from now", andtheir negations AYAMŌ HUEHCĀUH "recently" andAOCMŌ HUEHCĀUH "in a little while, shortly".

huehcāuhcāyō-tl.Spanish: antigu edad o vejez (M), antecesor, ancestro (Z)

huehcāuhpa.Spanish: mas tarde, despueŸs de un rato, hace tiempo (T)

huehcāuhtātah.Comment: Z also has the variant HUEHCĀUHTĒTĀT.

huehhuehca.English: far away, with respect to several things
huehhuehca.Spanish: distantes unas de otras (R), distancia de cosasapartadas unas de otras (M)
huehhuehca.Comment: This is the distributive of HUEHCA.  C and T haveHUĒHUEHCA with long-vowel reduplication but the samemeaning.  M's entry is ambiguous between the two.

huehhuehcāuhtica.Spanish: de tarde en tarde o raremente (M)

huehhuēi.Comment: M gives this a plural gloss in the absence of theplural suffix, which is consistent with the fact thatNahuatl in general does not overtly mark the pluralsof inanimate objects.

huehhuelihu(i).English: to go to pieces, to collapse
huehhuelihu(i).Comment: The glottal stop in the first syllable is notattested in C or X but is attested in transitiveHUEHHUELOĀ.

huehhueloā.English: to destroy, undo, lay waste s.t.
huehhueloā.Comment: The internal glottal stop is not attested in X butdoes appear in Z and R.

huehhuetzca.Comment: C contrasts this with HUEHUETZCA "to laugh a greatdeal".  In general, reduplication with glottal stopimplies a reiterated act, so HUEHHUETZCA would seemmore proper to "to laugh" than HUEHUETZCA, but C'scontrast is explicitly the opposite.  R hashuehuetzca as a modifier of TLAHTOĀ andTLAHTŌL-LI with the sense of "to blaspheme" and"blasphemy" respectively, but it is multiplyambiguous and may represent HUEHHUETZCA, HUEHUETZCA,or HUĒHUETZCA.

huehpām(i)-tl.Spanish: viga grande desbastada y por labrar (M), las vigas(C)

huehpōlhuiā.English: to be in love with one's brother-in-law
huehpōlhuiā.Spanish: tiene a su cun9ado por querido (T)

huehpōl-li.English: in-law of opposite sex, same generation;brother-in-law of woman, sister-in-law of man
huehpōl-li.Spanish: cun9ada de varoŸn o cun9ado de mujer (M)

huēhueh.Comment: This has T before the plural suffix but a glottalstop word-finally in the singular, except in Z, whichhas T thoughout.  Before -TZIN and -TŌN this has theform HUĒHUĒN.

huēhuehca.English: distance between more than two things
huēhuehca.Spanish: distancia entre maŸs de dos cosas (C), distancia decosas apartadas unas de otras (M)

huēhuehcāuhtica.Spanish: de tarde en tarde o raramente (M)

huēhuehhuah.Comment: This appears as a grammatical example in a discussionof the possessor suffixes and may have no realreferent.  It contrasts with HUĒHUĒHUAH "master ofdrums".

huēhuēhuah.Comment: C contrasts this with HUĒHUEHHUAH "master of old men".Only C glosses HUĒHUĒ-TL as "guitar".  Itspecifically means the indigenous upright drum.

huēhuehyō-tl.English: age; s.t. pertaining to old people
huēhuehyō-tl.Spanish: vejedad o costumbre y propiedad de viejos (M)

huēhuēihtzin.Comment: This is one of the cases where glottal stopintervenes between the stem and -TZIN.

huēhuelatzin.English: cripple, one who drags himself around
huēhuelatzin.Spanish: uno que no puede andar, no maŸs se arrastra, cojo (T)
huēhuelatzin.Comment: This is derived from HUILĀN(A).  T has E for I andLA for LĀN.  This is a reduplicated form of T'sHUELATZIN, but the reduplication has to do with theaction of the verb, "to drag oneself around invarious places", rather than with the whole derivednoun.

huēhuēntōn.English: little old man; character in a comical traditional"old men's" dance

huēhuēntzin.Comment: In T the vowel of the second syllable is short.

huēhuetcāyō-tl.Spanish: edad de viejos o vejedad (M), vejez (T)

huehuetzca.Comment: C contrasts this with HUEHHUETZCA "to smile".  Thevowel of the first syllable is specifically markedshort, and in the text it is also said to be short.

huēhuetzca.English: to laugh with a good will, to laugh hard
huēhuetzca.Spanish: me riŸo con mucha gana (C for first pers. sg. subject),se riŸe (T)
huēhuetzca.Comment: This is abundantly attested in T and Z and also oncein C, making a three-way contrast with HUEHUETZCA andHUEHHUETZCA.

huēhuetzcaliz-tli.Comment: This suggests that M's veuetzca, glossed in Spanishas dar carcajadas de risa, is HUĒHUETZCA.  Z marksthe vowel of the third syllable long, but it shouldnot be.

huehxōlōcuep(a).English: to turn into a turkey cock

huehxōlō-tl.Spanish: gallo de la tierra (C), guajolote, pavo (Z)
huehxōlō-tl.Comment: T and X lack the internal glottal stop.  Z has theform HUEHUEHCHO.

huē(i).Comment: In related forms such as HUEHCA "far away",HUEHCĀHU(A) "to detain s.o., postpone s.t. for along time", and HUĒHUEH "old man" the stem has theform HUEH.  HUĒHUEH also has the variant stem formsHUĒHUET and HUĒHUĒN.

huēica.English: in a grand, noble manner; for a long time

huēichīhu(a).English: to grow large, to aggrandize oneself, to be vain; toenlarge, augment, exaggerate s.t.
huēichīhu(a).Spanish: se da por maravilla (esta fruta) (C), jacta, seenorgullece, es egoiŸsta, se hace grande (T), loengrandece (T)

huēihcāyō-tl.Comment: In the same grammatical discussion C givesOHUIHCĀYŌ-TL "difficulty and danger" derived fromOHUIH "s.t. difficult", in both cases with a glottalstop followed by -CĀ-, implying a deverbalderivation.

huēiliā.English: to aggrandize oneself or s.o. else; to enlarge,augment s.t., to start bidding in a game of chance
huēiliā.Spanish: estimarse, engrandecerse o ensoberbecerse (M),engrandecer a otro (M), hacer mayor lo pequen9o oalargar y an9adir o envidar en juego (M)

huēimat(i).English: to hold oneself in high regard; to have a highopinion of s.o. or s.t.
huēimat(i).Spanish: tenerse y estimarse en mucho (M), tener y estimar enmucho a otro (M), estimar o tener en mucho algunacosa (M)

-huēinān.Comment: Z also has several other permutations of NĀN-TLI andHUĒ(I) in possessed form with the same sense.  Thisis peculiar to Z; the common Nahuatl word for"grandmother" is CIH-TLI.

huēinequ(i).English: to hold oneself in high regard

-huēitātah.Comment: Z also has the phrase TĀTAH HUĒ(I) with the samesense.  This is peculiar to Z; the common Nahuatlword for "grandfather" is CŌL-LI.

huēitōtol-in.English: a type of wild bird, probably the wild turkey

huēiy(a).English: to grow; to gain in honor and dignity
huēiy(a).Spanish: hacerse grande o crecer en honra y dignidad (M)

huēiyac.Comment: The I is only hypothesized from HUĒIY(A).  X marksthe vowel of the last syllable long in allattestations, and Z marks it long once.

huel.Comment: This often serves as an intensifier withoutcontributing any distinct lexical meaning of its ownin phrases that do not always translate well intoEnglish with "very", HUEL ĀXCĀN "right now", CAHUEL MOCHĪNTĪN "all, every single one", HUEL IHUI"vigorously".

huelatzin.English: cripple, one who drags himself around
huelatzin.Spanish: cojo, uno que no puede andar, no maŸs se arrastra (T)
huelatzin.Comment: This is derived from HUILĀN(A).  T has E for I andLA for LĀN.

huel(i).Comment: S gives this as an alternate for of HUEL, but it doesnot appear in M.  In the sources for this dictionaryHUEL(I) is abundantly attested across sources withnegation, as in AHHUEL(I) "impossible", AOC HUEL(I)"no longer possible", AYA HUEL(I) "not yet possible"and in Z as a shortened form of the verb HUELITI "tobe able to do s.t."  In view of the verb HUELITI "tobe able to do s.t.", HUEL is probably a truncation ofmore basic HUEL(I).

huēlic.Comment: Z and X mark the vowel of the second syllable long,but T has it short.

huēliliya.Comment: M has transitive uelilia "to make food taste good",which forms its preterit as a regular -IĀ verb,while this intransitive verb adds -C in the preterit.

huelīliz-tli.Comment: This is a shortened form of HUELITILIZ-TLI.  Zconsistently marks the vowel of the second syllablelong, which may be in compensation for the elidedsyllable.  M's veliliztli is derived fromHUĒLILIYA "for food to taste good" which has a longvowel in the first syllable in contrast with thisitem.

hueliti.English: to be able to do s.t., to be sufficient for s.t.
hueliti.Spanish: poder hacer algo, o tener suficiencia y ser bastantepara algo (M)

huelitiliz-tli.English: possibility; power and authority to do s.t.
huelitiliz-tli.Spanish: posibilidad, facultad, poder y autoridad para haceralgo (M)

huelitta.English: to enjoy oneself; to find s.t. pleasing and good, toapprove of s.t.
huelitta.Spanish: se goza, se regocija (Z), agradarme y parecerme bienalguna cosa (M for first pers. sg. subject)

hueliz.Spanish: quizaŸ, quizaŸs, tal vez (T), posible, puede que siŸ(Z)
hueliz.Comment: This is abundantly attested but only in T and Z.

huelmat(i).English: for s.t. to taste good to s.o.
huelmat(i).Spanish: saberme bien el manjar (M for first pers. sg. subject),le gusta mucho, lo saborea (T)

hueloā.English: to be dislocated; to consume, undo, demolish s.t.
hueloā.Spanish: se disloca (Z), desboronar, deshacer, o derribar algo(M)
hueloā.Comment: This also has a reduplicated form with the samesense, HUEHHUELOĀ

huēltīuh-tli.Comment: The possessed form adds a glottal stop before -TZIN,-HUĒLTĪHUAHTZIN.

huelyehhuā-tl.Spanish: el mismo en persona (M), eŸl mero (T)

huentlāliā.English: to set an offering on the altar

huetzcani.English: a laughing person, or s.t. amusing
huetzcani.Spanish: risuen9o, o cosa que se suele reiŸr naturalmente (M)

huetzquiliā.English: to laugh at s.t., with s.o.
huetzquiliā.Spanish: reiŸrse de alguno (M), reiŸrse a la risa de otro (M)

huetzquīltiā.Comment: T has a long vowel in the second syllable where ashort one is to be expected.

huetzquītiā.Spanish: hacer reiŸr a otro o hacer algo por donde se riŸan demiŸ (M)

huetztoc.English: to be lying down, stretched out
huetztoc.Comment: T has the variant forms HUETZTICAH and HUETZTOTICAHderived with the verb CĀ and with the same sense.

huezhuah-tli.Comment: C has stem-final Z, but this is probably atypographical error, since Z is absent in M and inthe possessed form attested in T.

hui.Grammar: exclamation for attracting s.o.'s attention orexpressing surprise or distress
hui.Spanish: vaŸlgame Dios (C), hao, hola, oyes ... para llamar aotro, o interjeccioŸn para hacer exclamacioŸn o paraquejarse (M)

hu(i).Comment: In view of HUĪLOHUA, and possibly of HUĪCA, HUĪTZ,and HUĪCATZ, a case might be made for basic HUĪ,but the I is short in the imperfect and optative, andit disappears in the construction YĀ-HU(I) ˛ YAUH.Only short vowels are susceptible to such deletion,but there is clearly irregularity in the wholesuppletive relationship of YĀ and HU(I).

-huiā.Comment: This suffix is added to nouns to create verbs with anessentially applicative sense -- to wield, use, orapply the thing named by the noun in relation to s.o.or s.t., or to bring forth, produce the thing fors.o. Such verbs are generally paired withintransitive verbs in -OĀ, so that the -HUIĀ verbsmay be considered the applicative forms of thecorresponding -OĀ verbs.

-huīc.Comment: C contrasts ĀHUĪC "toward the water" with AHHUĪC"to and fro, in no one direction".  This can alsoindicate direction from a point.

huīca.English: for people to go together, hence to get married;; totake, carry s.t.; to accompany others
huīca.Spanish: se llevan, se casan (T), llevar algo (M), ir conotros, o ir acompan9ando o en compan9iŸa de otros (M)

huīcaltiā.English: to conform to what others do; to send s.t. withs.o., to cause s.o. to go accompanied by others, tocharge s.o. with s.t.
huīcaltiā.Spanish: seguir el hilo de la gente, haciendo lo que los otroshacen (M), hacer que alguno lleve a otra persona o aalguŸn animal consigo (M), hacer que vaya acompan9adauna cosa con otra (M), dar quien acompan9e a otro(M), lo encarga (un favor) (T)

huicci.Comment: This is the T variant of IUCCI.  The CC representsthe phonetic sequence $ks).  X has lost the initialHU.

huīcōlloh.Spanish: jarro de dos asas redondas como anillos (C forconstruction with TECOM(A)-TL)
huīcōlloh.Comment: M has vicollotl "handle of a pitcher".  Theattestations in C do not mark the vowel long.

huīcōltic.Spanish: cosa tuerta como asa de jarro o persona cencen9a yenjuta (M)

huicxitiā.Comment: Although the vowel of the second syllable beforecausative -TIĀ is long in X, as it should be, it isshort in T and also in C's corresponding IUCXITIĀ.

huihhuīcaltiā.Comment: This is the causative form of unattested *HUIHHUĪCA,which in turn would be a reduplicated form of HUĪCA"to take, carry s.t."

huihhuītequ(i).English: to beat s.o.; to beat clothes, mats, etc., with astick
huihhuītequ(i).Spanish: apalear a otro (M), sacudir ropa, esteras o cosa asiŸcon vara (M)

huihhuitōn(i).Comment: M has viuitomi "to be sick and unable to stand".In the attestation in B the final vowel is deleted,and the nasal agrees with the adjacent T, hence it isambiguous between basic M(I) and N(I).  T has N(I).

huihhuitztlah.Spanish: lugar lleno de espinas o puyas (M)
huihhuitztlah.Comment: M also has the unreduplicated form HUITZTLAH.

huihhuitzyoh.Spanish: espinosa cosa, o llena de puyas (M), trae muchasespinas en la ropa o en el pelo (del animal),espinudo (T)

huihhuīxtiliā.Comment: M has viuixcatilia "to weaken s.o. so that hestaggers".  The Z form seems to be the same verb withone syllable elided.

huīhuīca.English: to stagger; to go along with other people repeatedly
huīhuīca.Spanish: bambolea (Z), seguir muchas a algunas veces yeŸndolosacompan9ando (M)

huihuitla.English: to pull up weeds; to pluck feathers
huihuitla.Spanish: pelar o desplumar aves, o coger yerbas con la manosin arrancar, o arrancarlas de raiŸz (M), coger matasde frijoles (M)
huihuitla.Comment: X marks the vowel of the second syllable long.

huihuixoā.English: to shake or rock s.o. or s.t.
huihuixoā.Spanish: sacudir o menear el aŸrbol, o mecer la cuna al nin9o,o menear al que duerme porque despierte, o prenderpor pena (M)

huihuiyoca.Comment: In one attestation Z marks the O long, but elsewhereit is short and conforms to the pattern of this typeof verb.

huihuiyōniā.English: to shake, shiver; to shake s.t.

huilān(a).English: to drag oneself along; to drag s.t.
huilān(a).Spanish: andar arrastrando y a gatas por el suelo (M),arrastrar algo (M)
huilān(a).Comment: T has HUILĀN(A) in the compound ĀHUILĀN(A) "toswim" but elsewhere the variant HUELĀN(A).  T alsohas the derived nouns HUELATZIN, HUĒHUELATZIN"cripple, one who drags himself around".

huilāniliā.English: for people to want to take s.t. away from oneanother; to haul s.t. for s.o.
huilāniliā.Spanish: quieren quitaŸrselo uno a otro (T), se lo jala (T)
huilāniliā.Comment: T has E for I in the first syllable.

huilāntiquīxtiā.Spanish: echar o sacar a otro de casa a empujones, oarrastraŸndolo (M)

huilān-tli.English: cripple, one who drags himself around
huilān-tli.Comment: T has E for I and LA for LĀN.

huīlohua.Comment: B marks the O long twice and leaves it unmarked forlength once.  C and T share a notation which appearsto represent OHUA but possibly represents ŌHUA.

huīlohualiz-tli.English: the act of general leavetaking, departure
huīlohualiz-tli.Spanish: el acto de partirse todos a alguna parte (M)

huīlohuatz.Comment: This is only attested in T.  The plural is formed byreduplication, HUIHUĪLOHUATZ.  This appears to berelated to HUĪTZ "to come".

huīpān(a).English: to form a line; to line people up, to put s.t. inorder
huīpān(a).Spanish: se forma en cola (T), poner por orden y concierto lagente, cuando hay procesioŸn, etc. (M), poner ordeny concierto en las cosas o en la repuŸblica (M), loforma en liŸnea o cola, lo pone en liŸnea (T)

huīpānticah.Spanish: estaŸn formando en cola (T for plural)

huīpīl-li.Comment: T has P for HU.  X marks only the second syllablelong.

huīptla.Comment: This often appears in the phrase MŌZTLA HUĪPTLA "inthe future", literally "tomorrow, day aftertomorrow".

huīptlati.English: to return on the day after tomorrow

huīptlatica.English: on the third day, every third day
huīptlatica.Spanish: a tercer diŸa (M), cada tercer diŸa (C)

-huīptlayōc.Spanish: dos diŸas despueŸs (M for iuiptlayoc), dos diŸasdespueŸs, a los dos diŸas (S)
-huīptlayōc.Comment: This takes the third person singular prefix.

huīquiliā.English: to take, carry s.t. for s.o.; to owe s.t. to s.o.
huīquiliā.Spanish: lo lleve a eŸl, lo debe a eŸl (T)
huīquiliā.Comment: The sense of "to owe" this verb has in modern Nahuatlappears already in C on f.101r and is common incolonial-period texts.

huītecōni.Spanish: escoplo, o cosa semejante (M), el digno de serazotado (C)
huītecōni.Comment: C contrasts HUĪTECŌNI with TĒHUĪTECŌNI"instrument for whipping, beating s.o."

huītequ(i).English: to get whipped; to whip, beat s.o.; to thresh grain
huītequ(i).Spanish: se azota, se arroja (T), herir o castigar a otro (M),desgranar semillas con varas o palos (M)

huītōlihu(i).English: to arch, to form an arc
huītōlihu(i).Spanish: entortarse o torcerse la vara o cosa semejante (M),torcerse algo ... en forma de arco (C)
huītōlihu(i).Comment: This implies transitive HUĪTŌLOĀ "to bend, archs.t."

huītōloā.Spanish: enarcar sin tirar flecha, o doblegar vara o cosasemejante (M)

huītz.Comment: This is a preterit-as-present verb, the preteritbeing HUĪTZ, and the pluperfect HUĪTZA.  It appearsto be related to HU(I), which enters into asuppletive paradigm with YĀ "to go".

huitzhuiā.English: to prick s.t. with a thorn

huītzil-in.Spanish: pajarillo que zumba (S), chuparrosa, chupamirto,colibriŸ, chupamiel (T)
huītzil-in.Comment: M has vitzitzilin with an additional syllable inthe stem.  T has the variant HUĪTZTZĪTZIQUIH, and Zhas the variant HUĪTZIQUITZIN.  Despite thethorn-like shape of the hummingbird's beak, B and Tagree that the vowel of the first syllable is long,hence contrasting with HUITZ-TLI "thorn".  Z does notmark the the vowel long, and neither does X insynonymous HUITZACATZIN.

huītzilōpōch-tli.Comment: There is much disagreement on the meaning of thisname.  Contrary to some hypotheses, the firstelement, HUĪTZIL "hummingbird", modifies the second,ŌPŌCH-TLI "left-hand side".

huitzōc-tli.Spanish: palanca de roble puntiaguda para arrancar ceŸspedes yabrir la tierra (M)

huītztzītziquih.Comment: The final consonant of this appears only before -MEHand could represent the weakening of some consonantother than H, possibly N.  M has tzitzicuini "s.t.light, free, nimble", which, somewhat reduced, couldbe the second element of this.

ī.Spanish: beber mazamorra, cacao, pinol, o cosa semejante (M)
ī.Comment: The evidence for a long vowel rests on a future tenseform in B that has ĪZ (f.11v) and on C'snominalization TLAĪ-TL.  Z also makes a contrastbetween ĀTIC "s.t. melted" and ĀTĪC < Ā-TL "water"and Ī "to drink", which is possible only becauseTL and T do not contrast in Z.

*iā.Comment: This is a hypothetical element included in ĀQUIHQUEH"who are they?", the plural of ĀC, and of IN IHQUEHĪN (or ŌN) "these (or those) present".

īc.Comment: This often fuses with IN to form INĪC with the samesense.  It is abundantly attested across sources,especially in C where, in keeping with C's practiceof not marking the noncontrastive and the obvious,the vowel is marked long only half the time.

īca.Comment: This is the third person singular possessive prefixĪ- and the postposition -CA "means, reason, cause".Two common phrases with ĪCA are TLE ĪCA "why?" andYEH ĪCA "because of s.t., since".

icah.Spanish: en alguŸn tiempo o alguna vez (M)

-īcampa.Spanish: detraŸs de algo (M), detraŸs de miŸ (M for firstpers. sg. possessor), detraŸs de algunos (M), detraŸs delas espaldas de algo (C)
-īcampa.Comment: C fails to mark the vowel of the first syllable longin seven attestations on a single page.  Some of theother attestations can be understood as possessiveĪ- added to -ICAMPA, yielding a single long Ī.  Buta half dozen cases with a marked long vowel remain.Z consistently marks the vowel of the second syllablelong as well and has a nominal reading "one'sshoulders" for the gloss of one attestation.  For thelocative sense "behind s.t." Z has the alternateforms TLAĪCAMPA and TLAĪCAN.  This conventionallypairs with -TEPOTZCO "at one's back", the wholephrase meaning "when one is dead".

iccāuh-tli.Comment: S has the absolutive suffix, which is unattested inthe sources for this dictionary.

iccemmaniyān.Spanish: siempre, para siempre, para siempre jamaŸs (S)
iccemmaniyān.Comment: C gives this as synonymous with CEMMANIYĀN.  It issometimes written with only a single M.

iccen.Comment: The CEN element of this is undoubtedly CEM "one", butthe IC element never occurs with a marked long vowel,so this is apparently not a simple compound of ĪCand CEM.

ichca-tl.Comment: C provides the reduplicated plural as an alternativeto the simple -MEH plural.

(i)chcua.English: to remove earth with a hoe, to dig s.t.

(i)chpān(a).Comment: M has an entry chpana to be used with the prefixTLA- and also TLACHPĀN(A), where the object prefixhas been absorbed into the stem and the verb istreated as intransitive.  (I)CHPĀN(A) may be relatedby metathesis to CHIPĀHU(A) "to purify s.t."  Z has thevariant (I)CHPĀHU(A) and also two attestations of OCH for(I)CH, which appears to relate this to M's ochpantli"road", in the sense that a road is kept swept clean.

(i)chpocatzin-tli.Comment: Z has a long vowel in the second syllable, but Bspecifically marks it short.

(i)chpōch-tli.Comment: (I)CHPŌCH-TLI and also TĒLPŌCH-TLI "young man"both form the plural by reduplicating the PŌCHelement, which suggests that *PŌCH-TLI, although itdoes not appear as a free form, is a stem in its ownright, and (I)CH is a modifier.  A variant form of(I)CHPŌCH-TLI is (I)CHPOCA-TL, correspondingto the variants TĒLPŌCH-TLI and TĒLPOCA-TL"young man".

ichtaca.Comment: T has the variant form ICHTECA.  With -TZIN there isan intervening glottal stop which does not appear incompounds.  The alternation Ā = AH is to be foundelsewhere, suggesting that this should be ICHTACĀ,but even in compounds where it is not word-final, thefinal vowel is never attested long in the sources forthis dictionary.

ichtacanamaca.Spanish: lo vende (a escondidas de la familia) (T)

ichtacanōnōtz(a).English: to whisper, to converse in secret; to speak to s.o.in secret
ichtacanōnōtz(a).Spanish: cuchichea, platica en secreto (T), le habla ensecreto (T)

īch-tli.Spanish: cerro o copo de maguey (M), ixcle (de pita, maguey),hilo (T)

ici.Comment: This appears to be a reduction of IHCIUHCĀPAN with aloss of the glottal stop characteristic of T.

(i)cnēliā.English: to look after one's own welfare; to do a favor fors.o., to be charitable to s.o.
(i)cnēliā.Spanish: hacer bien a siŸ mismo (M), hacer bien a otro (M)

(i)cnēlīlmat(i).English: to be grateful; to thank s.o.
(i)cnēlīlmat(i).Spanish: ser agradecido (M), agradecer algo a otro (M)
(i)cnēlīlmat(i).Comment: By regular derivational process, the vowel of thethird syllable should be long, but it is unmarked forlength in C.

(i)cnēlilō.Comment: C specifically says that the I of the third syllableis short by contrast with the Ē of the precedingsyllable, but this is probably the result of somesecondary shortening.  By general rule this should be(I)CNĒLĪLŌ.

(i)cnīuhtla.English: to become friends; to cause people to befriend each other
(i)cnīuhtla.Spanish: hacerse amigos o tomar amistad unos con otros (M),dar a conocer a otros para que se amen o haceramigos a los enemistados (M)

(i)cnīuh-tli.Spanish: amigo (M), su hermano, hermana (T for possessed form)
(i)cnīuh-tli.Comment: The "sibling" sense extends to "cousin" in the phraseHUEHCA ICNĪUH-TLI, literally "distant sibling".

(i)cnōitta.English: to have pity on s.o., to regard s.o. with compassion
(i)cnōitta.Comment: In one attestation in T the initial vowel is notdeleted in the presence of a reflexive prefix.

(i)cnōoquich-tli.Comment: M writes the two elements as separate words, while Twrites them solid and reduces the sequence ŌO to Ō.

(i)cnōpilhuiā.Spanish: alcanzar o impetrar algo (M), recibir mercedes oalcanzar lo deseado o cosa provechosa (M with fusedTLA-)

(i)cnōpil-li.English: fatherless child, person deserving of compassion;one's fate, future, lot in life

(i)cnōpilti.English: to prosper in life, to be favored, to attain one'sdesires
(i)cnōpilti.Spanish: obtener lo que se desea, ser feliz, recibir favores,enriquecerse (S)
(i)cnōpilti.Comment: This has only a singular form and takes possessiveprefixes rather than subject prefixes, AMOCNŌPILTI"you are favored, you prosper".  The preterit is(I)CNŌPILTIC, the future (I)CNŌPILTIZ.  No otherforms are used.

(i)cnō-tl.English: orphan, s.o. or s.t. poor, humble, worthy ofcompassion and aid

īcōltiā.English: to long for, desire s.t., s.o.
īcōltiā.Spanish: antojaŸrseme alguna cosa o codiciarla (M for firstpers. sg. subject), codiciar algo (M)
īcōltiā.Comment: T consistently has the O short, although it is longelsewhere.  S has an associated noun ĪCŌL-LI "s.t.desirable".

-(i)cpac.English: on or at the head of, above
-(i)cpac.Spanish: encima de lo alto, o en lo alto de alguna cosa (M),sobre, encima, en la cima, sobre la cabeza, delante(S)

(i)cpal-li.English: seat, specifically a certain type of seat for personsof authority, hence by extension such a personhimself or the authority of such a person
(i)cpal-li.Spanish: asentadero (M), silloŸn con respaldo, signo de poderde los antiguos jefes, los uŸnicos que teniŸan elderecho de usarlos; ... protector, jefe, gobernador,padre, madre, etc. (S)

(i)cxeh.English: possessor of a foot or feet
(i)cxeh.Comment: C and R give this without a gloss as an example of thepossessor derivation.

(i)cxicotōn(a).English: to cut one's foot; to cut s.o. in the foot
(i)cxicotōn(a).Spanish: se mocha el pie (T), le mocha el pie (T)

(i)cxicuauhti.English: for one's legs to get tired
(i)cxicuauhti.Spanish: se cansa los pies, se cansa el pie (T)

(i)cxicuechaquiā.English: to sprain one's ankle, break one's leg; to injures.o. in the leg
(i)cxicuechaquiā.Spanish: se tuerce el pie, se zafa (T), le lastima el pie (alotro) (T)

(i)cxicuetlaxihu(i).English: for one's foot to become weakened, paralyzed
(i)cxicuetlaxihu(i).Spanish: se suelta el pie, se debilita el pie (T)

(i)cximōtla.English: to throw s.t. at the legs of s.o., s.t.

(i)cxipoztequ(i).Spanish: se quiebra la pata, la pierna (T)

(i)cxiquechcochtitlan.Spanish: su empeine (de pie) (T for possessed form)
(i)cxiquechcochtitlan.Comment: T drops the -TI- and word-final N.

(i)cxitepāchoā.English: to bruise one's leg; to bruise s.o. in the leg
(i)cxitepāchoā.Spanish: se machuca el pie (T), le machuca el pie (T)

-(i)cxitlan.Spanish: a sus pies (T), en sus pies (T), al pie de (Z)
-(i)cxitlan.Comment: Z marks the vowel of the last syllable long.

(i)cxitlanītz-tli.Spanish: su canilla (del pie) (T for possessed form)

(i)cxitohmi-tl.Spanish: su pelo de la pierna (T for possessed form)

(i)cxopal-li.Spanish: su planta de pie (T for possessed form)

(i)cxopil-li.Spanish: su dedo del pie (T for possessed form)
(i)cxopil-li.Comment: This is abundantly attested but only in T.  It is notattested in absolutive form, and the -LI here is byanalogy with MAHPIL-LI.  This contrasts with(I)CXOPAL-LI "sole of the foot".

(i)cxopiltepāchoā.English: to bruise one's toe; to bruise s.o.'s toe
(i)cxopiltepāchoā.Spanish: se machuca el dedo del pie (T), le machuca el dedodel pie (T)

icza.English: to step on or trample s.t.
icza.Comment: There is potential minimal contrast with ĪCZĀN"once upon a time, long ago" in case the latter losesits final N, but the transitive verb will always haveobject prefixes.

īczan.English: once upon a time, long ago
īczan.Spanish: desde hace tiempo, alguna vez (en tiempo pasado) (T)
īczan.Comment: In cases where this loses its final N, it contrastswith the verb ICZA "to step on s.t.", but the verbwill always have object prefixes.

iczō-tl.Spanish: palmera de las montan9as ... la fibra de ese aŸrbolse utilizaba en el tejido de pan9os (S)
iczō-tl.Comment: This is attested in the compound ICZŌXŌCHI-TL.

iczōxōchi-tl.Spanish: flor de yuca, flor de iczote (Z)

ihca.English: to be on foot, to be standing

(i)hcahuaca.English: for people or birds to make a lot of noise
(i)hcahuaca.Spanish: gorjear, cantar, hablando de paŸjaros (S), el ruido yel murmullo que hace la gente en la plaza (C)

(i)hcahuatz(a).Comment: This is indirectly attested in C's substantiveTLAHCAHUATZA "those that make such a noise"(referring to the verb IHCAHUACA).

(i)hcal(i).English: to engage in skirmishing; to contest with s.o.
(i)hcal(i).Spanish: escaramuzar o batallar (M), pelear contra otros (M),pelear unos con otros o escaramuzar (M)

ihcaticah.English: to be standing, to be on foot

(i)hchinoā.English: to burn; to scorch, set fire to, burn s.t.
(i)hchinoā.Spanish: se chamusca, se quema (T), lo chamusca, lo enciende,lo quema (T)

(i)hchiqu(i).English: to scrape the core of a maguey plant to collect itsliquid
(i)hchiqu(i).Spanish: raspar el corazoŸn del maguey para sacar miel (M)

ihcīca.English: to pant, to be winded, to palpitate
ihcīca.Comment: Z consistently has a long vowel in the secondsyllable, but the single attestation in B leaves itunmarked for length.  T has it long but has lost theinternal glottal stop.

(i)hcihu(i).Comment: Z has a reflexive form in which the initial I doesnot drop after reflexive prefixes, but in some otherderived forms it appears that the vowel is weak andis deleted when adjacent to another vowel.

(i)hciuhcā.Spanish: presto o de presto o prestamente (M)

ihciuhcāpan.Comment: This is attested in the phrase IHCIUHCĀPAN TŌNALLI"morning, in the morning".

(i)hciuhcāyō-tl.Spanish: apresuramiento o presteza y diligencia (M), raŸpido,pronto, inmediatemente (Z)

ihcop(i).English: to wink, blink, close the eyes
ihcop(i).Spanish: cerrar los ojos (M), pestan9ea ... cierra los ojos(Z)

ihcoyoca.Spanish: hacer ruido la llama del fuego o la avenida recia delriŸo, o el viento o huracaŸn, o zumbar (M)

ihcuāc.Comment: T has lost the initial syllable.

(i)hcuaniā.English: to withdraw; to move s.o. or s.t. from one place toanother
(i)hcuaniā.Spanish: dar lugar apartaŸndose (M), apartar a otro, odeponerlo y privarlo de su oficio (M), mudar oapartar algo de una parte a otra (M)

ihcuāquinōn.Spanish: en ese tiempo, en ese momento; en esaocasioŸn (T)

(i)hcuilhuiā.English: to write s.t. to or for s.o.

(i)hcuilihu(i).Spanish: estaŸn escritas (C for construction with the verb O)

(i)hcuiloā.English: for s.t. to get written; to write or paint s.t., tosign or inscribe s.o.'s name
(i)hcuiloā.Spanish: se escribe (T), inscribir a alguien, escribir sunombre ... escribir, pintar una cosa (T)
(i)hcuiloā.Comment: In Z the initial I does not drop before the reflexiveprefix.  M has this as cuiloa "to write or paints.t.", the initial syllable being lost to theorthography, because the weak intial vowel dropsafter the object prefix TLA- and the glottal stopis not written.

(i)hcuiy(a).English: to wrap or coil oneself, to coil one's hair up
(i)hcuiy(a).Spanish: coger o revolver los cabellos la mujer a lacabeza, o cen9ir la culebra por el aŸrbol opor el cuerpo de hombre (M)
(i)hcuiy(a).Comment: This is implied by TEHCUIY(A) "to wrap or entangles.t."

ihichtequ(i).English: to go from house to house committing robbery
ihichtequ(i).Spanish: voy a hurtar a casas ajenas, de casa en casa (M forfirst pers. sg. subject)
ihichtequ(i).Comment: This reduplicated form has a frequentative sense.The intervocalic glottal stop arises fromreduplication of initial I.

ihīcōltiā.English: to be arbitrary, tyrannical; to entice and thendisappoint s.o.
ihīcōltiā.Spanish: tiranizar (M), se lo muestra, se lo ensen9a para quelo quiera y despueŸs no se lo da (T)

(i)hilnāmiqu(i).English: to daydream, to indulge in fantasies
(i)hilnāmiqu(i).Spanish: me divierto en mil disparatadas imaginaciones (C)
(i)hilnāmiqu(i).Comment: This reduplicated form has a frequentative sense.

ihitta.English: to watch, observe others, to pick out or choose s.t.
ihitta.Spanish: estar mirando a los otros (M), lo escoge, loselecciona, lo elige (Z)

ihitztoc.Spanish: estoy desvelado (C for first pers. sg.present), estaba despierto (C for imperfect)

ihixhuic.English: s.o. full, satisfied after a meal

ihīy(a).English: to be in a bad mood, to be peevish; to hate s.o.,s.t.
ihīy(a).Spanish: aborrecerse estando mohino (M), aborrecer a otro (M)

ihīyōcāhualtiā.English: to suffer exhaustion, prostration; to drive s.o. toexhaustion, collapse, to cause s.o. to faint
ihīyōcāhualtiā.Spanish: perdais el aliento (M for second pers. pluralsubject); hacer desfallecer a otro el huelgo de muchotrabajar o de enfermedad (M)

ihīyōcui.English: to have s.t. to eat, take some refreshment

ihīyōcuītiā.English: to take a rest, to have some refreshment; to gives.o. s.t. to eat and a chance to rest
ihīyōcuītiā.Spanish: coma usted (C for imperative), refocilar o dar decomer a otro (M)

ihīyōhuiā.English: to endure hardship, to labor hard in order tosubsist, to acquire s.t. by one's own hard effort
ihīyōhuiā.Spanish: padecer necesidad el pobre, o adquirir con trabajo lonecesario a la vida (M), padecer trabajos (M)

ihīyōmiqu(i).English: for s.o. to suffocate, to be strangled

ihīyōquīz(a).English: to evaporate, to breath, and by extension, to give anorder
ihīyōquīz(a).Spanish: vaporiza, sale de aire (T), vahear ... mandar algunacosa (M)

ihīyōtēm(a).English: to inflate, to fill up with air; to inflate s.t.
ihīyōtēm(a).Spanish: infla, se llena de aire (T), henchir algo con viento(M)

ihīyōtiā.English: to inhale or exhale loudly, to break wind; to dos.t. breathtaking
ihīyōtiā.Spanish: refollarse o peerse o tomar aliento, o resplandecer ylucir con ricas vestiduras (M)
ihīyōtiā.Comment: This is abundantly attested across sources.  T failsto mark the vowel of the first syllable short.

ihīyō-tl.English: breath, respiration, hence one's life, sustenance
ihīyō-tl.Comment: In T and Z the second vowel has been absorbed intothe following Y, reducing the stem by a syllable to(I)HYŌ.  This is a reduplicated form that implies anunattested *ĪYŌ-TL or an unattested verb *IHĪ "tobreath" ultimately from Ī "to take a breath", butĪ exists as a verb in Nahuatl with the sense "todrink".  IHĪYŌ-TL appears to be related toEHĒCA-TL "wind", which in some dialects of Nahuatleven has A in the first two syllables.  The longvowel of the second syllable of IHĪYŌ-TL isabundantly attested in C.

ihīyōtzacu(a).English: to choke, suffocate; to choke, strangle s.o.
ihīyōtzacu(a).Spanish: enmudecer o atravesaŸrsele el bocado (M), atapar elhuelgo a otro (M)
ihīyōtzacu(a).Comment: T gives the preterit of this as -TZACUAC, but M dropsthe final vowel.  M also has ihiomotzaqua "tosuffer from asthma".  Z has an intransitive formbased on IHĪYŌTZACU(I) meaning "to close".

ihmatcāchīhu(a).Spanish: hago con cordura (C for first pers. sg. subject)
ihmatcāchīhu(a).Comment: One of the two attestations in C is unclear;apparently TC has been reversed.

ihmatcānem(i).Spanish: vivir recatadamente y sobre aviso (M), vive concordura (C)

ihmat(i).Grammar: vrefl,vt; pret: IHMAH, pret. pl: IHMATQUEH
ihmat(i).English: to be careful in what one does; to know how to dos.t. well, to be deft, expert in s.t.
ihmat(i).Spanish: ser prudente y avisado, o ir convaleciendo el enfermo(M), proveer o disponer lo que se ha de hacer (M),travesear ... hacer algo de habilidad (C)
ihmat(i).Comment: The form TLAHMAT(I) "to know how to do s.t. well,etc." has absorbed the nonspecific object prefix TLA-and essentially become an intransitive verb "to beexpert".  Although the initial I is lost inTLAHMAT(I), it is retained in the presence ofreflexive prefixes.

ihpotoca.English: to vaporize, to turn to steam

ihpotocaliz-tli.Comment: Z marks the vowel of the fourth syllable long, but itshould not be.

ihpotoquīlca-tl.Comment: Z marks the vowel of the last syllable long, but itshould not be.

ihpōtz(a).Comment: T has E for I.  X has ILPŌTZ(A).

ihtac(a)-tl.Spanish: provisioŸn, mochila, o despensa de camino omatalotaje (M), comestibles, comida, lonche, taco,itacate (T)

ihtalhuiā.Comment: In TLAHTALHUIĀ "to speak for s.o., etc.", theprefix TLA- has been absorbed into the stem with theloss of initial I, but in B and C it is not lost whenpreceded by reflexive prefixes.  It is lost, however,in T, where initial I deletion is more widespread.

-ihtec.Comment: A common variant is -IHTIC.  The I may drop or beretained after possessive prefixes, NOHTIC = NIHTIC"inside me".

-ihteccopa.Spanish: en siŸ mismo, dentro de uno (T)
-ihteccopa.Comment: N intervenes between this and -TZINCO in anattestation in T, but the final element here shoulddefinitely be -PA, not -PAN.

ihtecoyoctic.Comment: T has YA for YO.  T also has a variantIHTECOYOCTICAH.

-ihtecpa.English: out of or into one's belly

ihteh.Spanish: obeso, ventrudo, ventruda, que tiene vientre (S)

-ihtepāchyō.Spanish: migaja, la parte interior de bolillo, de la can9a dela milpa, etc. (T)

ihte-tl.Comment: A common variant of this is IHTI-TL.

ihtetzacqui.Spanish: soŸlido o duro por dentro (T for possessed form)

ihtexahuaca.Spanish: corre el grun9imiento de un lado al otro, grun9e labarriga (T)

ihtexocotic.Comment: The second element of this is a reduction ofXOCOTETIC "s.t. round in form".  T has the furtherreduction IHTEXOCO with the same sense.

-ihteyō.Comment: Z regularly has IHTI for IHTE.  This is theinalienably possessed form of IHTE-TL.

ihtezōnēhu(i).English: for one's belly to swell up

ihtezōnēhuiliz-tli.Spanish: su barriga aventada (T for possessed form)

-ihtic.Comment: This is a common variant of -IHTEC "inside".

(i)htlacahu(i).English: to go wrong, to be ruined or corrupted, to injureoneself, to spoil
(i)htlacahu(i).Spanish: corromperse, dan9arse, o estragarse algo ... oempollarse el huevo (M)
(i)htlacahu(i).Comment: This has the same sense as (I)HTLACOĀ usedreflexively.

(i)htlacoā.English: to be corrupted, spoiled, damaged; to spoil, damages.t.
(i)htlacoā.Spanish: se empeora (la cosa), se envicia (T), enfermar por sedar mucho a mujeres (M), estragar o dan9ar algo (M)
(i)htlacoā.Comment: In Z the I does not drop after the reflexiveprefixes.

ihtlan(i).Comment: Attestations are very mixed about loss of the initialvowel before prefixal vowels.

ihtlaniā.English: to beg, to ask for alms; to question, examine s.o.
ihtlaniā.Spanish: mendigar, pedir limosna (S), le pregunta, le pide (T)

ihtlaniliā.English: to make a request on s.o.'s behalf

(i)htoā.English: to speak up, to volunteer; to say s.t., to speak wellor ill of s.o.
(i)htoā.Spanish: comedirse u ofrecerse a hacer alguna cosa (M), deciralguna cosa (M), decir bien o mal de otro (M)

(i)htopōloā.English: to say s.t., to criticize s.t.
(i)htopōloā.Comment: When -PŌLOĀ is added to a verb, it contributes asense of deprecation or reproach, as in thisattestation where the object of (I)HTOĀ is thespeaker's sins.

ihtōtiā.English: to dance; to get s.o. to dance
ihtōtiā.Spanish: bailar o danzar (M), hacer bailar a otro (M)

(i)htzom(a).English: for s.t. to get sewn; to sew s.t.
(i)htzom(a).Comment: The nonspecific object prefix TLA- has been absorbedto form intransitive TLAHTZOM(A) "to sew".

ihtzōmiā.Comment: This stem also appears with fused TLA-, meaning "tosnort", which is then reduplicated to formfrequentative TLAHTLAHTZŌMIĀ "to snortrepeatedly".  T has the variant (I)LTZŌMIĀ.There is inconsistency about the strength of theinitial I.  It is retained in the presence of thereflexive prefix in M and C but not in T.  WithTLA- it is dropped in M and C as well.  M alsohas a derived form with NE- in which the I is dropped.

ihuā.Spanish: enviar a otro a alguna parte o dar de mano el preso(M), enviar mensajero (M)
ihuā.Comment: The long vowel of the second syllable is evident inthe applicative form, which is abundantly attested inB.  C, R, and M agree on the preterit form above, butS also gives IUH and IHUAC (with vowel lengthindeterminate) as alternate preterits.

īhuān.English: in the company of s.t. or s.o. else, and
īhuān.Comment: The third person singular possessed form of thepostposition -HUĀN has virtually the function of aconjunction.  In T and Z it has lost the possessiveprefix Ī- and has been lexicalized as HUĀN "and".In T the final N is also lost by general rule.

ihu(i).Grammar: singular present and preterit only, plus derivations
ihu(i).English: to be or become a certain way; thus, such, so
ihu(i).Comment: Although this is transparently verbal with itspresent and regular preterit forms and the derivedagentive IUHQUI "s.o., s.t. of a particular nature",it has been lexicalized in an essentially adverbialrole of "thus, such, so".  The optative phrase MĀZO IHUI "let it be so" has been lexicalized asMĀCIHUI "though, however".  Other particlecompositions with IHU(I) are HUEL IHUI "greatly,grandly, vigorously", ZAN YE NŌ IHUI "in likemanner", IHUI ĪN "in this way", IHUI ŌN "in thatway".  The preterit form IUH is often misleadinglyspelled yuh.

ihuīhuih.Spanish: con mucha dificultad, a mucha costa (C)
ihuīhuih.Comment: This is related to OHUIH "with difficulty, danger" insome not entirely direct way.  The first element isprobably IHU(I) "thus, such, so".

ihuīhuihcāyōtica.English: at great cost, with great difficulty
ihuīhuihcāyōtica.Spanish: mucho me ha costado (C), con sentimiento, con pena,dificultad (S)

ihuinti.Spanish: se emborracha, se ataranta, se embriaga (T), estareŸbrio, embriagarse (S)
ihuinti.Comment: Intransitive IHUINTI has the same sense as IHUINTIĀused reflexively.

ihuintiā.English: to get drunk; to get s.o. drunk
ihuintiā.Comment: T and Z have lost the initial vowel.  There is arelated form ĪXHUINTIĀ "to make s.o. dizzy",which even in C has lost the initial I of the stem,being compounded with ĪX-TLI "face".

ihuintiltiā.Comment: T has a long vowel before -LTIĀ where a short oneis to be expected.

īhuiyān.English: calmly, peacefully, moderately, a little at a time
īhuiyān.Spanish: mansamente o con tiento (M), paciŸficamente (C), pocoa poco (C)

ihxāmiā.English: to wash one's face; to wash s.o.'s face
ihxāmiā.Spanish: lavarse la cara (M), lavar a otro la cara (M)

(i)hxīca.English: for s.t. to leak, ooze, trickle
(i)hxīca.Comment: In the Z attestations the vowel of the secondsyllable is marked long, while in C it is unmarkedfor length.  T has ĪXĪCA.

(i)hxītza.Comment: C does not mark the vowel of the second syllablelong.

-ihyāca.Comment: This contrasts with the element ĪYACA- to be foundin some compounds and having to do with noses orpoints, as in M's iyacamecayo "(horse's) bridle".The latter is formed from YAC(A)-TL "nose" with thepossessive prefix Ī-.

(i)hyāliliā.English: to let s.t. turn foul, rotten
(i)hyāliliā.Spanish: lo hace que apeste (la carne, etc., por no atenderlaluego) (T)

(i)hyān(a).English: to hide, conceal oneself; to hide, conceal, deny s.t.
(i)hyān(a).Spanish: se esconde, se oculta (T), lo esconde, lo niega, looculta (T), esconder algo (M)

(i)hyāya.Comment: This drops the initial I after the reflexive prefixesbut retains it after the nonspecific object prefixTLA-.

(i)hyehuiliā.Spanish: lo descascara, levanta la caŸscara (de aŸrbol, yerba,etc.) (T)
(i)hyehuiliā.Comment: Since T characteristically has YE for YA, this may berelated to M's iyauilia "to raise s.t. up insacrifice".

(i)hzanaca.English: to make a rustling noise like dry leaves
(i)hzanaca.Spanish: hacer ruido las hojas secas, etc. (C)
(i)hzanaca.Comment: M has this as a substantive, s.t. that makes such anoise.  T has lost the glottal stop.

(i)hzanatz(a).English: to cause s.t. to make a rustling noise
(i)hzanatz(a).Spanish: hace ... ruido con hojas secas, pliegos de papel,etc. (C)

ihzolihu(i).English: for things to get old, wear out
ihzolihu(i).Spanish: envejecerse la ropa, los libros, las esteras, o cosassemejantes (M)

ihzoloā.English: to abase oneself; to mistreat, wear out things likeclothes, books, mats, etc.
ihzoloā.Spanish: deshonrarse (M), maltratar o envejecer las cosasdichas (la ropa, los libros, las esteras, o cosassemejantes) (M)
ihzoloā.Comment: This implies intransitive IHZOLIHU(I) "for things toget old, wear out".  There is a derived formTLAHZOL-LI in which the initial I drops after theprefix TLA-, but M has strong, undeleting I for the verb.

īihteccah.Comment: This is a fusion of the preterit-as-present verb CĀwith the postposition -IHTEC prefixed with the thirdperson singular possessive prefix.  T treats thesequence CC as though no morpheme boundary intervenesand probably shifts stress accordingly as inCUALLICAH "for s.t. to be good".  T also hasĪIHTICCAH "for s.t. to be done correctly; to beempty, to be without work", apparently with the samederivational history.

ilacatzihu(i).Spanish: torcerse alguna cosa asiŸ como la punta de alesna ocosa semejante (M), torcerse (C)

ilacatzoā.English: to turn one's back on s.o., to wrap oneself arounds.t.; to roll up blankets, mats, paper, thread, etc.
ilacatzoā.Spanish: volver el cuerpo por no ver ni mirar al que aborrece,o cen9ir la culebra al aŸrbol (M), arrollar manta,estera, papel o cosa asiŸ, o coger y revolver hilo ocordel al dedo, etc. (M)

ilama-tl.Comment: M gives this with an absolutive suffix and in itsmore common form without the suffix.  A T appears inthe plural and possessed forms, but there is noattestation of a corresponding stem-final glottalstop in the singular as in HUĒHUEH "old man".  Theshape of the absolutive suffix in M's entry requiresthat the stem end in a vowel.  From the plural andpossessed forms, ILAMA seems to be a truncation of*ILAMATQUI.  T and Z have lost the initial vowel.

(i)lcāhu(a).Comment: A common variant has E for I.

(i)lchīn(a).English: to suck s.t. up, to consume s.t.

(i)lhuiā.English: to take counsel with oneself, to make a complaint; tosay s.t. to s.o., to reveal s.t. to s.o.
(i)lhuiā.Spanish: quejarse a la justicia (M), consultar algo consigomismo (M), decir algo a otro o descubrir el secreto(M)
(i)lhuiā.Comment: Because this is an inherently applicative verb, ittakes both a direct and an indirect object prefix.NITĒTLALHUIĀ "I say s.t. to s.o.", NINOTLALHUIĀ"I consult myself about s.t."

ilhuicacayō-tl.Comment: M gives the alternatives ilhuicacayotl andilhuicaccayotl with identical sense.

ilhuicaccopahuīc.Comment: This is synonymous with ILHUICACOPAHUĪC.  It isapparently built on ILHUICAC rather than ILHUICA.

ilhuicayō-tl.English: s.t. of or pertaining to heaven

ilhuiceh.Spanish: mucho maŸs (M), especialmente o mucho maŸs (C)

(i)lhuīlō.Comment: C specifically states that the vowel of the secondsyllable is short through the influence of thepreceding two consonants, but this is probably due tosome superficial neutralization of lengthdistinctions.  In T there is the reflex of a longvowel in this position.

(i)lhuilti.English: to be deserving of s.t., to be worthy
(i)lhuilti.Comment: This verb is always in the singular and takes thepossessive prefixes instead of the subject prefixes,NOLHUILTI "I am worthy", but its tense inflection isregular.

ilhui-tl.Spanish: fiesta de guardar, o cualquier diŸa de la semana (M)
ilhui-tl.Comment: In some derived forms this loses the initial vowel.

-ilhuiyōc.Grammar: preceded by possessive prefix and quantifier
-ilhuiyōc.Comment: An example with a number is ĪCHICŌMILHUIYŌC "sevendays after that"; one with a nonnumeral quantifier isĪQUĒZQUILHUIYŌC "several days after that".  With amonth or year, the expression means on the designatedday of that unit of time.

īlihuiz.Comment: C marks the initial vowel long in only two offourteen attestations; in the others it is unmarkedfor length.  Z has E for I in the initial syllableand does not mark it long but consistently marks thevowel of the final syllable long.  This is synonymouswith TLALHUIZ and often forms the phrase ZAN ĪLIHUIZwith the same sense.  This may be related to anintensifier in T, the canonical form for which wouldprobably be LALEHUIZ.

īlihuizhuiā.Spanish: hago algo inconsideradamente (C for first personsubject)

īlihuiztlahtoā.Spanish: hablar cosas sin tiento ni consideracioŸn (M)

(i)lnāmictiā.Spanish: traer a la memoria, o acordar algo a otro (M)

(i)lnāmictinem(i).English: to go along recalling, thinking on s.t.

(i)lnāmiqu(i).English: for memory to return, sharpen; to remember, reflecton s.t.
(i)lnāmiqu(i).Spanish: se refrescaraŸ la memoria de esto (C for futuretense), acordarse de una cosa, imaginar, pensar,reflexionar, considerar (S)
(i)lnāmiqu(i).Comment: A common variant has EL for (I)L.

īlōchtiā.English: to turn s.t., s.o. back, to set back a clock, torevoke a sentence, to sell s.t. at a loss
īlōchtiā.Spanish: tornar a otro, desde donde le habiŸa ido a acompan9ar(M), achicar o acortar algo (M), tornar atraŸs elreloj, o tornar a enviar algo al que me le enviŸo, omudar o revocar la sentencia que se habiŸa dado, ovender algo por menos de lo que vale (M)

īlōt(i).English: to return whence one came; for an illness to abate
īlōt(i).Spanish: volverse o tornarse de donde iba (M), aflojarse laenfermedad (M)

(i)lpiā.English: to gird oneself; to tie s.t. or s.o. up, to takes.o. into custody
(i)lpiā.Spanish: cen9irse (M), atar alguna cosa (M), atar a alguno oprenderlo y encarcelarlo (M)

ilpihticah.Comment: T is missing the internal glottal stop.

ilpihtihu(i).Comment: T shortens this to ILPIHTI and is missing the glottalstop.

ilpiliz-tli.English: the act of tying s.t., s.o. up

(i)lpītz(a).English: to blow s.t. up, to inflate s.t.
(i)lpītz(a).Spanish: soplar (M), soplar a otro (M), lo sopla (T)

ilpōtz(a).Comment: T and Z have synonymous IHPŌTZ(A).

(i)ltequ(i).Spanish: sorber algo (M), lo bebe (caldo, huevo, etc.) (T)

īmacac(i).English: to hold s.o. in awe, to fear s.o., to be respectfultoward s.o.
īmacac(i).Spanish: temer a alguno (M), tener respecto o temorreverencial (M)

īmacax-tli.English: s.o. worthy of being held in awe, s.o. of authorityand dignity
īmacax-tli.Spanish: digno de ser temido, o persona grave y de autoridad(M)

imman.English: to be high time for s.t.
imman.Comment: This is also written INMAN, reflecting its origin ofIN MAN(I).  M also has immani, which may representIMMANĪN rather than IMMAN(I).  This generally occurswith YE "already".

immānel.Spanish: aunque, desde que, o puesto que (M)
immānel.Comment: This is a fusion of MĀNEL with the particle IN andis synonymous with MĀNEL.  This also combines withthe cliticizing element -(Y)EH with no change ofsense.

immanti.English: for the right moment to be at hand
immanti.Spanish: ser ya hora y tiempo oportuno para hacer algo, ovenir y cumplirse el tiempo y hora que se esperaba(M)

immanyeh.Comment: T has multiple ambiguity involving Ē, YE, and IYE.Possibly this should be from IMMANĪNYEH with T'scharacteristic loss of syllable-final N.

īmonequiyān.Spanish: en tiempo y sazoŸn, o en buen tiempo y coyuntura (M)
īmonequiyān.Comment: This is prefixed with the third person singularpossessive prefix Ī-.

īmōztlayōc.English: the following day, the next day
īmōztlayōc.Spanish: el diŸa siguiente (C), un diŸa antes que (C)
īmōztlayōc.Comment: This is prefixed with the third person singularpossessive prefix Ī-.  When preceded by OC, it meansthe day before.

īn.Comment: This is often postposed after the element it refersto and becomes bound to it as a suffix, YEHHUĀTLĪN"this one, this person", INĪN "this", IMMANĪN "atthis very time".  It contrasts with the distalparticle ŌN "that, those".  The phrase IN IHQUEH ĪNis used for the plural.

in.Comment: This particle is pervasive in Nahuatl and appears yetmore so in texts in which IN and ĪN are notdistinguished.  Moreover, it tends to lose N, whichleads to confusion with possessive Ī-.Alternatively, in high-frequency items it may lose I,with the N then being reanalyzed as part of thefollowing item, as in NICI < IN ICI and NAN- "we" <IN AN-.  IN is generally translated as "the" or leftuntranslated, especially when in construction with awhole phrase.  While it has no lexical sense of itsown (unlike the proximal particle ĪN "this"), itsgrammatical sense can be conveyed with the Englishphrases "as for" or "with reference to".  IN tends tofuse with time adverbials and other particles,sometimes yielding lexicalized forms of slightlydifferent sense; ICI "here", INICI "recently".

īnāntzīca-tl.Comment: According to popular belief, this snake resides inant hills and protects the ants.

īnāy(a).English: to hide or take refuge somewhere; to hide s.t.
īnāy(a).Spanish: esconderse o guarecerse en alguŸn lugar (M), encubriro esconder algo (M)

īnāyiliā.Spanish: esconder y encubrir algo a otro (C)

inīc.English: with, by means of, so that

inici.Comment: See ICI.  The initial vowel can drop, yielding NICI,which C accepts as an alternate form.

inihqueh.Comment: When followed by ĪN, this means "these" and whenfollowed by ŌN, "those"; such phrases are equivalentto the plurals of INĪN "this one" and INŌN "thatone".

iniuh.Spanish: asiŸ como (M), de la manera que (C)
iniuh.Comment: According to C's examples, this is used with verbalconstructions, while INIUHQUI is used withsubstantives.

iniuhqui.Spanish: asiŸ, como (M), de la manera que (C)
iniuhqui.Comment: According to C's examples, this is used withsubstantives, while INIUH is used with verbalconstructions.

inoc.Spanish: mientras que, o en tanto que (M)

intlā.Comment: There are two homophonous particles, TLĀ "let it beso that" (synonymous with MĀ) and TLĀ "if".  Thisform with fused IN is more common across sources thansimple TLĀ "if".

intlāca.Spanish: y si no (M), para negar, si no (C)

intlācaīc.Spanish: si en ninguŸn tiempo, y si nunca (M)
intlācaīc.Comment: One of the two attestations has an additionalsyllable intlĀcayaĪc.

intlācamō.Spanish: y si no (M), para negar, si no (C)

īoccāmpaixti.Grammar: possessed form, prefixed with third person singularpossessive Ī-

īoccānixti.Grammar: possessed form, prefixed with third person singularpossessive Ī-
īoccānixti.Spanish: en ambas partes (C), de ambas partes (C)

īōntlapalixti.Grammar: possessed form, prefixed with third person singularpossessive Ī-

īpal.Grammar: possessed form, prefixed with third person singularpossessive Ī-
īpal.English: for, by means of s.t. or s.o.

īpalnemohuani.Grammar: possessed form, prefixed with third person singularpossessive Ī-
īpalnemohuani.English: that one through whom living goes on, giver of life
īpalnemohuani.Spanish: por quien se vive, el que da vida (C), DioŸs, porquien se vive (C)
īpalnemohuani.Comment: There are three attestations (Bf.1r,2r,7r) of alonger form ĪPALNEMOHUALŌNI.  NEMOHUA is thenonactive form of NEM(I) "to live", and an alternate,through infrequent, nonactive form is with -HUALŌ.B also has attestations in which the HU is notwritten and the A, the preceding O, or both aremarked long, but this is an -OHUA, not an -OĀderivation, in spite of the fact that it is almostalways spelled ipalnemoani.  The possessive prefixis bound with -PAL, not with the whole construction.

īpampa.Grammar: possessed form, prefixed with third person singularpossessive Ī-
īpampa.English: because of s.t., for some reason
īpampa.Spanish: por esto, dando razoŸn o causa porque se hizo la cosa(M)

īpan.Grammar: possessed form, prefixed with third person singularpossessive Ī-
īpan.English: on, on top of, at or for s.t.

īpanti.English: to hit the mark with an arrow or shot
īpanti.Spanish: dar la saeta o arcabuz en el blanco (M)

īpantiā.English: to hit the mark, to be right in what one says
īpantiā.Spanish: acertar o atinar en lo que dice (M)
īpantiā.Comment: T has what appears to be an attestation of this withincorporated YŌL-, but the vowel corresponding to Īis short.  Elsewhere this takes TLA- as objectprefix.

īpantiliā.English: to hit upon what one is searching for; to fall uponone's enemies
īpantiliā.Spanish: hallar lo que se busca o dar sobre los enemigos (M)

īquin.Spanish: cuaŸndo?  o en queŸ tiempo?  preguntando (M)

-itcōca.English: that which s.o. carries, that for which s.o. isresponsible
-itcōca.Spanish: vasallos, gente menuda o suŸbditos (M for itconi)
-itcōca.Comment: B does not indicate the presence of the possessiveprefix Ī- by vowel length marking, but this isconventionally paired with possessed forms of otherdeverbal constructions about carrying s.t. or s.o.,hence governing and being responsible for s.o..

ītech.Grammar: possessed form, prefixed with third person singularpossessive Ī-
ītech.English: next to, on, attached to s.t., s.o.
ītech.Spanish: en, en eŸl, o de eŸl (M), junto a eŸl, pegado a eŸl(T)

ithua.Comment: This is cognate with (I)TTA, which developed anunusual geminate TT corresponding to this item's morehistorically conservative sequence THU.

itlah.Comment: Although it is abundantly attested short in othersources, B marks the initial vowel long in sixteenattestations.

ītloc.Grammar: possessed form, prefixed with third person singularpossessive Ī-
ītloc.English: by, with, next to s.t., s.o.
ītloc.Spanish: par de eŸl, o junto a eŸl (M)
ītloc.Comment: T has A for O in -TLOC.

ītōnal-li.Comment: In the Nahuatl-to-Spanish side of T there isĪ-TŌNAL-LI "one's shadow, spirit, soul", butthe Spanish-to-Nahuatl side has ĪTŌNAL "sweat(third pers. sg. possessor)", which represents aconsolidation of Ī-ĪTŌNAL.  M has absolutiveytonalli "sweat".

ītōniā.Comment: This appears only in the Spanish-to-Nahuatlside of M.

(i)tqui.English: to carry s.t., to govern people (by extension ofmeaning)
(i)tqui.Spanish: llevar algo (M), regir o gobernar a otros (M)
(i)tqui.Comment: This verb is abundantly attested in B and C.

(i)tquitiā.Spanish: enviar algo con otro a alguŸn cabo (M)
(i)tquitiā.Comment: By general rule the vowel of the second syllableshould be long, but C specifically marks it short.

(i)tta.English: to look at oneself; to see s.t. or s.o.
(i)tta.Spanish: mirarme (M for first pers. sg. subject), ir a visitar aotro, o mirar a otro (M), hallar lo que se habiŸaperdido o lo que se procura y busca, o mirar a otro(M)
(i)tta.Comment: This verb has an unusual internal geminate consonant.

(i)ttiliā.English: to take aim at, point out, look after s.t.
(i)ttiliā.Spanish: lo apunta (una cosa), lo cuida, lo atina (T)

(i)ttītiā.English: to appear to s.o., to reveal oneself to s.o.; to shows.t. or s.o. to others, to get others to see s.t.
(i)ttītiā.Spanish: aparecer a otro o mostraŸrsele (M), dar a conocer aotro o mostraŸrselo (M), mostrar algo a otros (M),hallar o procurar algo para siŸ (M)
(i)ttītiā.Comment: By general rule the vowel of the second syllableshould be long, but T consistently has a short voweland C leaves it unmarked.  In one of four entries inM there is an extra TI syllable, but its place inalphabetical order and its sense make it clear thatthis is a printing error.

(i)tz-.Comment: This appears as a variant stem form of (I)TTA in anumber of constructions, especially before theligature -TI-.  Although (I)TTA is transitive, (I)TZ-appears in some constructions with no object prefix.

itzcuīn-tli.Comment: Z consistently has the vowel of the second syllablelong, while C and X leave it unmarked for length.This commonly occurs without the absolutive prefix.

itzmīn(i).English: to receive an injection; to inject s.o.
itzmīn(i).Comment: This is abundantly attested but only in T.  In T theinitial vowels drops after reflexive prefixes but notafter the prefix TLA-.

(i)tzmolīn(i).English: to sprout again, to grow, to appear
(i)tzmolīn(i).Spanish: reton9ecer (C), reton9a (T), nacer, crecer,reverdecer, hablando de vegetales ... ser juicio,discreto, razonable, rico, no carecer de nada (S)
(i)tzmolīn(i).Comment: T has the reflex of Ō although B and C do not markthe vowel long.

itztapalāpan.Comment: The literal sense of this has to do with pavingstones in the vicinity of water.

itztapal-li.Comment: TAPAL- occurs as an element in compounds having to dowith flat stones.  ĪTZ-TLI "obsidian" would makesense as the first element here, but C does not markthe initial vowel long in either attestation ofITZTAPAL-LI, while the single attestation of ĪTZ-TLIin T does have a long vowel.

(i)tztēhu(a).English: to go away out of sight

(i)tztihu(i).Spanish: ir a ver, buscar, mirar, considerar (S)

(i)tztiliā.Comment: This is used in place of applicative (I)TTILIĀ inconstructions with the ligature -TI-.  There is adiscussion of this in C on f.68r.  (I)TZTILIĀcontrasts with ĪTZTILIĀ "to chill s.t."

ītztiliā.English: to get cold; to chill s.t.
ītztiliā.Spanish: se le enfriŸa la cabeza (T for CUĀĪTZTILIĀ),refrescarse (S), enfriar, refrescar a alguien (S),enfriar una cosa (S), lo enfriŸa (T)
ītztiliā.Comment: This is abundantly attested, but only in T.It contrasts with (I)TZTILIĀ < (I)TTA.

(i)tztilihtihu(i).Comment: This applicative form is attested in use only as anhonorific form.

(i)tztiltiā.Comment: This is used in place of causative (I)TTALTIĀ or(I)TTĪTIĀ in constructions with the ligature -TI-.

(i)tztinem(i).English: to go along looking at s.t., s.o.; to consider s.t.
