ītztiya.Comment: R has itzti and itztia, and S gives them with thepreterits itztic and itzti respectively, implyingĪTZTI and ĪTZTIĀ as well as ĪTZTIYA.

ītz-tli.Spanish: obsidiana o fragmentos de obsidiana utilizados comocuchillos, navajas de afeitar, lancetas, flechas,espejos, etc. (S)

itztoc.Comment: In Z this appears with reflexive and objectprefixes, while in R it appears as an intransitiveverb glossed as "to be sleepless".

iucci.Spanish: madurarse la fruta o cocerse algo (M)
iucci.Comment: T has a variant form HUICCI, X has ICCI, and Z hasYOCCI.  The UCC sequence here represents $kw<s),not $ukk).  This is often misleadinglyspelled icuci.

iuc-tli.Spanish: mi hermano o hermana menor (dice la hermana mayor) (Mfor first pers. sg. possessor), mi hermana menor (diceel hermano mayor) (M for first pers. sg. possessor)
iuc-tli.Comment: S provides the absolutive suffix.  This is onlyattested in possessed form.  M's gloss is ambiguous;it may mean that this term is used for "youngersibling of the opposite sex" and also for "littlesister" by older sisters.  Or it may mean that it isused by both sexes for "little sister" and also for"brother" by sisters in general.  The possessed formof this is often misleadingly spelled -icuh.

iucxitiā.Comment: By general rule the vowel of the second syllableshould be long, but C specifically marks it short.

iucxoā.Comment: Z has delabialized the final consonant of the firstsyllable and has the form ICXOĀ.  T has the formIHCUIXOĀ.  X has ECXOĀ, which M also has inaddition to IUCXOĀ.

iuhcān.English: in or with reference to such a place
iuhcān.Spanish: de la misma manera que eŸsta (C)

iuhqui.English: thus, in such a way, like
iuhqui.Spanish: semejante o asiŸ o de essa manera (M)

iuhquinmah.Comment: The NM sequence may assimilate to MM.

iuhtoc.English: s.t. established, appearing to be a certain way

īx-.Comment: This is a modifier common in T but also attested in Bwhich conveys the sense of "somewhat, middling".Although it is homophonous with the stem of ĪX-TLI"face", the sense suggests that it might be areduction from ĪXQUICH "all".

īxaca.Comment: This is abundantly attested in Z and also appears inX.  In one attestation the vowel of the secondsyllable is marked long, and in three the vowel ofthe third syllable is marked long, but otherwise Z isconsistent.

īxacahuilān(a).English: to drag oneself along, to crawl

īxacaman(a).Comment: X marks the vowel of the fourth syllable long, but itshould not be.

īxacatlamōtla.English: to throw s.o. face downwards, headlong

īxacatlapachoā.English: to upset s.o., to mix s.o. up
īxacatlapachoā.Spanish: lo trabuca (Z), lo pone boca abajo (Z)

ixachi.English: much, great in number, very many
ixachi.Spanish: mucho o grande en cantidad (M), muy muchos en nuŸmero(M for plural)

īxācoztic.Grammar: possessed form, prefixed with third person singularpossessive Ī-
īxācoztic.Comment: This is a reduction of ĪXĀYACCOZTIC and isanalogous to ĪXĀIZTĀC "s.o. pallid".

īxahci.English: to approach s.t., s.o. closely, to comprehend s.t.completely
īxahci.Spanish: acercarse mucho, agarrar, alcanzar por completo algo(S)
īxahci.Comment: This also appears in P with the glottal stop marked.

īxahmōl.Comment: Z also has a variant ĪXNĀMŌL.  The literal meaningof this seems to be "s.o. with a soapy face".

īxāhuiā.Spanish: lo enjuaga, lo lava (T), embarrar o enjalbegar (M)

īxāhuiltiā.English: to make signals with one's eyes

īxāiztāc.Grammar: possessed form, prefixed with third person singularpossessive Ī-
īxāiztāc.Comment: This appears to be a reduction of ĪXĀYACIZTĀC.  Zonly marks the vowel of the second syllable long inone of two attestations.

īxāyōtepēhu(i).English: for tears to come in floods

īxāyō-tl.Comment: There is also nearly synonymous ĪXXĀYŌ-TL derivedfrom ĪX-TLI "eye" and XĀYŌ-TL "discharge, excrement".It is possible that the frequently attestedĪXĀYŌ-TL is a reduction or reanalysis ofĪXXĀYŌ-TL, which is attested just once.  Thesimplification of XX to X is common in the modernsources and may extend to B and C too in this case.On the other hand, ĀYŌ-TL "watery substance" is asplausible for a second element here as XĀYŌ-TL"discharge".

(i)xca.English: to bake s.t.; to fire pottery
(i)xca.Spanish: cocer loza o asar huevos, batatas, o cosa semejante(M)
(i)xca.Comment: This is also abundantly attested in the derived formTLAXCAL-LI "bread".

īxcahcayāhu(a).English: to deceive, mislead s.o., to falsify s.t.

ixcahuiā.English: to be single-minded, preoccupied with one's ownaffairs; to have or do just one thing to theexclusion of others
ixcahuiā.Spanish: hacer algo a solas o entender solamente lo que metoca (M), no tener maŸs de una cosa (M), comeŸrmeloyo todo (M), aprovecharse eŸl solo de alguna cosa,sin partirla con otros (M), entender en sola una solacosa (M)
ixcahuiā.Comment: It is possible that C fails to mark a long initialvowel and that this is derived from ĪX-TLI andCĀHU(A).

īxcapotztic.English: s.t. gray, dark, swarthy, s.o. with a black face
īxcapotztic.Spanish: (negro claro), gris, medio negro, triguen9o, moreno(T), cara negra (Z)
īxcapotztic.Comment: This is also attested in Z in the shortened formĪXCAPOTZ.

īxcauhtōtō-tl.English: ani, a bird that eats ticks off domestic animals
īxcauhtōtō-tl.Comment: Z idiosyncratically has a P corresponding to the UHof the second syllable.  This may reflect a confusionbetween ĪXCAUH-TLI "tick" and ĪXCAPOTZTIC "black",since the bird is glossy black.

īxchicāhuac.Comment: Z's gloss is not the literal sense implied by theverb, which would be "s.o. brave, dauntless".

īxchīchīlēhu(i).English: to blush, flush, turn red in the face
īxchīchīlēhu(i).Comment: M has reflexive ixchichiloa with the same sense.

īxchicotic.Comment: Z also gives the shortened form ĪXCHICO.

-īxco.English: on one's face, on the surface of
-īxco.Spanish: en la cara o en la sobrehaz (M), en su superficie (T)

īxcocoā.English: to have s.t. the matter with one's eyes

īxcocoxcātiā.Comment: This appears in T as a reflexive verb and also as anintransitive verb.

īxcocoy(a).English: to have s.t. the matter with one's eyes

-īxcohtiyān.Comment: C gives this as a less common variant of -ĪXCOHYĀN.

-īxcohyān.English: s.t. of one's own, s.t. personally owned, proper tooneself or its purpose
-īxcohyān.Comment: This is abundantly attested in C where it is given assynonymous with NOHMAH.  Bf.11v has Īxcoca, whichfrom context appears to mean "one's business, one'sown responsibility".  It would seem to be derived insome indirect way from -ĪXCO.

īxcomaca.English: to confess to having done s.t.; to tell anotherperson his faults to his face, to give evidence
īxcomaca.Spanish: confesar y conocer haber hecho algo (M), decir aalguno sus tachas o faltas en la cara (M), comprueba(Z)
īxcomaca.Comment: In M this appears as a double transitive verb, takinga direct and an indirect object prefix, while it isattested as simply reflexive in T and transitive in Zand has to do with clarification, verification, andproof.

īxcopitzotic.English: s.o. with a dirty, messy face

īxcoztic.English: s.t. clear yellow, somewhat yellow, tending toyellow

īxcuahmōlquehquetz(a).Spanish: para las cejas de coraje, frunce el cen9o (T)

īxcuāhuiā.English: to cut the heads of grain with a sickle; to carrys.t. with a tumpline across the forehead
īxcuāhuiā.Spanish: arrasar trigo o cosa semejante (M), lo carga en lafrente (T)

īxcuā(i)-tl.Comment: Z has the locative construction ĪXCUĀCO with thesame sense.  M also has the variant ixquatl.  Incompounds this often appears as ĪXCUAH rather thanĪXCUĀ.

īxcuātehuiā.English: to hit one's forehead; to hit s.o. in the forehead
īxcuātehuiā.Spanish: se pega en la frente (T), le pega en la frente (T)

īxcuāte-tl.Spanish: su frente, su rostro (T for possessed form)

-īxcuātlacuaxēl.Comment: This should be derived ultimately from XELOĀ "todivide s.t.", but the attestation has the reflex of along vowel in the last syllable, suggesting XĒLOĀ"to spread s.t. out" instead.

īxcuehcholhuiā.English: to beckon to s.o. with one's head
īxcuehcholhuiā.Spanish: le hace sen9a (con la cabeza que venga) (T)
īxcuehcholhuiā.Comment: M has ixcuechoa "to nod one's head in agreement"and ixcuechilhuia "to wink at s.o."

īxcuep(a).English: to lose one's way and get confused; to deceive s.o.,to turn s.t. inside out or upside down
īxcuep(a).Spanish: errar el camino o andar descarriado (M), embaucar oengan9ar a otro (M), volver lo de dentro a fuera (M),lo trabuca, lo pone boca arriba, le tiene dos caras(T)

īxcuītiā.English: to follow s.o.'s example; to set a good example toothers, to reproach s.o.
īxcuītiā.Spanish: tomar ejemplo de otras (M), dar buen ejemplo (M), lereprocha (T)
īxcuītiā.Comment: M gives the reflexive use of this in composition withTĒTECH "next to s.o."

īxeh.Spanish: que tiene cara, ojos, buena vista, cabeza,inteligencia (S)
īxeh.Comment: The literal sense of this is "s.o. who has a face"or "s.o. who has eyes".  It is conventionally pairedwith NACACEH "s.o. who has ears", the whole phrasemeaning "s.o. who is prudent".

īxēhuiā.English: to take a risk, to expose oneself to hazard

īxēlēhuiā.Spanish: codiciar a alguna persona (M), lo desea, lo codicia(T)

ixhua.English: for a seed to sprout, germinate; for a plant to comeup
ixhua.Spanish: nacer la planta o brotar la semilla (M)
ixhua.Comment: The attestations in Z are inconsistent, with ixoa,ĪxŌa, ixua and Īxua, but C's attestationsare consistent with each other and with M.

īxhuē(i).Spanish: un ojo grande, los dos ojos grandes (T)

īxhuetzca.Spanish: sonreiŸrse o hacer gestos con risa (M)

īxhuetzcaliz-tli.Comment: M has ixhuetzquiliztli with the same sense.

īxhuetzcani.English: s.o. who smiles, s.o. agreeable and good-natured
īxhuetzcani.Spanish: el que asiŸ se sonriŸe (M), risuen9o (T)

īxhuetzqui.English: s.o. who smiles, s.o. agreeable and good-natured
īxhuetzqui.Comment: Both attestations of this have a final s whichseems out of place.

(i)xhui.English: to satisfy one's appetite for food, to become full
(i)xhui.Comment: In a reversal of the prevailing pattern, C has thiswith I deleted in the presence of the reflexiveprefix, and T retains I.

īxhuiā.English: to level s.t., to make s.t. even, to cross s.t., toput s.t. crossways
īxhuiā.Spanish: nivelar con el ojo o con astrolabio (M), lo cruza, loatraviesa (T)

ixhuic.English: s.o. satisfied, full after a meal

īxhuicci.Comment: This is in a phrase with de huetzca, hence "toflush from laughing".  In Z HUICCI has the variantform YOCCI, and here the initial Y assimilates to theX of ĪX-.  Z's reduction of geminate consonantsshortens the resulting XX, and the resulting localform is ĪXOCCI.  T has ĪXHUICCI as a substantive.

īxhuīhuīca.English: to shake one's head back and forth

īzqui.Comment: In the single attestation of the plural form C marksthe vowel of the third syllable long but not thesecond.  But by analogy with other quantifiers, thereshould be alternate plural forms ĪZQUĪN andĪZQUĪNTĪN.

īzquicān.English: so many places as there are, an equal number ofplaces
īzquicān.Spanish: de todas partes o de todos lugares (M forizquicampa)

īzquipa.English: as many times, so many times

īzqui-tl.English: popcorn (used to describe many plants and trees thatproduce clusters of white flowers)
īzqui-tl.Comment: M has izquiatl "drink made of ground popcorn".

īzquixōchi-tl.English: a tree that produces fragrant white flowers(Bourreria huanita), or any of a number of plantsand trees that produce clusters of whiteflowers
īzquixōchi-tl.Comment: The literal sense of this is "popcorn-flower".  Xfails to mark the initial vowel long although X hasit long in ĪZQUI-TL.

iztācātōl-li.English: white atole (a beverage made of cornstarch)

iztācāyō-tl.Comment: Z fails to mark A long, and T has a short vowel andpostvocalic glottal stop in the third syllable.  Mhas iztacayotl "whiteness", which is probablyderived simply from IZTĀCĀ- (the compounding formof ĪZTĀC) and -YŌ.

iztāctzapo-tl.English: white zapote, the fruit of which is narcotic(Casimiroa edulis)

iztacuacuā.Comment: T has CA for CUA in the third syllable.

(i)ztahuiā.Spanish: salar algo, o echar sal al manjar o guisado (M)

iztalectic.English: s.o. pale from chill, fear, or illness
iztalectic.Spanish: descolorido o blanquecino de friŸo, o de temor, o deenfermedad (M)
iztalectic.Comment: Z has IZTĀLTIC, which seems to be a shortened formof this, possibly with compensatory lengthening ofthe vowel caused by loss of a syllable.

iztalēhu(a).English: to turn pale from chill, fear, or illness
iztalēhu(a).Spanish: pararse descolorido de esta manera (de friŸo, o detemor, o de enfermedad) (M)
iztalēhu(a).Comment: This appears to be synonymous with T's IZTALĒHU(I).

iztalēhu(i).Spanish: se pone paŸlido, aneŸmico, estaŸ descolorido (T)
iztalēhu(i).Comment: This appears to be synonymous with C's and M'sIZTALĒHU(A).

iztāltic.Comment: Z marks the vowel of the second syllable long, butit should not be, unless it is lengthened incompensation for the loss of a syllable.

iztapinolhuiā.Spanish: salo (C for first pers. sg. subject)

iztāquēhu(a).English: for s.t. to bleach out; to bleach s.t.

izta-tl.Comment: In verbal derivations the initial I is weak anddeleted when preceded by a prefixal vowel.

iztay(a).English: for s.t. to turn white, to appear white because ofbeing at a distance
iztay(a).Spanish: pararse blanca alguna cosa, o blanquear algo de lejos(M), pararse blanco (M)

(i)ztehuetz(i).English: to burst forth from a place

(i)zte-tl.English: fingernail, toenail, a very small unit of lengthmeasurement
(i)zte-tl.Comment: This has a variant form (I)ZTI-TL.  Both are oftenused in metaphors referring to offspring as parts ofone's own body, especially when conventionallypaired with TZON-TLI "hair".

iztlaca-.Comment: This does not appear as a free form but only incompounds and derivations.

(i)ztlacatiliz-tli.Comment: R has the shortened free form IZTLACALIZ-TLIbut has the full form in a compound.

iztlacmīn(a).English: for a snake to bite s.o.

(i)ztlācoā.English: to consult one's own judgement; to examine and judges.t., especially without appearing to do so
(i)ztlācoā.Spanish: examinar o tomar consejo consigo mismo (M), mirar concautela, y notar lo que otro dice o hace,acechaŸndole (M)
(i)ztlācoā.Comment: T has a vowel length discrepancy; half itsattestations have a long vowel in the initialsyllable.

iztlac-tli.Spanish: baba (M), su saliva (T for possessed form)
iztlac-tli.Comment: By extension of meaning, this has the sense "poison".

mā.Grammar: introductory particle for clauses expressing wishes,commands, admonitions; negative form: MĀCA =MĀCAMŌ
mā.Spanish: es partiŸcula de optativo ... y de imperativo, y delavisativo, vetativo, y entonces quiere decir no (M)
mā.Comment: Preceding a verb in the optative or vetative form,this particle implies that a wish is being expressedrather than a direct command.  The negative sensementioned in M's gloss is not inherent in MĀ but inthe vetative form of the verb, which warns againstdoing s.t. (Or M may be combining the senses of MĀand MAH in a single entry.) MĀNĒN is more emphaticwith the vetative.  With negative wish clauses, MĀCA= MĀCAMŌ occurs in place of the sequence *MĀAHMŌ.  TLĀ may occur in place of MĀ with theoptative and TLĀCA = TLĀCAMŌ in correspondingnegative wish sentences.

mā.English: to hunt, catch s.t., to take captives
mā.Comment: It is possible that this shares a common root withMĀ(I)-TL "hand, arm".

māahci.English: to reach s.t. with one's hand
māahci.Spanish: lo alcanzar (T), alcanza con la mano (Z)
māahci.Comment: Z gives this as an intransitive verb.

māāzcacualō.English: for one's hand or arm to tingle because of reducedcirculation
māāzcacualō.Comment: The literal sense of this is "for one's hand or armto be eaten by ants".  One of the attestations givesit with final -C, "s.t. that tingles as though anarm were being eaten by ants".  The other attestationhas a final A, which is surely an error.

-māc.Spanish: en, por mi mano o mis manos (S for first pers. sg.possessor), en la mano, en las manos de alguien (Sfor TĒMĀC)
-māc.Comment: Although this commonly takes only possessiveprefixes, in C's ĀMĀC "at the brink of the river",it appears to be bound to a noun in the manner of afull postposition.  An alternative analysis isĀMĀ(I)-TL (M has amaitl "inlet, bay") plus -C(O),but in either case, the component elements are thesame.

maca.English: to dose oneself, to take s.t. like medicine; to gives.t. to s.o.
maca.Spanish: tomar medicina (M); dar algo a otro o restituiŸr (M)
maca.Comment: Because of the inherent applicative nature of thisverb, it takes two object prefixes, one direct andthe other oblique reflexive or indirect.  X has thisas a simple intransitive verb.

mācahcapān(i).Comment: This refers to the slapping motion of shaping atortilla.

mācāhu(a).English: to drop s.t., let go of s.t.; to concede s.t., togive consent, to agree to s.t.
mācāhu(a).Spanish: dar licencia a otro (M), otorgar algo o conceder osoltar algo de la mano (M)
mācāhu(a).Comment: Z has derived forms with MAH in place of MĀ.

mācāhuiliā.Spanish: otorgar o conceder algo a otro (M)

mācamō.English: let not ... , may it not be that ...
mācamō.Comment: This contrasts with MAHCAMŌ "as though it weren't"the negated form of MAH "such that".  Each has asynonymous short form, MĀCA "let not ..."contrasting with MAHCA "as though it weren't".  Rtwice attests this with a glottal stop in the secondsyllable, but C repeatedly attests the secondsyllable with a specifically short vowel and with noglottal stop.

mācanah.English: if only somewhere, let it be that somewhere ...
mācanah.Spanish: sea o no sea en alguna parte o lugar (M)

mācapāniā.English: to make a noise with one's hands, to applaud
mācapāniā.Spanish: si el ruido (de las palmadas) es poco, y con sola unamano (C), aplaude (Z)

mācāuhtoc.Comment: Z has MĀ in the verb MĀCAHCĀHU(A), and there isagreement across sources on MĀCĀHU(A), but in twoof the three attestations of this in Z, there is MAHinstead of MĀ.

māccuahu(i)-tl.English: hand sword of wood edged with obsidian
māccuahu(i)-tl.Spanish: macana, especie de espada de madera guarnecida porambos lados de cuchillos de obsidiana (S)
māccuahu(i)-tl.Comment: The single attestation has locative MĀC "in thehand" as the initial element, although S assumes itis MĀ "hand".

mācecēpahtic.Spanish: sudoroso de las manos, friŸo de las manos (Z)

mācecepoc-tli.Comment: M has macecepoa "for one's arm to go to sleep, totingle from lack of circulation".  This seems tospecifically refer to one's funny bone.

māceh.Grammar: particle cluster used in place of simple MĀ tointroduce clauses expressing wishes, commands,admonitions

mācēhual-li.English: subject, commoner; indigenous person, speaker ofNahuatl
mācēhual-li.Spanish: vasallo (M), hombre plebeyo (C), mejicano, azteca,uno que habla nahuat, triguen9o (Z)
mācēhual-li.Comment: This contrasts with MAHCĒHUAL-LI "merit, recompense,fortune".  T glosses this as specifically referringto the language as well as to a speaker of thelanguage.  M gives as a gloss for the plural form"vassals or plebians".

mācēhualtiā.English: to make others vassals to oneself; to provide s.o.with vassals
mācēhualtiā.Spanish: hacer a otros vasallos miŸos (M for first pers. sg.reflexive); dar vasallos a otro, o echar algo a larebatin9a (M)
mācēhualtiā.Comment: This is not directly attested in the sources for thisdictionary, but it can be derived from MĀCĒHUAL-LI.It contrasts with MAHCĒHUALTIĀ, and M gives them inseparate contiguous entries.  Because it isinherently applicative, this takes both a direct andan indirect or oblique reflexive object prefix.

mācepōhuiā.English: for the hand or arm to tingle because of reducedcirculation

mach.Spanish: mucho, en gran manera (C), mucho, en extremo,ciertamente, positivamente (S)
mach.Comment: This is generally accompanied by antecessive Ō- orby NEL or is used in the extended form MACHEH, all ofwhich serve to distinguish it from dubitive MACH.

machiā.English: to be known, to be apparent
machiā.Spanish: ser conocido, descubierto (S), se sabe, se siente (T)
machiā.Comment: T has E for I and gives no preterit form.  S gives apreterit form implying that this is a verb ending inIĀ.  M has tlamachia to do s.t. well, toarbitrate for people", which appears to be this verbused transitively and fused with the prefix TLA-.

machiliā.English: to be aware of defects in s.o. or s.t., todiscriminate among things by their quality
machiliā.Spanish: saber defectos ajenos (M), disponer o repartir algo aotros conforme a la calidad de cada uno (M)

machīltiā.Comment: This causative form of MAT(I) should by general rulehave a short vowel before -LTIĀ, but the vowel isspecifically marked long in B, is consistently thereflex of a long vowel in T, and is marked long oncein C.  It is so conventionally used as an honorificform that the reflexive object can be taken as fusedwith the verb.  Z has the variant form MATĪLTIĀ.

machītiā.English: to reveal oneself, to make oneself known; to informor notify s.o.
machītiā.Spanish: mostrarse, darse a conocer (S), hacer saber onotificar algo a otros (M)

machiyōtiā.English: to make a sign upon oneself, as in making the sign ofthe cross; to make a sign on s.o. or s.t. or to setan example to s.o.
machiyōtiā.Spanish: se persigna (T), dar buen ejemplo, incitar a lavirtud a alguien (S), confirmar o crismar (M), reglarpapel o dibujar algo (M)
machiyōtiā.Comment: T has E for I in the second syllable.  One of Z's twoattestations has the vowel of the second syllablemarked long.

machiyō-tl.Comment: This is implied by the verb MACHIYŌTIĀ.

machiztiā.English: to say that one knows or believes s.t., to meddle; toannounce s.t., to make s.t. known to others
machiztiā.Spanish: decir que sabe o entiende alguna cosa ... oentremeterse sin ser llamado (M), publicar,notificar, o hacer saber algo a otros (M)
machiztiā.Comment: Because this is inherently applicative or causative,it takes both a direct object prefix and an obliquereflexive or indirect object prefix.  M also hasmachizti and machiztia "for s.t. to be known orbelieved".  Both form the preterit by adding -C,which shows that the latter represents MACHIZTIYArather than MACHIZTIĀ.

machtiā.English: to learn, to study; to teach s.o.
machtiā.Spanish: aprender o estudiar (M), ensen9ar o predicar (M)
machtiā.Comment: X has X for CH and glosses the reflexive use of thisas "to pray".

mach-tli.English: nephew, or niece (from the point of view of an uncle)
mach-tli.Comment: S glosses this as specifically "nephew", butaccording to the Spanish-to-Nahuatl side of M, itapplies equally to nephews and nieces.

mācihui.Spanish: aunque o dado que o puesto caso (M)
mācihui.Comment: This is attested once in B with MAH in place of MĀ,but it is clearly a shortened form of MĀZO IHUI.

māciuhqui.English: no matter, nonetheless, however that may be
māciuhqui.Spanish: aunque sea tal, o tal cual es (M), no importa, aunque(T)
māciuhqui.Comment: This shortened form of MĀZO IUHQUI has undergonefurther syncopation in T, Z and other modern Nahuatlspeech communities, and in the form MĀZQUI orMĀZQUE has become a conventional leave-taking phrasein some localities.

māco.Comment: This only occurs in Z.  By general rules, MĀ(I)-TLplus -C(O) yield MĀC.

mācohcoztic.English: paw or foot of an animal colored yellow

mācotoltic.English: person who has had a hand or arm cut off
mācotoltic.Spanish: manco de la mano por se la haber cortado (M formacotoctic)
mācotoltic.Comment: Z has COTOLTIC for COTOCTIC elsewhere.

mācotōn(a).English: to cut off s.o.'s hand, to injure a hand
mācotōn(a).Spanish: cortar a otro la mano (M), le mocha la mano (T)
mācotōn(a).Comment: T provides an additional gloss "to make memelas (atype of thick, oblong tortilla)".  In this sense itprobably means to section s.t. off by hand.

-mācpa.Spanish: de mis manos o por mis manos (M for first personpossessor)

mācpalxōchi-tl.Comment: This is not directly attested in the sources for thisdictionary, but its component elements are.  It has adiversity of medicinal uses as an anti-inflammatoryagent, an anti-epileptic, and for heart ailments.

māctiā.English: to surrender, submit; to hand s.t. over
māctiā.Spanish: se entrega, se rinde (T), lo pone en la mano, loentrega (T)

mācuauhpitzoā.English: to extend the arm or hand and hold it rigid, to exertforce with the arm
mācuauhpitzoā.Spanish: extiende la mano y la detiene riŸgida, endurece lasmanos, se hace fuerza con las manos (T)

mācuauhti.English: for the hands, arms to tire, grow stiff

mācuēleh.Grammar: compound introductory particle for clauses expressingstrong wishes and exhortations
mācuēleh.English: let it be that ... , on with ...
mācuēleh.Spanish: ea ea, alto a ello, suso (M), ojalaŸ (C)

mācuēloā.English: to twist, dislocate one's hand or arm; to twists.o.'s hand or arm, to pull down the branch of a tree
mācuēloā.Spanish: torceŸrseme o desconcertaŸrseme la mano (M for firstpers. sg. subject), torcer a otro la mano o el brazo(M), abajar la rama del aŸrbol, tirando de la (M)
mācuēloā.Comment: This is implied by MĀ(I)-TL, CUĒLOĀ, andMĀCUELPACHYĀN.

mācuep(a).English: to recoup one's losses, to get square; to return,restore s.t.
mācuep(a).Spanish: se desquita, se venga (Z), lo recompensa (Z), lodevuelve (Z)
mācuep(a).Comment: Z has this as both MĀCUEP(A) and MĀQUEP(A),apparently synonymous.

mācuetlaxtic.English: s.o. lacking strength in an arm, s.o. with awithered arm
mācuetlaxtic.Comment: M has macuetlaxtli for a type of bracelet, possiblyone of cured leather.

mācui.English: to grasp s.t., to take s.t. in one's hand
mācui.Spanish: lo coge en la mano, lo agarra con la mano (T)
mācui.Comment: Z has MAHCUI "to baptize" and TLAMAHCUĪLIZ-TLI"baptism" which may be variants of this verb in thesense of faith taking one into its hands or beingbestowed by the laying on of hands.

mah.English: as though, as though it were
mah.Comment: According to C, with negated locatives such as AHCĀN"nowhere" MAH emphasizes the negation (Cf.90v).  WithIUHQUI, MAH may precede or follow, and the sense is"as, like".

mahca.English: such that not, as though it weren't
mahca.Comment: This has a counterfactual implication "not as thingsin fact are".  Double negations with MAHCA affirm;the sense of AHMŌ MAHCA is "without doubt"(Cf.123v).  This contrasts with MĀCA, the negativecounterpart of the clause-introductory particle MĀ.

mahcamō.English: such that not, as though it weren't
mahcamō.Comment: C specifically contrasts this with MĀCAMŌ, theextended negated form of MĀ which is exclusivelyused with the optative and vetative forms of the verb(Cf.123v).

mahcēhu(a).English: to obtain or to deserve what one desires; to dopenance
mahcēhu(a).Spanish: conseguir o merecer lo deseado (M), hacer penitencia(M)
mahcēhu(a).Comment: The penitential sense of MAHCĒHU(A) probably has theobject prefix TLA- fused and can be regarded as anintransitive verb.  M has intransitive maceua "todance", but it is not attested in the sources forthis dictionary, so it cannot be determined whetherthere is an internal glottal stop and what the vowellength pattern is.

mahcēhual-li.Comment: This contrasts with MĀCĒHUAL-LI "subject, commoner,indigenous person".

-mahcēhualti.English: to be fortunate, to attain what one deserves, to beworthy
-mahcēhualti.Spanish: ser dichoso o alcanzar lo que desea (M), sermerecedor (C)
-mahcēhualti.Comment: This takes possessive rather than subject prefixesand is paradigmatically limited to third personsingular form.  The preterit is -MAHCĒHUALTIC.

mahcēhualtiā.English: to give s.o. his due, or to assign penance to s.o.
mahcēhualtiā.Spanish: dar a merecer o dar penitencia a otro (M)

mahcic.Comment: This is implied by MAHCITICAH and MAHCITOC.

mahcuextiā.English: to bedeck s.t. with a bracelet
mahcuextiā.Comment: M has macuextli "bracelet or string of preciousstones for the wrist".

mahiuhqui.Comment: Both attestations of this occur in the phrase INMAHIUHQUI.

mahmaca.English: to divide s.t. up among several people; to handles.t.
mahmaca.Spanish: repartir algo a otros (M), repartir algo entre siŸ ohacer algo a veces (M), lo toca (T)

mahmāihcihu(i).English: to gather things together quickly and leave

mahman(i).English: for things to be individually spread out
mahman(i).Spanish: para significa la multitud de cosas que estaŸntendidas (R)
mahman(i).Comment: This is a distributive use of MAN(I) "to spread out".

mahmat(i).Comment: This is the distributive reduplicated form of MAT(I).

mahmauhtiā.English: to get frightened; to frighten or threaten s.o.
mahmauhtiā.Spanish: se espanta (T), espantar o amenazar a otro (M)

mahpēhu(a).English: to shove s.t. aside, cast s.t. down with disgust,to hold s.t. in contempt
mahpēhu(a).Spanish: dar empujoŸn a otro o echar a alguno por ahiŸ condesdeŸn (M), lo desprecia (Z)

mahpilhuiā.English: to signal to s.o. with one's finger, to point s.t.out to s.o. with one's finger
mahpilhuiā.Spanish: mostrar o sen9alar a otro con el dedo o escoger oelegir a alguno (M), sen9alar algo con el dedomostraŸndolo a otros (M)

mahpiltepāchoā.English: to bruise one's finger; to bruise s.o.'s fingers
mahpiltepāchoā.Spanish: se machuca el dedo (T), le machuca el dedo (T)

mahpilzahzālihuiyān-tli.Spanish: conjunturas de los dedos de las manos (M), artejo (Z)

mahtēl.Spanish: asiŸ se responde cuando otro saluda y se va de nuevo(T)
mahtēl.Comment: The literal sense of this is "well anyway, though soit is".  C has abundant attestations of MĀTĒL, aclause introductory compound particle used with theoptative and implying doubt or difficulty, whichcontrasts phonologically with MAHTĒL.  In T MAHTĒLis used as MĀCIUHQUI is in some other communities.

mahtequiā.Comment: C contrasts this with the imperfect form ofMĀTEQU(I) "to cut one's hand".  This would seem tobe from MĀ(I)-TL "hand" and ĀTĒQUIĀ "to sprinklewater on s.t.", but the vowel length pattern iscompletely wrong.  Even deriving it with MAH, thealternative stem of MĀ(I)-TL, and TĒQUIĀ "tosprinkle s.t.", there remains a discrepancy.  X hasMĀ for MAH.

-mahtlaccānixti.English: in all ten parts of s.t.

mahtlac-tli.Comment: This is abundantly attested across sources, and withthe exception of X (which has MĀ) and R (which failsto indicate either vowel length or glottal stop), allagree on MAH for the first syllable.  But inreduplicated form it is attested twice, both times asmĀtlĀtlaquilhuitica (Cf.19v,107r).  Thisreduplication is unusual in that it is the secondsyllable that reduplicates, as well as in theoccurrence of MĀ for expected MAH.

mahtzolcui.English: to seize s.t. with the hands, talons
mahtzolcui.Spanish: lo agarra con las manos, con las un9as (T)
mahtzolcui.Comment: M has matzoloa "to take a handful of s.t."

māhu(a).English: for illness to spread; to infect s.o., to spreadcontagion to others
māhu(a).Spanish: se contagia, infecta (T), inficionar o pegarenfermedad contagiosa a otro (M)

mahu(i).Comment: Z has O for A in the first syllable, and thissubstitution in this particular item is common inmodern Nahuatl, although not in T.  X gives u,which is not the local reflex of either O or Ō.  Inboth cases the labial vowel represents anassimilation of A to following HU.

māhuiliā.Comment: This contrasts with MAHUILIĀ "to fear s.o., s.t.".

mahuiliā.Comment: This contrasts with MĀHUILIĀ, the applicative formof MĀHU(A).

mahuiliz-tli.Comment: Z has O for A.  This appears to be synonymous withMAHUIZ-TLI.

māhuiltihqui.Comment: S has the variant mauiltiani with the same sense.

māhuiltiliz-tli.Comment: By general derivational processes this should beNEĀHUILTILIZ-TLI, which is the form to be found inM.

mahuizcuītiā.English: to learn from experience; to correct s.o., to inspirea respectful attitude in s.o.
mahuizcuītiā.Comment: M has intransitive mahuizcui "to take fear, becomefrightened".

mahuizoā.English: to marvel at s.t., to observe s.t.
mahuizoā.Spanish: admirarse (M), estar sorprendido (S), lo divierte (T)lo observa (Z)
mahuizoā.Comment: This is abundantly attested across sources.  Itcontrasts with intransitive MAHUIZOHUA "to receivehonor" not only in preterit formation but also inthat in C the intransitive is sometimes representedwith a geminate ZZ.  This may be the basic form, withthe single Z the result of degemination.  S combinesthe the transitive and intransitive verbs in a singleentry, while M separates them in contiguous entries.

mahuizoh.English: s.t. or s.o. honorable and glorious
mahuizoh.Spanish: cosa honorosa y gloriosa (M), cosa o persona quetiene honra y gloria (C)
mahuizoh.Comment: This appears to be a reduction of MAHUIZZOH bydegemination, but it is possible that a differentderivation is involved.

mahuizohua.English: to become renowned, to receive honor
mahuizohua.Spanish: afamarse o recibir honra (M), hacerse ilustre (C)
mahuizohua.Comment: This appears to be a reduction of MAHUIZZOHUA bydegemination.  It contrasts with transitiveMAHUIZOĀ.

mahuizō-tl.Comment: This is apparently a reduction of MAHUIZZŌ-TL bydegemination.

mahuizpoloā.English: to disgrace oneself; to defame, insult s.o.
mahuizpoloā.Spanish: disfamarse o deshonrarse (M), disfamar o deshonrar aotro (M)

mahuizti.English: to be held in esteem, respect

mahuiztic.English: s.t. marvelous, awesome, worthy of esteem

mahuiztiliā.English: to honor, respect s.o., to hold s.o. in awe, toadore s.o.
mahuiztiliā.Spanish: honrar y respetar a otro (M), lo adora (Z)

mahuiztilīllani.English: to desire to be honored, respected, held in awe
mahuiztilīllani.Comment: By general derivational rules the vowel of the fourthsyllable should be long, but it is not marked long inthe single attestation.

mahuiz-tli.English: awe, or person worthy of awe and respect
mahuiz-tli.Spanish: miedo o persona digna de honra (M)

mahuizzoh.English: s.o. who is the embodiment of honor
mahuizzoh.Comment: In one of the attestations, the ZY sequence of thisderived form remains unassimilated.  This alsoappears as MAHUIZOH, apparently by degemination.

mahuizzohua.English: to become renowned, to receive honor
mahuizzohua.Spanish: afamarse o recibir honra (M), recibo honra y dignidad(C)
mahuizzohua.Comment: The preterit of this intransitive verb isMAHUIZZOHUAC, which contrasts with preterit MAHUIZOHfrom transitive MAHUIZOĀ.  Neither attestation ofMAHUIZZOHUA marks the vowel before -HUA long,although by derivation from MAHUIZZŌ-TL it shouldbe.  Cf.31v has this as a stem and in its preteritform, both spelled with a single rather than ageminate consonant, although on Cf.54v it has twoconsonants.

mahuizzōtiā.English: to render honor and glory to s.o.
mahuizzōtiā.Spanish: dar honra y gloria a otro (C)
mahuizzōtiā.Comment: The B attestation and one of the C attestations arein applicative form derived from this.  Although Mspells this with a single consonant between thesecond and third syllables, B and C have a geminate,and C also spells it with the unassimilatedZY sequence.

mahuizzō-tl.Comment: The ZY sequence of MAHUIZ-YŌ-TL assimilates to ZZ,and then apparently optionally degeminates to yieldalternative MAHUIZŌ-TL, which is the formrepresented in M.

mahxītiā.English: to complete s.t., to make s.t. whole
mahxītiā.Comment: M has maxiltia "to supply s.t. that was missing",which is clearly an alternate causative form of averb that underlies this verb too.  It appears to bea reflexive form of the verb AHCI "to arrive, reach"with the reflexive prefix fused to the stem.  M alsohas macic "s.t. whole".

mā(i)-tl.Spanish: mano (M), mano. por ext. brazo, rama (S)
mā(i)-tl.Comment: In addition to the alternating stem forms MĀ andMAH, the reduplicated form MĀMĀ is used in somecompounds.  In referring to a tree's branches theinalienably possessed form is -MĀYŌ or -MĀMĀYŌ.MĀYEH "s.o. with hands" has -EH as the possessorsuffix, which is the form used with stems ending inconsonants.  Perhaps the Y is from I, or possiblythis should be MĀY(I)-TL.  X givesMĀ-TLI, which also implies a stem-final consonant.MĀH-TLI, however, is impossible in terms of Nahuatlphonology, because vowels before glottal stops arealways short.

māitzmīn(i).English: to receive an injection in the arm; to inject s.o.in the arm
māitzmīn(i).Spanish: se vacuna en el brazo, se injecta en el brazo (T), loinyecta en el brazo, lo vacuna en el brazo (T)

-māīxco.English: in the palm of one's hand

māīxnōtz(a).English: to beckon to s.o. with one's hand

malacachihu(i).Comment: This intransitive verb is only attested in thecompound ĪXMALACACHIHU(I) "to be dizzy, bewildered"and in derived forms in M.

malacachoā.English: to turn, revolve; to turn, spin s.t.
malacachoā.Spanish: volverse al derredor estando en pie, o dar vueltas alrededor (M), volver algo al derredor (M)
malacachoā.Comment: P has this in reduplicated form, MAHMALACACHOĀ, usedreflexively.

malacaehēca-tl.Comment: This occurs in a phrase meaning "rain squall withwind".

malcochoā.English: to embrace s.t., to carry s.t. in one's arms
malcochoā.Spanish: abarcar algo (M), lo lleva en los brazos, lo coge enlas manos (T)

malhuiā.English: to be careful with one's appearance or reputation; tohandle s.t. delicately, to take care of s.t.
malhuiā.Spanish: regalarse, tratarse bien, o tener cuenta con su honra(M), tratar bien y delicadamente alguna cosa (M), loguarda, lo ahorra, lo asegura (T)

malīn(a).English: to wind, twist; to wind, twist, sprain s.t.
malīn(a).Spanish: se tuerce (T), lo tuerce (T), torcer cordel encimadel muslo (M)
malīn(a).Comment: Fused with the prefix TLA-, this means "to makerope".

māl-li.Comment: M also has a reduplicated plural mamaltin and thesame form missing the final consonant mamalti.

māmā.English: to bear s.t., to carry s.t. on one's shoulders, togovern s.o.
māmā.Spanish: llevar carga a cuestas (M), llevar a cuestas a otro,o regir y gobernar a otros (M)
māmā.Comment: Although there is agreement across sources that thevowel of the second syllable is long (as it must beto form the preterit as it does), the correspondingvowel in TLAMĀMAL-LI "burden" is short, and B alsomarks the corresponding vowel short in TLAMĀMALŌNI"s.o. who bears a burden".  T gives doublets forderived forms with long and short vowel variants.This vowel length variation in verb and derived nounsparallels that in the verb CUĀ "to eat" andTLACUAL-LI "food".  MĀMĀ may be derivationallyrelated to the verb MĀ "to take s.o. captive",since captives were bound and borne on the shoulders.The preterit is homophonous with that of MĀMAT(I)"to be embarrassed".

māmācuīl-li.Spanish: de cinco en cinco, o cada uno cinco (M)

māmalhuāz-tli.English: gear for carrying s.t. on the shoulders
māmalhuāz-tli.Comment: This is paired with CUEXĀN-TLI "packing bags", thewhole phrase meaning "under the protection of s.o."  Mhas mamalhuaztli "the constellation of Castor andPollux" (literally "the Drill"), which would contrastwith this item in vowel length of the first syllable.

māmalhuiā.English: to acknowledge one's sins, to load s.t. on oneself
māmalhuiā.Comment: Although this would appear to be an alternativeapplicative form of the verb MĀMĀ, it makes bettersense as a truncation of TLAMĀMAL-LI plus -HUIĀ.

mamal(i).English: to drill a hole through s.t.
mamal(i).Comment: This verb is easily confused with forms derived fromthe verb MĀMĀ "to bear, carry s.t.".

māmaltiā.English: to assume a burden, to take s.t. on one'sconscience, to take a load onto one's shoulders; toburden s.o. with responsibility for s.t.
māmaltiā.Spanish: tomar algo sobre su conciencia, encargarse de algo, otomar algo a cuestas (M), tomar la carga a cuestas(M), cargar a otro o encargarle algo (M), abonar aotro en la hacienda (M), le carga, lo acusa (T)
māmaltiā.Comment: The vowel of the second syllable is short here,although it is long in the verb MĀMĀ "to bears.t." and in the applicative derivation from MĀMĀ.Derived forms of MĀMĀ with L are easily confusedwith MAMAL(I) "to drill a hole through s.t.".

māmat(i).English: to be timid, embarrassed; to be embarrassed by othersby others
māmat(i).Spanish: ser empacho o vergonzoso (M), tener empacho de otros(M)
māmat(i).Comment: The preterit is homophonous with that of MĀMĀ "tobear s.t."  R attests this with MAH in place of MĀfor the first syllable.

māmatiloā.English: to confound s.o., to ensnare s.o.

-māmāyō.Comment: M has this in mamatlapaltia "for a tree toto come into leave".

-māmomoloc.Comment: In the Spanish-to-Nahuatl side this has the reflex ofa long vowel in the last syllable.

-mān.Comment: This appears to be derived from MAN(I) "to extendover a surface", but both attestations in C,ĀCŌLMĀN and ŌZTŌMĀN, have a specifically markedlong vowel.  Unlike a postposition, this combinesonly with full stems, not with possessive prefixes.

man(a).English: to spread s.t. out flat and smooth, to pat outtortillas
man(a).Spanish: poner en el suelo plato o cosas llanas, o hacertortillas de maŸiz antes que las cuezan en el comalli(M)
man(a).Comment: M also glosses this as "to make an offering",presumably by laying something out on a surface.

mānāhual-li.Comment: This appears in M and B in possessed form.  Sprovides the absolutive suffix.

mānahuatiā.English: to cast s.t. or s.o. away
mānahuatiā.Spanish: se despide de eŸl (con la mano) (Z)

mānahuiā.English: to extricate oneself; to extricate s.o. from adispute or to take leave of people who are quarreling
mānahuiā.Spanish: defenderse (M), defender a otro o departir a los querin9en (M)
mānahuiā.Comment: M also glosses reflexive manauia as "to suffer fromdiarrhea".

mānehnenqui.English: s.t. that goes on all fours
mānehnenqui.Comment: R fails to mark the vowel of the first syllable long.

mānelihu(i).English: to be stirred, mixed, beaten together
mānelihu(i).Comment: Z marks the vowel of the third syllable long, but bygeneral rule it should be short.

māneliuhtoc.English: s.t. beaten together, mixed by hand

māneloā.English: to mix s.t. together by hand, to swim
māneloā.Spanish: nadar o revolver algo con la mano (M), lo mueve, lorevuelve, lo mezcla, lo bate (con la mano) (Z)

mānēn.Grammar: compound introductory particle for clauses expressingadmonition
mānēn.English: let it not be that ... , let it be in vain that ...
mānēn.Spanish: mirad que no ... se haga tal cosa, advertiendo, ...mirad bien y advertid (M)
mānēn.Comment: This serves as a more emphatic introductory particlethan simple MĀ with the admonitive.  If thefollowing clause includes explicit negation, inaddition to the admonitive construction itself,MĀNĒN creates a double negative which serves toaffirm rather than to negate.

man(i).English: for s.t. flat to cover a surface, as water in ashallow pan, etc.
man(i).Comment: M has the phrase nican mani with the gloss "here isthe book, plate, or pan of water".  There is alocative suffix -MĀN which, though close in sense,has a long vowel in its attestations in C.  Zconsistently has the corresponding vowel in MAN(I)long, but there is agreement across the other sourcesthat the verb has a short vowel.

maniliā.Spanish: ofrecer o poner algo ante otro (M)
maniliā.Comment: C has one attestation of this with a long vowel inthe initial syllable.

mānoceh.Spanish: ni (C), o (C), sirve algunas veces ... de lo mismoque mĀ (C)
mānoceh.Comment: Although C glosses this as "or", he elsewherespecifically says that it has the sense of Spanishni rather than o in the presence of negation andis synonymous with NOCEH.  It is also used as acompound introductory particle for clauses expressingwishes, commands, and admonitions in place of simpleMĀ.  C marks the vowel of the first syllable long inonly one attestation.  This is also attested in P,where the glottal stop is indicated but not the longvowel.

mānōtz(a).English: to beckon to s.o. with one's hand

mānozo.Grammar: compound introductory particle for clauses expressingwishes, commands, or admonitions
mānozo.Comment: Only B marks the vowel of the first syllable long.  Bspecifically marks the vowel of the second syllableshort.

manqui.Comment: M has manqui "advanced in years, aged", which mayhave a different derivation, possibly from ĀN(A),since M has ana, used reflexively, "to grow inbodily size".

mantiman(i).English: to lie in a place, to be located somewhere

māntzoco.English: child unwilling to be separated from its mother
māntzoco.Spanish: nin9o que no quiere dejar a su mama (T)
māntzoco.Comment: S has tzocoton "s.t. very small".  The firstelement may be from ĀN(A), used reflexively, "togrow in bodily size".

māolīniā.Comment: There is a vowel length discrepancy between -OLĪNIĀin compounds and ŌLĪNIĀ as a free form.

māpach-in.Comment: This apparently can extend to coatis and ringtails.

māpachoā.English: to seize s.t., lay hold of s.t. or press s.t. withthe hand
māpachoā.Spanish: tomar, asir, apretar algo con las manos (S)

māpātiliā.Comment: In this applicative form of MĀPĀTLA, there is Trather than expected TL before the applicative suffix-ILIĀ.

māpātla.English: to defend oneself, to put up resistance; to beat s.t.with one's hand, to mix s.t. by hand
māpātla.Spanish: defenderse o resistir (M), lo bate con la mano, lorevuelve con la mano (T)

māpīcca-tl.Comment: This is only attested in third person singularpossessed form, but S has piccatl.

māpīch-tli.Comment: X has X before the absolutive suffix and CHelsewhere.

māpīqu(i).English: to close the hand, make a fist; to grip s.t. inone's fist
māpīqu(i).Spanish: cerrar la mano (M), empun9ar o apretar algo en elpun9o (M)

māpiy(a).English: to hold s.t. in one's hand

māquechtlan-tli.Comment: M has maquechtli with the same sense.

māquītzquiā.English: to detain s.o. or to seize s.t. with one's hand
māquītzquiā.Spanish: lo detiene con la mano, lo agarra con la mano, locoge con la mano (T)

māquīxtiā.English: to escape, free oneself from danger or harm; todeliver s.o. from danger, to free s.o., to redeems.o.
māquīxtiā.Spanish: escaparse o librarse de alguŸn peligro o dan9o (M),librar o salvar a otro (M)

māquīz(a).English: to escape, free oneself from danger or harm
māquīz(a).Spanish: escaparse o librarse de alguŸn peligro o dan9o (M)

māquīz-tli.Comment: There is a typographical error in M; this is spelledmequiztli but alphabetized as maquiztli.

mātahtapayoltic.English: s.o. broken out with bumps on the arms

matcā.Spanish: apaciblemente, con dulzura (S), poco a poco (C)
matcā.Comment: M has this in the construction matcanemini "s.o.peacable, tranquil".

mātēca.Comment: The nonspecific object prefix TLA- appears to befused to the stem in this verb.

mātechān(a).English: to seize s.t. with the hand, to direct s.t. withone's hand
mātechān(a).Spanish: lo agarra con la mano, lo coge con la mano, lo guiŸacon la mano, lo lleva con la mano (T)

mātēl.Grammar: compound introductory particle for clauses withimplied doubt, difficulty
mātēl.English: let it be ... after all, anyway
mātēl.Spanish: cuando uno tuvo duda, ... en resolvieŸndose, dicemĀtĒl (C)

mateloā.English: to bruise one's foot by stepping on a stone
mateloā.Spanish: se magulla el pie por pisar en piedra, etc. (T)
mateloā.Comment: Both M and S have transitive mateloa referring tostriking things with the hand, and S believes it to bederived from MĀ(I)-TL, but if so the initial syllablewould be MĀ or MAH.  Conceivably T has characteristicallylost a glottal stop.

mātepāchoā.English: to bruise one's hand, to bruise s.o.'s hand
mātepāchoā.Spanish: se machuca la mano (T), le machuca la mano (T)

mātepoz-tli.Comment: M glosses this as "adze, a hand-held cutting tool".The literal sense is "hand metal".

mātequ(i).English: to cut one's hand; to cut s.o.'s hand, to prune trees
mātequ(i).Spanish: cortar o herirse la mano con cuchillo (M), corta lamano a otro asiŸ (M), podar vides o aŸrboles (M)
mātequ(i).Comment: C contrasts the present reflexive form of this withthe preterit of reflexive MAHTEQUIĀ "to wash one'shands".

mātetlahtlatzcuepōniā.English: to beat s.o. or s.t. with one's hand

mat(i).Comment: There are many lexicalized constructions built onMAT(I), and in many cases it is difficult todistinguish derivations from MAT(I) and derivationsfrom IHMAT(I) "to know how to do things deftly,cleverly".  In their extensive glossing of this itemboth M and S intersperse derivations from both ofthese.  MAT(I) used reflexively can mean "it seems,it is thought that ...", and when this is in otherthan in third person, as in "It seems to me", thesubject prefix is omitted, hence NOMAT(I) rather thanNINOMAT(I).  ONMAT(I) with the directional particle ON-means "to know the way to a place".

mātiā.English: to equip s.t. with hands or arms
mātiā.Spanish: poner manos a la estatua o figura (C)
mātiā.Comment: C contrasts this with MATIYA, the imperfect form ofMAT(I).

matiliā.Comment: This applicative form of MAT(I) is attested only inthe construction TLAZOHCĀMATILIĀ on Tp.210, but Talso has the applicative form TLAZOHCĀMACHILIĀ onp.209.

matiloā.English: to injure s.t. or s.o. by rubbing or abrading
matiloā.Comment: This is a variant of MATELOĀ.  M has them both withglosses about the rubbing on of ointment.  In T, thereflexive form has E in the second syllable and thetransitive form has I.

matīltiā.English: to inform s.o., to make s.t. known
matīltiā.Comment: This corresponds to MACHĪLTIĀ in the othersources.

-matiyān.English: one's time, span of personal experience
-matiyān.Spanish: en mi tiempo (M for first pers. sg. possessor)

mātlahpaltic.Spanish: bracero que tira mucho (M), es en gran manera fuerte(C)

mātlalhua-tl.Spanish: su tendoŸn de la mano (T for possessed form)

mātlāl-in.Comment: This is attested in Z in MĀTLĀLZAHUA-TL (literally"green pox") and possibly in MĀTLĀLPAN, althoughthe sense of the latter would be obscure from itsgloss, which appears to have s.t. to do with lownessof stature.  Conceivably it is derived instead fromTLĀLPAN "on the ground".

-mātlan.English: in the hand of, under the power of

mātlanītz-tli.English: the long bone of the arm

mātlapītz(a).English: to make a whistle with the hands and mouth
mātlapītz(a).Spanish: silbar con las manos y boca (M)

mātlapoā.English: to be injected intravenously; to give s.o. anintravenous injection
mātlapoā.Comment: The literal sense of this is "to open the arm".

mātlapolōltiā.English: to make a slip of the hand

mātlaquechiā.English: to lean on s.t., support oneself with s.t.
mātlaquechiā.Comment: This is used in construction with a possessed form ofthe postposition -TECH.

mātl(a)-tl.Comment: M has this in the Spanish-to-Nahuatl section of thedictionary, but it is missing from theNahuatl-to-Spanish side.

mātlātlac-tli.Comment: This reduplicated form is implied byMĀTLĀTLAQUILHUITICA.

mātlātlaquilhuitica.Spanish: de diez en diez diŸas (M), cada diez (diŸas) (C)

mātlaxcaloā.Comment: The literal sense of this is to slap one's handstogether as in making tortillas.  M has thereduplicated form matlatlaxcaloa with the samesense.

mātlāxiliā.English: to signal to s.o., to beckon to s.o. with the hand
mātlāxiliā.Spanish: le hace sen9as con la mano, lo llama con la mano (T)

mātoca.English: to fondle oneself, to masturbate; to touch, feel, fondles.o. or s.t.
mātoca.Spanish: palpar o tocar sus partes vergonzosas (M), palpar aotro asiŸ (M), tocar o tentar algo con la mano (M)
mātoca.Comment: M gives a specifically sexual interpretation that islacking in the literal Nahuatl "to hand-follow".

mātohmi-tl.English: the hair of one's hands and arms
mātohmi-tl.Spanish: su pelo de la mano o del brazo (T)

matzah-tli.Comment: R marks the glottal stop.  The vowel of the firstsyllable is unmarked for length.

-mātzālan.English: between the hooves, paws of an animal

mātzocuitlaneltic.Comment: M has tzocuitlatl "thick sweat of the body".

mauhcācāhu(a).English: to keep one's silence out of fear
mauhcācāhu(a).Spanish: tu callas por miedo (R for second pers. sg. subject)
mauhcācāhu(a).Comment: R fails to mark the vowel of the third syllable long.

mauhcāitta.English: to regard s.o., s.t. with fear, respect
mauhcāitta.Spanish: ver a alguien con temor, respeto (S), prestaratencioŸn a una cosa, mirarla con temor (S)

mauhcāmictiā.Spanish: lo espanta, le da un susto (T)

mauhcāmiqu(i).English: to get scared, to take fright; to faint or urinatefrom fear
mauhcāmiqu(i).Spanish: mearse o amortecerse de temor (M), se espanta, seasusta, tiene miedo (T)

mauhcā-tl.Comment: MAUHCĀ-, the verb MAHU(I) plus the ligature -CĀ-,is an element in a large number of constructions, butMAUHCĀ-TL as a free nominal form with an absolutivesuffix appears only in Z.

mauhcātoca.English: to put s.o. to flight by scaring him

mauhcāyacān(a).Spanish: va adelante huyendo (el otro le sigue) (T)

mauhtiā.English: to be frightened; to frighten s.o.

maxac-tli.Spanish: entre mis piernas o en la horcajadura (M for firstpers. sg. possessor), parte interior de las piernas (X)

maxal-li.Comment: Despite the vowel length discrepancy, this appears tobe related to MĀXTLA-TL "breechclout".  M hasmaxaltic "s.t. divided like a road or the crotchof a tree".  The absolutive form is attested in thecompound CUAUHMAXAL-LI.  It is possible that theinsect name should take absolutive -IN rather than-TLI.  T is ambiguous between the two.

maxauhtinem(i).English: to go about with one's crotch exposed
maxauhtinem(i).Spanish: anduvieras con las carnes defuera (C for secondpers. sg. subject, future tense)
maxauhtinem(i).Comment: M has reflexive mamaxauia "to undress, to exposeoneself" in the Spanish-to-Nahuatl side only.

māxittomōn(i).English: for blisters or bumps to appear on the hand

māxixittomōniā.English: for blisters or bumps to appear on the hand
māxixittomōniā.Spanish: le levantan ampollas en la mano, ampolla la mano (T)
māxixittomōniā.Comment: Because of the distributive sense of this, a glottalstop is to be expected in the reduplication ofXITTOMŌNIĀ, but none is attested, perhaps due toT's characteristic tendency to lose internal glottalstops.

māxoxocotetic.English: s.o. with blistered hands or arms

māxtla-tl.Comment: Without the absolutive suffix, this may serve as apersonal name.  The sequence max appears in manyentries in M and S having to do with bifurcation, butthe length of the vowel is in question, since it isattested short in MAXAL-LI and MAXAC-TLI "crotch,s.t. forked" and long in MĀXTLA-TL.

māyahu(i).English: to fall; to hurl s.t. down, to dash s.o. down tohis death
māyahu(i).Spanish: se tumba (T), lo tumba, lo mata (T), echar o arrojarpor ahiŸ (M), derribar a otro en el suelo (M),arrojar o echar algo por ahiŸ (M)

mayānmiqu(i).English: to be very hungry, to be perishing of hunger
mayānmiqu(i).Comment: This is attested without assimilation of the NMsequence to MM.

-māyēccāncopa.Spanish: a tu mano derecha (C for second pers. sg. possessor)

māyecuēleh.Grammar: compound introductory particle for clauses expressingstrong wishes and exhortations
māyecuēleh.English: let it be that ... , on with ...
māyecuēleh.Comment: M glosses this as synonymous with MĀCUĒLEH.

māyeh.Comment: The Y of this form may be the stem-final I ofMĀ(I)-TL, or it may be an intrusive intervocalicglide between the stem and the possessor suffix.

mayī.Spanish: se responde asiŸ cuando otro dice que ya se va (T)
mayī.Comment: This may be a further reduction of MĀCIUHQUI, whichis used as a leave-taking phrase in someNahuatl-speaking communities.

-māyō.English: a tree's crown, its branches and foliage
-māyō.Comment: T has this in reduplicated form -MĀMĀYŌ.  M hasthe imamainquauitl "branches of a tree", whichrepresents the phrase ĪMĀMĀ IN CUAHUITL,literally "its-branches the tree", where the suffix-YŌ indicating inalienable possession is not used.

māzā.Grammar: compound introductory particle for clauses expressingwishes, commands, admonitions
māzā.Comment: C mentions this as one example of numerous suchclause-introductory particles without specificallyglossing it.

mazācōā-tl.English: a type of horned caterpillar or a type of large,nonvenomous snake, a boa
mazācōā-tl.Spanish: gusano gordo con cuernos o culebra grande que no hacemal (M), culebra mazacuate (Z)
mazācōā-tl.Comment: Several Spanish sources remark that the snake of thisname is large enough to feed on four-legged animals.The literal sense of the name "deer snake" probablyrefers to its alleged diet rather than to any aspectof its appearance.  The caterpillar, on the otherhand, takes its name from its antler-likeprojections.

māzoihui.Spanish: aunque, dado que, o puesto caso (M)
māzoihui.Comment: This is commonly shortened to MĀCIHUI.

māzolhuiā.English: to make gestures while talking to s.o.
māzolhuiā.Spanish: habla agitando las manos enfrente de otra persona (Z)
māzolhuiā.Comment: This appears to have the literal sense "to wear s.o.out with gesturing", and Z has what seems to be asecondary derived form MĀZOL "s.o. who goes abouttouching things".

māzonelihui.Spanish: aunque, dado que, o puesto caso o puesto caso que seaasiŸ (M)

mecahuītequ(i).English: to flagellate oneself; to beat s.o. with a whip
mecahuītequ(i).Spanish: azotarse a siŸ mismo (M), azotar a otro (M)

mecāniā.English: to hang oneself; to hang s.o.
mecāniā.Comment: Z has the sense of "to stumble, to trip" for thisverb.  The sense common to M and Z is "to be broughtup short by a rope".

mecānīlō.Comment: This is attested twice (Bf.11r), both times with thevowel of the third syllable marked short, although byregular derivational processes it should be long.

mecapal-li.English: tumpline, rig for carrying a load on the backsupported by a band across the forehead
mecapal-li.Spanish: mecapal, cordel para llevar carga a cuestas (M)

meca-tl.English: cord or rope, whip made of knotted cords, vine
meca-tl.Spanish: cordel o soga o azote de cordeles (M)

mecayō-tl.Comment: This is indirectly attested in MECA-TL.

meceyō-tl.Comment: M has mecellotl "maguey heart, crown before it hassprouted".

melactic.Comment: T also has MELAC as an internal component ofOHUAMELAC-TLI "long, whole stalk of cane".  There isa variant in T, MELAZTIC, which appears to besynonymous.

melāhu(a).English: to stretch oneself out on a surface; to straightens.t. out, to get directly to a point or destination.
melāhu(a).Spanish: tenderme en el suelo (M for first pers. sg. subject),enderezar alguna cosa tuerta, o exponer y declarar laescritura o lo que es dificultoso de entender (M),caminar derecho, pasando de largo sin detenerse enalguŸn lugar o enderezar alguna cosa tuerta (M)

melāhuac.Comment: C gives the phrase ca huel melahuac "it is verytrue".  The negation AHMŌ MELĀHUAC means "false".As variants of this, Z has MELĀUH, which has theform of the preterit of the verb MELĀHU(A), andMELĀN with N replacing the final -UH.

melāuhcāpōhu(a).Spanish: narrar, exponer algo fielmente, exactamente (S), loafirma, lo declara, lo explica, testifica (T)

melaztic.Spanish: derecho (se dice de palo, etc.), vertical, recto (T)

me-tl.English: century plant, maguey, member of the Agave family ofplants (most commonly those cultivated for theproduction of pulque and mezcal)
me-tl.Comment: T has the reduplicated form MEME-TL for cultivatedmaguey, presumably referring to a field of plants.

metlamā(i)-tl.English: stone rolling pin used to grind cornmeal on themetate
metlamā(i)-tl.Comment: A more common name for this is METLAPĪL-LI.

metlapīl-li.English: stone rolling pin used to grind cornmeal on themetate
metlapīl-li.Spanish: moledor con que muelen el maiŸz (M)

metlate-tl.English: type of stone used in making metates
metlate-tl.Comment: Z also has TEMETL(A)-TL with the same gloss.

metl(a)-tl.English: stone slab for grinding cornmeal, metate
metl(a)-tl.Spanish: piedra donde muelen el maiŸz, etc. (M), metate (T)

-metzācayō.Spanish: su tibia, su canilla, su espinilla (Z)

metzcamoh.Comment: The second element appears to be CAMOH-TLI "sweetpotato", but the sense would be obscure.

metzcopīn(i).English: for one's hip to become dislocated

metzcotoltic.Comment: This would seem to mean "s.o. lame by virtue ofhaving lost a leg".

metzcotōni.English: s.o. crippled by loss of a leg or foot

mētzcualo.Comment: T also has CUALOMĒTZ-TLI with the same sense.  Ifthe second element is the nonactive form of the verbCUĀ "to eat s.t.", the final vowel should bebasically long, but it is not long in the synonymousconstruction CUALOMĒTZ-TLI.

metzcuauhyoh.English: thigh, inner side of the leg
metzcuauhyoh.Spanish: el muslo o el largor de toda lo pierna (M)

metzihcatoc.Lexical Reference: see METZ-TLI, IHCA, the verb O

-metzīxco.Comment: This is a locative expression "at the sole of one'sfoot" and implies a noun METZĪX-TLI.

metzohohuicān.English: a road, path very hard on the legs, rocky anddifficult

-metztlampa.Comment: This is a locative construction rather than a nounand has the literal sense "to, from under one'sfoot".

mētz-tli.Comment: M combines the glosses of MĒTZ-TLI and METZ-TLI"thigh, leg" in a single entry.

metz-tli.Comment: M combines the glosses of METZ-TLI and MĒTZ-TLI"moon, month" in a single entry.

mētztōna.English: for the moon to be up and shining

mexcalā-tl.English: sap, juice of the maguey used as an unfermented drink
mexcalā-tl.Comment: In both attestations this is bound with -TZIN.

mexcalcohcohyoc.Comment: M has cocoyonenemi "to crawl on all fours", whichmay contain another instance of what is the secondelement here.

mexcalhuiā.English: to rub alcohol, mezcal on oneself; to rub mezcal ons.o.
mexcalhuiā.Spanish: se unta con alcohol (T), lo unta con alcohol (T)

mexcal-li.English: mezcal, distilled alcoholic drink made by cooking theheart of the maguey plant
mexcal-li.Spanish: cierta planta comestible de la clase de los magueyeso aŸloes de la cual se saca un licor fortiŸsimo (R),mezcal (T)
mexcal-li.Comment: T has MEZ for MEX and a long vowel in the secondsyllable in this and all derivations, probably byreceiving it from Spanish as a back loan andinterpreting the Spanish stressed syllable ascontaining a long vowel.  A possible derivation isfrom ME-TL "maguey" and (I)XCA "to bake s.t."Distilling was a late introduction, and the earliestattestation of this item among the sources for thisdictionary is R.

mēxihcayō-tl.English: the essence of Mexica community and culture
mēxihcayō-tl.Spanish: el imperio mexicano (C), el sen9orio de Mexico (C),la nobleza o republica de los Mexicanos (C), cosa deMeŸxico (C)

mēxihco.Comment: The etymology of this is opaque.  Because of thedifference in vowel length, it cannot be derived fromME-TL "maguey".  The sequence XIH also differs invowel length from XĪC-TLI "navel", which has beenproposed as a component element.  The final elementis locative -C(O).

mēy(a).Spanish: manar la fuente o cosa semejante (M)

mēyal-li.English: spring, fountain, place where s.t. comes gushingforth
mēyal-li.Comment: This is only attested as ĀMĒYAL-LI "water spring,water fountain".

miac.English: very much, many; the constellation Pleiades (byextension)
miac.Spanish: mucho en cantidad, o las siete cabrillas,constelacioŸn (M for miec)
miac.Comment: This varies greatly in form.  B, C, and R have MIEC,while Z and X have MIAC.  T has MEYAC.  M has bothmiac and miec.  The A is probably basic to theform, with MIEC the result of the prevalentvowel-raising that affects A in Nahuatl.  Because theyare stem-internal, it cannot be determined if there isa segmental Y between the I and the A.  T has thereflex of a long vowel in the plural suffix -TIN withthis item, as B, C, and T do with MOCH(I) and C doeswith ĪZQUI.

miaquiliā.English: to increase, multiply; to augment, multiply s.t.
miaquiliā.Spanish: se aumenta, multiplica, produce (T), lo aumenta, lomultiplica (T)
miaquiliā.Comment: This has the same sense as MIACTILIĀ.

miccā-.Comment: This has two sources.  It is the compounding form ofthe derived noun MICQUI "corpse, dead person", and italso arises directly from the verb MIQU(I) "to die"followed by the -CĀ- ligature.

miccācāhu(a).Comment: Z idiosyncratically raises the Ā to Ē.

miccācāhual-li.Comment: The literal sense of this is "s.o. left behind bys.o. who has died".  Z also has a variant in whichthe vowel of the second syllable is idiosyncraticallyraised to Ē.

miccāchīhu(a).Comment: Z idiosyncratically raises Ā to Ē.

miccācoyoc-tli.Comment: Z also has a variant in which the second vowel isidiosyncratically raised to Ē.

miccātēca.English: to be stunned, dazed, unconscious; to daze, stun s.o.
miccātēca.Spanish: se priva, estaŸ inconsciente (T), lo priva (T)

miccātlatlaxiz-tli.Comment: Z has a variant with the Ā idiosyncratically raisedto Ē.

miccātlatzilīn(i).English: for the bell for the dead to toll
miccātlatzilīn(i).Spanish: repica la campana para el muerto (T)

miccātōnahuiz-tli.Comment: Z idiosyncratically raises Ā to Ē.

miccātzontecom(a)-tl.Comment: Z idiosyncratically raises Ā to Ē.

miccāxōchi-tl.Comment: This is a translation from Spanish.  The indigenousname for the large native marigold associated withprecolumbian rituals and today specifically with AllSouls Day is CEMPŌHUALXŌCHI-TL.  Zidiosyncratically raises Ā to Ē.

miccāyehyecoā.Comment: The literal sense of this is "to sample death".  Talso has MIQUILIZYEHYECOĀ "to have a brush withdeath".

-micecuil.Comment: One of these attestations reduplicates the initialsyllable.

michhuah.English: possessor of fish, person from Michoacan
michhuah.Spanish: duen9o de pescado (C), natural de MichoacaŸn (C)

mich-in.Comment: This is commonly reanalyzed so that the stem is takento be MICHI or MICHIN.  X has the plural formMICHIMEH, but in X this is the general way in whichstems that take the -IN absolutive suffix form theirplurals.

michpah-tli.Comment: The literal sense of this, "fish potion", refers toits use in fishing, the leaves having a narcoticeffect rendering the fish easier prey.

michtlahzol-li.English: small fresh water fish abundant in Michoacan
michtlahzol-li.Comment: Despite the literal sense of its name "trash fish",this fish is caught and dried and is important to thelocal economy.  T has lost the glottal stop.

micohua.Comment: C has the O before -HUA marked long twice.

micohuani.Spanish: cosa mortiŸfera o ponzon9osa (M), instrumento paramorir (C)

micohuayān.Comment: C marks the O long in the single attestation.

micqui.Comment: Since in texts the medial geminate is often writtenas though there were only a single consonant, nominalMICQUI is often confused with the verb MIQU(I).

mictiā.English: to commit suicide, to mistreat oneself; to kill orinjure s.o.
mictiā.Spanish: matar o maltratar a siŸ mismo (M), matar o maltratara otro (M)
mictiā.Comment: M provides additional glosses of "to be unable toprocreate" and "to engage in blood sacrifice" forthis with the object prefix TLA-.  M also has anopaque gloss of the reflexive as "to choose thebest".

mictlāncayō-tl.English: s.t. pertaining to the realm of the dead
mictlāncayō-tl.Comment: C also gives the synonymous short formMICTLĀNYŌ-TL.

mictlān-tli.Spanish: infierno o en el infierno o al infierno (M),infierno, purgatorio (T)
mictlān-tli.Comment: This is consistently attested across sources with along vowel in the second syllable.  M gives it bothwith and without the absolutive suffix.  It is morecommon without and does not take the suffix when usedas a locative expression.

mictlānyō-tl.English: s.t. pertaining to the realm of the dead
mictlānyō-tl.Comment: C gives this as synonymous with MICTLĀNCAYŌ-TL.

mihmiloā.Spanish: trastornar o derrocar caŸntaro o cosa semejante (M),lo vierte, lo derrama (T)
mihmiloā.Comment: This contrasts with MĪMILOĀ "to trample about" andMIMILOĀ "to revolve, turn s.t."  Z has a formCOCHMIHMIL "sleepyhead", which may be derived fromthis.  In both attestations of the verb in Z theinternal glottal stop is omitted.

mihtōtiāni.Comment: Z glosses this as "dance" rather than "dancer", butfrom a derivational viewpoint, M's gloss is thecorrect one.

mīhuah.Spanish: $el que tiene flechas, el duen9o de las flechas)

mīllah.English: place where there is an abundance of cultivated land

mīllahca-tl.Comment: R fails to indicate the glottal stop, but it isattested in C.

mīltepān-tli.English: boundary, landmark, wall separating sections ofcultivated land
mīltepān-tli.Spanish: linde entre heredades de muchos (M), la sen9al queindica las secciones de la milpa (T)

mīltiā.English: to prepare a cultivated field for oneself
mīltiā.Spanish: hago sementera para miŸ (C for first pers. sg. subject)

mīmiac.Comment: T attests this reduplicated form with a plural sense(p.141).

mimilahu(i).Comment: Z consistently marks the vowel of the third syllablelong, but it should not be.  This appears to be acharacteristic case of Z representing a stressedsyllable with a long vowel.

mimilihu(i).English: to round out or swell, to unroll or unfold
mimilihu(i).Spanish: abotonarse la flor o crecer el vientre de la queestaŸ pren9ada (M), rodar (X)

mimilīn(i).Comment: This form should have long-vowel reduplication orvowel and glottal stop reduplication, but theattestations indicate neither.

mimiloā.English: to roll over and over; to roll or revolve s.t.
mimiloā.Spanish: rodar por el suelo (M), lo rueda (T)
mimiloā.Comment: C contrasts this with MĪMILOĀ "to trample about".They both contrast with MIHMILOĀ "to spill s.t."  Mcombines the reflexive glosses of MIMILOĀ andMĪMILOĀ in a single entry.

mīmiloā.Comment: C contrasts this with MIMILOĀ "to roll over andover; to roll s.t.". They both contrast withMIHMILOĀ "to spill s.t."

mimite-tl.Comment: T has this and also -MICECUIL = -MIMICECUIL =-MIMICECUILYŌ "rib".  These latter all correspondto OMICICUIL-LI, which is derived from OMI-TL "bone".Here too T has lost the initial vowel of OMI-TL andperforms reduplication on the resulting form.

mimiyāhuatzin.English: a type of brightly colored bird
mimiyāhuatzin.Comment: M has mimiauatl for a type of honeycomb and the beethat makes it.  In both attestations Z has the vowelof the fourth syllable marked long instead of thevowel of the third.  The derivation is questionable.

mīn(a).English: to shoot arrows, to pierce s.o. with arrows
mīn(a).Spanish: tirar saeta o garrocha (M), asaetar a alguno (M)
mīn(a).Comment: The variant MĪN(I) is abundantly attested in T.

mīn(i).Spanish: le quema (el sol), le pica (abeja, etc.) (T)
mīn(i).Comment: This is abundantly attested in T.  The preterit isMĪN, not MĪNIC, but T's nonactive form consistentlyhas the reflex of a long vowel in the secondsyllable.  This is a variant of MĪN(A).

mīnilō.Comment: By general rule the vowel of the second syllableshould be short, but T consistently has the reflex ofa long vowel.

miqu(i).Comment: There are a number of verbs built on MIQU(I) which donot have the literal sense of "to die", but rather"to suffer", such as ĀPĪZMIQU(I) "to be hungry",CECMIQU(I) "to suffer from cold".  Other verbs withMIQU(I) as second element are even further removedfrom the literal sense of "to die", TĒMIQU(I) "todream".

miquiliz-tli.Comment: The short form MIQUIZ-TLI is more common, but this isabundantly attested across sources.

miquilizyehyecoā.English: to have a brush with death
miquilizyehyecoā.Comment: T also has MICCĀYEHYECOĀ "to be in terminalagony".

miquizcuahu(i)-tl.Comment: This tree is believed to be poisonous to people andanimals.

miquiz-tli.Comment: X glosses this as "corpse", which is more appropriateto MICQUI.

mī-tl.Comment: This is also abundantly attested in the verbs MĪN(A)and MĪN(I) "to prick, pierce s.t."

mīxcuepani.Comment: This specifically refers to someone other than oneself.Presumably it could also take first person prefixes, butit is not attested with them.

mixhuāqu(i).English: for fog or clouds to lift
mixhuāqu(i).Spanish: se levanta la neblina (Z for preterit form)

mīxihu(i).Spanish: parir la mujer (M), le da a luz, pare su hijo (T)
mīxihu(i).Comment: In T and X this is a transitive verb, but in Mand C it is intransitive.

mīxīhuiā.English: to use an intoxicating herb, to get drunk
mīxīhuiā.Comment: This is conventionally paired with TLĀPĀHUIĀ, thewhole phrase meaning "to become intoxicated".  Thisverb contrasts with intransitive MĪXIHU(I) "to givebirth" both in the final syllable and in beingreflexive.

mīxī-tl.Comment: C gives the vowel of the second syllable long.According to S, the possessed form is -MĪX, but thisis unlikely, since long stem-final vowels do notdrop.  This is conventionally used in the phrase INMĪXĪ-TL, IN TLĀPĀ-TL "intoxication".

mixmolōn(i).Spanish: se levantan las nubes atraŸs de los cerros, estaŸnublado (T)

mixtēm(i).Comment: Z treats this as a transitive verb and prefixes itwith TLA-.

mixteteica.Comment: The literal sense of this is for a cloud to getground up, chewed up.

mixtlayohua.English: to be dark because of heavy clouds
mixtlayohua.Spanish: medio se obscurece por estar muy nublado (T)

mix-tli.Comment: T has the variant form MEX-TLI.

miyāhuapah-tli.English: a parasitic plant used to stimulate the appetite
miyāhuapah-tli.Comment: R fails to mark the vowel of the second syllablelong.

miyāhuati.English: for a cornstalk to produce tassels and flowers
miyāhuati.Spanish: echar espiga y flor la can9a del maiŸz (M)
miyāhuati.Comment: In one of the attestations C has a glottal stopbefore verbal -TI, but since the noun stem ends in avowel, this is probably an error.

miyāhua-tl.English: the tassel and flower of maize
miyāhua-tl.Spanish: la espiga y la flor de la can9a de maiŸz (M)
miyāhua-tl.Comment: B attests this once with the vowel of the secondsyllable specifically marked short.  Because thesequence is stem-internal and unalternating, it isimpossible to determine whether this is MIYĀ orMIĀ.

mizqui-tl.Spanish: aŸrbol de goma para tinta (M), mesquite (T)
mizqui-tl.Comment: X marks the vowel of this long, while T reduplicatesit to yield MĪMIZQUI-TL.

miz-tli.English: The diminutive of this, MIZTŌN, is used for thedomestic cat.

mō.Grammar: particle which combines with negative particles toform AHMŌ "no,not", AOCMŌ "no longer", AYAMŌ"not yet", etc.
mō.Comment: MŌ can serve as a negative particle on its own inquestions expressing doubt; in such a context MŌ issynonymous with AHMŌ, and MŌNEL is synonymous withAHMŌ NEL (Cf.121v).

mo-.Comment: Possessive MO- and reflexive MO- are homophonous, butthe former binds with nominals, and the latter bindswith verbals.

moān(a).Comment: T gives the variant MĀN(A).  This appears to beĀN(A) used reflexively, which in M is glossed as "togrow in bodily size".

mocāhu(a).Spanish: cesar de llover, o de llorar, o de hacer algo (M)
mocāhu(a).Comment: This reflexive use of CĀHU(A) has become lexicalizedand is commonly used only in the third personsingular.

mocēloquich-tli.Comment: This is attested only in the vocative, and evenin the plural vocative the possessive prefix remainsMO-.  This suggests a lexicalization of MOCĒL- as"peerless".

mochahchamāhuani.Spanish: el que se jacta y alaba (M), arrogante, orgulloso (T)
mochahchamāhuani.Comment: This is specifically non-first person.  Presumably itcould also take first person prefixes.

mocheh.English: all of s.t. not named but understood

moch(i).Comment: M lists this under muchi, but the initial vowel isnot long.  The plural suffix with this item, as withMIAC and ĪZQUI is attested as -TĪN rather than-TIN, in this case in B, C, and T.  T, Z, and X haveNOCH(I) for MOCH(I), as do many communitiesperipheral to the central dialect area.  X uses theplural suffix -MEH with NOCH(I).

mochīhu(a).Comment: This is the non-first person reflexive form of theverb CHĪHU(A) "to make or do s.t."

-mochīhuayān.English: proper time or place for s.t. to come about, as forfruit trees to bear fruit
-mochīhuayān.Spanish: tiempo o lugar ... donde o cuando se da (C)
-mochīhuayān.Comment: C also has the shorter form -MOCHĪUHYĀN with thesame sense.

mochipa.Comment: T and Z have NOCHIPA with the same sense.

-mochīuhyān.English: the proper time for s.t. to come about

mocuihcuīliāni.English: s.o. who makes another entreat him, s.o. whoresists
mocuihcuīliāni.Spanish: el que se hace de rogar o el que resiste (M)

mocuihcuīlihqui.English: s.o. who makes another entreat him, s.o. whoresists
mocuihcuīlihqui.Spanish: el que se hace de rogar o el que resiste (M)

mohcihuiā.English: to suffer, agonize, be troubled; to bother, upsets.o.
mohcihuiā.Spanish: congojarse, trafagar o agonizar (M), se molesta, sefastidia (T), ser importuno o desasosegar a otro (M)
mohcihuiā.Comment: T has lost the internal glottal stop.

mohmōtla.English: to stone s.o., to throw rocks at s.o.

mohmotzaltic.Comment: Related forms in T and C lack the internal glottalstop.

mohmoxtic.Comment: The related verbs MOMOXTIYA and MOMOTZOĀ lack theinternal glottal stop.

mohmoyāhu(i).English: to emit air or fluid, to deflate

mōla.English: to get ground up; to grind s.t.
mōla.Spanish: se muele (chile, tomate, etc.) (T), lo muele (chile,tomate, etc.) (T)

mōlca-tl.English: secondary ear of maize that remains small and doesnot develop fully
mōlca-tl.Comment: In one attestation the vowel of the second syllableis marked long.

mōlēhu(a).English: to root about in the ground, to break up soil
mōlēhu(a).Comment: Neither attestation has the first vowel marked long.This is attested only with the object prefix TLA-,which may be fused to the stem.

molic-tli.Spanish: codo (M), su codo (parte del cuerpo) (Z), codo(medida) (Z)
molic-tli.Comment: Z has a long vowel in the first syllable, but Bspecifically marks it short, and it is also short inMOLICPI-TL.  Z has extended this to mean a unit oflength measurement on the model of Spanish codo.

molōn(i).English: to waft, to rise and drift on air currents, toeffervesce
molōn(i).Spanish: manar la fuente o cosa asiŸ o levantarse muchasnubes, o levantarse con el aire las plumas, oextenderse o oler mucho los perfumes o olores suaves(M)

molōniā.English: to lighten s.t. or to fill s.t. with air byboiling, carding, tilling, etc.
molōniā.Spanish: mullir lana o pluma (M), labra (tierra), hocica,escarba (T for reduplicated form), lo hierva (T)
molōniā.Comment: This is abundantly attested, but only in T.

momaca.Comment: This is a lexicalized use of the reflexive of MACA"to give".

momat(i).English: it appears, it is thought, it happens that
momat(i).Spanish: se halla, se engriŸe, se acostumbra, se impone (T)
momat(i).Comment: This is a lexicalized use of the third personreflexive form of MAT(I) "to know s.t."  The firstperson reflexive is also lexicalized and means "itseems (to me) that ..."

momoloca.English: to bubble up, to waft up on air currents
momoloca.Spanish: burbujear el agua, o levantarse gran polvo de cosassecas y livianas asiŸ como harina, cal, o de cosassemejantes (M)

momolotz(a).Spanish: hacer espuma en el agua, meneaŸndola (M), levantar... polvo (C)

momotzalhuiā.English: to pluck, clean feathers or s.t. of the sort
momotzalhuiā.Spanish: rozar o repelar pluma o cosa semejante (M), mesar aotro (C)

momotzoā.English: to scrape, scratch oneself; to scrape, scratch orpluck s.t. or s.o.
momotzoā.Spanish: rasgun9arse o rascarse (M), rasgun9ar o rascar a otro(M), rozar o coger yerbas sin arrancarlas (C)

momoxtiya.English: to come apart, to get tattered
momoxtiya.Comment: Z also has MOHMOXTIC "s.t. torn, tattered" with aninternal glottal stop.

momoyoca.Comment: This is only attested in YACAMOMOYOCA "for one's noseto itch" in T.

mōmōztlaeh.Comment: T omits the final -EH; Z has it unreduplicated asMŌZTLAH.

-monecyān.English: the proper time or place for s.t.
-monecyān.Comment: This is a short form of -MONEQUIYĀN.

mōnel.Comment: MŌNEL is synonymous with AHMŌ NEL.

monequ(i).English: to be necessary or wanting, to be useful
monequ(i).Spanish: es necesario, se necesita (Z), serme uŸtil,ventajoso, usarse en provecho miŸo, hablando de unacosa (S for construction with NOTECH)
monequ(i).Comment: The person or thing experiencing lack or need isexpressed with -TECH in construction with thislexicalized use of the reflexive of the verb NEQU(I)"to want s.t."  In Z the negation AHMŌ MONEQU(I) isglossed as "it does not matter".
