M glossesmonequi.atle notech as "to live in poverty", butatle monectoc "for there to be an abundance ofwhatever is necessary".

monequini.Comment: T also has MONECQUI with the same sense.  M hasMONEQUINI with its more literal sense of "s.t.necessary".

-monequiyān.English: the proper time or place for s.t.
-monequiyān.Comment: C also has the short form -MONECYĀN.

mōntah-tli.Spanish: suegro, padre de la mujer casada (M)

mōntiā.English: to take a father-in-law by marrying his daughter, fora prospective son-in-law to do work in the householdof the father of the bride
mōntiā.Spanish: tomar yerno casando su hija (M), estaŸ sirviendo denovio (trabaja dos meses en la casa del suegro) (T)
mōntiā.Comment: All attestations are in complex progressive form.

mōntīltiā.Comment: T has a long vowel in the second syllable, althoughby general rule it should be short.

mōn-tli.Comment: In general MŌN carries the sense of "related bymarriage".  CIHUĀMŌN-TLI is "daughter-in-law",MŌNNĀN-TLI "mother-in-law", and MŌNTAH-TLI"father-in-law".  T has the reflex of a short vowelin this item, but in C and Z it is long.  M providesan additional gloss "mousetrap", which probablybelongs to a different lexical item which is notattested in the sources for this dictionary.

-mopiloāyān.English: place where s.t. hangs, gathers, or looms
-mopiloāyān.Spanish: lugar donde se arman los aguaceros (C referring incontext to rain)

mopītznequi.Spanish: un nin9o berrinchudo, se enoja pronto (T)

-motēcayān.English: place where s.t. spreads itself out on a surface
-motēcayān.Spanish: lugar donde el aguacero descarga y cae (C referringin context to rain)
-motēcayān.Comment: R glosses this as "place where rain clouds form",which is the gloss C provides for -MOPILOĀYĀN.

motēcuitlahuiāni.Comment: C contrasts this with MOTLACUITLAHUIĀNI "guardian ofs.t."

motēuczōma.Comment: Because word-final vowels are subjected toshortening, and because this is not attested insuffixed or compounded form, the basic length of thefinal vowel cannot be determined.

mōtla.English: to stone s.o., to throw a rock at s.o. or s.t., tohunt s.t.
mōtla.Spanish: dar pedrada a otro (M), tirar con piedra (M), caza(Z)

motlacuitlahuiāni.Spanish: el que cuida de algo (C), hombre cuidadoso (M)
motlacuitlahuiāni.Comment: C contrasts this with MOTĒCUITLAHUIĀNI "guardian ofs.o."

motta.Comment: Two of the attestations in Z have a long vowel in thefirst syllable, but it should be short, since this isthe reflexive form of (I)TTA.  AHMŌ MOTTA has thesense "to be invisible, hidden".

mottitiā.English: to see s.t. in a dream
mottitiā.Spanish: lo revela (lo ve en un suen9o) (T)
mottitiā.Comment: The reflexive prefix MO- has been absorbed into thestem, so this receives a second MO- when usedhonorifically.

motzolihu(i).Comment: M has motzoloa to hold on to s.o., to grapple withs.o."

moyāhu(a).English: to disseminate or disperse s.t., to deflate s.t.
moyāhu(a).Spanish: echar fama de algo, o enturbiar el agua (M),desbaratar o hacer alzar el cerco a los enemigos oahuyentar gente o ganado (M), enturbiar el agua ootra cosa liŸquida (M), lo deshincha (T)

moyōlēhuani.Comment: M has moyoleuhqui "s.o. in love, s.o. driven byinternal motivation".

moyōn(i).Spanish: brullir las hormigas, gusanos o cosa semejante (M)
moyōn(i).Comment: This appears to be related to MŌYŌ-TL "mosquito,flying insect", but there is a vowel lengthdiscrepancy in the first syllable.

mōzō-tl.English: plant that produces indigo dye and from which anantidysentery medicine is made

mōztla.Comment: This is conventionally paired with HUĪPTLA "dayafter tomorrow", the sense of the phrase being "inthe future, from this day forward".

mōztlati.English: to see another day, to survive until tomorrow

mōztlatica.English: the following day, in the future
mōztlatica.Spanish: el diŸa siguiente, el diŸa proŸximo, en el futuro (T)
mōztlatica.Comment: Z has a shortened form MŌZTICA, which is onlyattested in possessed form.

-mōztlayōc.Comment: All attestations are in possessed form.  Inconstruction with preceding OC, this means "the daybefore s.t."

nacaceh.Spanish: que tiene orejas, aŸngulos (S), jarro de dos asas,pero no redondas (C for NECOC NACACEH)
nacaceh.Comment: This combines with ĪX-TLI "eye" to form the phraseNACACEH ĪXEH "s.o. prudent", literally "s.o. withears and eyes".  It is also attested in P, where theglottal stop is marked but not the long vowel.

nacacic.Comment: This is attested in Z's NACACICAHUĪCA and T'sNACACICATĒCA.  In M it appears as an initial elementof seven different entries, although it does notappear independently.  Since this is not derived froma verb, it is probably a locative construction basedon a stem form *NACACI rather than NACAZ.

nacacicahuīca.English: to make s.t. get out of line, to carry s.t. on itsside
nacacicahuīca.Spanish: lo desploma ... lo lleva de lado (Z)

nacacicatēca.English: to sleep on one's side; to lay s.t. down on its side
nacacicatēca.Spanish: duerme del lado (T), lo acuesta de lado (T)

nacacitta.English: to gaze upon s.o. with affection, to cast s.o. asidelong glance
nacacitta.Spanish: mirar a otro con aficioŸn (M), lo ve del lado (T)

nacacuā.Comment: M has nacaqualizpan "period during which one mayeat meat", i.e. a nonfast day.

nacanamacac.Spanish: carnicero que pesa y vende carne (M)

nacaocuil-in.English: maggot or cataract of the eye

nacatamal-li.Spanish: empanada de carne o cosa semejante (M)

nac(a)-tl.Comment: The inalienably possessed form means "one's ownflesh, one's body".

nacayoh.English: s.t., s.o. fleshy, of flesh and blood, incarnate
nacayoh.Spanish: cosa carnuda y gorda (M), cosa o persona que tienecarne en siŸ (C)

-nacayohcāpoh.English: sharing flesh and blood with another, a human beinglike oneself
-nacayohcāpoh.Spanish: el que tiene cuerpo como yo (C for first personpossessor)

nacayōtiā.English: to assume flesh, to grow fat; to give s.o. a fleshlyform, to fatten animals
nacayōtiā.Spanish: encarnar o pararse gordo (M), cebar o engordar aves opuercos, etc. (M)
nacayōtiā.Comment: M also gives this as a double object verb with adirect object and an oblique reflexive prefix andmeaning "to get used to s.t."

nacayō-tl.Spanish: cosa que pertence a la carne (M)
nacayō-tl.Comment: In the sources for this dictionary all instances of-NACAYŌ are instances of the inalienably possessedform of NAC(A)-TL, but this is indirectly attested inthe derived verb NACAYŌTIĀ.

nacazcōlō-tl.English: divi-divi, a tree that produces curved podsresembling a scorpion's tail which are high in tannicacid and used for making black dye (Caesalpiniacoriacea)

nacazcotoctic.English: s.t., s.o. with a cropped ear

-nacazcoyoc.Comment: M has the necessarily possessed locative formnacazco "in one's ears".

nacazcoyōniā.English: for one's ear to get pierced; to pierce s.o.'s ear
nacazcoyōniā.Spanish: se agujera la oreja (T), le agujera la oreja (T)

nacazcuihcuitl(a)-tl.Comment: The single attestation in Z has CHI for the thirdsyllable instead of CUIH.

nacazmahu(i).English: to live in fear with one's ears cocked
nacazmahu(i).Spanish: tienen temores (y) sobresaltos (C for third personplural subject)

nacazpachōntic.English: s.o., s.t. shaggy, with a great deal of hair on thehead
nacazpachōntic.Spanish: mechudo, le crece mucho el pelo (T)

nacaztepoltic.English: s.t., s.o. with a cropped ear

nacazte-tl.Comment: Although this does not occur as a free form, it is anelement in a number of entries in M having to do withthe ear.

nacaztitīca.Comment: One of the attestations is missing the Z.  M hasreflexive nacastititza "to have a buzzing in theears".

-nacaztlan.Spanish: junto a eŸl, a lado de, proximidad (Z)

nacaztzatza.Comment: In one attestation Z gives this with a preteritsuffix, although the gloss does not suggest that itis a verb, and M's verb tzatzati "to go deaf" isderived from the noun TZATZA.

nahnaltic.Spanish: habla de ronco, con voz ronca (T)

*nāhua-.Comment: This element enters into many derivations withdivergent meanings.  The basic sense appears to be"audible, intelligible, clear", from which differentderivations extend to "within earshot, near","incantation" (hence many things to do with spellsand sorcery), and "language".

-nāhuac.Spanish: par de miŸ o conmigo (M for first pers. sg. possessor)

nāhuahtequ(i).English: to hug oneself, to embrace s.o.
nāhuahtequ(i).Spanish: abrazar a siŸ mismo (M), abrazar a otro (M)
nāhuahtequ(i).Comment: The attested final consonant of the second syllableis ambiguous in T between glottal stop and thereduction of some other consonant before T.Conceivably this should be NĀHUACTEQU(I).

nāhualahci.English: to take s.o. by surprise, stealth

nāhualhuiā.English: to put a spell on s.o.

nāhualiz-tli.Comment: X marks the vowel of the second syllable long insteadof the first.

nāhual-li.English: sorcerer, one who uses spells and incantations

nāhuallō-tl.Spanish: nigromancia o cosa semejante (M), brujeriŸa, maŸgico(Z)

nāhualpoloā.English: to go into danger unwittingly; to lure s.o. intodanger
nāhualpoloā.Spanish: vas a la muerte sin saber lo que haces (C for secondpers. singular subject), llevar con cautela a otro aalguŸn lugar peligroso, para hacerle mal (M)

nāhuaqueh.English: the one that is close to all things, god
nāhuaqueh.Spanish: con quien estaŸ el ser de todas las cosas, dios (M),nombre que se da a Dios, y significa aquel en quienestaŸn todas las cosas; se usa ordinariamente con elTloque, que expresa casi lo mismo (R)
nāhuaqueh.Comment: This is conventionally paired with TLOQUEH < -TLOC,which also has the sense of vicinity, the wholephrase being an epithet for divine presence.

nāhuat(i).English: to speak clearly, to make a clear sound, to answer orrespond
nāhuat(i).Spanish: hablar alto o tener buen sonido la campana o cosaasiŸ (M), responde, contesta (T)

nahuatiā.Spanish: mandar algo a otros, o pedir licencia o darla parahacer algo, o para ir a alguna parte, o citar a otro,o despedir y echar los criados de casa, o despedirsede algunos el que quiere partirse para alguŸn lugar(M)
nahuatiā.Comment: Although this would appear to be related toNĀHUAT(I) "to speak clearly", it is attested with along vowel in the first syllable only in X.Elsewhere, across sources, it is nowhere marked long.In T, NĀHUAT(I) has the reflex of a long vowel inthe first syllable, and NAHUATIĀ a short one.  Thisis attested twice in C, three times in X, andabundantly in T and Z.

nāhua-tl.English: s.t. that makes an agreeable sound, s.o. who speakswell or speaks one's own language
nāhua-tl.Spanish: cosa que suena bien, asiŸ como campana, etc., ohombre ladino (M)
nāhua-tl.Comment: This is not attested as a free form in the sourcesfor this dictionary.  As a language name the compoundNĀHUATLAHTŌL-LI is attested rather than simpleNĀHUA-TL.

nāhuatlācah.Spanish: nombre que se dioŸ a las naciones cultas que hablabanla lengua mexicana (R)

nāhuatlahtalhuiā.English: to serve as interpreter for s.o.
nāhuatlahtalhuiā.Spanish: ser nahuatlato o inteŸrprete de otro (M)

nāhuatlahtoā.Spanish: tener oficio de faraute (M), hago oficio deinteŸrprete (C for first pers. sg. subject)

nāhu(i).Comment: M glosses naui as "four or my aunt", the secondpart of the gloss being the first pers. sg. possessedform of ĀHUI-TL "aunt".

-nāl.English: across, through, to the other side
-nāl.Comment: This is nearly exclusively restricted to compositionswith Ā-TL "water"; ĀNĀL = ĀNĀLCO "across thewater, on the other side of the river".  In Z, ĀNĀLsimply means "on the other side", and to convey thesense of "across water" ĀNĀL is further compoundedwith Ā-TL to yield ĀNĀLĀ-TL.

nāl-.Comment: This is the initial element of a number of verbshaving to do with crossing, travelling through, andbeing at a distance.

nālcaqu(i).English: to hear s.t. from a distance
nālcaqu(i).Spanish: lo estaŸ oyendo de afuera o de lejos (Z forconstruction with the verb O)

nālīxahci.English: to recognize s.o. from a distance

nālpanohua.English: to cross to the other side

nālquīz(a).English: for s.t. to be traversed, penetrated, torn in half
nālquīz(a).Spanish: traspasarse o penetrarse alguna cosa (C), se rompe delado a lado (Z)
nālquīz(a).Comment: In M this is compounded to other verbs with theligature -CĀ- to convey the sense of "entirely,thoroughly".

nāltlachiy(a).Comment: M has the longer form nalquizcatlachia "to seecompletely, to observe, to take notice".  In bothattestations in Z, CHIY(A) has been reduced to CHA,once with the vowel marked long.

nāltoctic.Comment: M has naltonac with the same sense.

nāltōna.Spanish: hacer claro por todas partes (M), estar traspasado deluz y trasparente (C)

namaca.Comment: This verb commonly incorporates objects, yieldingsuch constructions as OCNAMACA "to sell pulque",ĒLŌNAMACA "to sell corn", etc.

namaquiltiā.Comment: T consistently has a long vowel in the thirdsyllable, although by general rule it should not belong.  C and R do not mark it long.

nāmictiā.English: to get married, to come together with s.o. for somepurpose; to marry s.o. off, to join two thingstogether or to even things off
nāmictiā.Spanish: casarse (M), casar a otro (M), contender o tenerbragas con otro (M), juntar o igualar una cosa conotra o declarar suen9os (M)

nāmictīl-li.Comment: X fails to mark the vowel of the third syllable long.

nāmiqueh.Comment: M has a separate entry for namiqueque "spouses",the regular plural of this.

nāmiqu(i).English: to go to meet s.o. or find s.t., to have aconfrontation or to incur a penalty under the law
nāmiqu(i).Spanish: salir a recibir al que viene, o encontrar con alguno,o contender con otros (M), incurrir en pena puestapor la ley (M)

nāmiquiltiā.English: to make s.t. even, equal with s.t. else
nāmiquiltiā.Spanish: aparear e igualar una cosa con otra (C)

nāmoyā.Comment: C gives an applicative form of this with the vowel ofthe third syllable marked long.

nanac(a)-tl.Comment: This is attested in all sources except B.  Z has thevowel of the first syllable long, but C specificallymarks it short.  R has this as NAHNAC(A)-TL.

nānāhuacoco-tl.Comment: Although this looks like a reduplicated form ofNĀHUALCOCO-TL, which has the same gloss, there is noL in either attestation.  If this is insteadderivationally related to M's nanahuatl "bubo,swollen gland", then Z has confused two similar butdistinct items.

nanahuapah-tli.English: medicinal plant used to alleviate syphilis
nanahuapah-tli.Spanish: cierta planta medicinal, especialmente contra lagaŸlico (R)

nanahua-tl.Comment: This is attested without diacritics in R.

nānāhu(i).Comment: M has nanauin with the same sense.

nanalca.English: for various animals to make their characteristic lownoises, or to make a sound like a cracked bell orvessel
nanalca.Spanish: graznar el ansar, ladrar o regan9ar y grun9ir elperro o el puerco, o sonar aquebrada la campana o laolla (M)
nanalca.Comment: T has related NAHNALTIC with an internal glottalstop.  In two of three attestations in Z the vowel ofthe second syllable is marked long.

nānānquiliā.English: to respond to s.o.'s criticism with impatience; tooppose s.o.
nānānquiliā.Spanish: responder con impaciencia el que es reprehendido ocorregido (M), le opone, le hace oposicioŸn (T)

nanatzca.Comment: In both attestations Z has an intrusive O, NANATZOCA.

nanatzoā.English: to get fat; to bother s.o.
nanatzoā.Spanish: pararse gordo o engordarse (M), lo molesta (T)
nanatzoā.Comment: This may be related to NAC(A)-TL "flesh".

nānāuhte-tl.Spanish: de cuatro en cuatro, o a cada uno cuatro (M)
nānāuhte-tl.Comment: This attestation is affixed with the diminutive-TZIN, and T glosses it as poquito.

nānquiliā.English: to respond to s.o., to answer s.o.; to recite theresponses in a ceremony such as the Mass
nānquiliā.Spanish: responder o ayudar a misa o a otra cosa (M), lecontesta, le responde (T)

nāntēnēhu(a).English: to curse, swear; to curse s.o. by insulting his mother
nāntēnēhu(a).Spanish: mienta la autora de sus diŸas, mienta la madre (T),le mienta la madre (T)

nāntiā.English: to take s.o. as one's mother or godmother, or totake up residence
nāntiā.Spanish: tomar a alguna por madre o por madrina o avecindarse(M)

nān-tli.Comment: This can be used in the extended sense of"protector".  A tree planted to shade crops is calledNĀN-TLI, and the coral snake is called an"ant-mother", because it is believed to live in anthills and protect the insects.

nānyō-tl.Spanish: matriz generalmente (M), maternitas, oficio de madre(C)

nāpalhuiā.English: to carry s.t. in one's arms for s.o.
nāpalhuiā.Spanish: llevar algo en las manos o en los brazos para otro(M)
nāpalhuiā.Comment: P has this with NAH in place of NĀ.

nāpaloā.English: to carry s.t. in one's arms
nāpaloā.Spanish: tomar o llevar algo en los brazos (M)
nāpaloā.Comment: This is abundantly attested across sources.  P hasthis with NAH in in place of NĀ.

natzcuāltiā.Spanish: lo apresa, lo machuca, lo machaca (Z)

nāuhpa.Comment: The UHP sequence often assimilates to PP.

nāuhpōhuallahtōl-li.English: court of justice held every eighth day
nāuhpōhuallahtōl-li.Spanish: tribunal que celebraba audiencia cada ochenta diŸas(S)

nāuhpōhual-li.Comment: The UHP sequence often assimilates to PP.

nē.Comment: This is abundantly attested in T, Z, and X but not inthe older sources.

ne-.Comment: The nonactive form of reflexive verbs and nominalsderived from reflexive verbs take this prefix.  Forexample, NĀMICTIĀ used reflexively has the sense"to get married", and NENĀMICTILIZ-TLI "marriage" isa derived nominal, while the nonactive form isNENĀMICTĪLŌ "people get married".  NEHCALILIZ-TLI"battle, engagement" is derived from (I)HCAL(I) "toengage in skirmishing".  CĒHUIĀ used reflexivelyhas the sense "to rest", and -NECĒHUIĀYĀN means"s.o.'s resting place".

nēcah.Comment: This is a compound of the deictic particle NĒ andthe verb CĀ.  It appears to have been lexicalized tofunction as a demonstrative particle, but its pluralretains the verbal plural form of -CĀ, -CATEH.

-necāuhcā.Comment: M has unpossessed necauhcayotl with the same sense.

-necēhuiāyān.Spanish: lugar para descansar o de descanso (M forneceuiloyan)
-necēhuiāyān.Comment: M's form is derived from the nonactive form ofCĒHUIĀ "to rest", while B's derivation is from theactive form.

nechca.Comment: According to C, this points to a place in sight,albeit distant (f.89v).

nechicoā.English: to be collected; to collect s.t.
nechicoā.Spanish: se cobra (T), lo cobra (T), ayuntar o recoger algo(M)

nēc(i).English: to appear, to reveal oneself, to become visible
nēc(i).Spanish: parecer ante otros o descubrirme a los que no mehallaban (M)
nēc(i).Comment: Referring to money or assets, this means "to beproduced, gotten together".

necoc.English: on both sides, from or to one side and the other
necoc.Spanish: de ambas partes, o a una parte y a otra, o a un ladoy a otro (M)

necoccāmpa.Spanish: de ambas, o desde ambas, o hacia ambas partes (M)

necōni.English: s.t. that is necessary, beneficial, advantageous
necōni.Spanish: cosa que es menester y es provechosa (M), lo que esdigno de quererse y desearse (C)
necōni.Comment: Z postposes YA "already" and cliticizes it to this.

necpachoā.English: to rise above s.t., to exalt oneself; to place s.t.on top, to raise s.t. on high
necpachoā.Spanish: se enciman, se sobreponen (T), lo encima (T)
necpachoā.Comment: This shares some common meaning with MONECQUI andMONEQUINI "s.o. proud, arrogant", suggesting thatthe first element is derived from the verb NEQU(I)"to want s.t."

nectiā.English: to desire s.t. for oneself; to get s.o. to desires.t. to court s.o.
nectiā.Spanish: codiciar algo para siŸ (M), hacer querer algo a otro(M), requebrarse con alguna persona procurando ser deella codiciado (M)
nectiā.Comment: This takes both a direct object prefix and anindirect object or oblique reflexive prefix.

necuāātēquiliz-tli.Comment: The sequence ĀĀ is conventionally written with asingle letter.

necuilihu(i).Comment: This is only attested in CAMANECUILIHU(I) "to makegestures with the mouth".

necuiloā.English: to bow or bend; to bend or twist s.t., to engage incommerce
necuiloā.Spanish: se echueca (T), contratar, regatonear, o entortaralguna cosa (M)
necuiloā.Comment: With the nonspecific object prefix TLA- and inconstruction with -TECH, this means to make a loanwith interest to s.o. Z glosses the reflexive as "toget dislocated".

-necuitlahuīlōcā.English: the care with which one is looked after
-necuitlahuīlōcā.Spanish: el cuidado con que se cuida de mi (C for first personpossessor)
-necuitlahuīlōcā.Comment: This is derived from the nonactive form ofCUITLAHUIĀ "to care for, nurture s.o.".

necuitlahuīlōni.English: s.o. or s.t. deserving to be cared for
necuitlahuīlōni.Spanish: merecedor que se tenga del cuidado (M)

-neēllelquīxtiāya.English: that with which one entertains oneself
-neēllelquīxtiāya.Spanish: instrumento con que yo me recreo (C for first personpossessor)

neh.Comment: This is a freestanding pronoun, as contrasted withthe personal prefixes NI- "I" and NĒCH- "me".

nehcaliliz-tli.Comment: M also has the shorter form necaliztli with thesame sense.

nehhuā-tl.Grammar: first person singular pronoun, long form
nehhuā-tl.Comment: When this appears without the absolutive suffix, theĀ is subject to the general rule of word-finalshortening.  The sequence NEH, NEHHUĀ, NEHHUĀ-TLrepresents increasingly emphatic "I, me".

-nehhuiyān.Spanish: mi propia (cosa), de mi propio (S for first personsingular possessor)
-nehhuiyān.Comment: M also has the noun neuhyantli "s.t. personal,created of one's own will, voluntary".

nehhuiyānhuiā.English: to be the occasion or cause of s.t. happening tooneself
nehhuiyānhuiā.Spanish: sucederme algo dando yo la oracioŸn, o siendo yo lacausa (M for first pers. sg. subject), doy yo la causa alo que me sucede de mal (C for first pers. sg. subject)

nehmachyō-tl.Spanish: la prudencia, y el estar sobre aviso (C)

nehnectiā.English: to volunteer oneself, to meddle, to aspire to do s.t.one is not equipped for
nehnectiā.Spanish: se acomide, se entremete, pretende hacer una cosa(sin poder hacerlo bien) (T)

nehnecuil-li.Comment: This is only attested in ĪXTENEHNECUIL-LI "s.o.cross-eyed".  It implies NEHNECUILOĀ.

nehnecuiloā.Spanish: bambanearse a una parte y a otra (M)

nehnehnem(i).Spanish: pasearse por las calles, por las plazas, etc. (S)

nehnehuiliā.English: to equal s.t. else, to make things equal or pairedwith one another, to compare things
nehnehuiliā.Spanish: ser igual a otros (M), emparejar o igualar algunascosas o hacer comparacioŸn o concordancias de unascosas a otras (M)
nehnehuiliā.Comment: P also attests this with a glottal stop in the firstsyllable, while M has NĒNEHUILIĀ and T hasNENEHUILIĀ "to weight, consider, imagine s.t.",which is probably just this item with T'scharacteristic loss of glottal stop.

nehneloā.English: to stir s.t., to disorder things, to make a mess
nehneloā.Spanish: mezclar o revolver unas cosas con otras o desordenarlo bien ordenado (M)

nehnem(i).Comment: This is a reduplicated form of NEM(I), which in thefree form generally means "to live" but here and incompounds "to go about".

nehnemiliā.English: to mull s.t. over, to imitate or copy s.o., s.t.
nehnemiliā.Spanish: juzgar (Z for TLANEHNEMILIĀ), lo imita, lo remeda(Z)

nehnemiliz-tli.English: the act of walking about, travel
nehnemiliz-tli.Spanish: el acto de andar o caminar (M), viaje (R)

nehnemiltiā.Comment: By general derivational rules the vowel of the thirdsyllable should be short.  It is unmarked for lengthin C and long in T.

nehnenqui.English: walker, foot traveler, pilgrim, one who comes to afiesta from a distance
nehnenqui.Spanish: caminante (M), andariego, los invitados en la fiesta(T)

nehnequ(i).English: to pretend to be s.t. one is not, to try to pass fors.o. else; to get a craving for s.t., to becapricious
nehnequ(i).Spanish: hacerse de rogar, o contrahacer y arrendar a los deotra nacioŸn (M), antojaŸrseme algo, o ser tirano (Mfor first pers. sg. subject)
nehnequ(i).Comment: The reflexive form incorporates the name of what oneis posing as, NINOCOCOXCĀNEQUI "I pretend to be s.o.sick".

nehneuhcā.Comment: This is also attested in P with the glottal stopmarked.

nehneuhqui.English: s.t. equal, on par with, like another
nehneuhqui.Spanish: cosa igual o pareja, o cosa que es semejante a otra(M)
nehneuhqui.Comment: The attestaton is in the plural, for which M has aseparate entry with the gloss "equals, with respectto people or animals".  This also appears in P.

nehtōl-li.Comment: By general derivational rules the vowel of the secondsyllable should be long, but it is unmarked forlength in R.  In derived NEHTŌLTIĀ T has thereflex of a long vowel.

nehtōltiā.Spanish: hacer voto (M), prometer (R), se encomienda a lasimaŸgenes (T)
nehtōltiā.Comment: T has the reflex of a long vowel in the secondsyllable; the other sources do not mark the vowel forlength.

nehuān.Spanish: ambos a dos o juntamente ambos a dos (M)
nehuān.Comment: M gives as a separate entry the plural formneuantin.  T has a short vowel in the secondsyllable, but B and C mark it long.  This isgenerally, but not necessarily, possessed, ĪNNEHUĀN"the two of them".  The phrase NEHUĀN ĒHUAH appearsin C and M meaning "they are siblings".

nehuāntiliā.Comment: T has a short vowel in the second syllable, butNEHUĀN has a long syllable elsewhere.

nehuiltiā.Comment: An unattested verb *NEHUILIĀ underlies thereduplicated forms NEHNEHUILIĀ and NĒNEHUILIĀ,and this appears to be the causative form of it.

nehuiltiliz-tli.Comment: In both attestations Z marks the first vowel long.There should be an object prefix, but Z has atendency to drop them.  M has tlaneneuililiztli.

nēhuīn.Comment: Z gives this as synonymous with NĒPA.

neīxcuītīl-li.Spanish: dechado o ejemplo (M), sen9al, demostracioŸn, prueba,maravilla, milagro (Z)
neīxcuītīl-li.Comment: In Z the sequence NEĪX has been consolidated toNĒX.

nel.Comment: This is a particle that combines with the otherparticles and contributes the sense of "in truth,indeed", although in some lexicalized constructionsit appears to contribute no sense of its own at all.According to C, in conjunction with an interrogrativeparticle -NEL implies that there is no other choice(f.91r), but this does not seem to hold in all cases,CĀMPANEL "where in the world?" Among commonconstructions are AHNEL "isn't it so?", CANEL (NOZO)"because", CĀNNEL "where?", MĀNEL "however", MŌNEL"isn't it so?", NELNOZO = NOZONEL "how could it beotherwise?" and QUĒNNEL "how else?"

nelchīhu(a).Comment: This is implied by the applicative formNELCHĪHUILIĀ.  M gives it as a reflexive verb withthe sense of "to take s.t. from s.o. as a joke andthen keep it."

nelchīhuiliā.English: to demand s.t., to insist on s.t., to struggle fors.t.

nelhua-tl.Comment: Z has Ā in the first syllable in place of E.  Theinalienably possessed form is probably -NELHUAYŌ,but there are no unambiguous attestations.

nelhuayōtiā.English: to take root, settle down; to base a discourse on aparticular authority
nelhuayōtiā.Spanish: arraiga o echar raices (M), fundar platica o sermoŸnsobre alguna autoridad de escritura (M)

nelhuayō-tl.English: base, foundation, starting point, root or vein
nelhuayō-tl.Comment: This is an abstract derivation from NELHUA-TL "root",but apparently it can be used concretely and hencesynonymously with NELHUA-TL itself.  It is not clearwhether the possessed form attested in T is thesimple possessed form of this or the inalienablypossessed form of NELHUA-TL.  M also has nelhuayo,which represents NELHUAYOH "s.t. that has a root",which also appears in P.

nelhuiā.English: to stir up s.t., to disorder s.t., to make a mess ofs.t. for s.o.
nelhuiā.Spanish: remar a otro o mecerle y revolverle alguna cosa (M),agitar, sacudir a alguien, desordenarle, revolverlealguna cosa (S)

nelihu(i).Comment: This is only attested in the constructionPITZONELIHU(I) "to get dirty".  NELIHU(I) is theintransitive verb corresponding to transitive NELOĀ"to stir up s.t., to make a mess of s.t."

nel-li.Comment: In five attestations, B twice marks the E long,although other derivations from NEL-LI in B have thevowel specifically marked short.  It is abundantlyattested in C with no length marking at all.  T hasthe reflex of a short vowel, while Z consistently hasit long.  This often occurs in the phrase HUEL NEL-LI"s.t. very true and certain, s.t. genuine".

nelnozo.Comment: This is attested four times in C and NOZONEL, withthe elements in reverse order, three times.  All areon Cf.91r with no gloss.  It should probably betreated as a phrase composed of NEL and NOZO inoptional order with a sense of "how could it beotherwise?"

neloā.English: to get mixed together; to stir up s.t., to beat s.t.,to make a mess of s.t.
neloā.Spanish: se revuelve, se mezcla (T), remar, mecer, o batiralgo (M)

nelōltiā.English: to get mixed together; to mix s.t.
nelōltiā.Spanish: se mezcla (T), lo revuelve, lo mezcla (T)
nelōltiā.Comment: On p.193 T gives the nonactive form of this verb asNELTĪLŌ, but this is clearly a typographical errorinvolving the omission of two letters.  The nonactiveform should be NELŌLTĪLŌ.

nelti.English: to prove true, to be verified, to be realized
nelti.Comment: C gives NELTIĀ with the same sense.

neltiā.English: to prove true, to be verified, to be realized
neltiā.Comment: C gives this as synonymous with NELTI.  S providesthe preterit form onelti.  If this is correct,assuming the vowel of the second syllable to beunmarked for length rather than specifically short,the future form neltiz on Cf.110v is ambiguousbetween the two.  On the other hand, a verb with theform NELTIĀ should be transitive.  B's NELTIY(A)would be the intransitive, and S's preterit form, onwhich this entry is based, may simply be an error.

neltic.Comment: This is only attested in the constructionsPITZONELTIC and MĀTZOCUITLANELTIC, both meaning"s.t. dirty".  It is related to NELIHU(I) "to getmessy" and NELOĀ "to make a mess of s.t."

neltiy(a).English: to prove true, to be verified, to be realized
neltiy(a).Comment: The single attestation is in preterit form.  C'sneltia, given as synonymous with NELTI, mayrepresent NELTIY(A) rather than NELTIĀ, in whichcase the future form neltiz on Cf.110v isunambiguously the future form of NELTI alone.  Sassumes that it represents NELTIĀ with the preteritform NELTIH.  If this were correct, then there arewould be three nearly synonymous verbal derivationsfrom NEL-LI "s.t. true, certain", namely NELTI,NELTIĀ, and NELTIY(A), each with a differentparadigm, but NELTIĀ is questionable.

neltlanahu(i).English: to be in a bad way, to be gravely ill

neltoca.English: to hold a belief; to believe in s.t.

-neltocōcā.English: the faith others have in one
-neltocōcā.Spanish: la feŸ con que me creen (C for first personpossessor)
-neltocōcā.Comment: S has neltococayotl "faith, belief".  Cdistinguishes between -NELTOCŌCĀ, the faith othershave in one, and TLANELTOQUILIZ-TLI, the faith onehas in s.t. else, which is the general distinctionbetween nonactive derivations in -CĀYŌ-TL andactive ones in -LIZ-TLI.

neltoquiliz-tli.Comment: This appears to be a truncated form ofTLANELTOQUILIZ-TLI.  M has neltoquiztli "s.t.worthy of belief".

nelyōlcocoliz-tli.Comment: Z also has NEYŌLCOCOLIZ-TLI "affliction, trouble,grief", which is formed with the nonspecificreflexive prefix NE- rather than with NEL.

nemachtiā.English: to prepare, to accustom oneself; to become accustomedto s.t., to use s.t.
nemachtiā.Spanish: apercebirse o aparejarse (M), se acostumbre (T), loacostumbre (T)

nemachtīl-li.Comment: C marks the vowel of the first syllable long, whichis incorrect.

nemactiā.English: to give a portion, endowment, dowry to s.o.
nemactiā.Spanish: dar algo de balde o dotar a otro (M)
nemactiā.Comment: With the oblique reflexive, this means "to obtain aportion, gift, dowry".

nemac-tli.Spanish: don, o merced que se recibe (M)

nemāpohpōhualōni.Spanish: instrumento para limpiarse las manos (C), pan9o demanos o toalla (M for nemapopoaloni tilmatli)

nemauhtīl-li.Comment: Z has O for A in this item and no absolutive suffix.M has the longer form nemauhtiliztli with the samesense.

nem(i).Comment: In compound constructions NEM(I) also has the sense"to go about doing s.t.", but as a free form it isgenerally reduplicated, NEHNEM(I) "to go along, towalk, to wander".  The preterit form contrasts invowel length with NĒN "in vain".

nemiliā.English: to provide own's own sustenance, to support oneself,to be resolved; to consider, ponder, or look intos.t.
nemiliā.Spanish: mantenerse con su industria (M), se resuelve (Z),pesquisar o inquirir vida ajena (M), pensar odeliberar algo (M)
nemiliā.Comment: There are divergent senses here, between concretesupport and sustenance of life on one hand and mentalprovision of life through imagination andinvestigation on the other.

nemiliz-tli.Spanish: vida (C), vida, conducta, manera de vivir (S)

nemiltiā.English: to raise, maintain s.o. or s.t.
nemiltiā.Spanish: le crio o sustento (C for first pers. sg. subject)

nemiltiliā.Comment: T has the reflex of a long vowel in the secondsyllable, but it is not marked long in C.

nemiltīlō.Comment: T has the reflex of a long vowel in the secondsyllable, but it should not be.

nemini.Spanish: el que vive o mora en alguŸn lugar (M)
nemini.Comment: The attestation is of a verb form which is, however,homophonous with the noun.

nemītiā.English: to maintain, nurture s.o. or s.t.
nemītiā.Spanish: mantener o sustentar a otro (M), tener o sustentarcriado o caballo (M)

-nemiyān.English: the place or time in which one lives
-nemiyān.Spanish: lugar donde yo vivo (C for first pers. sg. possessor),duracioŸn, tiempo de vida (S)

nemohua.English: for living or residence to go on
nemohua.Spanish: todos viven o todos moran en alguna parte (M)
nemohua.Comment: This is only attested in the spelling nemoa, butM's preterit form nemoac shows that it is an -OHUAverb rather than an -OĀ one.

nemohuayān.Spanish: lugar donde algunos moran o habitan, o poblacioŸn (M)
nemohuayān.Comment: R fails to mark the vowel of the last syllable long.

nēmpancah.English: s.t. without a clear outcome or benefit, s.t. invain
nēmpancah.Spanish: cosa sin provecho o por demaŸs (M) usarse cuando unopretende hacer algo y dudando si le ha de salir bien,se resuelve a cometerle (C)

nēmpēhualtiā.English: to mistreat s.o. for no good reason

nēmpēhu(i).English: to begin to have some feeling of apprehensionfor no good reason
nēmpēhu(i).Spanish: empieza (a tener miedo, etc.) sin causa (T)

nēmpolihu(i).English: to spoil, to get stale, to be ruined
nēmpolihu(i).Spanish: desperdiciarse algo (M), se echa a perder, se pierde(T)

nēmpoloā.English: to waste, spoil or damage s.t., to kill s.o.
nēmpoloā.Spanish: desperdiciar o echar a perder (M), lo pierde, lo echaa perder, lo asesina (T)

nēmpoti-tl.Comment: T gives the variants NĒMPOTI-TL and NĒMPOTE and aplural form NĒMPOTEMEH.

nēn.Spanish: en vano, por demaŸs, o sin provecho (M)
nēn.Comment: This commonly occurs bound with ZAN.  It contrasts invowel length with the preterit form of NEM(I).

nenāmictīlōyoh.Comment: It seems that this should be derived with -YŌ or-YĀN rather than -YOH, but T's form has noabsolutive suffix as -YŌ would and has the reflexof O rather than Ā.  T would not retain final H or Nin any case.  M has nenamictiliztli "marriage,wedlock" and also nenamictiloni "s.t. pertainingto marriage".

nēncah.English: to be idle, without profit, in vain, futile
nēncah.Spanish: estar ocioso y sin alguna ocupacioŸn (M)
nēncah.Comment: T and Z both have this in composition with ZAN,either before or after NĒNCAH, the phrasefunctioning adverbially.

nēncāhu(a).English: to be negligent; to leave s.t. undone throughnegligence
nēncāhu(a).Spanish: ser desdichado (M), dejar de hacer algo pornegligencia o dejar de castigar alguŸn delito (M)
nēncāhu(a).Comment: This is implied by -NĒNCĀUHYĀN and NĒNCĀHU(I).Its preterit form contrasts in vowel length with-NENCĀUH "one's servant".

nēncāhu(i).Comment: T only gives a gloss for the negation of this, AHMŌNĒNCĀHU(I) "not to be in vain, hopeless".  Thepreterit of this verb contrasts in vowel lengthwith -NENCĀUH "one's servant".

-nencāuh.Spanish: mi criado (M for first pers. sg. possessor)
-nencāuh.Comment: This contrasts in vowel length with the preterit formsof the verbs NĒNCĀHU(A) "to leave s.t. undone" andNĒNCĀHU(I) "to be in vain".

nencāyō-tl.English: sustenance, what one needs to support life
nencāyō-tl.Comment: This conventionally appears in the phrase -YŌLCĀ-NENCĀ (both possessed) with the sense "one's dailysustenance".  The possessed form -NENCĀ contrastswith NĒNCAH "for s.t. to be in vain" both in vowellength and in the presence or absence of a finalglottal stop.

nēnchīhu(a).English: to do s.t. in vain or without profit
nēnchīhu(a).Spanish: hacer algo en vano o sin alguŸn provecho (M)

nēncuep(a).English: to go somewhere for naught; to restore, return s.t.to no avail
nēncuep(a).Spanish: va en balde, va en vano (T), lo devuelve en vano (T)

nēnecoc.English: on, to or from both sides, both sides of severalthings
nēnecoc.Spanish: a una parte y a otra, o de una parte y de otra, o alun lado y al otro, o a ambos lados (M), pluralidad decosas que tienen los dos lados (C)

nenecuil-li.Comment: This is attested only as the second element ofCUAUHNENECUIL-LI "jinicuil tree".  It is certainlyrelated to M's nenecuiloa "to stagger, meander thisway and that".  It is possible that the absolutivesuffix should be -IN, because this is attested onlyin T, where there is an ambiguity between absolutive-LI and -IN in cases where the stem ends in L.

nenehtōltiliz-tli.Comment: R fails to mark the vowel of the third syllable long.

nēnehuiliā.English: to equal s.t. else; to pair things, to comparethings
nēnehuiliā.Spanish: ser igual a otros (M), emparejar o igualar algunascosas o hacer comparacioŸn o concordancias de unascosas a otras (M)
nēnehuiliā.Comment: T has NENEHUILIĀ with the closely related sense of"to consider, imagine s.t." but with a short vowel inthe initial syllable.  R has NEHNEHUILIĀ with aglottal stop in the first syllable.  This implies anunattested verb *NEHUILIĀ with all the possiblekinds of initial-syllable reduplication.  M has theverb neuiuilia "to be equal to s.t., s.o. else".

nenehuiliā.Spanish: lo piensa, lo considera, lo imagina, lo opina, loprueba, lo supone (T)
nenehuiliā.Comment: This is probably NEHNEHUILIĀ with loss of theglottal stop, which is characteristic of T.

nēnemizqui.Comment: In one of two attestations T gives a plural gloss toa singular form and a different form as the plural.

nenepiltiā.English: for ears of corn to bud; to serve as a spokesman ortranslator
nenepiltiā.Spanish: brotar la marzorca de maiŸz en la can9a (M), (sesirve como) lengua ... hablar por ellos (C)
nenepiltiā.Comment: The literal sense of this has to do with becominglike or serving as a tongue.

nēnetech.English: close together (of more than two objects)
nēnetech.Spanish: muy juntos unos de otros (C), cercaniŸa de cosas ...maŸs de dos (C)

nene-tl.Spanish: la natura de la mujer, iŸdolo, o mun9eca de nin9os(M)
nene-tl.Comment: In the sources for this dictionary this is onlyattested as the first element of NENEPIL-LI "tongue"and the second element of CUAHUINENETZIN (the name ofan insect).  Since the two senses of this item are atsome distance from each other and both distant fromthe senses of the attestations, it is possible thatmore than one lexical item is represented here, andthey may differ phonologically.

nenētz.Comment: Z gives NENĒTZTIC as an alternative form.Relationship to NĒNETECH "close together" isplausible, but the vowel length values are reversed.

nēnmaniyān.Comment: M has nemayan with the same sense.  There is noassimilation of the NM sequence in the attestations.The sequence IY is provided here on the model ofanalogous CEMMANIYĀN.  It is written only as y inthe attestations.

nenohmahhuiliz-tli.Comment: This is also attested in P with the glottal stopsmarked.

nēnquēn.Comment: This is abundantly attested, but only in Z.

nēnquēnti.Comment: The sense of this may be related to that of thephrase AHMŌ QUĒN CAH "for nothing to be the matterwith s.t."

nenqui.English: resident of some place, s.o. who lives
nenqui.Spanish: morador de alguna parte (M), el que vive (R)
nenqui.Comment: Z marks the vowel of the first syllable long in twoattestations of the compound OHNENQUI "traveler", butNENQUI is clearly derived from NEM(I) "to live",which has a short vowel.  The possessed form-NĒNCĀUH is glossed by M and C as "one's servant".

nēnquīzcāyō-tl.Comment: S has nenquizqui "s.t. useless, futile,profitless", and M has nenquic˛a "to labor invain".

nēntequiti.English: to labor in vain, to no end
nēntequiti.Comment: T forms the preterit of this by dropping the finalvowel, but M forms the preterit of TEQUITI by adding-C.

nēnti.English: for s.t. to turn out to be in vain, to be frustrated

nēntlamachiliz-tli.Comment: Z's gloss does not seem to follow directly from thecomponent parts of this item.

nēnyān.Comment: Both C and S provide a variant of this without thefinal N.

nēpa.English: there, at some distance in space or time
nēpa.Spanish: alliŸ o allaŸ o de alliŸ o de allaŸ (M), antiguamente(C for IN YE NĒPA), en aquel tiempo, en aquellosdiŸas (T for CA YE NĒPA)
nēpa.Comment: According to C this is close in sense to NECHCA butdoes not require the point in question to be visible,as NECHCA does (f.89v).  C also says that this isclose in sense to NIPA "over there, on the otherside" (which has a short vowel in the initialsyllable) but NIPA does not specifically point at alocation (f.90r).

nēpacah.Spanish: helo alliŸ o helo allaŸ o alliŸ estaŸ (M), de aquellado (Z)

nēpacatica.Comment: Since Z does not mark the vowel of the third syllablelong or have a glottal stop, the first element maynot be NĒPACAH but rather NĒPA and -CA, and that inturn suffixed by the sequence -TI-CA.

nepan-.Comment: This appears only as an element of compounds andderivations and conveys a sense of mutuality orreciprocity.

nepanoā.English: for things to intersect, unite, join together; tojoin, unite s.t., to examine s.t.
nepanoā.Spanish: reunir, juntarse (S), juntar, unir, amontonar;averiguar, examinar algo (S)

nepanōhuiliā.Comment: In the Spanish-to-Nahuatl side of Z, NEPANOĀ isgiven instead of NEPANŌHUILIĀ.  This may not bederived from the verb NEPANOĀ but from NEPANŌ-TLand -HUIĀ.  In either case the vowel of the thirdsyllable should be long but is not so marked in thesingle attestation.

-nepanōl-li.English: s.t. joined, crossed, formed by placing one thing ontop of another
-nepanōl-li.Comment: This is not attested as a free form but only as thesecond element of CUAUHNEPANŌL-LI "cross".  M hascalnepanolli "two-story house, attic of a house"and tlanepanolli "s.t. collated or investigated".

nepanō-tl.Spanish: unos a otros, o unos con otros, o los unos a losotros (M)
nepanō-tl.Comment: The NY sequence NEPANYŌ-TL apparently undergoesassimilation of Y to N and then degemination of theresulting NN.  This is mainly used in adverbialconstructions with the sense "mutually,reciprocally".

nepantlah.Spanish: en el medio, o en medio, o por el medio (M)

nepantlahtic.English: late in the morning, near to noon
nepantlahtic.Comment: In one attestation this appears with YA "already"postposed and cliticized to the end, with a spellingchange that makes the construction opaque.  The otherattestation, which is not written solid, clarifiesthe situation and confirms this analysis.

nepantlahtiliā.English: for it to get late in the morning, to draw near tonoon

nepantlahtitoc.English: late in the morning, near to noon
nepantlahtitoc.Comment: This appears with YA "already" postposed andcliticized to the end, with a spelling change thatmakes the construction opague.  The analysis issupported by Z's paired phrase TEŌTLACTOC YA "latein the afternoon", which is not written solid (p.16).

nequetzaliz-tli.English: raising up, resurrection, raising of doubt
nequetzaliz-tli.Spanish: levantamiento del que estaba asentado, o duda del quela tiene, o resurreccioŸn el que resuscita (M),estatura, apariencia, presentacioŸn (Z)

nequ(i).English: to want or use s.t., to engage, accept, or want s.o.in some enterprise (M)
nequ(i).Spanish: querer algo o gastar y emplear alguna cosa (M),admitir a otro para alguŸn negocio (M)
nequ(i).Comment: In construction with a verb in the future tense form,NEQU(I) means "to want to ..."  Used reflexively withan incorporated noun, NEQU(I) means "to pretend to be..."

nequiliz-tli.Comment: Z appears to have lost a necessary prefix, probablyNE-.

nequiltiā.English: to want s.t. for s.o. else or to make s.o. wants.t.
nequiltiā.Spanish: desear algo a otro o hacerle querer alguna cosa (M)
nequiltiā.Comment: With the oblique reflexive this means "to want s.t.for oneself".

netech.English: close together, adjacent (with respect to twoobjects)
netech.Spanish: entre siŸ (M), cercancia de cosas ... solas dos (C)
netech.Comment: For more than two objects, the reduplicated formNĒNETECH is used.

netechoā.English: for things to join or stick together; to get twothings together, to join things
netechoā.Spanish: se junta, se acerca, se pega uno junto al otro (T),hacer llegar o juntar una cosa con otra (M)

netēcuitlahuiliz-tli.Comment: C contrasts this with NETLACUITLAHUILIZ-TLI "care ofs.t."

netequipachōliz-tli.Spanish: afliccioŸn y angustia del que la padece (M)

netlacuitlahuiliz-tli.Comment: C contrasts this with NETĒCUITLAHUILIZ-TLI "care ofs.o."

netlazohtlaliz-tli.English: love of people for one another or of s.o. forhimself
netlazohtlaliz-tli.Spanish: amor con que algunos se aman, o amor propio (M),estimacioŸn (Z)
netlazohtlaliz-tli.Comment: M contrasts this with netlac˛otiliztli"exaggeration of worth".

netloc.Spanish: juntamente (M), muy juntos, cerquita, junto a (T)
netloc.Comment: T treats this as a postposition -NETLOC and has A forO in the second syllable.

neucchīuhpan.Comment: X has L for UH.  M has necuchiua "for bees to makehoney".

neuc-tli.Comment: T and Z have lost the labialization of the stem-finalconsonant, NEC-TLI.

nēuhcāyō-tl.English: sustenance, a meal taken upon rising, breakfast
nēuhcāyō-tl.Spanish: el sustento necesario (C), lo que se come despueŸs delevantarse (C), viŸveres, alimentos, nutricioŸn,subsistencia (S)
nēuhcāyō-tl.Comment: This is conventionally paired with COCHCĀYŌ-TL"evening meal", both possessed, the whole phrasemeaning "one's daily bread".

nexā-tl.English: lime water (used in preparing maize for grinding)
nexā-tl.Spanish: lejiŸa (M), el agua de nixtamal, nijayote, aguaencalada (T)

nexcōmeh.Spanish: una clase de avispa maŸs chiquita (Z)
nexcōmeh.Comment: The literal meaning of this is "possessor of anixtamal pot".  Presumably this is a wasp that buildsa pot-shaped nest.

nexcōm(i)-tl.English: vessel for soaking maize in lime water
nexcōm(i)-tl.Comment: Z has a gloss that seems to refer to the process ofpreparing nixtamal rather than to the container whichis its literal referent.

nexhua.English: a type of gray snake that inhabits rocky places

nexhuītīl.Spanish: enfermo del estoŸmago, descompuesto del estoŸmago,indigestioŸn (Z)
nexhuītīl.Comment: M has nexuitiliztli with the same sense.

nēxiltiā.English: to make s.t. appear, to show s.t.
nēxiltiā.Spanish: le hago parecer, le muestro (C for first pers. sg.subject)

nēxītiā.English: to make s.t. appear, to show s.t.
nēxītiā.Spanish: le hago parecer, le muestro (C for first personsubject)

nexpīqu(i).English: to be put under coals, ashes; to put s.t. undercoals, ashes
nexpīqu(i).Spanish: se pone debajo del rescoldo (T), lo mete debajo delrescoldo (T)

nexquetz(a).English: to soak maize in lime water
nexquetz(a).Spanish: pone el nixtamal, encala el maiŸz (T)

nextamal-li.English: maize soaked in lime water and then ground for makingtortillas, tamales, and other cornmeal-based dishes

nextecuil-in.English: type of large, whitish caterpillar that eats theroots of plants; a deranged person
nextecuil-in.Spanish: gusano de muladar, o persona desatinada y loca (M),nextecuil, gallina ciega (gusano) (T)

nēxtiā.English: to reveal oneself; to reveal s.o., s.t.; to eke out aliving
nēxtiā.Spanish: descubrirse o manifestarse (M), descubrir ymanifestar a otro (M), descubrir o manifestar algo, obuscar lo necesario a la vida (M)

nextic.Spanish: gris, de color ceniciento (S), gris, pardo, color deplomo (T)

nēxtiliā.English: to reveal oneself to others; to reveal, teach s.t.to s.o., to tell s.t. to s.o. in confidence
nēxtiliā.Spanish: aparecer o manifestarse a otros (M), revelar odescubrir algo a otro (M), descubrir secreto al amigo(M)

neyōlcocoliz-tli.Comment: The pairing of NE- with COCOLIZ-TLI is irregular.Possibly this is derived instead from the reflexiveuse of YŌLCOCOĀ "to suffer".  For this alternativeanalysis it may be significant that in bothattestations the vowel of the fourth syllable ismarked long.  Z also has NELYŌLCOCOLIZ-TLI"sadness".

neyōlcuītiliz-tli.Comment: In the single attestation, the vowel of the thirdsyllable is not marked long, but the vowel in thecorresponding verb is long.

nezahualcoyō-tl.Comment: The honorific form of this is NEZAHUALCOYŌTZIN.

nezahualiz-tli.Spanish: ayuno de la iglesia o voluntario (M)

nezahualpil-li.Comment: The honorific form of this is NEZAHUALPILTZIN-TLI.The sense here, in spite of truncation, is "son ofNezahualcoyotl".

nezcaliliz-tli.Spanish: resurreccioŸn, cordura, o aprovechamiento del que vaaprovechando en algo (M)

nezohuahtīlōyō-tl.Comment: This implies an otherwise unattested reflexive use ofZOHUAHTIĀ, which in its transitive (and literal)sense means "for a man to take a wife".

nicān.Spanish: aquiŸ, acaŸ, de aquiŸ, o por aquiŸ (M)

nicca.Grammar: exclamation used for hailing s.o., getting s.o.'sattention
nicca.Spanish: hola, hao, oyes, para llamar a alguno (M)

nici.Comment: This form arises from a reanalysis of IN ICI as INNICI.

nipa.Spanish: acullaŸ, o a eŸsta parte (M), por ahiŸ, a otra parte(C)
nipa.Comment: C remarks that this is close in sense to NĒPA "atsome distance", which however has two senses notshared by NIPA, namely to point out a particular spotor to refer to a remote time.  NIPA is indefinite anddoes not point to a particular spot.  Rather, thesense is "away from here, anywhere but here", whichsomewhat resolves the apparent conflict between M's"this way" and C's "the other way".

nō.Comment: This particle bonds with others in various clustersincorporating the sense of "also", but there appearsto be another clitic NO with a short vowel, which isa component of NOCEH "or else", NOZO "either", AHNOZO"neither, and NOZAN "still, up until now".  In thesethe vowel of NO is specifically marked short or leftunmarked for length; it is never marked long.  Thisis abundantly attested in B and C and also appears inR and X but not at all in T and Z.

noceh.Comment: This is abundantly attested in B and C.  The vowel ofthe initial syllable is unmarked for length in C andis specifically marked short in B (f.7v,10r,10v).  Csays that NOCEH is a syncopated form of NOZO (Y)EH(f.111v), which implies that neither NOCEH or NOZOhas NŌ "also" as a component part, although itwould be compatible with their senses.

nochehhuā-tl.English: all of a set of things, s.t. homogeneous andconsisting entirely of one thing
nochehhuā-tl.Spanish: todo eso asiŸ lo uno como lo otro, o cosa se cuentacon lo demaŸs, o que es de la misma cosa (M), solo,puro, nada maŸs (T)
nochehhuā-tl.Comment: M combines the gloss of this with that for "the fruitof a prickly pear cactus" < NŌCH-TLI.  M also hasmucheuatl derived from corresponding MOCH(I).

noch(i).Comment: T, Z, and X have NOCH(I) for MOCH(I) as do many otherNahuatl speech communities.

nōch-tli.English: fruit of the prickly pear cactus

nōcuēl.Comment: This often has a lexically empty final (Y)EH added toit.  It may also be preceded by YE "already".  Noticethat although they may be spelled alike in a text,these are different particles.  The extended form YENŌCUĒLYEH occurs on Cf.108r.

nohmah.Comment: M contrasts this with NOMĀ "my hand" by giving themin separate contiguous entries, although he spellsthem identically.

-nohmah.Comment: C gives a full paradigm of this for all personssingular and plural.  The free form and thenecessarily possessed form share the sense ofspontaneity, internal control.  Some sort ofreanalysis relates this to IYOĀ "to be alone" andIYOH "only".

nohmahhuiā.English: to act of one's free will
nohmahhuiā.Spanish: hacer algo de su propio albedriŸo y voluntad (M)

nohnōncuah.English: apart, with respect to a number of discrete objects
nohnōncuah.Spanish: aparte o de por siŸ, hablando de muchas cosas (R)
nohnōncuah.Comment: This also appears in P with the glottal stop markedbut not the long vowel.  C has the reduplicated formNŌNONCUAH for the distributive plural.

nohnōncuahquīxtiā.English: to divide, separate things, to set things apart
nohnōncuahquīxtiā.Comment: This also appears in P with the glottal stop markedbut not the long vowels.

nohnōncuahtlāliā.English: to divide, separate things, to set things apart

nohnōquihu(a).English: to spread out, to be scattered, to leak
nohnōquihu(a).Comment: This also appears in P with the glottal stop markedbut not the long vowel.  M has nonoquiuhtiuh withthe same sense.

nohnōtz(a).English: to speak with s.o., to have a conversation
nohnōtz(a).Spanish: parlo con eŸl (C for first pers. sg. subject), habla conotro ... consultar ... advertir (R)
nohnōtz(a).Comment: This is abundantly attested across sources.  It isdifficult to distinguish in sense from NŌNŌTZ(A),although the latter seems to have the sense of "toadvise, instruct" not shared by NOHNŌTZ(A).  Since Mdoes not distinguish between the two, the glosses areprobably mixed.  M's gloss for nonotza with thedirectional prefix ON- "to go to chat with others" isundoubtedly this one; M's other glosses appear hereunder NŌNŌTZ(A).

nohpal-li.Spanish: nopal, cactus del que se cuenta con dos especiesprincipales: opuntia vulgaris, que da la mejornochtli, y opuntia cochinillifera, en el cualvive la cochinilla (S)
nohpal-li.Comment: M gives NOHPAL-LI as part of a phrase meaning tocultivate the plant.  T has the variant formNOHPALI-TL.

nōhuiyān.Comment: In C the vowel of the initial syllable is markedlong, but in B it is specifically marked short.  Thas the reflex of a short vowel, and in Z the vowelis unmarked for length.

nōiuh.Comment: This often appears in the phrase ZAN NŌIUH.

nomati.English: it seems that ..., I think that ...
nomati.Comment: This is a lexicalized syncopated form of NINOMAT(I).

nōncuah.Comment: This is abundantly attested in C and R.  T has thevariant NENCUAH.

nōncuahquīxtiā.English: to set s.t. apart, to make an exception of s.t.
nōncuahquīxtiā.Spanish: poner aparte por siŸ lo que se escoge, o sacar deregla general algo (M)
nōncuahquīxtiā.Comment: This is implied by the reduplicated formNOHNŌNCUAHQUĪXTIĀ and is abundant in P, where theglottal stop is marked but not the long vowels.

nōncuahtlāliā.English: for s.t. to be set apart;to set s.t. apart, to make an exception of s.t.
nōncuahtlāliā.Spanish: se pone aparte (T), poner aparte por siŸ lo que seescoge, o sacar de regla general algo (M)
nōncuahtlāliā.Comment: C also gives NŌNCUAH TLĀLIĀ as separate wordswith verbal prefixes attached to TLĀLIĀ alone.  Mgives this as synonymous with NŌNCUAHQUĪXTIĀ.

nōncuahxeloā.English: to be separated, set apart; to separate s.t., to sets.t. apart
nōncuahxeloā.Spanish: se aparta, se separa (T), lo aparta, lo separa (T)
nōncuahxeloā.Comment: In the attestations in T the final glottal stop ofthe first element is missing.

nōnōncuah.English: apart, with respect to several discrete objects
nōnōncuah.Spanish: de maŸs de dos personas o cosas que cada una esteŸaparte (C)
nōnōncuah.Comment: R has NOHNŌNCUAH for the distributive plural ofNŌNCUAH.

nōnōquiā.Spanish: lo desparrama, lo derrama, lo riega (agua, leche,etc.), lo vaciŸa (liŸquido), lo vuelca (T)

nōnōquihu(i).Spanish: se tira (de una cosa llena), derrama, se desborda, seriega, se desparrama (T)
nōnōquihu(i).Comment: M has nonoquiuhtiuh "to go about spreading orscattering".

nōnōtz(a).English: to take counsel with oneself, to converse, consult,come to agreement; to caution, correct or informothers, to relate things
nōnōtz(a).Spanish: consultar o tratar algo consigo mismo, o enmendarse(M), amonestrar o hablar con otros, o corregir,castigar y aconsejar (M), informar o contar y relatarhistoria, o tratar del precio que vale lo que se hade comprar (M)
nōnōtz(a).Comment: It is hard to separate the senses of NŌNŌTZ(A) fromNOHNŌTZ(A).  Both are attested across sources.NŌNŌTZ(A) seems to carry more of the sense of "toadvise, instruct", while NOHNŌTZ(A) is moreneutrally "to converse".  C contrasts seriousdiscussion of business (NŌNŌTZ(A)) with casual chat(NOHNŌTZ(A)) (f.73r).

nōtz(a).English: to call or summon s.o., to talk to s.o.
nōtz(a).Spanish: citar o llamar a alguno, o hablar con otro (M)

nozan.Comment: This seems to have as a component the element NO witha short vowel rather than NŌ "also".

nozo.Comment: With CA, CA NEL, and INĪC this has the sense of"because".  According to C, CA NELNOZO indicatesstronger causality, to the point of necessity.

o.English: to be lying, to stretch out
o.Spanish: estar echada o tendida alguna persona, o madero, ocosa semejante que sea larga (M for onoc)
o.Comment: This verb as a free form always appears with thedirectional ON-, which in this case does not conveyany distal sense but gives more substance to anotherwise rather minimal verb and distinguishes theverb from OC "again".  The directional ON- is notincluded in the common construction in which anotherverb is bound to this one by the -TI- ligature.  Theresulting sequence -TI-OC is reduced to -TOC.Constructions with -TOC are of high frequency inNahuatl and convey a progressive sense.

ō.Grammar: exclamation that conveys admiration or surprise thatsomething is contrary to expectation, or initiates avocative, or is used as an expression of pain
ō.Spanish: exclamacioŸn de eŸl que se admira de oiŸr o saber loque no sabiŸa (C), interjeccioŸn del que estaŸafligido y hace exclamacioŸn (M)
ō.Comment: In B this is generally marked long except when it iscapitalized, while in C it is never marked long.  Ina discussion of Ō on f.124r,124v, C remarks thatthis particle can compound with honorific -TZIN forgreater formality.

ō-.English: antecessive particle indicating completion of someaction prior to some point
ō-.Comment: This particle generally cliticizes to preterit andpluperfect verb forms, sometimes to the imperfect,and serves as a redundant past tense marker.However, especially in early sources, otherconstituents can intervene between Ō (which is thenfreestanding) and the verb complex.  It can also befound with verbs in the future tense conveying thesense that the action in question will be complete atsome point in the future.

oc.Comment: Despite the discrepancy in vowel length, this isprobably related to ŌME "two".

occāmpa.English: to or from two places or directions
occāmpa.Spanish: de dos o a dos partes (C)

occān.Spanish: en dos partes o en dos lugares, o dos raciones decomida (M)

occē.Spanish: otro o otra, o otro maŸs (M)

occentlaman-tli.English: another thing altogether, in another way
occentlaman-tli.Spanish: otra cosa, en otra manera o de otra manera (M),diferente concepto (C)

occentlapal.English: other side, on or from the other side

occequi.English: s.t. more, s.t. additional, a bit more
occequi.Spanish: maŸs, o un poco, o otras cosas (M)

occequīntin.Comment: This also appears in the short form OCCEQUĪN in Cand Z.

ōcēlmotlahuēliltic.English: Oh how wretched you are.  Woe to you.
ōcēlmotlahuēliltic.Spanish: o desventurado de tiŸ, guay de tiŸ (M),desdichadiŸsimo (C)
ōcēlmotlahuēliltic.Comment: This is specifically second person singular, but theMO- could be replaced with any of the otherpossessive prefixes with a corresponding change inreference.

ōcēlō-tl.Comment: B marks the first vowel long, but C fails to.

ōcēlōxōchi-tl.English: Aztec lily, tiger flower (Tigridia pavonia), thebulbs of which are used as food and to treat feversand infertility
ōcēlōxōchi-tl.Comment: This is not directly attested in the sources for thisdictionary, but the component parts are.

ochpahuāz-tli.Comment: This appears only in the Spanish-to-Nahuatl side ofM.

ochpān(a).Comment: M has an entry chpana "to sweep" requiring theprefix TLA- and yielding TLACHPĀN(A).

ocmā.Comment: This shortened form of OCMĀYA is only attested inthe phrase TLĀ OCMĀ "wait a minute".

ocmāya.English: a bit further on, a bit ahead, soon
ocmāya.Spanish: de aquiŸ a un poco, o aguarda un poco (M)
ocmāya.Comment: The phrase TLĀ OCMĀYA and its short form TLĀOCMĀ mean "wait a minute", and OCMĀYA alone canalso be used with this sense.

ocnamacac.Spanish: tabernero o tabernera (M), el pulquero, que vendepulque (C)

ocnamacōyān.Spanish: taberna (M), taberna donde se vende pulque (C)

ocopetl(a)-tl.Comment: The literal meaning of this is "pine-mat", probablyreferring to ferns as ground cover in pine forests.

oco-tl.English: pine tree; torch made of pine
oco-tl.Spanish: tea, raja o astilla de pino (M), ocote (aŸrbol) (Z)
oco-tl.Comment: Z marks the vowel of the second syllable long, and itis so marked in half the attestations in X, but othersources have it consistently short.

ocotzocuahu(i)-tl.Comment: The gum from this tree is cooked and formed intotablets that are used for medicinal purposes.Burned, they produce a smoke used for fumigation.

ocoxāl-in.English: carpet of decayed pine needles that collects on thefloor of pine forests
ocoxāl-in.Comment: Z gives this twice with the -IN absolutive and twicewith no absolutive suffix.

oc-tli.Comment: Z has a long vowel in this item, but in abundantattestation elsewhere it is short.

ocuil-in.Spanish: gusano generalmente, o cebo para pescar (M)
ocuil-in.Comment: Z also uses OCUIL-IN with the sense "wild animal".

ohchīuhqui.Spanish: uno que hace caminos, repara caminos (Z)

ohhuitiā.English: to guide s.o., to show s.o. the way

ohhuiyō-tl.English: matters having to do with roads
ohhuiyō-tl.Comment: This is an abstract noun derived from OH-TLI.Neither attestation is specifically glossed, but thegloss given here parallels the others in the samesection in C.  This contrasts with OHUIHCĀYŌ-TL"danger, difficulty".

ohmactiā.English: to guide s.o., to show s.o. the way
ohmactiā.Comment: The single attestation of this has a long vowel inthe second syllable, but this is undoubtedly thecausative form of OHMACA.

-ohmi-tl.Comment: This contrasts with OMI-TL "bone, awl".  -OHMI-TL isonly attested compounded with TŌCH-TLI "rabbit".TOHMI-TL "down" occurs as a free form.

ohōme.English: each two, two by two, two apiece
ohōme.Spanish: cada dos, o de dos en dos, o cada uno dos (M)

ohōmeilhuitica.English: every other day, every second day
ohōmeilhuitica.Comment: This appears in R without diacritics.

ohpitzac-tli.Comment: Z has a long vowel in the second syllable, but it isinconsistent with the derivation.

ohtlatoca.English: to travel a road, to go along in life, for a stain tospread
ohtlatoca.Spanish: caminar, o ir cundiendo mucho la mancha (M)
ohtlatoca.Comment: Z has a short form OHTOCA attested twice, once with along vowel in TOCA.

ohtlīpanquetz(a).English: to set out on the road
ohtlīpanquetz(a).Comment: In the single attestation the second vowel is notmarked long, but the structure of the first part ofthis is parallel to OHTLĪCA.

ohuaneuc-tli.Spanish: miel de can9as de maiŸz, que parece arrope (M)

ohuapach-tli.English: remains of sugar cane after pressing

ohua-tl.Spanish: can9a de maiŸz verde (M), can9a de azuŸcar (Z)

ohuih.Comment: R marks the glottal stop on the wrong syllable, butthe other sources are in agreement.

ohuihcān.Spanish: lugar dificultoso y peligroso, o escondrijo defieras, o lugar oscuro y espantoso (M)

ohuihtitoc.Comment: In one attestation Z marks the vowel of the thirdsyllable long.

ohxiliā.English: to put salve on s.t., to annoint s.t., s.o.
ohxiliā.Comment: M has oxitl "salve made of turpentine" andoxiutia "to anoint s.t. with this salve".This also appears in P with the glottal stopmarked.

ohza.English: to put salve on s.t., to annoint s.t., s.o.

ōiliā.Comment: T has a medial glide w between the first twovowels, which conclusively demonstrates that the Y ofthe stem is dropped in this form.

ōlīniā.Spanish: menearse, o moverse (M), lo mueve, lo menea (T)
ōlīniā.Comment: The basic intransitive verb *ŌLĪN(I) is notattested in the sources for this dictionary.  As afree form in T and Z, ŌLĪNIĀ has a long vowel inthe initial syllable, but derived forms have a shortinitial vowel.  A single attestation of the verb in Bis a freestanding reflexive in which the vowel isunmarked for length.  X, however, has a long voweleven in derived forms.

olōchtlatzotzonanih.Grammar: This is a plural, which is formed by adding -H.
olōchtlatzotzonanih.Comment: In one of the attestations, the vowel of the next tolast syllable is marked long.

ololoā.English: to roll s.t. into a ball; to collect s.t.
ololoā.Spanish: hacer alguna cosa redonda como bola, o cosa semejanteesfeŸrica, o arreban9ar y ayuntar algo (M)
ololoā.Comment: The vowel of the second syllable is consistentlyshort in T but long in 4 of 6 attestations in Z.

ololtic.Comment: The single attestation has both the second and thirdvowels long.  See the note about attested vowellength in OLOLOĀ.  A long vowel in -TIC isidiosyncratic to Z.

ōlōtetzonte-tl.English: instrument for removing kernels from corncobs

ōlō-tl.English: ear of corn with kernels removed
ōlō-tl.Spanish: el corazoŸn o espiga desgranada de la mazorca demaiŸz (M)

om-.Grammar: prefix used in adding digits to larger numbers in theNahuatl vigesimal number system
om-.Comment: Despite the vowel length discrepancy, this appears tobe related to both ŌME "two" and OC "another,again".  Regular nasal assimilation gives this theform ON- with numbers beginning with a nonlabialconsonant.

ōmach-.Comment: This is MACH inserted between antecessive Ō- and therest of the verb complex.

ōme.Comment: Z has a single attestation of ŌMEN as a plural form,and C forms the plural of OMŌME "twelve" by adding-N too.  In compounds the final vowel is lost, andbefore nonlabial consonants there is nasalassimilation yielding the alternation ŌM- = ŌN-.B has an attestation of an honorific form in which aglottal stop intervenes between ŌME and -TZIN.

ōmequil(i)-tl.English: a fragrant white lily-like flower (Polyanthestuberosa, Polyanthes mexicana)
ōmequil(i)-tl.Comment: This is another name for OMIXŌCHI-TL.  Possibly theŌME element is a substitution for OMI.

omicicuil-li.Comment: T has lost the initial O and has a reduplicated formbased on the truncated form.  T also has CE for CI.The possessive of the reduplicated form ends in -YŌ.M has this in the Spanish-to-Nahuatl side, while inthe Nahuatl-to-Spanish side it occurs only in acompound.

omi-tl.Comment: The vowels are both consistently short except in Zwhere the first vowel is long in three attestationsof six and the second vowel is given long twice.This contrasts with -OHMI-TL "pelt, down".

omixōchi-tl.English: a fragrant white lily-like flower (Polyanthestuberosa, Polyanthes mexicana)
omixōchi-tl.Spanish: azucena (M), flor de hechura de hueso (C)

-omiyohcāpohtzin.English: s.o. who shares one's own type of bones
-omiyohcāpohtzin.Spanish: ha tomado ... huesos ... como nosotros (C for firstpers. plural possessed form with MOCHĪHU(A))
-omiyohcāpohtzin.Comment: This is said of Christ's incarnation.  It is pairedwith -EZYOHCĀPOHTZIN "sharing one's own type ofblood".

omōme.Comment: C marks the vowel of the last syllable long in theplural form.

ōmpa.Comment: T consistently has a short vowel in the firstsyllable.

on-.Grammar: prefix for verbs primarily indicating direction ofaction away from the speaker; sometimes used forformality without literal directional sense
on-.Spanish: partiŸcula que se junta a verbos para significardistancia de lugar, o por viŸa o manera de ornato ybuen sonido, etc. (M)
on-.Comment: Although this shares the distal sense with theparticle ŌN found in ŌMPA, INŌN, etc., they differin vowel length.

ōn.Spanish: adj. que indica la distancia, la lejaniŸa (S)
ōn.Comment: This particle contrasts with the proximal particleĪN to form such pairs as INŌN "that, those" andINĪN "this, these".  The vowel length is generallyleft unmarked in C because of this item's highfrequency.  C does mark the long vowel part of thetime, and T is consistent in having the reflex of Ō.The directional verbal prefix ON- differs from theparticle ŌN in vowel length despite the similarityof meaning.

oncān.Comment: This sometimes has the sense "within sight", closerthan ŌMPA.  One would expect the ON to have a longvowel as ŌMPA does, and in fact B marks the vowellong in two out of six attestations, and X has ufor O.  Elsewhere it is consistently short.

ōnte-tl.English: two (of a class of lump-shaped things)

ōntlapal.Spanish: de dos lados (M), de ambos lados (C)
ōntlapal.Comment: C does not mark the vowel of the first syllablelong in any of the attestations.

-ōpōchcopa.Spanish: a tu mano izquierda (C for second pers. sg.possessor)
-ōpōchcopa.Comment: C does not mark the first and second vowels long inthe single attestation.

ōpōchehēca-tl.Comment: Z fails to mark the long vowels in this item.

ōpōch-tli.Comment: There is inconsistency across sources in vowel lengthmarking.  In a single entry in B both vowels of thestem are long; in three out of four attestations in Conly the first vowel is marked long, with both vowelsunmarked in the fourth attestation.  Z consistentlyleaves the first vowel unmarked and twice out of sixtimes marks the second long.  M's alternativespelling opuch suggests a long second vowel, but Mis not consistent with using this convention only forlong Ō.

ōppa.Comment: In two attestations C does not mark the initial vowellong, but T consistently has the reflex of Ō, and Zmarks it long once out of two times.  In T ŌPPA hasbeen reanalyzed as a unitary lexical item and asecond -PA attached to yield ŌPPAPA.  In Z ŌPPA alsoseems to have been lexicalized and from it has beenderived ŌPPATICA "for a second time".  X has adifferent derivation, OCPA < OC "another" and -PA,but with the same sense.

oquīc.Comment: The sense of this appears to be the combined sense ofOC and ĪC, but the second vowel is attested markedlong only a single time in B.  C does not mark itlong in any of abundant attestations.

-oquichnacayō.Spanish: de sus partes, hablando honestamente ... de las delvaroŸn (C)

oquichpil-li.Comment: Z idiosyncratically has PĪL where other sources havePIL.

oquichpīpiloc.Comment: Z idiosyncratically has PĪL where other sources havePIL.  The long vowel of the reduplication isstandard.  The derivation is opaque; perhaps itshould be from PĪPIL, -YŌ, and -C(O).

-oquichtiuh.English: older brother (from the point of view of a sister)
-oquichtiuh.Spanish: la hermana dice de su hermano mayor (C)

oquichtlaīcōltiā.Comment: T has COL for CŌL here, but there should bethe reflex of a long vowel.

oquich-tli.Spanish: varoŸn, o macho en cada especie (M)
oquich-tli.Comment: The possessed honorific form is -OQUICHHUAHTZIN witha glottal stop intervening between the possessed nounform and -TZIN.

otla-tl.Comment: In one attestation Z has both vowels long, the firstfollowed by the reflex of a glottal stop (a phonologicallyimpermissable sequence), whereas T has both vowelsshort.

otomi-tl.English: a member of the group of people who speak Otomi (alanguage unrelated to Nahuatl)

ōtztiā.English: to become pregnant; to impregnate s.o.
ōtztiā.Comment: M and X have an intransitive verb "to becomepregnant" in addition to a transitive verb "to causes.o. to become pregnant", while T has this as areflexive verb "to conceive".  M and X give thepreterit as onotztic, but T has it as a regular-IĀ verb.  X has Z for TZ.

ōtztitoc.Comment: This is not directly derived from ŌTZTIĀ butrather from M's related intransitive verb, whichforms its preterit with -C.

ōy(a).Comment: T has a reduplicated form that loses the Y and formsthe preterit as a regular -OĀ verb, OHOĀ.  T alsohas lost the Y where ŌY(A) is bound with the prefixTLA-, while C gives an applicative form that alsoloses the Y, ŌILIĀ.

*oztetiā.Comment: If this is the correct analysis, this would seem tobe related in an idiosyncratic way involving vowellength and consonant discrepancies to ŌTZTIĀ "toconceive, to become pregnant".  A possible alternatederivation is from a reflexive verb *(I)ZTETIĀhaving to do with becoming powerful, taking command.See also TĒIZTI-TL "s.o.'s fingernail" as a metaphorfor "child, offspring".

ōztōmēca-tl.English: a type of merchant; person from Oztoman

-pa.Comment: This indicates movement toward or from apoint and, with numerals, how many times; MĀCUĪLPA"five times" < MĀCUĪL-LI "five".

pā.Spanish: ten9ir algo con tinta o colores de tinteros (M)
pā.Comment: M only gives the nonspecific object prefix ascompatible with this verb, and it is exclusively soattested in C, but Z gives it as a full transitiveverb.  T has a synonymous full transitive verbTLAPALLŌTIĀ derived from TLAPAL-LI "dye".

pāc(a).English: to bathe; to wash, launder s.t.
pāc(a).Spanish: se lava, se asea (T), lavar algo o batanar pan9os osayales (M)
pāc(a).Comment: In a section on the preterits of verbs represented byMACA and TOCA which retain their stem-final vowels, Cpoints out that PĀC(A) follows the rules ofvowel-dropping but leaves it open that it may have analternate preterit PĀCAC (Cf.31v).  M givesalternative preterits -PĀC and -PĀCAC forTLAHTLAPĀC(A) "to wash s.t. repeatedly".  This verbpreserves the Proto-Uto-Aztecan initial *P which hasbeen lost in Ā-TL "water, liquid".

pāccā.Spanish: alegremente (M), con quietud y sosiego (C), poco apoco, etc. (C)

pāccāpolihu(i).Spanish: tiene flojera, se desmaya, tiene poca salud (T)

pachihu(i).English: to eat one's fill, to be satisfied
pachihu(i).Spanish: hartarse de vianda o estar satisfecho (M)
pachihu(i).Comment: With YŌLLŌ this means to satisfy s.o. about somematter in doubt.  This may be an extension ofPACHIHU(I) "to collapse, settle" in the sense thatone is satisfied when one's meal has settled.

pachihuiā.English: to waylay or spy on s.o.
pachihuiā.Comment: This takes a direct object plus an oblique reflexiveprefix.  C contrasts this with PAHCHĪHUIĀ "tobenefit from medicine".

pachilhuiā.English: to press s.t. down on s.o.
pachilhuiā.Spanish: apretar o apesgar algo a otro (M)

pachoā.English: to be gathered; to reap s.t. to oneself
pachoā.Spanish: se arrima, se acerca (T), lo arrima, lo acerca (T),aplicar o allegar algo junto a siŸ (M forconstruction with -TECH)
pachoā.Comment: As a transitive verb this occurs in construction with-TECH to express "oneself" as the recipient.  Thismay be an extension of PACHOĀ "to press s.t." inthat in gathering, one presses s.t. to oneself.

pachōhuāzhuiā.English: to comb, groom oneself; to comb, groom s.o.
pachōhuāzhuiā.Spanish: se peina, se acepilla (T), lo peine, lo acepilla (T)

pachōhuāz-tli.Comment: T's notation is ambiguous between OHUA and ŌHUA,but by general rule the sequence here should beŌHUA.

pach-tli.Spanish: malojo o cierta yerba que se cria y cuelga en losaŸrboles (M), heno (T)
pach-tli.Comment: CUAUHPACH-TLI is Spanish moss.  The sense common tothe many uses of PACH-TLI is of worthlessness,parasitism, or refuse with respect to plants.

pācohua.Comment: This nonactive form of PĀQU(I) "to be happy"contrasts with PĀCALŌ = PĀCŌ, the alternativenonactive forms of PĀC(A) "to bathe, wash".

pāctiā.English: to enjoy, take pleasure in s.t.; to give s.o.pleasure
pāctiā.Spanish: fruir de algo o tener mucho placer y contentamientocon alguna cosa (M), dar placer a otro (M)

pacyō-tl.Comment: This appears only in the Spanish-to-Nahuatl side ofM.  Z appears to have an intrusive vowel between thefirst and second syllables, PAQUIYŌ-TL.

pahchīhuiā.English: to avail oneself of s.t. as medicine
pahchīhuiā.Spanish: me aprovecho de algo, como de medicina (C for firstpers. sg. subject)
pahchīhuiā.Comment: This takes a direct object plus an oblique reflexiveobject.  C contrasts it with PACHIHUIĀ "to spy ons.o., to waylay s.o.".

pahcualtiā.English: to take poison; to poison s.o.

pahhuiā.English: to take poison; to poison s.o. or s.t.
pahhuiā.Spanish: se envenena (Z), lo envenena (Z), lo fumiga (T)
pahhuiā.Comment: M has pauia "for a mother to chew food for herchild".

pahī.Spanish: tomar o beber purga o jarabe (M)

pahītiā.English: to take medicine or poison; to administer medicine orpoison to s.o.
pahītiā.Spanish: tomar o beber purga o ponzon9a jarabe o cosa asiŸ(M), dar purga o ponzon9a a otro (M)

pahmictiā.English: to take poison; to poison s.o.
pahmictiā.Spanish: tomar ponzon9a para matarse (M), matar con veneno (R)

pahpāc(a).English: to bathe; to bathe s.o., scrub s.t.
pahpāc(a).Spanish: lavarse (M), enjabonar ... a otra (M), fregar olavar vasos, o quitar y limpiar heces (M)
pahpāc(a).Comment: This contrasts with PĀPĀC(A) "to insult s.o."  Mcombines them in a single entry.

pahpahzol.Comment: M has the transitive verb papac˛oloa "to snare,perplex, entangle s.t. or to make impertinentremarks".  T has lost the glottal stop in the secondsyllable.

pahpahzoltic.Comment: T has lost the glottal stop in the second syllable.Z has PĀPAHZOLTIC "s.t. disordered, messed up".

pahpāl-li.Comment: This is only attested in compounds with ĪX-TLI"eye", the construction having the sense "blind".Although TLAPAL-LI "dye" has a short vowel in thesecond syllable, this item and the verb from whichthey are both derived have the corresponding vowellong.

pahpaloā.English: to lick one's lips; to lick s.t., to touch s.t.lightly
pahpaloā.Spanish: lamerse o relamerse (M), lamer algo (M), lamer a otro(M)

pahpāqu(i).English: to enjoy oneself, to take great pleasure
pahpāqu(i).Comment: M also has transitive papaqui "to repeatedly enjoys.t."  R consistently has PAHPAHQU(I) for PAHPĀQU(I)and its derivations.

pahpāquiltiā.English: to cause s.o. to be happy
pahpāquiltiā.Spanish: alegro a otros (C for first pers. sg. subject)

pahpāt(i).Spanish: deshacernos (C for first pers. plural subject)

pahpatla.Comment: This seems to describe foliage rather than to referto a specific plant.  T has PĀPATLA.

pahti.Comment: The preterit of this, PAHTIC, contrasts with thepreterit of PĀT(I) "to melt, dissolve, be consumed",which is PĀT.

pahtiā.English: to cure s.o., to restore s.o. to health, to restoreor fix s.t.
pahtiā.Spanish: curar o sanar a otro (M), restaurar, adobar, oenmendar algo (M)

pahtiliz-tli.Spanish: cura o sanidad (M), restablecimiento de la salud (R)

pahtīltiā.Comment: By general rule the vowel of the second syllableshould be short here but is attested as long in bothT and Z.

pahtlāliliā.English: to recover with the aid of medicine; to cure s.o., toadminister medicine to s.o.
pahtlāliliā.Spanish: se medicina, se cura (T), lo cura, lo medicina, losana (T)

pah-tli.Spanish: medicina generalmente, emplasto, ungu ento, etc. (M)
pah-tli.Comment: This often has the sense of "poison" as well asbeneficial medicine.

pāhuac(i).English: to cook s.t. in a pot, to stew s.t.
pāhuac(i).Spanish: cocer algo en olla o en cosa semejante (M)
pāhuac(i).Comment: The initial syllable of this is probably cognate withĀ-TL "water, liquid" and preserves theProto-Uto-Aztecan initial *P.

pāhuaxīltiā.Comment: By general rule the vowel of the third syllableshould be short but is attested long in C.  It isunmarked for length in R.

-pahuīc.Comment: The order of elements appears to be optional.-HUĪCPA also occurs with the same sense.

pahzolhuiā.English: to be bothered by s.t., s.o.
