pahzol-li.Comment: M has pac˛oltic "s.t. tangled, matted, thick" InTEPAHZOL-LI T and X have lost the internal glottalstop.

pahzoloā.English: to bristle, to be bothered, troubled; to snarl,entangle, bother, or trouble s.o.
pahzoloā.Spanish: erizaŸrsele el pelo al gato o al perro (M), semolesta, se estorba (T), reburujar, enhetrar, omaran9ar algo (M), lo molesta, lo estorba (T)
pahzoloā.Comment: This is abundantly attested in T, where the glottalstop has been lost.  Z has it in reduplicated formand with the glottal stop present.

-pal.English: for, by means of, for the sake of
-pal.Spanish: por, y mediante, como (C), por, por medio de, cerca,con, etc. (S)

palāctic.Comment: By general rule the vowel of the second syllableshould be short, but is attested as long in Z.

palānaltiā.Comment: M has palaniltia with the same sense.

-palāncā.English: one's unworthiness, one's sins, one's rottenness
-palāncā.Spanish: nuestra podredumbre (C for first pers. pluralpossessor)

palāncānac(a)-tl.Comment: C fails to mark the vowels of the second and thirdsyllables long.

palāncāpah-tli.Spanish: nombre de dos o tres plantas medicinales (R)
palāncāpah-tli.Comment: R indicates the glottal stop but not the long vowels.

palānqui.Comment: Z has PALĒNQUI (once with the vowels of both thefirst two syllables long) with the sense "distilleryof aguadiente".  This may be a variant of PALĀNQUIand refer to the fermentation process.

palax-tli.English: s.t. festering or rotten, a wound, sore, or tumor
palax-tli.Comment: This implies an unattested verb *PALAY(A) "to fester,become infected".

pālchichīn(a).English: to suck s.t. in, to inhale

palēhuiā.English: to look after one's own interests; to help s.o., fors.t. to favor s.o.
palēhuiā.Spanish: favorecer y ayudar a miŸ mismo (M), ayudar a otro(M), serme favorable y provechosa alguna cosa (M withfirst pers. sg. object)

pal-li.English: black clay used in dying cloth
pal-li.Comment: This is indirectly attested in TLAPAL-LI "dye".  Theverb PĀ "to dye s.t." has a long vowel, while thecorresponding vowel of TLAPAL-LI is short.  Byanalogy, the vowel of PAL-LI is probably also short,but T has ĪXPAHPĀL-LI "blind", also derived fromPĀ and with the reflex of a long vowel.

paloā.English: to sip, taste s.t.; to sop bread in soup or gravy
paloā.Spanish: gustar alguŸn manjar o mojar el pan en alguŸn potajeo salsa (M), probar alguna bebida o manjar (C), losopea (T)
paloā.Comment: The reduplicated form of this, PAHPALOĀ, has amongits senses "to lick s.t."

paltiā.Comment: This contrasts with intransitive PALTIY(A) "to getwet, soaked".

paltic.Comment: T consistently has a short vowel in the initialsyllable and Z a long one.

paltiliā.English: to get wet, soaked; to wet, soak s.t.
paltiliā.Spanish: se moja (T), mojar a otro (M), mojar algo (M), se lomoja (T)

paltiy(a).Spanish: mojarme (M for first pers. sg. subject)
paltiy(a).Comment: T consistently has a short vowel in the initialsyllable and Z a long one.  The initial P is asurvival of Proto-Uto-Aztecan *P, and this item isrelated to PĀC(A) "to wash s.t.", PĀT(I) "todissolve", and Ā-TL "water, liquid".  M also has thevariant palti.

pām(i)-tl.Comment: A variant of this is PĀN-TLI, which is homophonouswith the word for "row, wall".  The possessed form-PĀN contrasts in vowel length with locative -PAN"at (surface or time)".  M has this in the compoundedforms quachpamitl, quachpantli and quachpanitl.

-pampa.English: for, for the sake of, through, because of
-pampa.Spanish: por, por amor, a causa de (S)

-pan.English: on the surface of, for or at a particular time
-pan.Comment: Z consistently has a long vowel, while there isagreement across other sources that the vowel isshort.

panahuiā.Spanish: vencer o sobrepujar a otros, o ser mayor que ellos, opasar a los que van adelante caminando, o pasar de laotra parte del riŸo a alguno, en barca, o acuestas(M), traspasar mandamiento o ley (M), lo cruza, lospasa (T)

panhuetz(i).English: to climb upward, to scale the heights, to attainhonor
panhuetz(i).Spanish: alcanzar honra o encumbrar sierra o cuesta (M),encumbra, va cuesta arriba, va subiendo (T)
panhuetz(i).Comment: This has the opposite sense from HUETZ(I) "to fall".T has the variant form PAHUETZ(I).  M has entries forboth forms.

panhuetzītiā.Spanish: lo sube, lo saca para arriba (T)

pani.English: on top, on the outside or surface
pani.Spanish: encima, o por de fuera, en la sobre haz (M)

-pani.Comment: This item takes possessive rather than subjectprefixes and is always singular in form.

paniyān.English: place on top, at the summit

panō.Spanish: pasar el riŸo a pie, o nadando, o en barca (M)
panō.Comment: Z has intransitive PANOĀ "to go by, cross over" andtransitive PANŌHUIĀ "to cross s.t."  X has PANOHUAbut drops the HUA and adds C to form the preterit.

panoā.Comment: Z has this as an intransitive verb "to go by, crossover" and has PANŌHUIĀ as the correspondingtransitive verb "to cross s.t."

panōltiā.English: to pass, convey s.t., s.o. from one place to another
panōltiā.Comment: This is abundantly attested in T and is also in Z.

panōltih.Grammar: salutation directed to a stranger, s.o. not local
panōltih.Spanish: saludo entre el mexicano (el de pueblo) y la personade afuera (T)
panōltih.Comment: This is most commonly used in honorific form,PANŌLTIHTZINOH.

panquīxtiā.Comment: T consistently has a short vowel in the firstsyllable of QUĪXTIĀ.  By general rule the vowelshould be long, and it is so marked in otherconstructions of this type from other sources.

panquīz(a).English: to rise, revive, bloom forth, issue

pantlāliā.Spanish: lo monta (Z referring to a horse)

pantlamōtla.Spanish: lo arroja (de arriba abajo), lo tira (de arribaabajo) (Z)

pān-tli.Comment: This is also abundantly attested in T in TEPĀN-TLI"stone wall".  PĀM(I)-TL "flag, banner" has avariant form that is homophonous with this.

pantzicuīn(i).English: to leap down from above; for water to fall, cascade
pantzicuīn(i).Spanish: brinca de arriba abajo (Z), salto de agua, cascada(Z)

pāpāc(a).Spanish: baldonar una mujer a otra (M), lo escarnece (T)
pāpāc(a).Comment: C contrasts this with PAHPĀC(A) "to scrub s.t.".

papachca.Spanish: cortarse el almendrada o otra cosa semejante (M),trasmina (T)
papachca.Comment: In the Spanish-to-Nahuatl side T has PAHPACHCA.

papactic.Spanish: pegajoso, se siente el cabello pegajoso, grasiento(T)

pāpahzoloā.English: to mess s.t. up, to disorder s.t.
pāpahzoloā.Spanish: maran9ar o enhetrar algo o mezclar plaŸticasimpertinentes (M), desordena (Z)
pāpahzoloā.Comment: T has two related forms with PAH instead of PĀ forthe initial syllable.

pāpālōquil(i)-tl.English: edible plant used for food and medicinally forrheumatism
pāpālōquil(i)-tl.Comment: In T the third syllable has been elided.

pāpatla.Comment: This seems to describe foliage rather than refer to aspecific plant.  Z has PAHPATLA.

papatlaca.Spanish: revolar el ave, o temblar y tiritar de friŸo (M),revolotear el ave, temblar el corazoŸn, etc. (C)

papatlatz(a).English: for s.t. to beat its wings
papatlatz(a).Comment: Z gives this as though it were a preterit-as-presentverb, although verbs of this type are otherwiseregular.

pāpāyīn(i).Spanish: anda por aquiŸ y por allaŸ, inquieto (Z)
pāpāyīn(i).Comment: In one of the attestations the vowels of the firsttwo syllables are unmarked for length.

pāqu(i).English: to be happy, to experience pleasure
pāqu(i).Comment: M also gives this as a transitive verb "to enjoys.t., to lead a happy life".  It contrasts with PAQUI"now and then".

paqui.Spanish: a veces, de vez en cuando (T)
paqui.Comment: This contrasts with the verb PĀQU(I) "to be happy".R consistently has PAH for PĀ.

pāquiltiā.English: to make s.o. happy, to give s.o. pleasure
pāquiltiā.Spanish: alegrar a otro (M), le alegro (C for first pers. sg.subject)
pāquiltiā.Comment: M gives this as synonymous with papaquiltia, whichis only to be found in the Spanish-to-Nahuatl side ofthe dictionary.

pāquītiā.English: to make s.o. happy, to give s.o. pleasure

patca.Spanish: de parte de, por parte de, en lugar de (Z for-ĪXPATCA), su querida (del hombre casado) (T)
patca.Comment: M has patcayotia "to substitute for s.o., tosucceed s.o. in office".

pāt(i).Spanish: deshacerse la sal, nieve, o hielo y caraŸmbano ohacerse agua y derretirse (M)
pāt(i).Comment: This verb preserves the Proto-Uto-Aztecan initial *Pwhich has been lost in Ā-TL "water, liquid".C contrasts this with PAHTI "to recover one'shealth".

*pati.Comment: This is implied by PATIUH-TLI, and PATIYOH.  It hasto do with worth or price and may also be related toPATLA "to exchange s.t."

pātiliā.English: to dissolve, melt s.t. for s.o.
pātiliā.Spanish: se lo derrite (para otra persona), se lo revuelve (T)
pātiliā.Comment: The applicative forms of intransitive PĀT(I) "todissolve" and transitive PĀTLA "to dissolve s.t."appear to have fallen together in T.

patiliā.English: to change; to misdirect s.o., to change, exchange, orbarter s.t. with s.o.
patiliā.Spanish: se cambia (T), errar a otro en el camino (M), vender,trocar ... una cosa (S)
patiliā.Comment: C contrasts this with PĀTILIĀ, the applicative formof PĀT(I) "to dissolve".  S confuses this withPAHTILIĀ "to cure s.o." and PĀTILIĀ "to dissolves.t. for s.o."

patiuh-tli.Spanish: paga, precio de lo que se vende, o soldada (M)
patiuh-tli.Comment: This is almost always used in possessed form, and theUH of the second syllable is probably the possessivesuffix absorbed into the stem.

patiyoh.Spanish: cosa que tiene precio o que vale tanto (M), precioalto, caro, costoso (Z)
patiyoh.Comment: This is abundantly attested in T and Z.  T has avariant with E for I.  It contrasts with PAHTIYOH"s.t. with medicinal properties".

patiyōhua.English: to rise in price, to be expensive
patiyōhua.Spanish: costar o valer tanto, o cosa que tiene precio (M), seencarece, sube el precio (T)

patiyōtiā.English: to raise the price of s.t.

patla.Comment: M combines the glosses of this and PĀTLA "todissolve, melt s.t." in a single entry.  C contraststhe two.

pātla.English: to lose hope, to weary of waiting
pātla.Spanish: enfadarse o cansarse de espera o desconfiar (M)
pātla.Comment: If this is just a reflexive use of PĀTLA "todissolve, decompose, melt s.t.", it is considerablyremoved in sense.  C contrasts both this andtransitive PĀTLA with PATLA "to change, exchanges.t."

patlachihu(i).Comment: This is synonymous with the reflexive use ofPATLACHOĀ.

patlachoā.English: to become flat, to collapse; to flatten, press, crushs.t.
patlachoā.Spanish: se aplasta (T); lo aplasta, lo prensa (T)
patlachoā.Comment: This is abundantly attested but only in T, Z, and X.

patlachtic.Spanish: cosa ancha, asiŸ como mesa, viga, etc. (M)

patlāhua.Comment: M has intransitive and transitive patlahua andgives no preterit form for the transitive verb.  Itis likely that the preterit of this item isPATLĀHUAC, contrasting with the transitive preteritPATLĀUH, but this is not adequately attested.

patlāhu(a).Spanish: ensanchar camino, mesa, lecho, o cosa semejante (M)

patoā.English: to throw dice, gamble, play patole
patoā.Spanish: jugar a los dados, o a juego de fortuna (M)
patoā.Comment: M glosses patolli as "dice" although it is actuallya game played with coloriŸn seeds.

patohuiā.Spanish: jugar con otro a los dados o a juego de fortuna (M)

pātz-.Comment: This element is a constituent of many constructionshaving to do with liquid; PĀTZCA "to squeeze liquidout of s.t.", PĀTZIHU(I) "for a swelling tosubside", PĀTZCALAQU(I) "to sink", PĀTZTŌCA "tosubmerge s.t.", etc.  This preserves theProto-Uto-Aztecan *P that has been lost in Ā-TL"water, liquid".

patzac-tli.Spanish: trigo, maiŸz, o cacao an9ublado o helado o cosassemejantes (M for patzactic)
patzac-tli.Comment: M has patzac in a phrase referring to mildewedmaize.

pātzca.English: to express, give forth liquid; to squeeze liquid outof s.t., to wring out wet clothes
pātzca.Spanish: se exprime, se aprensa, se oprime (T), exprimir osacar zumo de alguna cosa o torcer ropa mojada (M),exprimir cosa que da aqua o zumo (C)
pātzca.Comment: PĀTZCA is an element of CŌCOHPĀTZMICTIĀ andQUECHPĀTZCA "to choke, strangle s.o."

pātzcalaqu(i).Spanish: se hunde, se sume, se sumerge (T)

pātzihu(i).English: for s.t. to get crushed, bruised, dented in, or fora swelling to subside
pātzihu(i).Spanish: abollarse alguna cosa o deshincharse el encordio (M)

pātzoā.English: to bruise s.t., to mash fruit, to crush s.o., to makelight of what s.o. says or does
pātzoā.Spanish: abollar algo, o ablandar fruta o cosa semejante entrelos dedos (M), apretar a otro, o deshacer y apocar loque otro dice o hace (M)

pātzquiliā.English: to squeeze, wring out excess liquid from s.t. fors.o.
pātzquiliā.Spanish: sacar, estrujar o exprimir zumo de alguna cosa paraotro (M)

pātztic.English: s.t. dripping wet, s.t. juicy; s.t. bruised, mashed, soft
pātztic.Spanish: cosa abollada o cosa blanda, asiŸ como fruta muymadura (M), mojado (X)
pātztic.Comment: X has reduced TZT to TZ.

pātztōca.English: to submerge, sink; to submerge s.t., to sink s.t.
pātztōca.Spanish: se sume, se sumerge, se hunde (Z), lo hunde, lo sume,lo sumerge (Z)

payān(a).English: for s.t. to get pulverized; to break up, crumble,grind s.t.
payān(a).Spanish: se muele (T), quebrantar terrones o desmenuzar algo(M)

payāniliā.Spanish: se lo muele (T), se lo muele (el nixtamal a otrapersona) (T)

pēchoā.English: to squat, crouch, bend over; to lower s.t., to bends.t. down
pēchoā.Spanish: se encorva, se agacha (T), lo agacha, lo encorva (T)
pēchoā.Comment: Only T has PĒCHOĀ as an independent verb, and in Tthe first syllable contains the reflex of a longvowel.  The other sources have items involvingprostrating oneself with PECH as an element, and thevowel is consistently short.

pechtēca.English: to bow low, to humble oneself
pechtēca.Comment: This is abundantly attested in applicative form.

pechtēquiliā.English: to bow down in reverence before s.o.
pechtēquiliā.Spanish: hacer a otro gran inclinacioŸn y reverencia (M)

pech-tli.Comment: This is not attested as a free element.  It appearsas prefixed TLAPECH-TLI, reduplicated PEHPECH-TLI,and in compounds.

pehpech-tli.Spanish: colchoŸn o ropa sobre que nos echamos a dormir (M),aviŸo (de las bestias), silla, fuste (T)

pehpen(a).English: to pick, choose s.o., to gather, collect, or gleans.t.
pehpen(a).Spanish: elegir o escoger a alguno (M), escoger algo oarreban9ar y recoger lo esparcido por el suelo (M)
pehpen(a).Comment: This is abundantly attested with incorporated objectsacross all sources but especially in T where itappears with more than a dozen different harvestableor collectable items such, such as CUAUHPEHPEN(A) "togather firewood", TLAŌLPEHPEN(A) "to harvest maize",XĪTOMAPEHPEN(A) "to pick tomatoes", etc.

pehpetla.English: to groom oneself; to groom s.o. or to stroke, pat,or pet s.t.
pehpetla.Spanish: peinarse (M), peinar a otro, o halagarle trayeŸndolela mano sobre la cabeza y asentaŸndole el cabello conella (M), lo acaricia (animal), lo alisa (Z)

pehpetzoā.English: to rid oneself entirely of s.t.
pehpetzoā.Comment: As a reduplicated form of PETZOĀ "to polish s.t.,to make s.t. shine", this seems to arrive at itsmeaning in T by way of the sense of losing one's hairor shaving one's head and hence having a shiny baldpate.

pehpetztic.Comment: M has pepetzca "for silk or fine plumage toshimmer".

pēhu(a).English: to drive s.t. ahead of oneself, to vanquish one'senemies
pēhu(a).Spanish: lo arrea (T), conquistar o vencer a los enemigos (M)

pepechiuhtoc.Comment: This implies intransitive *PEPECHIHU(I) "to stick, tobecome attached", although only the transitivePEPECHOĀ "to affix s.t." is attested.

pepechoā.English: to cover or patch s.t., to affix s.t., to attach s.t.permanently
pepechoā.Spanish: atapar o cerrar alguŸn agujero de pared a piedra lodo(M), lo pega, lo suelda (T), lo pega (con goma), loconecta (Z)

pepechōhuiliā.English: to hook s.t. up, to harness s.t.

pēpēhualtiā.Spanish: provocar a san9a a otro (M), lo ofende (T), loinjuria (T)
pēpēhualtiā.Comment: The sense of this reduplicated form is at somedistance from the sense of unreduplicated PĒHUALTIĀ"to initiate s.t."

pepetlaca.English: to shimmer, to reflect light, to be resplendent
pepetlaca.Comment: R has this with a glottal stop in the first syllable,but there should not be one, and C, T, and Z agree onthis.

pepetlatz(a).Comment: This should share with PEPETLACA and PETLĀN(I) thesense of "to shimmer, to reflect light".

pepeyaca.Comment: M has pepeyoca "for water or fields to shine in thelight of the sun or moon".  This is probably the sameverb with the sense referring to the scattering oflight.

pepeyotz(a).English: to give s.o. the shivers, to make s.o.'s skin crawl
pepeyotz(a).Spanish: le hace cosquillas, siente andar algo en la piel (T)
pepeyotz(a).Comment: This should relate in some regular way to M'spepeyoca "for s.t. to shimmer with reflectedlight".

petlācal-li.Spanish: petaca a manera de arca que hacen de can9as tejidas(M)
petlācal-li.Comment: The vowel of the second syllable is marked long inall attestations.  Possibly this is a compound ofPETL(A)-TL "woven mat" and ĀCAL-LI "boat" < Ā-TL"water" and CAL-LI "structure" and partiallyanalogous to CUAUHCAL-LI "cage".

petlāhu(a).English: to disrobe; to undress s.o., to uncover s.t., topolish or burnish s.t.
petlāhu(a).Spanish: despojarme o desnudarme (M), despojar o desnudar aotro (M), brun9ir, lucir, o acicalar algo (M)
petlāhu(a).Comment: This makes the same connection between "bare" and"shiny" that PEHPETZOĀ and PEHPETZTIC do.

petlahuah.Comment: In one of three attestations C marks the vowel of thesecond syllable long.

petlahuahcāhuah.English: master of the possessors of mats, petates
petlahuahcāhuah.Spanish: sen9or de los duen9os de las esteras y petates (C)

petlāhuiliā.English: to undress s.o., to uncover s.t. for s.o.

petlān(i).English: for s.t. to scatter, glisten, reflect
petlān(i).Spanish: derramarse alguna cosa liŸquida (M), derramarse algoy relumbrar (C), brilla, reluce, relumbra (T)

petlāniā.Spanish: derramar cosa liŸquida o acicalar y lucir algo (M),lo tira, lo riega (T)

petlazol-li.Comment: M has petlac˛olcoatl with the same sense.  It ispossible that the absolutive suffix here should be-IN, since T's notation is ambiguous for -LI and -INwith stems ending in L.

petōn(i).English: to dislocate, to move out of place
petōn(i).Spanish: desencasarse alguŸn hueso del cuerpo o cosasemejante, o salir fuera a la pared los canes demadera o el tablamento, etc. (M)
petōn(i).Comment: T gives as a nonactive form of this PETŌNĪLŌ withthe reflex of a long vowel in the third syllable,which is clearly wrong.

petzcahui.Comment: T gives the preterit of this as PETZCAHUIC eventhough it pairs with transitive PETZCOĀ as -HU(I)verbs in general pair with -OĀ verbs.

petzcoā.English: to slip, slide; to slide s.t. along
petzcoā.Spanish: resbalar, deslizarse, o descabullirse de entre otros(M), se resbala (T), lo resbala (T)
petzcoā.Comment: This seems to be related to PETZOĀ "to make s.t.smooth, to polish s.t."

petzcōhuīx-in.Spanish: aspia, tipo de lagartija muy brillosa y venenosa (X)

petzihu(i).Spanish: pararse muy lucio lo brun9ido o acicalado (M), seresbala, se alisa (T)

petzoā.English: to polish, burnish s.t., to make s.t. smooth andshiny

petztic.Spanish: pulido, brillante, reluciente, barnizado, fino, liso(S)
petztic.Comment: X has reduced TZT to ZT.

petz-tli.English: pyrite, material used in making mirrors

pexōn(i).Spanish: henchirse o rebosar la medida de cosa liŸquida (M),llena (Z)

pexōntiā.English: to fill s.t. up with liquid
pexōntiā.Spanish: henchir mucho alguna medida de cosas liŸquidas (M),lo llena (Z)

peyo-tl.English: mescal cactus (Lophophora lewinii, Lophophorawiliamsii), the button-shaped segments of which areconsumed as an intoxicant
peyo-tl.Spanish: cierta planta medicinal de que abusan para lasupersticioŸn (R)
peyo-tl.Comment: This appears in R without diacritics.  M has peyutl"cocoon".

pī.English: to gather plants without disturbing the roots, topluck s.t.
pī.Spanish: pelar o sacar de raiŸz los pelos o coger yerbas sinarrancar las raiŸces de las (M)
pī.Comment: The evidence for the vowel of this verb being long iscircumstantial.  The verb is abundantly attested in Cbut not in the modern sources, which have only CUIand PEHPEN(A).  C does not mark the vowel long inseveral attestations of the preterit but doesconsistently mark it long in causative PĪLTIĀ.This is weak evidence, because there is somevariation over verbs in general between short andlengthened vowels before -LTIĀ.  For CUI there ismore evidence of a short stem vowel, but its attestedcausative is nonetheless CUĪLTIĀ.  In the attestedapplicative form of reduplicated PIHPĪ T has thereflex of a short vowel before -LIĀ.

pīcca-tl.Comment: This is attested in the possessed forms -MĀPĪCCA"glove" and -CUĀPĪCCA "bonnet".  M has picca,also in possessed form, referring to the vulva, and Sgives piccatl as the absolutive form.  S is theonly authority for the absolutive form.  Theattestations from the sources for this dictionary arecompatible with this being the possessed form ofPĪCQUI "s.t. wrapped up".

pīchaquiā.English: to humble oneself; to humble s.o., to bring s.o. low
pīchaquiā.Spanish: es humilde, se humilla (T), lo humilla (T)

pīchaquīhua.Comment: This is the nonactive form attested for thetransitive use of PĪCHAQUIĀ.

pīchaquīlō.Comment: This is the nonactive form attested for the reflexiveuse of PĪCHAQUIĀ.

pīchiliā.English: to blow or snort at s.o.
pīchiliā.Comment: This is abundantly attested in T.

picīlihu(i).English: for s.t. to get worn down, diminished, ground fine
picīlihu(i).Spanish: hacerse menudo lo que era grueso y redondo (M)

picīloā.English: to wear s.t. down, to make large, round thingssmaller, to grind s.t. fine
picīloā.Spanish: desbastar o achicar cosas grandes y redondas (M)
picīloā.Comment: This is implied by PICĪLTIC.  X has TLAPICĪLOĀ"to rain" and a derived noun meaning "(rain)drop".

picīltic.English: s.t. small or fine, s.t. ground down to small size
picīltic.Spanish: cosas menudas asiŸ como chinas o aljofar (M), tejidoapretado (de tela, ayate, zaranda, etc.) (T), picado,pequen9o (Z)
picīltic.Comment: Z also has the shortened form PICĪL referring togravel.  This implies PICĪLOĀ and PICĪLIHU(I).

pīcqui.Comment: This is indirectly attested in MĀPĪCTŌN "handful",MĀPĪCCA-TL "glove", and -CUĀPĪCCA "bonnet".  Inthe sources for this dictionary and in M there isonly possessed -PĪCCA, which would seem to be thepossessed form of this, but S has piccatl as wellas picqui, assuming two lexical items distinct intheir absolutive forms.

pihpī.English: to pluck, gather s.t. in quantity
pihpī.Comment: This reduplicated form is the distributive of PĪ"to pluck, gather s.t."  In T it is attested withincorporated objects referring to hair and beard,hence "to cut one's hair" and "to shave".  Althoughthere is some evidence that PĪ has a long stemvowel, the attested applicative form in T has a shortvowel before -LIĀ and -TZĪNOĀ.

pihpītzcua.English: for s.t. to make one's skin itch
pihpītzcua.Spanish: le cosquillea la piel (p. ej. cuando ha andado en layerba o en la milpa, etc.) (T)

pihpiy(a).English: to spy on s.o., to lurk in wait for s.o.
pihpiy(a).Comment: Z has PIHPĪX as the name of a thrush (tordo real).If this is derived from the verb, then the preteritform of the verb is also PIHPĪX.  See PIY(A) formore about the alternation of long and short I inpreterits ending in X.

pih-tli.English: older sister (from the point of view of a woman),lady's maid
pih-tli.Spanish: hermana mayor o dama o criada que acompan9a a susen9ora (M)
pih-tli.Comment: C comments that the honorific form -PIHTICĀTZIN ismore affectionate than simple -PIHTZIN.

pīhuic.English: s.t. extra given over and above what is paid for
pīhuic.Spanish: lo que se da maŸs de lo pesado cuando uno estaŸcomprando (T)

-pil.Comment: To mean the offspring of s.o., this is used inpossessed form, and the plural is necessarilysuffixed with plural possessive -HUĀN.  UnlikePIL-LI "noble person", this plural does notreduplicate, NOPILHUĀN "my children" contrasts withNOPĪPILHUĀN = NOPĪPILLŌHUĀN "my lords", thelatter forms rather unlikely without the honorific-TZIN.  Honorific -TZIN is generally but notuniversally used with "offspring" too, nopiltzin"my child" (Cf.55v).  Although PIL with the sense ofchild rarely occurs in absolutive form, thediminutives PILTŌN-TLI and PILTZIN-TLI do, and inthese the plural stem does reduplicate in just thesame form as PIL-LI "noble person", PĪPILTZITZINTIN.

-pīl.Comment: C gives the difficult example of PILPĪL "littleboy", the plural of which (to be found in M as well)is PĪPILPIPĪL, with reduplication of both the stemand the diminutive element.  Since PIL "child" has ashort vowel in the stem and a long vowel in itsreduplication, while diminutive -PĪL has a longvowel with short-vowel reduplication, this leads tomirrored relative vowel length (long-short,short-long) which has been confused in the 1892reprinting of Carochi.  It is correct in the originalprinting.

pilāhuiltiā.English: to look after children, to play with a child
pilāhuiltiā.Spanish: hace por cuidar a las criaturas, juega con el nin9o(T)

pilalacconē-tl.Comment: T has the possessed form -PĪPILANCONĒ and theplural possessed form -PĪPILANCŌCONĒHUĀN.

pilalac-tli.Comment: T has the variants PILAN- and PĪPILAN- in compounds.

pilcaticah.Comment: M has pilcaticac with the same sense.

pilcatoc.Comment: In three of the attestations Z marks the vowelof the initial syllable long, but it should not be.

pilhuahtiā.English: to conceive children; to provide s.o. with children
pilhuahtiā.Spanish: hacer hijos o engendrarlos (M), le engendra hijos (T)

pilhuēhuehca.English: s.o. who has children separated by long intervals
pilhuēhuehca.Spanish: tiene hijos de vez en cuando, no continuamente (T)

pilhuiā.English: to hang s.t. up for s.o.
pilhuiā.Spanish: colgar algo a otro de alguŸn palo, etc. (M)

pil-li.Spanish: caballero o noble persona (M), los cortesanos del Rey(C for possessed form)
pil-li.Comment: There is a variation in vowel length across sources.C and T consistently have a short vowel in the stem;Z consistently has a long one.  B in general has thevowel unmarked for length or specifically marks itshort but commonly marks it long when the vowel of anadjacent syllable is long.  This is not consistent; Bhas both cihuĀpĪpĪltin and cihuĀpĪpiŸltin.B marks the corresponding vowel long in TĒCPILLŌ-TL"nobility" and TĒCPILCAL-LI "court".  (The sameassimilation appears when B marks the vowel of thelast syllable of CUITLAPIL-LI "tail" short whenfollowed by -LI but long when followed by pluralpossessive -HUĀN.) The honorific vocative form hastwo full honorific -TZIN's, NOPILTZINTZINE "my nobleperson", etc.  This best makes sense if thought of asthe iterative addition of -TZINE to PILTZIN; it isnot reduplication, which would give -TZITZINE.PIL-LI is neutral with respect to sex or masculine bydefault.  "Lady" has the modified form CIHUĀPIL-LI.M has nopilo "my nephew (from the point of view ofa woman)", which is probably a different andcontrasting item, since both times that it occurs inM it is spelled with a single l.

-pil-li.Comment: This component element of CUITLAPIL-LI "tail",NENEPIL-LI "tongue", MAHPIL-LI "finger", and(I)CXOPIL-LI "toe" appears to have the general sense"appendage", hence it is not unreasonable toassociate it in sense with -PIL "offspring".  On theother hand, it can also be reasonably connected withPILOĀ "to hang".  The vowel of the stem is shortacross sources except in Z where PIL is always long,whether as "lord", "child", "appendage", or thediminutive compounding element.  Z also has thiscompounded with TĒN-TLI "beak" to mean "stinger" andwith TZON-TLI "head" to mean "cold, respiratoryinfection".  Despite the affinity of meaning, it isapparently not a component of TŌPĪL-LI "staff, rod"or METLAPĪL-LI "rolling pin", since it differs invowel length.

pillō-tl.Comment: M also gives "childishness", which is derived from-PIL "child".

piloā.English: to hang oneself; to hang s.t. up, to hang s.o.
piloā.Spanish: ahorcarse o colgarse (M), ahorcar o colgar a otro(M), colgar alguna cosa de alto, asiŸ como ropa, etc.(M)
piloā.Comment: This contrasts with PĪLOĀ "to make s.t. thinner".

pīloā.English: to make s.t. thinner, to taper s.t.
pīloā.Comment: This contrasts with PILOĀ "to hang s.t. up".

pilōhuiliā.English: to connect s.t., to hook s.t. up
pilōhuiliā.Comment: Only one of the three attestations marks the O long.

piltic.Spanish: hombre gentil (M), cosa ahidalgada y noble (C)
piltic.Comment: This contrasts with PĪLTIC "s.t. thin or tapered toa point".

pīltic.English: s.t. thin or tapered to a point
pīltic.Comment: This contrasts with PILTIC "s.t. or s.o. noble".

-piltiyān.Spanish: mi nin9ez o el tiempo de mi nin9ez (R for firstpers. sg. possessor)
-piltiyān.Comment: This implies *PILTI "to be a child".  R fails tomark the vowel of the final syllable long.

piltōn-tli.Spanish: nin9o o nin9a, muchacho o muchacha (M)

pīnaca-tl.Spanish: escarabajo grande y bermejo que no vuela (M)

pīnāhua.Comment: T has preterit PĪNĀUH rather than PĪNĀHUAC.  Malso has transitive pinahua "to be embarrassed toappear or to do s.t. before others" with the samepreterit form as T's intransitive.

pīnāhuiā.Spanish: le hace burla, se burla de uno (T)

pīnāuhtiā.English: to be ashamed; to shame or insult s.o.
pīnāuhtiā.Spanish: tiene vergu enza, se avergu enza (T), avergonzar oafrentar a otro (M)

pinolīyō.Comment: Because of word-final shortening, the length of thefinal vowel is ambiguous.  This seems to be relatedto PINOL-LI "flour".

pinol-li.Spanish: la harina de maiŸz y chiŸa antes que la deslian (M),sal molida (C for IZTAPINOL-LI)

pipīctic.Spanish: correoso, duro (un palo que se raja con trabajo) (T)
pipīctic.Comment: Z marks the vowel of the second syllable long, but Tmarks it short.

pipihyāc.Spanish: perfumado (T), huele a orines (T for ĀXĪXPIPIHYĀC)
pipihyāc.Comment: M has pipiyaliztli "underarm odor".  T has YOC forYĀC.

pīpinoā.English: to draw s.t. out into a point, to sharpen s.t.

pipītz(a).English: to blow on s.t. with bellows, to blow on s.t.repeatedly

pīpitzatzin.English: s.t. drawn into a point, s.t. or s.o. thin, narrow

pipitzca.Spanish: brama el ciervo, relinchar el caballo, o chillar elratoŸn (M), rechina (T)

pipitzoā.Comment: T specifically marks the vowel of the reduplicatedsyllable short.

pīpixahu(i).Comment: M also has unreduplicated pixaui with the samesense.

pīqu(i).English: to invent or fabricate s.t., to wrap s.t. up orenclose s.t.
pīqu(i).Spanish: forgicar o fingir e inventar alguna cosa o mentir asabiendas, o envolver tamales en hojas cuando loshacen, o cosa semejante (M), lo envuelve (Z)

pīquilōni.Comment: This is attested in CUĀPĪQUILŌNI "bonnet" andTLAXCALPĪQUILŌNI "napkin for wrapping tortillas".

pītz(a).English: to huff and puff with anger; to blow on s.t., to playa wind instrument
pītz(a).Spanish: pararse bermejo o encenderse de enojo (M), tan9er otocar trompeta, chirimiŸa, flauta o otro instrumentosemejante o soplar el fuego (M)
pītz(a).Comment: This contrasts with PITZA "s.t. thin, tough".

pitza.Comment: This contrasts with the transitive verb PĪTZ(A) "toblow on s.t."

pitzac-tli.Spanish: cosa delgada y larga asiŸ como vara, soga, o cosassemejantes (M)
pitzac-tli.Comment: Z marks the vowel of the first syllable long, but itis short elsewhere.

pītzahtzi.English: to talk in a high, thin voice, to squeak
pītzahtzi.Spanish: habla en voz delgadita, chilla (garganta, puerta,etc.)
pītzahtzi.Comment: Despite the discrepancy in vowel length, this appearsto be related to PIPITZCA "to whinny, shriek,squeak".

pitzāhua.Comment: This is implied by PITZĀHUAC and is synonymous withPITZĀHU(I).

pitzāhu(a).English: to make s.t. thin, to cut boards or lengths of rope
pitzāhu(a).Comment: This is implied by PITZĀHUAC and PITZĀHU(I).  Mcombines this gloss in one entry with anotherreferring to a high-pitched voice, which is derivedfrom PĪTZ(A).

pitzāhuac.Spanish: cosa delgada, asiŸ como varas, pilares, columnas,sogares, y cosas largas y rollizas, o el camino, elviento delgado y sutil, los frijoles pequen9os,lentejas, o cosas semejantes (M)
pitzāhuac.Comment: This implies intransitive PITZĀHUA "to get thin" andtransitive PITZĀHU(A) "to make s.t. thin".

pitzāhu(i).Comment: In a compound with CUAUH T has a short vowel in thesecond syllable but in the free form T has a longone.  M has synonymous pitzaua, which forms itspreterit by adding -C.  It is apparently the sameverb with an idiosyncratic vowel-length variation.

pitzāuhcācecuīhua.Comment: This is attested in T, which has CŌHUA for CUĪHUA.

pitzcotōn(a).Comment: T has a long vowel in the first syllable of PĪTZCUA"to pinch s.t." and a short vowel here.

pītzcoyōnqui.English: s.t. pierced, s.t. with a narrow opening
pītzcoyōnqui.Spanish: estrecha cosa asiŸ como agujero o cosa semejante (M),agujerado (T)
pītzcoyōnqui.Comment: Despite the vowel length discrepancy, this appears tobe related to PITZĀHU(A) "to make s.t. thin".

pītzcua.Comment: T has a short vowel in the first syllable ofPITZCOTŌN(A) "to pinch s.t." and a long vowel here.

pītzēhua-tl.Comment: Z also has PĪCHĒHUA-TL with the same sense.

pitzīn(i).Spanish: quebrarse el huevo, machucarse la fruta, o quebrarseel ojo, o reventar el encodio o cosa semejante (M),se exprime (T)

pitzīniliā.English: to squeeze s.t. out for s.o.

pitzoilama.Comment: In T the initial I of ILAMA drops after the finalvowel of PITZO-TL, but elsewhere ILAMA retains itsinitial I adjacent to preceding vowels.

pitzoneloā.English: to get dirty, to get s.t. dirty
pitzoneloā.Spanish: se ensucia (T), lo ensucia, lo mancha (T)

pitzotic.Spanish: feo, escabroso, cosa inmunda, sucio, terrible (T)
pitzotic.Comment: This is attested twice in T and abundantly in Z.  Itcontrasts with PITZŌTIC "narrow".

pitzotiliā.English: to soil oneself; to make s.t. ugly, to defile s.t.
pitzotiliā.Spanish: se ensucia (Z), lo hace feo, lo afea, lo mancha (T)

pitzo-tl.Comment: There is agreement across sources that both vowelsare short except for Z in which about half theattestations mark that of the second syllable long.Association of PITZO-TL with filth and defilementis limited to T and Z.

pitzotlahtoā.English: to speak in a crude manner

pitzotlahtoāni.English: s.o. who speaks in a gross or obscene way

pitztic.Spanish: delgado (animal o hombre), duro, macizo, tieso,paraliŸtico (T for CUAUHPITZTIC)
pitztic.Comment: This is not attested as a free form but only as thesecond element of two compounds in T.  X reduces TZTto ZT.

pītz-tli.Spanish: cuesco o hueso de cierta fruta (M)

pixca.Spanish: coger el maiŸz o segar el trigo (M)

-pixqui.Comment: That which is kept or guarded is bound to this as anincorporated object of the verb PIY(A).  B and Zattest this with a long vowel in the first syllable.

pixqui-tl.Spanish: cosecha, lo que se coge, o siega de la heredad osementera (M)

piy(a).English: to protect oneself from s.t.; to take care of s.o.or s.t., to have stewardship of s.t., to hold s.t.
piy(a).Spanish: guardarse de algo (M), guardar a otro (M), guardaralguna cosa (M)
piy(a).Comment: T consistently has a short I throughout the verbalparadigm, and Z has a long vowel.  B and C have ashort vowel throughout except in the preterit, wherethe I is followed by X.  In these cases the vowel issporadically marked long.  The incidence ofTLAHPIY(A) implies a virtually synonymous derivedverb (I)HPIY(A).  A common variant of PIY(A) isPIY(E).

piyaliā.English: to keep s.t. for s.o., to care for s.t. for s.o.
piyaliā.Comment: A common variant of this is PIYELIĀ.  T reduces itfurther to PILIĀ in compounds and PĪLIĀ as afree form.

piyaltiā.English: to entrust oneself to s.o.; to deposit s.t. withs.o. for safekeeping
piyaltiā.Spanish: encomendarme a otro o fiar mi persona del que piensoque me aprovecharaŸ (M for first pers. sg. subject),depositar o dar guardar algo a otro (M)

piyāzoā.English: to make s.t. long and straight
piyāzoā.Spanish: hacer una cosa larga, derecha, y redonda como unavara (C)
piyāzoā.Comment: T has YO for YĀ, and C does not write theintervocalic Y.  C gives this as a metaphor for "tourinate" and T glosses it as "to defecate", while Mhas reflexive piazoa "to steal off, to slip away"and also piaztli "long, thin gourd used as a pipeto conduct liquid".  The basic meaning probably hasto do with liquid running in a narrow course.  Withthe senses "to urinate" and "to defecate", this takesthe prefix TLA-.

piyāztētēca.English: to lie stretched out; to lay s.t. straight
piyāztētēca.Spanish: se acuesta estirado (T), lo acuesta bien derecho (T)

piyāztic.Spanish: cosa larga y delgada asiŸ como hombre, columna, ocosa semejante, o cosa estrecha asiŸ como mesa,lecho, o cosa asiŸ (M), derecho (vertical--se dice depalo) (T)

-pōch.Comment: This element of (I)CHPŌCH-TLI "young woman" andTĒLPŌCH-TLI "young man" forms its plural byreduplication, -PŌPŌCHTIN, implying that (I)CH andTĒL are modifiers, but these elements do not appearindependently in other constructions.

pōchēhu(a).English: to get smoky; to smoke s.t., to fill s.t. with smoke
pōchēhu(a).Comment: M also has intransitive pocheua, preterit formedwith -C, "for a house to fill up with smoke, forbread to scorch".

pōchēhu(i).Comment: This has the same sense as PŌCHĒHU(A) usedreflexively.

pochictic.English: s.t. raveled, frayed, spongy; s.t. pale in color,blonde
pochictic.Spanish: cosa carmenada, fofa, o esponjada (C), huero, blonde,blanco (Z)
pochictic.Comment: The sense in Z points to PŌC-TLI "smoke" rather thanPOCHĪN(A) "to unravel s.t.", but in only one of thenine attestations is the vowel of the initialsyllable marked long.  Z also has POHPŌCTIC "smokecolored" derived from PŌC-TLI.  There are twotypographical errors in Z's attestations.  In one thefinal C of the second syllable is omitted, and in theother there is S in place of word-final C.

pochīn(a).English: to unravel s.t., to card wool, cotton
pochīn(a).Spanish: cardar o carmenar lana, algodoŸn, o cosa semejante(M)
pochīn(a).Comment: This is implied by POHPOCHĪN(I).  Z has what appearsto be the causative form POCHĪNALTIĀ with thesense of "to whiten s.t.", possibly because fibersbecome lighter in color as they are carded.

pochīnaltiā.Comment: In both attestations the vowel of the first syllableis marked long, and this seems to contain the elementPŌCH "smoke", but Z also has POCHICTIC "s.t. palein color, blonde" in which the vowel is not markedlong in eight of nine attestations.  This alsoappears to be the causative form of the verbPOCHĪN(A) "to unravel s.t., to card fiber".

pōchō-tl.Spanish: aŸrbol hermoso y grande, de cuyas raiŸces se sacabaun jugo que se utilizaba como febriŸfugo (S), aŸrbolgrande (C)

pōchtēca-tl.Comment: This is a regular derivation from a place name, whichin this case would be PŌCHTLAN, probably related toPŌC-TLI "smoke, vapor".

pōch-tli.Comment: S has this as a free form, and it appears as anelement of Z's PŌCHMĀ(I)-TL, but Z also has OPŌCH.Since C and M have exclusively OPŌCH, PŌCH can bethought of as a variant which has lost the initialvowel.  No absolutive form of it is attested in thesources for this dictionary, although S gives it inabsolutive form.

pōchuiā.Comment: This derivation with the form PŌC "smoke" isapparently synonymous with T's POPŌCHHUIĀ withPŌCH.

pōctēmītiā.English: to fill s.t. up with smoke

pōc-tli.Comment: In compounded and derived forms there is generallythe form PŌCH in place of PŌC, but Z retains PŌC,and T has both.

pōcyoh.Comment: Z has an intrusive I between the two syllables,PŌQUIYOH.

pōcyohua.Comment: The vowel of the second syllable of PŌCYOHUA is notmarked long in Z, but it probably should be.

-poh.Spanish: su igual, o su compan9ero (M),igualidad o semejanza (C)
-poh.Comment: This is abundantly attested in C, R, and P.Modifying elements may intervene between thepossessive prefix and the verb, NOPOH "my equal, s.o.like me", NOTLĀCAPOH "a human being like myself",NOCNŌPOH "s.o. poor like me".  This can be thoughtof as a preterit-as-present verb of the irregulartype which takes possessive rather than subjectprefixes and occurs only in singular form, in whichcase, it implies *POĀ "to be, become like s.o."  Shas absolutive potli, but it is nowhere attested inthe sources for this dictionary.

pohpochīn(i).Comment: This implies transitive POCHĪN(A) "to unravel s.t.,to card fiber".

pohpohtiā.English: to pair off, unite, join one thing with another
pohpohtiā.Spanish: parear, hermanar, o conchabar una cosa con otra (M)
pohpohtiā.Comment: In one attestation in R this takes a direct objectplus an oblique reflexive object prefix.

pohpōhu(a).Comment: M combines this with PŌPŌHU(A) "to pay s.t." in asingle entry.

pohpolhuiā.English: to pardon s.o. for s.t.; to destroy s.t. for s.o.
pohpolhuiā.Spanish: perdonar a otro la ofensa o destruirle alguna cosa(M)
pohpolhuiā.Comment: POHPOLHUIĀ as the applicative of POHPOLOĀ has aliteral sense of destruction, but it also has thelexicalized sense of specifically obliterating s.o.'ssins or guilt.

pohpoloā.Spanish: gastar la hacienda (M), destruir combatiendo oconquistando (M), desperdiciar o destruir algo, ohacer costa, borrar alguna cosa, o oscurecer laclaridad grande a la pequen9a (M)

pohpolōn(i).Spanish: ser tartamundo o impedido de la lengua (M)

pohpoxoā.English: to get turned over, to undergo upheaval; to turn s.t.over, to prepare ground for sowing
pohpoxoā.Spanish: se revuelca (T), barbechar o mollir la tierra (M)
pohpoxoā.Comment: T has this modified by TLĀL with the sense "to rollin the dirt" and by Ā "to wallow about in water".

pohpoxōn.Comment: In one of the attestations Z marks the vowel of thesecond syllable long.  This appears to be related toPOHPOXOĀ "to turn s.t. over" and implies*POHPOXŌN(I).  M's puxactic "s.t. spongy" mayalso be relevant.

pohpoztequ(i).English: to chop, break up, smash s.t.
pohpoztequ(i).Spanish: quebrar muchas veces palos o cosas semejantes (M)
pohpoztequ(i).Comment: This appears as a transitive verb in M, but C givesit as intransitive "to get broken".

pohtiā.English: to pair off, join one thing with another
pohtiā.Spanish: parear, hermanar, o conchabar una cosa con otra (M)
pohtiā.Comment: This appears in P as a reflexive verb.

pōhu(a).English: to be lofty, haughty, arrogant; to hold s.o. inrespect
pōhu(a).Spanish: ser soberbio (M), tener respeto a otro (M)
pōhu(a).Comment: M combines the gloss of the transitive use of thiswith that of the verb "to count", and the sense ofputting oneself or s.o. else first is a reasonableextension of "to count".

-pōhual-li.English: a unit of twenty in the vigesimal counting system
-pōhual-li.Comment: This is prefixed by a number which multiplies thetwenty, CEMPŌHUAL-LI "twenty", ŌMPŌHUAL-LI "forty"(two times twenty), etc. TLAPŌHUAL-LI means "s.t.countable", and the negated phrase AHMŌ ZANTLAPŌHUAL-LI "an infinite number".

pōhuani.Comment: This belongs to a group of deverbal nouns derivedfrom the customary present form of the verb.  Theverb in this sense is reflexive and retains arelexive prefix corresponding to the person andnumber of the referent, although the plural alsotakes an absolutive (i.e., nonpossessed) pluralsuffix, MOPŌHUANI "he is haughty", TITOPŌHUANIMEH"we are haughty" (Cf.44r).

pōhu(i).Grammar: intransitive verb form, object expressed aspossessive bound with -TECH.
pōhu(i).English: to pertain to s.t., to belong to s.o., to go withs.o.
pōhu(i).Spanish: pertenecer a alguna persona (M), partidario, con eŸlpertenece, lo acompan9a (Z)
pōhu(i).Comment: On the Spanish-to-Nahuatl side Z once has yohuicorresponding to pŌhui on the other side.

pōhuiliā.English: to count, to talk, to discourse; to count s.t., todiscuss s.t., to report s.t. to s.o.
pōhuiliā.Spanish: platica, cuenta (T), lo cuenta, lo platica, lo entera(T)
pōhuiliā.Comment: This is abundantly attested but only in T.

-pōl.Grammar: derogative compounding element implying large size,great degree; pl: -POPŌL
-pōl.Spanish: acrecienta la significacioŸn in malam partem deordinario (C)

polactiā.Spanish: anegar o sumir algo en el agua (M)
polactiā.Comment: M also has polacqui "s.t. submerged", whichimplies *POLAQU(I) "to sink, to submerge".

polhuiā.English: to lose or destroy s.t. for s.o.
polhuiā.Spanish: perder cosa ajena o borrarle algo de otro (M)

polihu(i).English: to perish, to disappear, to be missing or consumed
polihu(i).Spanish: perecer o desaparecer o perderse y destruirse (M)
polihu(i).Comment: This is the intransitive verb corresponding totransitive POLOĀ "to lose, ruin, destroy s.t."

poliuhcāyō-tl.Spanish: mi perdimiento, mi perdicioŸn (C for first pers. sg.possessor)
poliuhcāyō-tl.Comment: This is only attested in possessed form.

-pōloā.Grammar: derogative verbal compounding element added directlyto the preterit stem

poloā.English: to perish, to be destroyed; to destroy, squander orspend s.t., to lay waste s.t. or s.o.
poloā.Spanish: perderse y destruirse (M), perder o destruir a otroscon guerra o conquistarlos (M), gastar hacienda (M),perder algo (M), perder el juicio y desatinarse,borrar algo, o quitarla sen9al que estaba puesta enalguna parte (M)
poloā.Comment: This contrasts with PŌLOĀ "to mix flour, earth,etc., with water".  M combines the glosses of both ina single entry.  With the prefix TLA-, POLOĀ meansto lose one's senses or to make errors.

pōloā.English: to mix flour, bran, earth, etc., with water
pōloā.Spanish: hacer lodo o barro (M), revolver harina o salvado otierra con agua (C)
pōloā.Comment: This contrasts with POLOĀ "to lose, destroy s.t."

polochtic.Spanish: chino (T), cabello chino, pelo chino (T for TZON-TLIPOLOCHTIC)

popōca.English: to smoke, to give off vapor
popōca.Spanish: hacer humo (M), humear, echar humo de siŸ (M)

popōchhuiā.English: to be smoked; to smoke, fumigate s.t.
popōchhuiā.Comment: This is abundantly attested in T and also appears inB and R.  R has a glottal stop in the first syllable.This may be derived from POPŌCH-TLI "incense", butit seems to be synonymous with Z's PŌCHUIĀ and mayalso be a reduplicated derivation from PŌCH "smoke".

pōpōhu(a).English: to pay s.t., to make restitution for s.t.
pōpōhu(a).Spanish: restituir lo ajeno (M), pagar una cosa (S)
pōpōhu(a).Comment: M combines this with POHPŌHU(A) "to clean s.t." in asingle entry.  This is not directly attested in thesources for this dictionary but is implied byintransitive PŌPŌHU(I).

pōpōhu(i).Spanish: se ha cumplido con la obligacioŸn (C for phrase withpaired (I)XTLĀHU(A))

popoloca.English: to speak a language badly, to speak a foreignlanguage, to speak unintelligibly

popolotz(a).English: to speak in such a way that others fail tounderstand, to make one's speech unintelligible, tosay s.t. in a foreign language
popolotz(a).Spanish: no hacerse comprender, hablar una lengua baŸrbara (S)

popō-tl.English: plant used to make brooms; broom, straw

popōtz(a).Spanish: hace humo (para alguna cosa, p.ej. hacer salir alconejo) (T)

popōtzoā.Spanish: hinchar los carillos, apretarse la gente, o espesarselas yerbas (M)
popōtzoā.Comment: In one of the two attestations Z marks the vowel ofthe second syllable long and in the other leaves itunmarked for length.  Z glosses this as a noun"lung".

popoyactic.Comment: T omits the C of the third syllable in oneattestation, but it is present in the other and inthe entries of the Spanish-to-Nahuatl side.

popoyōtic.Comment: M has pupuyuctic referring to blighted grain.

popozoca.Spanish: hervir la olla o cosa asiŸ (M), hervir con muchoruido (C)

pōpozōnaliz-tli.Comment: M has popoc˛oniliztli "the bubbling, boiling of apot; great anger".

popozotz(a).English: to boil s.t. hard, to make s.t. foam

potōn(i).Comment: T has this compounded with TLĀL-LI with the sense of"for it to be dusty (weather)".  This would appear tobe a homophonous but separate item, yet M provides agloss about dust for related POTŌNQUI.

potōnqui.Comment: M has the additional gloss "very fine dust or siftedflour".  This would seem to be a separate item, but Tprovides a gloss for POTŌN(I) referring to dust.

pōtz(a).English: to throw up earth, to burrow
pōtz(a).Comment: One of the attestations is TLĀLPŌTZ(A), whilethe other appears to be TLAPŌTZ(A).

pōtzal-li.Comment: This is attested as an element of ĀZCAPŌTZAL-LI"ant hill" and the place name ĀZCAPŌTZALCO.

-pōx.Grammar: attested only in possessed form and in compounds, notin absolutive form
-pōx.Comment: This is abundantly attested but only in Z.  It may berelated to POZĀHU(I) "to swell".

poxāhuac.Comment: M has poxactic with the same sense.

poxāhu(i).English: to fall, to get out of plumb

poxcahu(i).Spanish: enmohecerse o henchirse alguna cosa de oriŸn (M)

pōxihcatoc.Comment: In one attestation PŌX is written out as a separateword.

-pōxnacaztlan.Spanish: su lado, su costado (Z for possessed form)

pōxpampilcac.Comment: One of the attestations omits the final C.

poyāhu(a).Comment: M also has poyahuac "s.t. shaded, s.t. dark",which implies intransitive *POYĀHUA.

poyāhu(i).Comment: This is attested in Z in the formĪXPOYĀHU(I) "to be dizzy" and in Tin ĪXTLAPŌPOYĀHU(I) "to get dark".

poyec.Spanish: cosa que tiene sal, asiŸ como el manjar o el agua (M)

poyeliā.English: to get salty; to add salt to s.t.
poyeliā.Spanish: se pone salado (T), le echa sal (T)

poyōmicqui.English: victim of treachery or evil design

poyōmiqu(i).English: to die by treachery or evil design of others

poyō-tl.Comment: This is more common in reduplicated form POPOYŌ-TL"rottenness, decay".

pozāhu(a).Spanish: hinchar ... a otro (M), se lo hincha (T)
pozāhu(a).Comment: M has intransitive poc˛aua, preterit poc˛ahuac,"for one's body to swell up", while T's correspondingintransitive is POZĀHU(I).

pozoc-tli.Comment: Z gives this with and without the absolutive suffix.

pozōn(i).English: for s.t. to boil, for the sea to be turbulent andcovered with foam; to get very angry
pozōn(i).Spanish: hervir la olla o la mar (M), enojarse mucho (M)

pozōnqui.Spanish: chiltejate, agua de orchata, una cosa hervida (T)

poztecpah-tli.Spanish: nombre de dos plantas medicinales (R), bejuco,huesero (X)

poztequ(i).English: to split, to break lengthwise; to break s.t.lengthwise
poztequ(i).Spanish: se quiebra, quiebra la direccioŸn en que va (T),quebrar palo o cosa asiŸ (M), lo quiebra (T)
poztequ(i).Comment: T also gives this as an intransitive with the samemeaning as the reflexive.

quechcochtitlan.Comment: T has possessed -QUECHTLAN, which may bea truncation of QUECHCOCHTITLAN.  M has theshorter form with an absolutive suffix,quechtlantli.

quechcotōn(a).English: to cut off the head of s.o. or s.t.
quechcotōn(a).Spanish: degollar, o cortar la cabeza a otro (M), cogerespigas o cosa semejante con la mano (M)

quechcotōnqui.Spanish: degollado, o descabezado (M), un muerto sin cabeza(Z)

quechcōzca-tl.Spanish: la asillas de la olla de la garganta, o cuentas ypiedras preciosas,o) joyas que se ponen en la garganta o en el cuello (M),collar, gargantilla (T)

quechcuauhti.English: for one's head to get tired

quechcuauhyō.English: the throat, neck, nape of the neck, neck of an animal
quechcuauhyō.Spanish: su cuello, su pescuezo, su nuca (T), su pescuezo (deanimal) (Z)
quechcuauhyō.Comment: No attestation indicates a final glottal stop,indicating -YOH rather than -YŌ, but this does nottake an absolutive suffix, and since vowels shortenword-finally, the length of the final vowel isambiguous.

quechiā.Comment: This appears without TLA- only in Z, where CUAUHTŌC"stake" is incorporated into the verb.

quechilacatzoā.English: to twist the neck, to wring s.o.'s neck, to strangles.o.

quechmalīn(a).Spanish: le tuerce el cuello (de gallina, etc.) (T)

quechnāhuahtequ(i).English: to hug s.o. around the neck

quechōl-li.English: bird with red plumage; flamingo or roseatespoonbill; the plumage of such a bird
quechōl-li.Spanish: paŸjaro de pluma rica (M), paŸjaro de brillanteplumaje muy solicitado; algunos autores lo hanllamado flamenco; pluma de dicho paŸjaro (S)
quechōl-li.Comment: This attestation is of TLĀUHQUECHŌL-LI "redflamingo", which is redundant in English translationbut not in Nahuatl, since QUECHŌL refers not to thecolor of the bird but apparently to thecharacteristic sweeping motion of its neck.Elsewhere in Nahuatl literature QUECHŌL-LI oftenappears without the modifying TLĀUH withoutalteration of sense, as illustrated in the gloss inS.  It commonly occurs without the absolutive suffix.

quechpanoā.English: to carry s.o. or s.t. on the shoulders
quechpanoā.Spanish: llevar a otro encima de los hombros (M), llevar otracualquier cosa encima de los hombros (M)
quechpanoā.Comment: This is indirectly attested in the causative formQUECHPANŌLTIĀ.

quechpanōltiā.English: for s.t. to be carried on the shoulders
quechpanōltiā.Comment: This implies QUECHPANOĀ, which is not directlyattested in the sources for this dictionary.

quechpātzoā.Comment: Z has QUECHPĀTZCA with the same sense.

quechpiloā.Spanish: colgar a alquien por el cuello (S)

quechquēm(i)-tl.English: an indigenous Mesoamerican garment consisting of acloth with a neck hole cut in the center; it ispulled on over the head and usually falls to a pointin front and back.  This literally means"neck-garment".
quechquēm(i)-tl.Comment: None of the glosses cited conveys a true sense ofQUECHQUĒM(I)-TL.

quechtamalayoh-tli.Comment: In one of the attestations Z has the first and fourthsyllables of TAMALAYOH long, and in the other thesecond and third, but on the basis of M'stamalayutli meaning a type of squash, it appearsthat the constituents of this compound are indeedTAMAL-LI and AYOH-TLI and that there are no longvowels at all.

quechtecoyāhu(a).English: to make a hole in s.t. (a huipil or quechquemitl) inorder to pull it on over the head
quechtecoyāhu(a).Spanish: lo agujera para poneŸrselo por la cabeza (T)

-quechtemēmecapal.English: tendons of the neck and head
-quechtemēmecapal.Comment: T has a reflex of a long vowel in the secondsyllable, but it should not be.  As attested, this isa possessed form with reduplicated stem but no pluralsuffix.  The absolutive singular should probably beQUECHTEMECAPAL-LI.

quechte-tl.Comment: This is only attested as the first elementof several compounds.

quechtetzom(i)-tl.Spanish: cabello o pelo (M for tzontli), lana, seda, crin (Sfor tzomitl)
quechtetzom(i)-tl.Comment: This entry is questionable in both form and gloss.Because the single attestation is in possessed form,the final element may be either TZON-TLI orTZOM(I)-TL.  This occurs in a metaphor withMĀNĀHUAL-LI "coverlet, blanket", and the sense ofthe whole construction is "protection".

quechtlan-tli.Comment: X has QUECHCOCHTITLAN "nape of the neck".

quechtlapān(a).English: to have a tumor of the neck

quech-tli.Comment: Z is inconsistent, with a long vowel in someattestations.  The rest agree with the other sourcesin having a short vowel.

quechtomāhuac.English: s.o. with a swollen neck, a tumor of the neck

quechtzon-tli.Comment: Z is inconsistent.  In one attestation both stemvowels are long, in the other only the second.  Thelatter form is consistent with other sources sinceZ regularly has a long vowel corresponding to the shortone in TZON-TLI elsewhere.

quēcīzquipa.Comment: C contrasts this with QUĒZQUIPA which means simply"how many times?".

quehquehquetztinem(i).English: to wander about stopping in one place and another
quehquehquetztinem(i).Spanish: andarse parando en una parte y otra (C)

quehqueleh.Comment: Z lacks the glottal stop of the first syllablein both attestations.

quehquelhuītiā.Comment: T has an alternation between QUEHQUELHUĪTIĀ andQUEHQUELIHUĪTIĀ.

quehquel-li.Comment: Z has this without the absolutive suffix with thesense of "jester, joker".

quehqueloā.Spanish: hacer cosquillas a otro, o escarnecer y burla aalguno (M)
quehqueloā.Comment: T lacks a glottal stop in the first syllable, andit is only present in some of Z's attestations ofQUEHQUELOĀ and its derivations.

quehquetz(a).English: to pace about aimlessly, wasting time; to kick out ats.t. in anger
quehquetz(a).Spanish: espaciarse, o perder tiempo (M), dar patadas decoraje (C)
quehquetz(a).Comment: Z has this in a phrase about ears standing up, aliteral distributive sense of QUETZ(A).  C contrastsQUEHQUETZ(A) with QUEQUETZ(A) "to trample on s.t."

quehtzom(a).Spanish: adentallar, morder a otro, o dar bocados (M)
quehtzom(a).Comment: T has lost the internal glottal stop.  This may berelated to (I)HTZOM(A) "to sew, stitch s.t.".

quēmahca.Comment: According to C, this is more polite than QUĒMAHalone.

quēmahcatzin.Comment: According to C this is yet more reverential thanQUĒMAHCA

quēm(i).English: to put on or wear clothes
quēm(i).Spanish: ponerse manta o capa, o traerla puesta (M), vestirsede una vestidura (C)
quēm(i).Comment: This most often occurs with the nonspecific objectprefix TLA- with the sense "to be dressed".  With aparticular item of clothing, the specific objectmarker is used.

quēmiloā.English: to wrap s.t. up, to cover s.t.

quēm(i)-tl.Comment: The variant QUĒN-TLI co-occurs with QUĒM(I)-TL INC, T, and Z.  When not modified by QUECH, this formis prefixed with TLA- in all attestations.

quēmman.Spanish: algunas veces, a tiempos, o a ratos, vel. a quehora?  (M)

quēmmaniyān.Spanish: algunas veces, o a tiempos (M), alguŸn diŸa, algunavez (T), cuando (Z)
quēmmaniyān.Comment: Z has a variant with ME for MA; T has variants in-EYA, -EYO, and -O for IYĀN.

quēnamih.English: how?  in what manner or condition?
quēnamih.Spanish: de queŸ manera, o de queŸ condicioŸn es?  o queŸ arteo condicioŸn tiene?  (M)
quēnamih.Comment: B and Z end in -MEH rather than -MIH.  Z has QUI forQUĒ.  AMIH is separable to the point that MACH canbe inserted to form QUĒMMACHAMIH.

quēnamihcātzintli.Spanish: de queŸ manera es su merced o sen9oriŸa?  (M)

quēnin.Spanish: de queŸ manera?  o coŸmo es eso?  (M)
quēnin.Comment: Z has this with QUĒN and QUIN variants and alsoQUEMEH with the same sense.

quēnnel.English: what is to be done (of s.t. irreversible)?
quēnnel.Spanish: hecho es, queŸ hemos de hacer?  o queŸ remedio hay?(M)

quēnocyeh.English: all the more, how much more?
quēnocyeh.Comment: C gives this together with QUĒNOQUEH to show thevariation -YEH = -EH.  The literal sense isapproximately "how-still-that?"

quēnoqueh.English: all the more; how much more?

quēntēl.Spanish: alguŸn tanto, o en alguna manera (M)

quep(a).Comment: Z has this form instead of CUEP(A) elsewhere.  Itappears to represent loss of labialization of theinitial consonant.  Since Z does not drop stem-finalvowels in the preterit, the last vowel of the stem isparenthesized here only because it corresponds to avowel that drops in other dialects.

quequetz(a).English: for birds to copulate; to trample on s.t.
quequetz(a).Spanish: de las aves, que se toman (C), pisar y trillar (C)
quequetz(a).Comment: C contrasts this with QUEHQUETZ(A) "to stand up, topace, to kick out at s.t."  M has moquetza "foranimals to mate".

quequexihu(i).Comment: Since this is only attested for T and since T has atendency to lose internal glottal stops, thisprobably corresponds to QUEHQUEXIHU(I) and is in someway related to QUEHQUELOĀ.

quēquēzquilhuitica.English: at an interval of how many days?

quetz(a).English: to stand up; to stop s.o. or to raise s.o. or s.t.
quetz(a).Spanish: levantarse el que estaba asentado (M), detener ohacer parar al que camina o hacer levantar al queestaŸ asentado (M)

quetzalcōā-tl.English: Quetzalcoatl (a major deity, also the name associatedwith the office of a high priest)
quetzalcōā-tl.Comment: T has a form EHQUETZALCŌĀ-TL meaning "whirlwind",suggesting a blend of this with EHĒCACŌĀ-TL "windserpent".  S has a long description of Quetzalcoatldrawn from SahaguŸn.

quetzalhuītōlihu(i).English: to twist, writhe in the manner of quetzal plumes
quetzalhuītōlihu(i).Spanish: se va ... retorciendo a manera de quetzal (C)

quetzalilacatzihu(i).English: to weave in and out in the manner of quetzal plumage
quetzalilacatzihu(i).Spanish: se va entretejiendo ... a manera de quetzal (C)

quetzal-li.English: plumage of the quetzal bird, a trogon with long greentail feathers (Pharomachrus mocinno)

quetzalteuh.English: in the manner of quetzal feathers, as s.t. veryprecious

quexahpāz-tli.Comment: The first element may be related to QUEXĪL-LI "groin"or QUECH-TLI "neck".

quexīlihu(i).English: to suffer pain in the groin

quexīl-li.Spanish: la ingre (M), su ingle (T for possessed form)

quēxquichca.Spanish: queŸ tanto trecho habraŸ hasta tal parte?  (M),interrogativo del espacio que hay de un lugar a otro(C)

-quēz.Grammar: only attested in possessed form and in compounds
-quēz.Comment: This seems to be related to QUEXĪL-LI "groin"but differs in vowel length in the first syllable.

-quēzcuauhyō.Grammar: only attested in possessed form and compounds

quēzqui.Spanish: queŸ tanto?  (C) cuaŸntos o cuaŸntas son?  (M forplural forms), un poco (T)
quēzqui.Comment: The noninterrogative sense of QUĒZQUI and itsderivatives is "a bit, a few".  Other quantifierswith -QUĪN plurals also have -QUĪNTĪN as a longerplural form.  The vowel of the last syllable of the longerform for QUĒZQUI is unmarked for length and is given longhere by analogy with MOCH(I) "all" and MIAC "many".

quēzquicān.Spanish: en cuaŸntas partes o lugares?  o cuaŸntas racionesson?  (M)
quēzquicān.Comment: The noninterrogative sense of QUĒZQUICĀN is "in afew places".

quēzquipa.Comment: The noninterrogative sense of QUĒZQUIPA is "fewtimes, seldom".

quēzzannel.Spanish: queŸ remedio hay, queŸ se ha de hacer?  (C)

-qui.Comment: This is the optative form related to -QUĪHU(I) and-CO.

quichpāya-tl.Comment: T has the reflex of Ō for Ā in the reduplicatedsyllable of the plural form.  Possibly the firstelement of this is a truncation of OQUICH-TLI"male".

quihquilpī.English: to gather edible plants by hand without pulling upthe root
quihquilpī.Spanish: coger con la mano yerbas comestibles, sin lasarrancar de raiŸz (M)
quihquilpī.Comment: Here QUIL(I)-TL is the incorporated object of PĪ,and there is vowel plus glottal stop reduplication.

quihtōznequ(i).Comment: This frozen form includes the specific object prefix.

-quīhu(i).Comment: This form is used in future constructions.  It isattested nineteen times in C, and in three of theseattestations the vowel of the first syllable ismarked long.  The corresponding vowel of -TĪHU(I)"to go to do s.t." is more abundantly attested long.

quil.Comment: This is abundantly attested in C.

quil(i)-tl.English: greens, quelite (the name of several ediblegrass-like plants)
quil(i)-tl.Comment: There is great inconsistency in Z with one or theother of the vowels long as well as with both short.C and T are consistent with both vowels short.

quilmach.Comment: In one of five attestations the vowel of QUIL ismarked long; elsewhere it is short.

quiltōnīl.Comment: The second element is not attested elsewhere.  Zoften omits absolutive suffixes.  The full form shouldprobably be QUILTŌNĪL-LI.

quimichcuitlaxōchi-tl.Comment: QUIMICH-IN "mouse" is sometimes used as a diminutive, sothis may mean "dwarf CUITLAXŌCHI-TL, lesser poinsetta".The Spanish gloss treats the name literally.

quimich-in.Comment: The alternate plural QUIMICHIMEH from M is thestandard one for X and is built on MICHIN as aunitary stem rather than stem plus -IN absolutivesuffix.  It probably represents QUIMICHIMMEH withnasal assimilation and reduction of the resultinggeminate consonant.  QUIMICH-IN is used as adiminutive meaning "small, dwarf, baby", as in Z withthe local word for opossum to mean "baby opossum".

quimichpah-tli.English: white-flowered lily used as a purgative

quimilcēhuiā.English: to relieve s.o. of his burden

quimilhuiā.English: to wrap or bundle s.t. for s.o.
quimilhuiā.Spanish: envolverle, o liarle algo a otro (M)

quimil-li.Spanish: liŸo de mantas, o de ropa (M)
quimil-li.Comment: M has quimili without the geminate, but elsewhereit behaves as a regular stem ending in L followed bythe -LI form of the absolutive suffix.

quimiloā.English: to wrap s.o. or s.t. in a blanket, to enshroud s.o.
quimiloā.Spanish: amortajar muerto, o envolver, enmantar, o vestir aotro (M), liar, o envolver algo en manta, o en cosasemejante (M)
quimiloā.Comment: T has ME for MI.  Z has QUĒMILOĀ with the samesense, and it appears derived from QUĒM(I)-TL"garment".

quin.Comment: This is abundantly attested in C but also appears inB.  Z has YĒQUĪNPA "recently, a while ago", whichappears to be related despite the vowel lengthdiscrepancy.

quinihcuāc.Comment: According to C, QUINIHCUĀC is distinct from IHCUĀCin that it implies some prior event (f.100v).

quiniuh.Spanish: una cosa recieŸn hecha, y que se acaba de hacer (C),ser la primer vez que acaecioŸ algo (M forquiniuhti)

quinīzqui.Spanish: poco tiempo ha, o no ha mucho tiempo (M)
quinīzqui.Comment: The vowel of the second syllable is not markedlong in the single attestation.

quiquic(i).Comment: The vowel of the second syllable is marked long in Xand in one attestation in Z.  This issynonymous with TLANQUIQUIC(I).

quiquinaca.English: to talk through clenched teeth because of pain oranger; to growl, grunt, squeal, buzz
quiquinaca.Spanish: gemir con dolor, o zumbar el abejoŸn, grun9ir elpuerco, regan9ar el perro, o hablar entre dientes (M)
quiquinaca.Comment: In one attestation Z has a long vowel in NA, butelsewhere it is short.

quiquinatz(a).English: to make various grunting, squealing, buzzing soundsat s.o.
quiquinatz(a).Spanish: rifar el caballo (M), me grun9e el perro (C), loplatica (Z)

quiquiz-tli.Spanish: bocina de caracol, o caracol que sirve debocina o de trompeta (M)

quītzquiā.Spanish: lo detiene con la mano, lo agarra (T)
quītzquiā.Comment: This is abundantly attested, but only for T and Z.

quīxohuayān.Spanish: puerta, o lugar por donde salen de casa (M)
quīxohuayān.Comment: The single attestation does not provide the HU or thelong vowel of -YĀN, but the form is built onQUĪXOHUA, the nonactive form of QUĪZ(A), which iselsewhere attested, and the locative suffix -YĀN isabundantly attested with a long vowel.

quīxtiā.English: to relieve oneself; to cause s.o. to leave, go out,withdraw
quīxtiā.Spanish: excusarse (M), sacar algo fuera de casa, odesempen9ar algo (M), echar de casa a la mujer o alcriado, o desterrar a alguno, o parecer el hijo a suspadres (M)
quīxtiā.Comment: T has the exceptional variant QUIXTIĀ with a shortvowel.  All the other sources agree that the longvowel of QUĪZ(A) is maintained in this derivation.In construction with -HUĪC, the reflexive ofQUĪXTIĀ means to discharge one's obligation tos.o.

-quiyāhuac.Comment: C glosses the construction TĒCPANQUIYĀHUAC,literally "outside the palace", as la plaza.

quiyāhuatēmpan.Spanish: en el lugar del portal, de la puerta (T), afuera (X)

quiyāhua-tl.Spanish: puerta o entrada de alguna casa o lugar (M), zaguaŸn(R)
quiyāhua-tl.Comment: This is abundantly attested, but because the sequenceis stem-internal and invariant, there is no evidenceto decide between QUIĀHUA-TL and QUIYĀHUA-TL.  Chas IĀ, T has IYĀ, and B has it both ways.  Thiscontrasts with QUIYAHUĀ-TL "rainstorm".

quiyahuā-tl.Comment: This contrasts with QUIYĀHUA-TL "entrance".  It isattested only for Z, which has O for A in the secondsyllable.

quiyahu(i).Comment: This is to be found only in the Spanish-to-Nahuatlside of M.

quiyahu(i)-tl.Comment: Because the sequence is stem-internal and invariant,there is no evidence to decide between QUIAHU(I)-TLand QUIYAHU(I)-TL.  Z has O for A.  X has the variantQUIYAUH-TLI.  Although this does not appear to be acompound word, there are the related forms such asĀYAHU(I)-TL "cloud, fog", and CEPAYAHU(I)-TL "snow".

quiyauhmānahuiā.English: to take shelter from the rain
quiyauhmānahuiā.Spanish: se quita de la lluvia (bajo de techo, aŸrbol, petate,etc.), se ataja de la lluvia (T)

quīz(a).English: to come out, to emerge, to conclude or finish
quīz(a).Spanish: salir de casa (M), concluirse o acabarse alguna obra,o correr el arroyo, o escampar, o sazonarse lo que sesembroŸ, o acabarse la fruta, por haber ya pasado eltiempo de ella (M)

-quīzayān.English: place from which s.t. comes forth
-quīzayān.Spanish: lugar de donde sale una cosa, comienzos (S)
-quīzayān.Comment: This is attested in a phrase with TONAL-LI "day", thewhole phrase meaning "east".

quīzqui.Comment: This is indirectly attested in CENQUĪZQUI"s.t. perfect".

tahtiā.English: to take s.o. as one's father
tahtiā.Comment: M gives this with a direct object prefix plus anoblique reflexive prefix, while R has only a directobject.  R also gives this as an intransitive meaning"to become a father".

tah-tli.Comment: This contrasts with TLAH-TLI "uncle".  For "father" Tand Z also have TĀTAH, a form widespread in modernNahuatl.  M has tata specifically as the term ofaddress used by a child.

tahyō-tl.Comment: The phrase IN TAHYŌ-TL, IN NĀNYŌ-TL refers toparental responsibility.

talatlāl-li.English: ant hill, colony of a certain type of ant

tamachīhu(a).English: to be measured or weighed; to weigh or measure s.t.
tamachīhu(a).Spanish: se mide (T), medir algo (M), medir, pesar (X)
tamachīhu(a).Comment: T has E for A in the first syllable.

tamalayoh-tli.Spanish: cierto geŸnero de calabazas comestibles y muy buenas(M), calabaza para dulce (T)

tamal-li.English: bread made of steamed cornmeal, tamale
tamal-li.Spanish: pan de maiŸz envuelto en hojas y cocido en olla (M)
tamal-li.Comment: By extension TAMAL-LI often refers to soft,unstructured things.

tamazol-in.Comment: For "big toad" T has TAMAZOLHUĒHUEH, forming theplural by adding the reduplicated plural form of thediminutive compounding element -TŌN.  X has -LI forthe absolutive suffix and E for A in the firstsyllable.

tāmpiloā.English: to swing, to rock; to swing or rock s.t.
tāmpiloā.Spanish: se columpia (T), lo columpia, lo mece (T)

tānah-tli.English: basket with a handle, woven of palm

tapach-tli.Spanish: coral, concha, o venera (M), concha (del mar) (Z)

tapahzol-li.Spanish: nido de paŸjaros (M), nido de aves (M)

tapalca-tl.Spanish: casco de vasija de barro quebrada, o teja quebrada(M)
tapalca-tl.Comment: In the compound ITZTAPAL-LI "paving stone" thisoccurs without final CA.

tapayoltic.English: s.t. round like a ball, s.t. broken out in bumps
tapayoltic.Spanish: cosa redonda como pelota o bola (M), boludo (T)

tataca.English: to scratch oneself; to scratch s.t., to dig in theearth
tataca.Spanish: rascarse (M), rascar a otro (M), cavar o escarbartierra (M)

tātahhuē(i).Comment: The more usual word for "grandfather" is CŌL-LI.

tatapah-tli.Spanish: manta gruesa, traiŸda y remendada (M), ropa, tela,trapo, geŸnero; cosa vieja (T)

tē-.Comment: By extension of its primary grammatical function,this nonspecific human prefix "someone"appears as the initial element of many nouns derivedfrom transitive verbs which take human objects,TĒMICTIĀNI "murderer" < MICTIĀ "to kill s.o.";TĒMACHTIHQUI "teacher" < MACHTIĀ "to teach s.o.";TĒCUILTŌNOHCĀN "place of recreation, pleasure" <CUILTŌNOĀ "to enrich s.o." TĒ- also occurs as apossessive prefix to convey a generic sense as in M'stenantzin "s.o.'s mother" < NĀN-TLI, tepiltzin"son or daughter of s.o." < -PIL "offspring", P'stetatzin referring to God the Father, etc.

tēāxcā.Comment: This is conventionally paired with TĒTLATQUI, thewhole phrase meaning "s.o. else's property".

tēca.English: through the agency of s.o., in the company of s.o.
tēca.Spanish: de alguno, o de alguna (M), con eŸl (T)
tēca.Comment: This is homophonous with the verb TĒCA "to stretchs.t. out", but the verb is transitive and alwaysappears with an object prefix.  The attestation is inhonorific form, TĒCATZINCO.

tecaltiā.Spanish: lo apedrea, lo avienta con piedra (T)
tecaltiā.Comment: Possibly a glottal stop has been lost, and the secondelement here is derived from (I)HCAL(I) "to skirmishwith s.o."

tecamac.English: place where there is an abundance of stone

-tēca-tl.Comment: This ending replaces -TLĀN in place names to yield"resident of, person from" that place, TEPOZTĒCA-TL"person from Tepoztlan".

tecax(i)-tl.English: stone trough or bowl for grinding, mortar
tecax(i)-tl.Spanish: pila de piedra o cosa semejante (M), molcajete (Z)
tecax(i)-tl.Comment: A variant form is TECAX-TLI.  M has tecaxtli in theSpanish-to-Nahuatl side and tecaxitli in theNahuatl-to-Spanish side.

tēcciz-tli.English: conch, the shell of which was used as a trumpet, orshell in general, including egg shell.

-tech.English: adjacent to, together with, adhering or attached to

techichicō-tl.English: a type of lizard with blue neck markings
techichicō-tl.Spanish: lagartija rasposa que tiene el cuello azul (T)

tēchichina.English: a caterpillar that inflicts a painful bite
tēchichina.Spanish: una oruga que pica muy recio, fuerte (Z)
tēchichina.Comment: In both attestations in Z the vowels of the secondand third syllables are marked long.  But C attestsTĒCHICHINATZ with short vowels, and this is clearlyrelated.

tēchīuhqui.English: one who governs, exercises control over people, onewho creates or engenders people
tēchīuhqui.Spanish: el que gobierna, dirige a la gente (S)
tēchīuhqui.Comment: This is abundantly attested but only in B.  Allattestations are in possessed form, and this may bein suppletive relationship with absolutiveTĒCHĪHUANI.

techtiā.English: to become possessor or custodian of s.t.
techtiā.Spanish: se hace poseedor, se hace duen9o (T)
techtiā.Comment: M has this as a double object verb taking both areflexive prefix and a specific object prefix andwith the sense "to take s.t. as one's own, toappropriate s.t."

tec(i).English: to grind s.t. like corn meal
tec(i).Spanish: moler maiŸz o cosa semejante en piedra (M), muele (T)
tec(i).Comment: This verb and its derivative TEX-TLI "flour, meal"are abundantly attested with the vowel of the initialsyllable short.  Hence it is a clear mistake that onCf.33r this verb and its nonactive form appear withthe vowel marked long.  T has this as a transitiveverb "to grind s.t."

tecihui-tl.Comment: Z has a variant with a glottal stop in the firstsyllable.  X has the variant form TECIUH-TLI.

tecoā.English: to entrust s.o. with s.t. safekeeping
tecoā.Comment: M has this used reflexively in construction with ĪCand meaning "to do s.t. on purpose".

tecoch-tli.Spanish: sepultura, hoyo, o mata de albahaca, etc. (M),agujero, hoyo, sepultura (Z)
tecoch-tli.Comment: X has TECOCHCUITLAPIL-LI as the name of a plant,possibly the same as in M's gloss.  X glossesTECOCH-TLI itself as "woodpecker", and as the name ofthe plant has TECOCHCUITLAPIL-LI, literally"woodpecker-tail".

tēcocoh.Spanish: cosa que escuece y duele (M), sufrimiento (T)

-tēcocolihcā.Spanish: los que mal me quieren (C for first pers. sg. possessor,plural)
-tēcocolihcā.Comment: M has synonymous absolutive tecocoliani, which maybe suppletive with this possessed form.

tēcocoliz-tli.Spanish: dan9o causado a alguien (S), dolor, dolencia (Z)
tēcocoliz-tli.Comment: M has tecocoliliztli with the sense "hatred,malice", which is derived from COCOLIĀ andcontrasts with this.

tecolō-tl.Spanish: buho o piojo blanco del cuerpo (M)
tecolō-tl.Comment: The compound TLĀCATECOLŌ-TL < TLĀCA-TL "person"and TECOLŌ-TL means "devil, monster".

tecom(a)-tl.Spanish: vaso de barro, como taza honda (M)
tecom(a)-tl.Comment: T gives the inalienably possessed form -TECOMAYŌwhen referring to the husk of a green tomato, but forthe inalienably possessed form of the compoundTZONTECOM(A)-TL "skull", T does not add -YŌ.  Z andX compound TE-TL with CŌM(I)-TL rather thanCOM(A)-TL, but the sense remains the same.

tecomaxōchi-tl.English: a member of the nightshade family, cup of gold(Solandra nitida) or wild cotton (Cochlospermumvitifolium)
tecomaxōchi-tl.Spanish: nombre de dos flores de figura particular (R), $copade oro, tecomaxochitl)

tecōni.Comment: This is derived from the nonactive form of TEQU(I)"to cut" and is opposite in meaning from TLATECŌNI"cutting instrument".

tecontic.English: s.t. deep (used with respect to vessels)

tēcpan.Spanish: casa o palacio real, o de alguŸn sen9or de salva (M)
tēcpan.Comment: In this derivation the final consonant of the stemTĒUC "lord" loses its labiality or has it absorbedinto the following labial consonant, and the resultis spelled TĒC.  TĒCPAN can refer to theorganization or household as well as to thestructure.

tecpān(a).English: to line up; to line s.t. up, put s.t. in a queue,set s.t. in order
tecpān(a).Spanish: fila (Z), poner en orden la gente (M), poner algo pororden y concierto o establecer o ordenar algo (M)

tēcpancal-li.Spanish: casas reales, o de grandes sen9ores (M)

tēcpantlāca-tl.English: courtier, member of a palace household or staff
tēcpantlāca-tl.Spanish: cortesano (M), gente de palacio, o consagrada alservicio inmediato de priŸncipe (R)
tēcpantlāca-tl.Comment: R gives this in plural form, and the only diacriticthat appears is the final glottal stop.

tēcpilcal-li.Spanish: sala del palacio donde se reuniŸan los soldadosnobles y donde el rey juzgaba los delitos deadulterio de esos guerreros (S)

tēcpillō-tl.Spanish: hidalguiŸa, nobleza, buena crianza y cortesiŸa (M)

tecpin-tli.Comment: M gives this both with and without the absolutivesuffix -TLI.

tēctoc.English: to lie spread out in a body

tēcuāni.Spanish: una fiera (C), animal fiero (onza, tigre, leoŸn,etc.) (T)
tēcuāni.Comment: The literal sense of this is "maneater".

tecueh.English: a type of large venomous lizard
tecueh.Comment: This may be an element of the personal nameTECUEPOHTZIN, but in the name B indicates just ashort E, not EH, in the second syllable.

tēcuiltōnoh.English: s.o. or s.t. that enriches s.o.
tēcuiltōnoh.Spanish: el que enriquece a otro, o cosa que enriquece a otro(M)

tēcuiltōnohcān.Spanish: luga de recreacioŸn y de alegriŸa (C)

tecuīnaltiā.Comment: M has tecuinaltia "to cause a fire to flame up",which is the causative form of TECUĪN(I) andhomophonous with this item.

tecuīn(i).English: for a fire to flare up or for one's heart to pound
tecuīn(i).Spanish: encenderse el fuego echando llama, o batir y dargolpes el corazoŸn (M)

-tēcuiyō.Spanish: mi sen9or (C for first pers. sg. possessor), cortesanos(C for plural)
-tēcuiyō.Comment: This slightly idiosyncratic or conservative possessedform of TĒUC-TLI is overwhelmingly attested asTOTĒCUIYŌ "our Lord" with Christian reference.  Phas an internal glottal stop, -TĒCUIHYŌ.

tēezzō.Spanish: hijo o hija de nobles caballeros (M), bien nacido (C)
tēezzō.Comment: This is conventionally paired with TĒTLAPALLŌ, thewhole phrase referring to good breeding.

teh.Comment: This is a freestanding pronoun as contrasted with thepersonal prefixes TI- "I" and MITZ- "you (singular)".

tehcuiliā.English: to wrap s.t. up for s.o., to entangle s.t. for s.o.

tehcuiy(a).English: to wrap s.t., to entangle s.t.
tehcuiy(a).Spanish: devanar, envolver, o liar algo (M), lo envuelve, loenreda (T)

tehhuān.Comment: This contrasts with TĒHUĀN "in the company of s.o."TEHHUĀN has a long form, TEHHUĀNTIN.

tehhuā-tl.Grammar: second person singular pronoun, long form
tehhuā-tl.Comment: When this appears without the absolutive suffix, theĀ is subject to the general rule of word-finalshortening.  The sequence TEH, TEHHUĀ, TEHHUĀ-TLrepresents increasingly emphatic "you (singular)".

tehtēca.Spanish: nos acostamos (C for first pers. plural subject)
tehtēca.Comment: M also has transitive teteca "to warp cloth or tomake a bed" and intransitive teteca "to lie with awoman", which may represent either TEHTĒCA orTĒTĒCA.

tehtēm(a).English: to cast s.t. down, to throw s.t. into s.t., toscatter s.t.
tehtēm(a).Spanish: echar y poner algo en vulgar (M), lo derrama, loriega (T)
tehtēm(a).Comment: M combines this in a single entry with TETĒM(A) "tofill s.t. with rocks".
