tehtēmoliā.Comment: The vowel of the third syllable is specificallymarked long on Cf.126r, although it is short inunreduplicated TĒMOLIĀ.

tehtequ(i).English: to cut, hack s.o., s.t. to pieces
tehtequ(i).Spanish: descuartizar, hacer pedazos a otro, o sajar a alguno(M), depedazar o cortar algo en muchas partes (M)
tehtequ(i).Comment: This contrasts with TĒTEQU(I) "to divide, distributes.t." M has reflexive tetequi "to pratice ritualbleeding".

tehtēzcatic.Comment: This is attested only with prefixed ĪX- "somewhat,rather".

tēhuān.Comment: This contrasts with the pronoun TEHHUĀN "we".

tēhuānyōlqui.Comment: In M the N of the second syllable is missing,teuayolqui.

tehuiā.English: to get struck with stones; to strike, pound s.t.with stones
tehuiā.Spanish: se topetea (T), dar golpes con piedra, pisar conpisoŸn, o brun9ir mantas, papel, o cosa asiŸ (M)

tēhuītecōni.Spanish: el instrumento para azotar y dar de palos (C)

tehuītequ(i).English: to scourge oneself, to shed blood

tehuītzo-tl.Comment: This has only a single attestation in Z.  If it isderived from TEHUITZ-TLI, the vowel of the secondsyllable should be short.

tehuitz-tli.Spanish: su pico (paŸjaro, etc.) (T for possessed form),piedra puntiaguda (S)
tehuitz-tli.Comment: If this is derived from TE-TL "stone" and HUITZ-TLI"thorn", as the glosses imply, the vowels of bothsyllables should be short, but in one of twoattestations T has them both long.

tēiccāuh.Comment: This basically possessed form, TĒ-ICCĀUH, literally"younger brother of s.o.", has been lexicalized andcan take a further possessive prefix, NOTĒICCĀUH"my younger brother".

tēicnēlīl-li.Comment: By general rule the vowel of the fourth syllableshould be long, but it is unmarked for length in bothattestations.

tēilhuiā.English: to bring a complaint; to accuse s.o., to bring acomplaint against s.o., to reveal s.t. to s.o.
tēilhuiā.Spanish: quejarse a la justicia (M), acusar a otro dando quejacontra eŸl (M), descubrir secreto (M)

tēilnāmiquiliz-tli.Spanish: recordacioŸn o memoria que de otro se tiene (M)

teīn(i).Spanish: quebrarse alguŸn vaso, saltando con ruido alguŸnpedazo de eŸl (M)

teīniā.English: to break s.t. into pieces, to shatter s.t.
teīniā.Comment: X marks the E long rather than the following I.

tēizcaliāni.Spanish: el que industria y doctrina a otro (M)

tēizcalih.Spanish: cosa que da doctrina y aviva y da entendimiento (M)
tēizcalih.Comment: M also has teizcalti with the same sense.

tēizti-tl.Comment: The literal sense of this is "s.o.'s fingernail".  Itis conventionally paired with TĒTZON "s.o.'s hair",the whole phrase meaning "offspring" in a genericsense.

tēl.Spanish: conjuncioŸn adversativa (M), duda si hariŸa algo, odificultad de hacerlo (C), pero (C)
tēl.Comment: This frequently binds with other particles, AHTĒL"is it not clear?", MĀTĒL "although", MĀZOTĒL"supposing that", TĒLYEH "but", QUĒNTĒL "somehow".

telāhuac.Spanish: grueso (p. ej. libro, tabla, pared, etc.) (T)

telchīhu(a).English: to undervalue, dismiss, malign s.o., s.t.
telchīhu(a).Spanish: menospreciar a otro (M), abominar o maldecir algunacosa (M)

telchi-tl.English: satisfaction in s.o.'s misfortune, feeling that s.o.has received his just deserts
telchi-tl.Spanish: endemal, del que se goza mal de otro (M)
telchi-tl.Comment: This is aundantly attested but only in C.

telicza.Spanish: dar de coces a otro o tirar coz (M)

telochcui.English: to be taken by surprise; to diminish or drain s.t.
telochcui.Spanish: sobresalta, se sorprende (T), lo achica (p. ej. aguacuando hay poca en la tinaja) (T)

tēlpoca-tl.Comment: Z has both TĒLPOCA-TL and TĒLPŌCH-TLI, which accordingto R are synonymous.  This corresponds to thevariants (I)CHPOCA-TL and (I)CHPŌCH-TLI "youngwoman".

tēlpōchcal-li.English: house of youths, an institution of education foryoung men
tēlpōchcal-li.Spanish: casa en la que se educaba a los nin9os a los que seencargaba diversos cuidados en las ceremoniasreligiosas (S)

tēlpōch-tli.Comment: This appears to be synonymous with TĒLPOCA-TL, whichdiffers in the length of the vowel of the secondsyllable.  The plural is formed by reduplication ofthe second syllable rather than the first.  This andthe fact that "young woman" is (I)CHPŌCH-TLI implythat PŌCH is a compounding element and TĒL amodifier.

tēm(a).English: to cause s.t. to fill up, to pour s.t. into acontainer
tēm(a).Spanish: echar o poner algo en alguna parte asiŸ como maiŸz,etc., o cocer algo en hornillo pequen9o (M)
tēm(a).Comment: This contrasts with TEM(A) "to bathe in a sweathouse".

tem(a).English: to bathe in a sweathouse; to bathe s.o. in asweathouse
tem(a).Spanish: ban9arse en temazcalli (M), ban9ar a otro asiŸ (M)
tem(a).Comment: In T the preterit of the reflexive is given as TEMAC,but the preterit of the transitive as TEN, while Cgives the preterits of both the reflexive and thetransitive as TEN.  TEM(A) contrasts with TĒM(A) "tocause s.t. to fill up".

tēmāc.English: in s.o.'s hands, at the hands of s.o.
tēmāc.Spanish: en las manos de alguno (M), en manos de la justicia ode mis enemigos (C)

tēmaca.English: to surrender, to give oneself up; to give s.t. tos.o.
tēmaca.Spanish: darse alguno asiŸ mismo y entregarse a otro (M), daralgo a otro (M)

tēmacalō.Comment: There should be an alternative form of this TĒMACŌ.

tēmachiā.English: to expect or have confidence in s.o. or s.t.; tohave expectations of s.o.
tēmachiā.Spanish: confiar o esperar algo (M), confiar o esperar en otro(M)

tēmachtiā.Spanish: yo predico, yo ensen9o (C for first pers. sg. subject)
tēmachtiā.Comment: C uses this verb in an illustrative paradigm andglosses it throughout as though the nonspecific humanobject prefix TĒ- were fused with the stem to forman intransitive verb.

tēmachtiāniti.English: to be a teacher, to serve as a teacher

tēmachtihcāti.English: to be a teacher, to serve as a teacher

tēmachtihqui.Comment: M has synonymous temachtiqui and temachti.  X hasreduplicated TĒMAMACHTIQUI.

tēmachtīl-li.English: s.t. taught to s.o., s.t. instructive or didactic,a sermon
tēmachtīl-li.Spanish: ensen9anza tal (M), cosa que se ensen9a a personas,como plaŸtica, sermoŸn (C)

tēmachtīlōyān.English: place where people are instructed, school
tēmachtīlōyān.Spanish: puŸlpito, caŸtedra, o lugar donde ensen9an a otros(M)
tēmachtīlōyān.Comment: Neither attestation marks the vowel of the thirdsyllable long, but it is marked long elsewhere inattestations of the nonactive form of MACHTIĀ.

tēmāctiā.English: to surrender; to hand s.t. over
tēmāctiā.Spanish: se rinde, se entrega (M), lo entrega (M)

tēmahmauhtihcān.Comment: The reflex of the glottal stop in the fourth syllableis missing in T on p.227, but it does appear in theSpanish-to-Nahuatl side of T on p.42.

tēmalloh.Comment: Z is inconsistent in the vowel length pattern but hasa reflex of the final glottal stop; T is reliableabout the vowel length but has lost the final glottalstop.

temalō.Comment: This nonactive form of TEM(A) "to bathe in asweathouse" contrasts with TĒMALŌ, the nonactiveform of TĒM(A) "to cause s.t. to fill up", and withTĒMALLOH "s.t. infected".

tēmalō.Comment: This nonactive form of TĒM(A) "to cause s.t. tofill up" contrasts with TEMALŌ, the nonactive formof TEM(A) "to bathe in a sweathouse", and withTĒMALLOH "s.t. infected".

tēmaloā.Comment: M has temalloa and timalloa "for an abscess toform".  The preterit of these is formed by adding -C,and they are given with medial ll except in thepreterit of temalloa, which appears as otemaloac.

tēmāquīxtihqui.Comment: This is abundantly attested, but only in Z does itappear without the honorific element -TZIN.Elsewhere it has the invariant formTOTĒMĀQUĪXTIHCĀTZIN "our Savior (honorific)" andwith Christian reference.  TĒMĀQUĪXTIĀNI isusually used in place of this as a free form.

tēmāquīxtiliz-tli.Comment: In all three attestations the vowel of the fourthsyllable is marked long, although by general rule itshould be short.

temateloā.English: to stumble, to stub one's toe
temateloā.Spanish: topetea, pisa en un piedra y se magulla el pie (T)

tēmauhtih.Spanish: cosa que espanta y pone temor a otros (M)

temāzcal-li.Spanish: casilla como estufa a donde se ban9an (M), temascal(T)

temeca-tl.English: vine, shoot, sucker, coral vine (Cissus cucurbitina)

temecayoh.English: vineyard, place where there are many vines
temecayoh.Comment: The final glottal stop is not attested because of thegeneral loss of word-final glottal stop in T.

temetl(a)-tl.English: type of stone from which metates are made
temetl(a)-tl.Comment: Z has TEMETL(A)-TL and METLATE-TL, both glossedas "piedra de metate".

tēm(i).English: to fill up, to be full
tēm(i).Spanish: estar harto y repleto, o henchirse la vasija dealguŸn licor, o estar juntos gatillos, perrillos, ocosas semejantes, asiŸ como maiŸz, cacao, calabazas(M)

tēmiā.English: to fill s.t., to stuff s.t.
tēmiā.Spanish: lo llena bien, lo empaca bien lleno (T forYĒCTĒMIĀ)

tēmictiāni.English: murderer or s.o. who assaults others, s.t. mortal,harmful or poisonous
tēmictiāni.Spanish: matador, o el que maltrata a otro, o cosa mortiŸferay venenosa (M)

tēmictih.English: murderer or s.o. who assaults others,, s.t. mortal,harmful or poisonous
tēmictih.Spanish: matador, o el que maltrata a otro, o cosa mortiŸferay venenosa (M), veneno (T)
tēmictih.Comment: Z has the longer form TĒMICTIHQUI.

tēmiliā.Comment: This is homophonous with the applicative form ofTĒM(A).

tēmiqu(i).English: to have a dream about s.t.
tēmiqu(i).Comment: M has this as an intransitive verb, but B, C, and Thave it as transitive.

tēmītiā.English: to fill s.t., to satisfy s.o.

tēmoā.Spanish: buscar algo, o inquirir de alguŸn negocio.
tēmoā.Comment: This contrasts with TEMŌHUA, the nonactive form ofTEMŌ "to descend".

temōhua.English: for descent to take place, for people to descend
temōhua.Comment: This nonactive form of TEMŌ with its preteritTEMŌHUAC has an entry of its own in M.  It contrastswith TĒMOĀ "to seek s.t." The notation of theattestations is ambiguous for the vowel of the secondsyllable.  Possibly this should be TEMOHUA on thepattern of verbs that drop their final vowels and add-OHUA to form the nonactive, as in MICOHUA < MIQU(I).

temohuiā.Comment: The vowel of the second syllable here contrasts inlength with that in TEMŌ "to descend".  T has oneattestation with a reflex of a long vowel, but it isabundantly attested in T and elsewhere with a shortvowel.

tēmoliā.English: to seek s.t. for s.o., or to make inquiry of s.o.
tēmoliā.Spanish: buscar algo para otro, o hacer inquisicioŸn de vidaajena (M)

temōliz-tli.Spanish: descendimiento o el acto de descender y abajar (M)

temōlo-tl.Comment: Z marks the vowel of the second syllable long in onlyone of four attestations.

temomox.Comment: No absolutive suffix is attested for this.

tēmōx-tli.Spanish: enfermedad o pestilencia (M for phrase withEHĒCA-TL)
tēmōx-tli.Comment: B is inconsistent in marking vowel length in thesecond syllable.  In three attestations it is markedlong, in one it is specifically marked short, and infive it is unmarked for length.  This isconventionally paired with EHĒCA-TL, the wholephrase meaning "pestilence, disease".

tēmpahpaloā.English: to lick one's lips; to lick s.o.'s lips
tēmpahpaloā.Spanish: se lame la boca (T), le lame la boca (T)

tēmpanhuetzoā.English: to mention s.t., to let s.t. fall in conversation

tēmpatiliā.English: to mix up one's words, to stammer
tēmpatiliā.Spanish: trastrocar las palabras o trastrabillarseme la lengua(M)

tēmpipitzoā.English: to suck s.t. in one's mouth

tena.Spanish: quejarse el enfermo (M), se queja (de dolor) (T)

tēnācecēc.Comment: Z consistently has a long vowel in the finalsyllable.  If the literal meaning of this is "s.t.that tastes like cold water", the final elementshould be CECEC with both vowels short

tenamaz-tli.English: the configuration of three hearth stones forsupporting pots over fire; by extension, triplets
tenamaz-tli.Spanish: piedras sobre que ponen la olla al fuego, o trescriaturas nacidas de un vientre (M)
tenamaz-tli.Comment: In T and X this is metathesized to TEMANAZ-TLI.  Mgives only the plural form tenamaztin.

tenāntiā.English: to wall s.t. in, to encircle s.t. with a wall ortrench
tenāntiā.Spanish: cercar de mura la ciudad o hacer albarrada (M)

tēnāyō-tl.Spanish: su saliva, su baba (Z for possessed form)

tēncāhual-li.Spanish: relieves o sobras de la mesa (M)

tēncaqu(i).English: to listen to s.o., to court s.o.

tēnchal-li.Spanish: barba, no los pelos (M), su barba (T for possessedform)
tēnchal-li.Comment: The CHAL element also occurs in CAMACHAL-LI "jaw".Although M specifically excludes individual hairs,in T TĒNCHAL is compounded with verbs of pluckingand cutting.

tēnchalpihpī.Comment: PIHPĪ literally means "to pluck" rather than "toshave".

-tēnco.Spanish: su orilla (T for third pers. sg. possessor)

tēncualac-tli.Spanish: babas (M), su saliva (T for possessed form)
tēncualac-tli.Comment: X marks the vowel of the second syllable long inTĒNCUALCAX(I)-TL "jaw".

tēncualcax(i)-tl.Comment: This is literally "saliva box".  X marks the vowel ofthe second syllable long, but it is short in T'sTĒNCUALAC-TLI.

tēncuātzin.Comment: M has tenquapol "s.o. lacking a lip".  In bothattestations of TĒNCUĀTZIN Z indicates a long vowelin the second syllable followed by a glottal stop,which is not possible in Nahuatl.

tēncui.English: to be in dispute; to copy s.t.
tēncui.Comment: In both attestations of the reflexive Z gives thiswith a final glottal stop, and there is noinformation about the preterit form.  The secondelement of the transitive form is given as CUI,preterit CUIC.

tēneh.English: s.t. sharp, s.t. with a cutting edge

tēnēhu(a).English: for s.t. to be mentioned, named; to endorse, giverecognition to s.o., to express, mention, praise s.t.
tēnēhu(a).Spanish: nombrarse, ser llamado (S), afamar a otro o dar votoen eleccioŸn o encartar a alguno (M), prometer oexpresar algo (M)

tenex-tli.Comment: This is abundantly attested in Z and also appears inT.

tenōchtic.Comment: This contrasts with the initial element ofTENOCHTITLAN in vowel length of the second syllable.

tenochtitlan.English: Tenochtitlan, the capital of the Mexica
tenochtitlan.Spanish: $TenochtitlaŸn), en el tunal de la piedra, o nacidoen la piedra (R)
tenochtitlan.Comment: B specifically marks the vowels of the first threesyllables short.  This contrasts with TENŌCHTIC"s.t. painted, mottled" as attested in T.  NŌCH-TLI"fruit of the prickly pear cactus" is often citedas a constituent of this name, but it contrastsin vowel length.

tēnohototiya.Comment: One of the two attestations is truncated, TĒNOHOTO,which would seem to be an associated noun, but it hasthe same gloss as the longer item.

tēnquīxtiā.Comment: T consistently has the reflex of a short vowel in thefirst syllable of QUĪXTIĀ and all its compounds,but B marks it long for this item, as it should be bygeneral rule.

tēnquīz(a).Comment: T gives the preterit of this as -QUĪZAC rather than-QUĪZ, although T elsewhere has QUĪZ from QUĪZ(A).

tēntiā.English: to interfere; to sharpen s.t., to give s.t. an edge,to tune an instrument
tēntiā.Spanish: hablar alguno o entremeterse donde no llaman, o ennegocio ajeno (M), amolar o afilar cuchillo o cosasemejante, o echar ribete o floradura o franja a lavestidura (M), lo afila, lo afina (guitarra, violiŸn)(T)
tēntiā.Comment: With the oblique reflexive in addition to a directobject prefix, this means "to make s.o. serve as avoice for s.o. else".

tēntilān(a).English: to haul, drag s.t. (by a bit or ring in the lip)

-tēntlan.Spanish: por delante de ... nuestros labios (C for firstpers. plural possessor)

tēntlān(i).English: to surpass s.o. in speaking or eating

tēntlapīquiā.English: to give false testimony about s.o.

tēn-tli.English: lip, mouth, edge, and (by extension) word
tēn-tli.Spanish: los labios, o el borde, o orilla de alguŸn cosa (M)

tēntoc.English: s.t. filled up, s.t. heaped, thrown together in aplace
tēntoc.Spanish: cosa que estaŸ llena o cosa que estaŸ puesta enalguŸn lugar (M)

tēntzacu(a).English: to be stifled, silenced; to force s.o. to be quiet,to imprison s.o.
tēntzacu(a).Spanish: ataparse o cubrirse la boca, o enmudecer (M), hacercallar a otro confundieŸndolo y convencieŸndolo (M),lo encierra, le aprisiona (Z)

tēntzoneh.Comment: In the Spanish-to-Nahuatl side M has this for "sheep,goat".  It contrasts with CUĀCUAHUEH "steer, cow".T has I for EH.

tēntzonquīxtiā.Comment: M has tentzonquic˛a "to be growing out one'sbeard, to be unshaven".  One of the three attestationsis prefixed with TLA- instead of a reflexive prefix.

tēnxīm(a).Comment: M has tentzonxima with the same sense.

tēnxīpal-li.Comment: In T the NX sequence assimilates to XX, which isthen degeminated, yielding X.

tēnyōtiā.English: to become famous; to make s.o. famous
tēnyōtiā.Spanish: afamarse (M), afamar y dar honra a otro (M)

teōāmox-tli.Spanish: libro divino, libro sagrado.  Especie derecopilacioŸn general escrita en caracteresjerogliŸficos que conteniŸa las leyes, lascostumbres, la religioŸn, el rito, lo cronologiŸa, laastronomiŸa, etc. (S)

teōchīhu(a).English: to celebrate divine ritual; to bless s.o. or s.t.
teōchīhu(a).Spanish: hacer oracioŸn, darse a dios, o celebrar los oficiosdivinales (M), absolver o echar o darle bendicioŸn aotro (M), bendecir ornamentos eclesiasticos o otracualquier cosa (M)

teōcuitlahuiā.English: to gild or silver plate s.t.

teohcal-li.Comment: B and C agree that a glottal stop intervenes betweenTEŌ and CAL-LI shortening the final vowel of thefirst element.

teohcihu(i).Spanish: tener hambre o tener gana de comer (M)
teohcihu(i).Comment: M also has transitive teociui "to crave s.t.material or spiritual".  T has lost the internalglottal stop.

teohciōhua.English: for there to be hunger, for people to be starving
teohciōhua.Spanish: tener todos gana de comer o hambre (M)
teohciōhua.Comment: C states that intransitive verbs ending in -HU(I) and-HU(A) form the impersonal by replacing those endingswith -ŌHUA (f.36r), and this is one such case.

teohpōhu(a).English: to suffer, be afflicted; to torment, afflict, offends.o.
teohpōhu(a).Spanish: angustiarse o afligirse (M), angustiar o afligir aotro (M)
teohpōhu(a).Comment: This is attested in applicative form only.

teohpōuhqui.Comment: Conventionally paired with COCŌC, this forms aphrase meaning "affliction and travail".

teōmat(i).English: to think oneself a god; to be engaged in, concernedwith spiritual matters
teōmat(i).Spanish: se tiene por Dios (C), ocuparse en cosas espiritualesy divinas (M)
teōmat(i).Comment: M's gloss is for this with the prefix TLA-, which maybe a lexicalized form in which the prefix has beenabsorbed to form an intransitive verb TLATEŌMAT(I).

teōpan-tli.Comment: M gives this both with and without the absolutivesuffix and with no difference in meaning.

teōpixcāti.English: to be or become a priest or a member of a religiousorder
teōpixcāti.Spanish: ser eclesiastico o ministro de la iglesia (M),hacerse sacerdote o religioso (C)

teōpixcāyō-tl.Spanish: sacerdocio, orden sacra, o dignidad eclesiastica (M)

teōpixqui.English: priest, religious, member of a religious order

teōtiā.English: to create gods for oneself, to be an idolater; totake s.t. to be a god
teōtiā.Spanish: hago dioses para miŸ, y usarse por idolatrar (C forfirst pers. sg. reflexive), tener o adorar alguna cosapor dios (M)
teōtiā.Comment: Used transitively, this takes a direct object prefixand an oblique reflexive prefix.

teōtlac.Spanish: la tarde del diŸa, a puesta de sol (M), anoche (T)
teōtlac.Comment: This is abundantly attested in C with Ō, but T, Z,and X have the vowel short.  Z has I for E.

teōtlahtōl-li.Comment: This also appears in P with the glottal stop markedbut not the long vowels.

teōtlaquiliz-tli.Comment: In one of the two attestations T has suffixed -pa,which probably represents -PAN.

teōtlaquiya.English: to grow late, to get dark
teōtlaquiya.Comment: This is attested in applicative form in Z.

teōtoca.English: to think oneself a god; to take s.t. as a god

teōxihu(i)-tl.Comment: M also gives teoxiuh with no absolutive suffix as"generous son or son of generous parents", probablyby metaphor.

teōxiuhyō-tl.Comment: C gives this without a gloss as an example of aderivation with -YŌ.  The sense would be somethinglike "the quality of being a turquoise".

teōyoh.Spanish: cosa que tiene en siŸ divinidad (C)

tepāchoā.English: to bruise s.o. or s.t., to pound s.t.
tepāchoā.Spanish: apezgar o emprensar algo (M), lo azota, lo quiebra(frijol, haba, etc.) ... lo martilla (T)
tepāchoā.Comment: This is abundantly attested but only in T.  Itcontrasts with TEPACHOĀ "to stone s.o."

tepachoā.Comment: This contrasts with TEPĀCHOĀ "to pound s.t., tobruise s.t.".

tēpahpāquiltihcān.Spanish: lugar deleitoso y placentero (M), lugar donde alegra(C)

tēpahtiā.Comment: This also appears in P with the glottal stop markedbut not the long vowel.

tēpahtihqui.Comment: M has tepati with the same sense.

-tepahyō.English: it serves one right (expression of satisfaction injust punishment)
-tepahyō.Spanish: cuando uno se huelga del mal de otro, o muestra quetiene u merecido (C), tanto mejor, bien hecho (S)

tēpalēhuiliz-tli.Comment: With the possessive prefix MO- and the honorificsuffix -TZIN, this is used as a request for aid.

tēpan.Spanish: sobre alguno o sobre algunos (M), despueŸs (C forc˛atĒpan)
tēpan.Comment: This is abundantly attested in C, mainly inconstruction with QUIN, ZĀ, or both and meaning"afterwards".  It contrasts with TEPĀN-TLI "wall".

tepāncal-li.English: enclosure, corral, house with stone or adobe walls
tepāncal-li.Spanish: corral o cosa cercada de paredes (M), casa de piedra,de tabique, de adobe (T)

tepehpech-tli.English: base of a column, stone foundation

tepēhu(a).Spanish: esparcir o echar algo por el suelo, asiŸ comotomines, cacao (M), lo siembra (Z)

tepēhuah.Comment: This possessor derivation from TEPĒ-TL "hill" isconventionally paired with the ĀHUAH, the possessorderivation of Ā-TL, the whole phrase meaning"resident of a town".

tepēhuāqu(i).Spanish: se seca y no se pudre (T)

tepēhu(i).English: for a multitude of small objects to fall, spill
tepēhu(i).Spanish: caerse las hojas de los aŸrboles, o esparcirse yderramarse trigo o otras semillas por el suelo (M)

tepēhuiliā.English: to scatter s.t. for s.o. or on s.o.

tepehxihuiā.English: to fling oneself headlong; to throw s.t., s.o. downfrom a height, or down a ravine
tepehxihuiā.Comment: This is abundantly attested in T, where the internalglottal stop is missing.  B has a single attestationwith the glottal stop (f.1v).  The high frequency inT is due to compounding with many possible locations,CUAUHTEPEHXIHUIĀ "to hurl s.t. down from a tree",TLAPECHTEPEHXIHUIĀ "to knock s.o. out of bed",etc.

tepehxi-tl.Spanish: pen9asco (M), roca, pen9asco, altura, precipicio (S),barranca, precipicio (Z)
tepehxi-tl.Comment: This is abundantly attested in T and also appears inB and Z.  T lacks the internal glottal stop, but itremains in B and Z.

tepehxiyoh.Spanish: barranca, una pen9a que tiene pura piedra (Z)

tepēīxco.English: face, slope of a hill, ridge
tepēīxco.Spanish: ladera del monte (C), frente del cerro (Z)

tepē-tl.Comment: This is conventionally paired with Ā-TL "water", thewhole phrase meaning "town".  The phrase may befurther reduced to ĀLTEPĒ-TL, but the possessedform often remains separated, TOTĀUH TOTEPĒUH "ourtown".

tepētlāl-li.Comment: The literal sense of this is "hill(side) land".

tepetl(a)-tl.English: a type of porous rock used in construction; s.o.rough, uncouth
tepetl(a)-tl.Spanish: tierra dura (C), pen9a, tepetate (T), tosca o cucilla(M)

tepēxīlōxōchi-tl.English: a shrub (Calliandra anomala) with reddish purpletassel-shaped flowers, used in treating inflammationsand dysentery.
tepēxīlōxōchi-tl.Comment: R fails to mark the long vowels.

tepil-li.Comment: C contrasts the honorific of this, TEPILTZIN, withTĒPILTZIN "offspring".  The word for "penis" isTEPOL-LI.

tēpiltzin.Spanish: hijo o hija de alguno (M), bien nacido (C)
tēpiltzin.Comment: This is -PIL "offspring" prefixed with the prefixTĒ-, which imparts a generic sense "offspring ofs.o.", and the honorific element -TZIN.  C contraststhis with TEPILTZIN, the honorific form of TEPIL-LI"vulva".

tepīniā.English: to punch s.o., to hit s.t. with one's fist, tostrike s.t. with one's elbow
tepīniā.Spanish: dar coscorroŸn con los artejos o dar de codo (M), darpun9ete con la mano cerrada o dar de codo (M), lotoca (T), lo picotea (Z)

tepitōn.Comment: In M the final N is missing.  This compounds withnouns to form diminutives, CALTEPITŌN "small house"< CAL-LI "house".

tepītzahu(i).English: for s.t. to become tough, hardened

tepītzīltic.Spanish: cerrado el tejido (de tela, ayate, zarando, etc.) (T)

tepitzin.Comment: Z also has the variant TIPITZIN.

tepitzintiā.Comment: Z has I for E in the initial syllable.

tēpohpolhuīlōni.English: deed or guilt which can or should be pardoned
tēpohpolhuīlōni.Spanish: cosa y culpa que se puede o debe perdonar (C)

tepol-li.Comment: In compounds this has the sense "stump, trunk, s.t.blunt".  In one attestation T has the reflex of along vowel in the second syllable, but in the six otherattestations T has it short.  The word for "vulva" isTEPIL-LI.

teponāz-tli.Spanish: cierto palo hueco que tan9en y hacen son con elcuando bailan o cantan (M)
teponāz-tli.Comment: One sense of TEPOL-LI is "stump", and since this typeof drum is carved from a short log, there may be somerelationship between the two words.

tepōtlamiā.Spanish: tropezar sin caer en el suelo (M)
tepōtlamiā.Comment: C fails to mark the vowel of the second syllablelong, but it is given as long in T and Z.

tepotzoh-tli.Comment: This is abundantly attested in C and also appears inX.

tepotztoca.English: to pursue, to follow s.o., to pursue a matter, toinsist on s.t.
tepotztoca.Spanish: seguir a alguien, andar detraŸs de eŸl (S), lepregunta, lo exija, lo insiste (Z)
tepotztoca.Comment: C marks the vowel of the first syllable long, whichis an error.  In one of three attestations Z marksthe vowel of the second syllable long, which is alsoincorrect.

tepozquechiliā.Spanish: lo marca (al animal) con el hierro (T)

tepoztēca-tl.Comment: This is also the name of a character in folk talesfrom the Tepoztlan area.

tepoztlālloh.Comment: The final glottal stop is not attested due to thegeneral loss of word-final glottal stop in T.

tepoz-tli.English: workable metal, copper or iron, device made frommetal

tēquiā.English: to sprinkle s.t. on s.o., s.t.
tēquiā.Comment: This is abundantly attested in T but alwayscompounded with Ā-TL "water" or CUĀ(I)-TL "head"and generally having to do with baptism.

tequih-.Spanish: adv. que se intercala entre los verbos y significamucho (S)
tequih-.Comment: This is prefixed directly to the stem; all otherprefixes precede it.

tequihmaca.Spanish: bebeis demasiado (C for second pers. plural subject)
tequihmaca.Comment: This is a double object verb which takes both anobject prefix and a reflexive prefix.  It contrastswith TEQUIMACA "to assign tribute or labor".

tequihuiā.English: to volunteer oneself; to present s.t., to beg s.t.of s.o.
tequihuiā.Spanish: se ofrece (Z), lo ofrece (Z), importunar algo a otro(M)

tēquiliā.Comment: C contrasts this with TEQUILIĀ, the applicative formof TEQU(I) "to cut s.t."

tequiliā.Comment: C contrasts this with TĒQUILIĀ, the applicativeform of TĒCA.

tequimaca.English: to assign tribute, tasks, or posts to people, to costs.o. effort
tequimaca.Spanish: repartir tributo o oficio, o tarea a otros (M), lecuesta (T)
tequimaca.Comment: This contrasts with C's TEQUIHMACA "to drink toexcess".

tequipachoā.English: to be anxious; to inflict worry or pain on s.o.
tequipachoā.Spanish: estar ocupando, descontento, y con pena (M),angustiar, dar pena o afligir a otro (M)

tequipachōliz-tli.Comment: This has lost the reflexive prefix NE-.

tequipachōl-li.Comment: This has lost the reflexive prefix NE-.

tequipanoā.Comment: This verb occurs as both intransitive and transitive.The intransitive form and the transitive form withthe nonspecific object prefix TLA- have the sense "towork, to hold office, to fulfill responsibilities,while with specific object prefixes it has the sense"to serve s.o., to work for s.o."

tequipanōliz-tli.Comment: In one of the two attestations there is anadditional LI syllable.

tequipoloā.English: to serve, attend s.o., to labor for s.o.

tequiti.English: to work or to pay tribute
tequiti.Comment: T forms the preterit by dropping the final vowel, butaccording to M it is formed by adding -C.

tequitiltiā.English: to put s.o., s.t. to work, to use s.t.
tequitiltiā.Spanish: le hace trabajar, lo ocupa, lo usa (T)
tequitiltiā.Comment: By general rule the vowel of the third syllableshould be short, but it is attested long in T.

tequitini.English: laborer, worker, one who delivers tribute

tequi-tl.English: tribute, labor, duty, quota, term (of office)
tequi-tl.Spanish: tributo o obra de trabajo (M), trabajo, obra,ocupacioŸn (T)
tequi-tl.Comment: This appears to be related to the verb TEQU(I) "tocut s.t."

tequitqui.English: laborer, worker, one who pays tribute
tequitqui.Comment: Z has the variant form TEQUITIQUI.

tequiuhtiā.English: to entrust s.t. to s.o., to make s.o. responsiblefor s.t.
tequiuhtiā.Spanish: tomar algo a su cargo o encargarse de alguŸn negocio(M with additional reflexive object), te encargo (Cfor second pers. sg. object)
tequiuhtiā.Comment: M gives this as a double object verb with a directobject prefix plus an oblique reflexive prefix.

tequīxqui-tl.English: a naturally occurring efflorescent carbonate of sodaused in laundry, preparation of food, and medicinally
tequīxqui-tl.Comment: T has a short vowel in the second syllable.  This isprobably related to the fact that T idiosyncraticallyhas a short vowel in QUĪXTIĀ < QUĪZ(A) "to comeout".  M has tequizqui "s.t. petrified,solidified".

tequiyoh.English: s.t. invested with labor, s.t. difficult
tequiyoh.Spanish: cosa que tiene o da trabajo (M), trabajoso, difiŸcil(T)
tequiyoh.Comment: The final glottal stop is not attested due to thegeneral loss of word-final glottal stop in T.  T hasE for I in the second syllable.

tequiyō-tl.English: work, labor, payment of tribute labor
tequiyō-tl.Spanish: trabajo de imposicioŸn de tributario (M), ejerciciode trabajo o el mismo trabajo (M), trabajo, obra,ocupacioŸn (T)
tequiyō-tl.Comment: T has E for I in the second syllable.

tētēca.English: to lie down, stretch out; to stretch s.t. out
tētēca.Spanish: se acuesta estirado (T), lo acuesta bien derecho (Tfor PIYĀZTĒTĒCA)
tētēca.Comment: X does not mark the vowel of the first syllable long,but T does have the reflex of a long vowel.  M hastransitive teteca "to make a bed or warp cloth" andintransitive teteca "to lie with a woman", whichmay respresent either TĒTĒCA or TEHTĒCA.

tetecuica.Spanish: hacer gran ruido la llama de fuego, o escocer, darlatidos, y doler mucho la llaga o el encordio o lahinchazoŸn, o zumbar y hacer ruido alguna cosa asiŸcomo el viento, o reten9ir el metal (M)

tetecuīnoā.English: to become enmeshed, tangled; to catch s.t., to wrapor roll up s.t.
tetecuīnoā.Spanish: se enreda, se revuelca (Z), lo enreda, lo enrolla, lorueda (Z)
tetecuīnoā.Comment: This does not seem to be related to TECUĪN(I) "for afire to roar, for one's heart to pound".

tetecuīnōl-li.Comment: Z glosses this derived noun as though it were a verb.M has tetecuintic "s.t. trimmed down, with allprojections removed".

tetecuitz(a).English: to stomp, to make noise with one's feet
tetecuitz(a).Comment: This is attested with TLA- and as an intransitivewith no object prefix at all.

teteica.English: to crumble, shatter, crunch, or for s.t. to comeapart from use
teteica.Spanish: crujir algo entre los dientes (M), quebrarse vidrio ootras cosas delicadas ... si los pedazos son muchos(C), se desmorona (Z)

teteitz(a).English: to shatter s.t., to grind s.t. to bits
teteitz(a).Spanish: roer hueso o cosa semejante (M), quebrar estas cosas(vidrio o otras cosas delicadas) en muchas pedazos(C), lo desmorona (Z)

tetēm(a).Spanish: henchir algo de piedras, asiŸ como cimiento de pared(M)
tetēm(a).Comment: This is implied by TE-TL "stone" and TĒM(A) "to fills.t." It contrasts with TEHTĒM(A) "to cast down,scatter s.t." and TĒTĒM(A) "to stack s.t.", but Mcombines them all in a single entry.

tētēm(a).Spanish: componer len9a, o echar y poner algo en vulgar (M),lo amontona, lo apila (Z)

tētemātl(a)-tl.Comment: M has tematlatl "slingshot", of which this seems to be areduplicated form.  Despite the affinity of sense,this does not contain AHTLA-TL "spear thrower" asan element of the compound.

tētemetl(a)-tl.Spanish: molleja de ave (M), su molleja (T for possessed form)
tētemetl(a)-tl.Comment: M has tememetlatl with reduplication of the secondelement of the compound instead of the first.  X fails tomark the vowel of the first syllable long, but T does havethe reflex of a long vowel.  T has I for E.

tētepitzin.Comment: M has tetepito which represents TĒTEPITŌN withthe same meaning.

tetequ(i).Comment: This is only attested with the object prefix TLA-.

tētequ(i).English: to slice s.t. evenly, to divide and distribute s.t.
tētequ(i).Spanish: rebano (C for first pers. sg. subject), derrama (T)
tētequ(i).Comment: This contrasts with TEHTEQU(I) "to hack s.t. topieces".

tētequihuiā.Comment: One attestation in Z has a long vowel in the firstsyllable and the other a short vowel and a glottalstop.  Both are prefixed with TLA-.  M hastetequiuia, but the initial te in M's entryrepresents the object prefix TĒ-.  Since Z's verbstake an additional prefix TLA-, their TĒ appears tobe reduplication rather than a prefix.

tetexoā.Spanish: lo roe, lo masca (el pie, la mano, etc.) (T)
tetexoā.Comment: Possibly T has lost a glottal stop, and this shouldbe TEHTEXOĀ.

tetez-tli.Comment: This is attested in the compound ZACATETEZ-TLI, atype of grass.

tetiā.English: to lay eggs; to collect stones
tetiā.Spanish: ovar los peces o poner huevos las aves o allegar yrecoger piedras para edificar (M)
tetiā.Comment: This is not directly attested, but it is implied byits derivation from TE-TL "stone, egg" and thepreterit form given in M.  It contrasts with TETIY(A)"to become hard as stone".

tetic.English: s.t. very hard, hard as stone

tetiy(a).English: to become as hard as stone
tetiy(a).Comment: This contrasts with TETIĀ "to lay eggs, to collectstones".

te-tl.Comment: By extension this can mean "gem" or "ornament" and inanother direction, any solid discrete object.TŌTOLTE-TL "egg" is literally "bird-stone", and itis often shortened to TE-TL.  ĀTE-TL "testicle" isliterally "water-stone".  TE-TL is used as a numeralclassifier in counting small objects, CENTE-TL "one"< CEM, ŌNTE-TL "two" < ŌME, etc.  It also oftencompounds with the names of body parts with noapparent change of meaning as in  QUECH-TLI = QUECHTE-TL"neck".

tētlaihīyōhuiltiliz-tli.Spanish: tormento que se da a otro, o castigo (M)

tētlamacani.Spanish: el que sirve a la mesa (M)

tētlamachtih.English: s.o. or s.t. that enriches or gives joy to others
tētlamachtih.Spanish: cosa o persona que enriquece o alegra a otro (M)
tētlamachtih.Comment: M has tetlamachtiani with the same sense.

tētlamachtihcān.Spanish: lugar de recreacioŸn y de alegriŸa (C)

tētlamahmacani.Spanish: el que sirve a otros de algo y les da recaudo (M), elque da repartiendo a varios (C)

tētlan.Spanish: con otros o par de los, o cerca de los, o con otro(M)

tētlaōcoltih.Comment: Because of general loss of final glottal stop in T,the H is not attested.

tētlapallō.Spanish: hijo o hija de noble linaje (M)
tētlapallō.Comment: This is conventionally paired with TĒEZZŌ, thewhole phrase referring to good breeding.

tētlapohpolhuiliz-tli.Spanish: perdoŸn o dispensacioŸn hecha a otro (M)

tētlapohpolhuīlōni.Spanish: instrumento con que se perdona, como la confesioŸn(C)

tētlatqui.Comment: This conventionally pairs with synonymous TĒĀXCĀ,the whole phrase meaning "s.o. else's property".

tētlatzacuiltīlōni.Comment: The vowel of the fifth syllable should be long bygeneral rule but is not so marked in C.  M hastetlatzacuiltiani "s.o. who inflicts punishment".

tētlaxxīmaliz-tli.Comment: M has this with a single x, but B has xx.

tētlazohtlaliz-tli.Spanish: amor o caridad que con otro se tiene (M)

tētlechipāhualōyān.English: purgatory, place of purification by fire

tētloc.English: by, close to, next to s.o.
tētloc.Spanish: con alguno o par de alguno (M)

tētolīnih.Spanish: cosa penosa y aflictiva (M), cosa que lastima yaflige (C)

tētōnēhualōyān.Comment: This appears in R without diacritics.

tētōnēuh.Comment: T has lost the final consonant.

tētzacuiltīlōni.Spanish: la culpa digna de castigar (C), digno de sercastigado (C)
tētzacuiltīlōni.Comment: The vowel of the fourth syllable should be long bygeneral rule but is not so marked in theattestations.

tetzāhu(a).Spanish: espesar o cuajar algo (M), lo hace espeso, lo espesa,lo condensa (T)
tetzāhu(a).Comment: M also has intransitive tetzaua "to condense,thicken, congeal", the preterit of which is formed byadding -C.

tetzāhu(i).Comment: This is synonymous with M's intransitive tetzauaand contrasts with TĒTZĀHUIĀ "to be beset byforboding; to augur ill for s.o."

tētzāhuiā.English: to be beset by forboding; to frighten others, fors.t. to augur ill for s.o.
tētzāhuiā.Spanish: tener alguna cosa por agu ero, o espantarse mucho yescandalizarse (M), escandalizar a otros (M), es malagu ero para eŸl (T)
tētzāhuiā.Comment: This contrasts with TETZĀHU(I) "to condense,thicken, congeal"

tētzāhui-tl.English: s.t. extraordinary, frightening, supernatural; anaugury, a bad omen
tētzāhui-tl.Spanish: cosa escandalosa o espantosa, o cosa de agu ero (M)

tetzāuhquiyahu(i)-tl.Comment: Z also has a variant form that has lost the final UHof the first element.

tetzīca-tl.Comment: M has tetzicatl "s.o. sterile, incapable ofreproduction".  Since there is no information aboutvowel length and glottal stop, it cannot be known ifit is homophonous.

tetzīcatlāl-li.English: ant hill of a particular type of ant

tetzīlpiticah.English: to be fastened with a knot

tētzon.Comment: This contrasts with TETZON-TLI "stone foundation".TĒTZON literally means "s.o.'s hair" and isconventionally paired with TĒIZTI-TL "s.o.'sfingernail", the whole phrase meaning "offspring" ina generic sense.

tetzonquil(i)-tl.Comment: In all three attestations Z has a glottal stop in thefirst syllable, but since nettles characteristicallygrow along walls and fences, the first element ismost likely TETZON-TLI "stone foundation".

tēuctlahtoā.English: to hold court, public hearing, council
tēuctlahtoā.Spanish: tener audiencia o entender en su oficio elpresidente, oidor, alcalde, etc. (M)

tēuc-tli.English: lord, member of the high nobility
tēuc-tli.Comment: In older Nahuatl texts this is misleadingly writtentecutli or tecuhtli, which suggests a bisyllabicstem with a stem-final glottal stop when in fact itis a monosyllabic stem with a final labialized velarconsonant.  The possessed form -TĒCUIYŌ contrastswith TĒUCYŌ-TL "lordship, dominion".  In compoundsthe final consonant of TĒUC tends to delabialize,yielding TĒC.  T and Z have -TĒCŌ as thepossessed form.

tēucyō-tl.Comment: This is abundantly attested in B and also appears inC.  It contrasts with -TĒCUIYŌ, the possessed formof TĒUC-TLI.

teuh-tli.Comment: This appears to be related to TEX-TLI "flour" andTEC(I) "to grind".  X has the variant TEUC-TLI.

teuhyohtihu(i).English: to go along covered with dust

teuhyōhua.Comment: C does not mark the vowel of the second syllable long.

teuhyōhuac.Comment: C does not mark the vowel of the second syllable long.

texāl-li.Spanish: piedra arenisca como mollejoŸn para amolarherramienta (M)

texcal-li.Spanish: pen9asco, risco, o horno (M), piedra volcaŸnica (Z)

texcalnahnac(a)-tl.Spanish: cierta piedra que se forman a orillas del mar amanera de hongo (R)

tēxcan.Comment: M has texca "large bedbug", which may representeither TĒXCA-TL without the absolutive suffix orTĒXCAN with a characteristically missing final N.

texiliz-tli.English: mill, or the act of grinding
texiliz-tli.Spanish: molienda o el acto de moler algo (M)

texoco-tl.English: tree of the Rosaceae family (Crataegus mexicana) andits fruit

texpetl(a)-tl.Spanish: batea (T), su concha (T for possessed form)

textiliā.English: to grind s.t. into flour, to crumble or mince s.t.
textiliā.Spanish: hacer algo harina, desmenuzarlo, y picarlo menudo

tex-tli.Comment: This appears to be related to TEUH-TLI "dust" andTEC(I) "to grind" and contrasts with TĒX-TLI"brother-in-law".  M combines TEX-TLI and TĒX-TLI ina single entry.  Z and X have the variant formTIX-TLI.

tēx-tli.Comment: This contrasts with TEX-TLI "flour", but M combinesthem in a single entry.

-tēxxōma.Comment: The first element of this should be TĒN "lip,mouth".  The N would assimilate to X, yielding XX,which T degeminates to X.

tēxxōmatelicza.English: to kick s.o. or s.t. in the snout

tēyacapan-tli.Spanish: primero engendrado o nacido, o primero nacida yengendrada, primogeŸnito o primogeŸnita (M)
tēyacapan-tli.Comment: M has the variant forms tiacapan and tiyacapan,where TĒ- has shortened and changed vowel quality,as in TIĀCHCĀUH.  T has E for A in the second syllable.

teyoh.English: place full of stones, lava bed

-tēyōlcuītiāyān.Spanish: lugar donde yo confieso, mi confesionario (C)

tēyōlicnēliliz-tli.Comment: Z is inconsistent in two attestations.  In one thevowel of the initial syllable is not marked long, andin the other the vowel of the fourth is not.  Bothattestations mark the vowels of the last twosyllables long, although by general rule they shouldnot be.

tēzcapah-tli.English: a shrub or small tree with clusters of yellowflowers (Senecio praecox), usedin treating wounds and rheumatism

tēzca-tl.Spanish: espejo parar mirarse en eŸl (M), vidrio, espejo,cristal (T)

tēzcatlepōca.Comment: Conventionally this is written with I in the thirdsyllable, but in the single attestation the vowel isE and is specifically marked short.  A commonlyaccepted analysis of this name takes PŌCA to be aconstituent modifying TĒZCA-TL "mirror" with thesense "smoking".  Although PŌC is a stem form ofPŌCH-TLI "smoke", there is no correspondingverb PŌCA.  However, for reflexive IHPŌTZ(A) "tobelch", there should be a corresponding intransitiveverb IHPŌCA "to give forth an exhalation",conceivably "to give forth smoke".  T has E forinitial I in IHPŌTZ(A), so its correspondingintransitive would be EHPŌCA.  B's attestation,however, specifically excludes a glottal stop.S provides a lengthy description of Tezcatlipocadrawn from SahaguŸn.

tezontic.Spanish: aŸspera cosa, asiŸ como piedra o cosa semejante (M)

tezon-tli.English: porous red volcanic rock used in construction
tezon-tli.Spanish: piedra tosca, llena de agujericos y liviana (M fortec˛ontli)

tezonyohcān.English: place covered with porous red rock

tiāchcāuh.English: elder brother or s.t. superior, better, more
tiāchcāuh.Spanish: hermano mayor, y persona o cosa aventajada, mayor, ymas excelente que otras (M)
tiāchcāuh.Comment: Weakening of the first vowel of what was originallythe prefix TĒ- leads to the form TIĀCHCĀUH withvowel length and quality change and ultimately toTĀCHCĀUH with vowel loss.  TIĀCHCĀUH contrastswith TIAHCĀUH "s.o. valiant", although they areprobably cognates.

tiahcāuh.Spanish: valiente hombre, animoso y esforzado soldado (M)
tiahcāuh.Comment: This contrasts with TIĀCHCĀUH "older brother",although they are probably cognates.

tiāmiqu(i).English: to buy and sell, to engage in commerce

tiānquizoā.Comment: With the directional ON- this means "to go tomarket".

tīci-tl.Spanish: meŸdico o agorero y echador de suertes (M)

tihticuīnaltiā.Comment: Both attestations in Z mark the vowel of the fourthsyllable long, although by general rule it should beshort.

tihtilān(a).English: to stretch one's arms and legs

tihtīxiā.Spanish: rebuscar despueŸs de la vendimia o cosecha (M),racimar, espigar (S), rejunta (T)

-tīhu(i).Grammar: centrifugal purposive verbal compounding element;singular -TĪUH, plural -TĪHUIH; pret: -TO, pret.pl: -TOH
-tīhu(i).Comment: This contrasts with the verb-final sequence -TIUHwhich is the progressive construction formed byjoining a truncated form of HU(I) "to go" to thepreterit form of a verb with the ligature -TI-.

tilān(a).Spanish: estirar o tirar de algo (M), lo jala (T)
tilān(a).Comment: This abundantly attested verb is subject toconsiderable variation in T, where the vowel of theinitial syllable varies from I to E to completedeletion, and the L varies with R.

tīlīn(i).Comment: In T the medial L varies with R.

tīlīniā.English: to exert effort; to press on s.t. or to tighten s.t.
tīlīniā.Spanish: cen9irse fuertemente o echar o poner fuerzas cuandotrabajan (M), tirar de algo, estirar, apretar n9udo oatadura, flechar o enarcar arco (M)
tīlīniā.Comment: In T the medial L varies with R.

tīlīnticah.English: to be tightened, pressed down, constricted

tīlīntimoman(a).English: for s.t. to remain at high tension

tilmahhuah.Comment: This is given in C and R without gloss as an example of thepossessor derivation.

tilmah-tli.English: cloak, blanket, an indigenous man's garment fastenedon one shoulder

tīmaloā.English: to aggrandize oneself, to be vain; to exhalt s.o. orto swell or increase s.t.
tīmaloā.Spanish: alegrarse, vanagloriarse (S), elogiar, exaltar,honrar a alguien (S)
tīmaloā.Comment: M's intransitive timalloa and temalloa "to swellup with infection" form their preterits by adding -C,and the ll implies that they are derived from thenoun TĒMAL-LI "infection, pus".  Hence they aredifferent from this verb, although S assumes that itis just a matter of variant spelling.  In B TĪMALOĀis always paired with MAHCĒHU(A) "to obtain what onedeserves", the whole phrase having to do withabundance.

timomotzoā.English: to scratch oneself; to scratch s.t.

titīchauhqui.Spanish: vestidura estrecha y corta (M), tupido, ajustado (Z)
titīchauhqui.Comment: Z has lost the final consonant of the third syllable.

titilatz(a).English: to creep along; to drag s.t. along

titītz(a).Spanish: desperezarse y estirarse, bocezando (M), lo estira(liga, etc.) (T)

tītlan(i).English: to send s.o. as a messenger, envoy

tītlaniliā.English: to send s.t. with s.o., to hurl s.t. at s.o.
tītlaniliā.Spanish: lo manda con eŸl, se lo arroja, se lo tira (T)

tītlan-tli.Comment: M also has tititlantli with the same sense.

tīzayohca-tl.Comment: This has a short form TĪZAYOH.  C states theprinciple that in general place names in -YOHCĀNhave alternative "resident" forms with -YOHCA-TL and-YOH.

toca.Comment: M combines this with TŌCA "to bury s.o., to sows.t." in a single entry.

tōca.Spanish: sembrar como maiŸz o habas o cosas semejantes (M)
tōca.Comment: Intransitive TŌCA appears only in theSpanish-to-Nahuatl side of M.

tōcā(i)-tl.Comment: Z retains the I in possessed form.  This contrastswith TOCA-TL "spider".

tōcāpatla.English: to change one's name; to rename s.o.
tōcāpatla.Spanish: se cambia el nombre cuando se casa la mujer por locivil o por la iglesia o por los dos (T), le cambiasu nombre (T)

toca-tl.Comment: Z marks the vowel of the second syllable long, but Thas the reflex of a short vowel.  This contrasts withTŌCĀ(I)-TL "name".

tōcāyoh.English: a signed document, or one's namesake
tōcāyoh.Spanish: firmada escritura (M), su tocayo, su nombre (T forpossessed form)
tōcāyoh.Comment: The single attestation is ambiguous between TŌCĀYOHand TŌCĀYŌ, but the sense appropriate to TŌCĀYOH"s.t. invested with a name" seems to agree with bothM's gloss and with tocayo as it has been absorbedinto Mexican Spanish as "namesake".

tōcāyōtiā.English: to give a name or value to s.o. or s.t., to spreads.o.'s renown, to call s.o. by name
tōcāyōtiā.Spanish: empadronar a alguno, o matricular, o engrandecer yafamar a otro, o poner nombre, o nombrar a alguno, ollamarle por su nombre (M), tasar o poner precio a loque se vende, o nombrar (M)

tōchoā.English: to lean over; to bend s.t. down
tōchoā.Spanish: se inclina ... se agacha (Z), lo agacha (Z)

tōchtecolō-tl.Comment: Since neither of the birds generally known asringdoves are indigenous to Mexico, the gloss doesnot make a clear identification among the many dovesand pigeons of the area.  Possibly this is Columbafasciata, a dove with a ring-like marking on theneck.

tōch-tli.Comment: There is variation of absolutive suffix with this,the alternative being TŌCH-IN.  M has an entry foreach.

-tōcmāyō.Spanish: su hoja (de la can9a de la milpa) (T), su hoja (delchinamiŸl) (T)

tocotzoā.English: to humble oneself, to make oneself smaller; to shrinkor shorten s.t., to take s.t. in
tocotzoā.Comment: This is related by metathesis to synonymousCOTOTZOĀ.

tocotztic.Comment: In one of two attestations, Z marks the vowel of thesecond syllable long but does not so mark thecorresponding vowel in the related verb TOCOTZOĀ.

tocotztlāliā.English: to sit down, to sink; to seat s.o.
tocotztlāliā.Comment: This is related to synonymous COTOTZTLĀLIĀ bymetathesis.

tocotzyetoc.Comment: In one of two attestations Z marks the vowel of thesecond syllable long but does not so mark thecorresponding vowel of the verb TOCOTZOĀ "to makeoneself smaller".

tōcti.Comment: This is attested just once in construction with theverb O, bound by the ligature -TI-.  The absence ofnotation for a glottal stop before the ligatureimplies that the verb is TŌCTI rather than TŌCTIĀ.

toctiā.English: to hide or shelter oneself behind s.t. or s.o., toreside with or accompany s.o., to put s.t. under theprotection of s.o.
toctiā.Spanish: esconderse o ampararse detraŸs de algo (M), se alojacon eŸl, se acompan9a (T), fortificar una cosa conotra (M), le encarga con el otro (T)

tōctitoc.Comment: In Z this has the shortened form TŌCTOC.

tōc-tli.English: young maize plant, stalk, or cane
tōc-tli.Spanish: porreta o mata de maiŸz antes que espigue (M), lacan9a (C)

tohmi-tl.Spanish: pelo o lana o vello sotil (M)
tohmi-tl.Comment: T has E for I in the second syllable.

tohpochoā.English: to bend, to double over; to bend s.t. so that itcannot be straightened
tohpochoā.Spanish: se encoge, se agacha (forzosamente) (T), lo encorva yno se puede enderezarse (T)

tohpochtic.Comment: T has lost the internal glottal stop.

tohtoca.English: to put s.o. to flight, to evict, dismiss, or exiles.o.
tohtoca.Spanish: perseguir a otro, echarle a puertas, o despedirle odesterrarle (M)
tohtoca.Comment: Z is inconsistent in marking vowel length, but theother sources agree.  This contrasts withintransitive TOTŌCA "to run" and TOHTŌCA "to plantthings".

tohtōca.English: to plant things individually in different places
tohtōca.Comment: This contrasts with intransitive TOHTOCA "to chases.o." and with intransitive TOTŌCA "to run".

tohtohuiā.English: to set a dog to barking

tohtolīna.English: to crave many different things to eat
tohtolīna.Spanish: antojaŸrsele a uno varias cosas de comer (C)

tohtom(a).English: to undress; to unfasten or loosen s.t., to undresss.o.
tohtom(a).Spanish: desabrocharse (M), desenvolver o desfajar criatura, odesabrochar a otro (M), desenvolver o desatar algo(M)

tohtom(i).English: to come loose, to come untied

tohtomiliā.English: to loosen, unfasten s.t. for s.o., to remove ababy's diaper or swaddling clothes
tohtomiliā.Spanish: desabrochar a otro o desenvolver la criatura (M), selo desata, se lo suelta (T)

tōl-in.Spanish: juncia o espadan9a (M), planta como can9as para hacerpetates (Z)
tōl-in.Comment: This appears in M with geminate ll before theabsolutive suffix -IN, but that is contrary to therules of Nahuatl morphology, and in compounds Mwrites the stem with only a single l.  This isabundantly attested in place names as well as theattestations in C and Z.

tolīna.English: to crave some particular thing to eat
tolīna.Spanish: antojarseme alguna cosa de comer sin la poder haber(M for first pers. sg. subject)

tōloā.English: to lower, bend down one's head
tōloā.Comment: In Z this is given with reflexive and transitiveprefixes, while in B and M it is intransitive.  Itcontrasts with transitive TOLOĀ "to swallow s.t."

toloā.Comment: This contrasts with TŌLOĀ "to lower, bend downone's head".

tololoh.Comment: In one of three attestations Z marks all vowels long,although by general rule the vowel of the lastsyllable is necessarily short.  In the other twoattestations no vowels are marked long.

tolōltiā.Comment: M has tololtia "to make s.o. bow his head", whichrepresents the causative of TŌLOĀ and whichcontrasts with TOLŌLTIĀ.

tom(a).English: for s.t. to come loose, to undo one's clothing; toloosen, free, unwrap s.t.
tom(a).Spanish: desatarse algo o abrirse (M), desatarse o descen9irse(M), desatar o soltar a otro de la prisioŸn (M),desatar o descoger algo o abrir carta (M)

tomachīl-li.English: sauce of tomatoes and chili peppers

tomāhua.Spanish: engordar o crecer o pararse gordo (M)
tomāhua.Comment: This is synonymous with the reflexive use oftransitive TOMĀHU(A).

tomāhu(a).English: to grow fat, to swell; to fatten s.t.
tomāhu(a).Spanish: engordarse o pararse grueso o querer vomitar (M),apacentar o pensar alguŸn ganado o habla con vozgorda (M)

tomāhualiz-tli.Comment: In both attestations Z marks the vowel of the thirdsyllable long, although by general rule it should notbe.

tomāhu(i).Comment: This is synonymous with TOMĀHUA and the reflexiveuse of TOMĀHU(A).

tōmānehnem(i).English: to go on all fours, to crawl

tomapach.Comment: Z uses the element PACH without an absolutive suffixin this and in CHĪLPACH with the sense of"profusion", possibly "waste".  It may be related toPACH-TLI "moss".

tōmāquetz(a).English: to get down on all fours; to set s.o., s.t. on allfours
tōmāquetz(a).Spanish: se pone en cuatro pies (T), le pone en cuatro pies(T)

toma-tl.Spanish: cierta fruta que sirve de agraz en los guisados osalsas (M), tomate (T)

tom(i).English: for s.t. to come open, to come loose
tom(i).Spanish: desatarse algo o abrirse la carta, o descoserse algo(M)
tom(i).Comment: This is synonymous with the reflexive use of TOM(A).

tomōniā.English: to break out in blisters, to feel nauseated; to raisebumps, bruises
tomōniā.Spanish: se levantan ampollas en la mano (T forMĀXIXIHTOMŌNIĀ), quiere vomitar, tiene ganas devomitar, tiene asco (T), hacer chichones (M)

tompiah-tli.English: cylindrical or conical container woven of palm andused for transporting goods
tompiah-tli.Spanish: esportilla honda, hecha de palmas (M), tompiate(canasta de palma en forma de racimo de uvas) (T)

tōna.English: to be warm, for the sun to shine

tōnacāyō-tl.English: produce, human sustenance, one's daily nourishment
tōnacāyō-tl.Spanish: mantenimiento humano o los frutos de la tierra (M)
tōnacāyō-tl.Comment: This often specifically refers to maize.  Itcontrasts with TONACAYŌ "our flesh", the firstperson plural inalienably possessed form of NAC(A)-TL"flesh".

tōnahu(i).Spanish: he tenido frios y calenturas (C for first pers. sg. ofĀTŌNAHU(I))

tōnalcāhu(a).English: to get frightened; to frighten s.o.
tōnalcāhu(a).Spanish: deja el aŸnima al espantarse (T), le espanta (T)
tōnalcāhu(a).Comment: The literal sense of this has to do with going coldor having chills, as with fright.

tōnalcalaquiyāmpa.English: west, point where the sun sets

tōnalcēhu(i).English: to be overcast, cloudy so that the sun does not shine

tōnalcēhuiā.English: to rest in the shade from the heat of the day; to puts.o., s.t. in the shade
tōnalcēhuiā.Spanish: tener la siesta o descansar el que camina (M), sesombrea, descansa en la sombra (T), le pone a lasombra (T)
tōnalcēhuiā.Comment: Z glosses this as insola, which is apparentlyantithetical to its literal sense.

tōnalcēuhyoh.Comment: Because of word-final vowel shortening and thegeneral loss of word-final glottal stop in T, itcannot be determined if this ends in -YŌ or -YOH,but the fact that it does not take an absolutivesuffix is evidence in favor of -YOH.

tōnallāliā.English: to put s.t. in the shade

tōnallatiā.English: to dry in the sun, to sunburn
tōnallatiā.Spanish: se asolea ... estaŸ quemado por el sol (Z)
tōnallatiā.Comment: This contrasts with TŌNALLĀTIĀ "to concealoneself by day".

tōnallātiā.English: to conceal oneself by day, to protect oneself fromthe sun
tōnallātiā.Comment: This contrasts with TŌNALLATIĀ "to dry in thesun".

tōnal-li.English: warmth of the sun, summertime, day
tōnal-li.Spanish: calor del sol o tiempo de estiŸo (M), diŸa, astro,sol (T)

tōnalmiqu(i).English: to be overwarm, to suffer from the heat

tōnalquīzayāmpa.Comment: In two of three attestations in Z the constituentparts are separated by spaces, but they should notbe.

tōnaltequitiqui.Comment: In two of three attestations, this is shortened toTŌNALTEQUITI.

tōnaltzahtziliā.English: to call down harm on the head of an enemy, mentioninghim by name
tōnaltzahtziliā.Spanish: nombra a la persona a quien quiere hacer maldad (T)

tōnamēyoā.English: to shimmer, to shine in rays
tōnamēyoā.Spanish: estaŸ resplandeciendo (C for compound with MAN(I)),resplandecer el sol, echando rayos de siŸ (M fortonameyotia)

tōnayāhuiā.English: to dry in the sun; to dry s.t. in the sun
tōnayāhuiā.Spanish: se asolea (T), lo solea, lo asolea (T)

tōnayān.English: the heat of the day, daytime
tōnayān.Comment: M has this in tonayampa ehecatl and tonayan vitzehecatl "warm wind from the east or south".

tōnayoh.English: s.t. permeated with the heat of the sun
tōnayoh.Comment: Because of the shortening of word-final vowels andthe general loss of word-final glottal stop in T, itcannot be determined if this ends in -YŌ or -YOH,but the absence of an absolutive suffix and the senseof the word are evidence for -YOH.

tōnēhu(a).English: to inflict burning pain on s.o.

-tōn-tli.Grammar: compounding element conveying the sense of smallness,insignificance; pl: -TOTŌNTIN
-tōn-tli.Comment: Although necessarily bound, this behaves in a mannerdistinct from suffixes and postpositions.  It has itsown absolutive suffix and forms the plural byreduplication of itself plus addition of the pluralsuffix -TIN.  If the noun with which it compoundsdoes not itself take an absolutive suffix, then thecompound does not either, and -TIN is omitted in theplural; CHICHI "dog", CHICHITŌN, CHICHITOTŌN"dogs".

topēhu(a).English: to press forward, to impel oneself forwards; to push,shove s.o. or s.t.
topēhu(a).Spanish: se empuja (T), empujar a otro (M), empujar otra cosa,o atizar el fuego allegandole los tizones (M)

tōpīleh.English: constable, minor official, holder of a staff ofoffice

tōpīlehcāhuah.Comment: This also appears in P with the internal glottal stopmarked but not the long vowels.

tōpīl-li.Spanish: bordoŸn, hasta de lanza, o vara de justicia (M)

topōn(i).English: to make an explosive noise, to thunder, for a firearmto discharge

topōniā.English: to make a thunderous noise, to discharge a firearm,to make an explosive sound
topōniā.Spanish: truena (el cielo), truena la boca al comer cosa dura,truena el pollito saliendo del huevo (T), lo truenacomieŸndolo (T)

tōp-tli.Spanish: iŸdolo o funda de caŸliz tejida con hilo de maguey, ocosa de esta manera (M), cofre (C)
tōp-tli.Comment: Idols were transported wrapped in bundles, whichaccounts for the extension of meaning from"container, wrapper" to "idol".

toquiā.English: to draw near; to draw s.o. or s.t. to oneself
toquiā.Spanish: se arrima (Z), lo arrima, le acerca (Z)
toquiā.Comment: This is homophonous with TOQUIĀ "to stoke a fire".

tōquiltiā.Comment: The vowel of the second syllable of this should beshort by general rule but is attested long in T.

totēcuiyō.Grammar: first pers. plural possessed form of TĒUC-TLI

totōca.English: to run, to hurry, for illness to worsen
totōca.Spanish: ir de priesa o correr, empeorar o crecer laenfermedad (M)
totōca.Comment: Despite the apparent affinity of meaning, this is notderived by reduplication from TOCA "to pursue s.o.",since they differ in transitivity and in vowellength.  C contrasts this with with TŌTOCA "to runafter s.t.", which is a genuine reduplicatedderivation from TOCA.

tōtoca.English: to run along after s.t., to go skirmishing with s.o.
tōtoca.Spanish: andar corriendo traŸs de alguna cosa o escaramuceando(C)
tōtoca.Comment: This contrasts with TOTŌCA "to run, to hurry".

totochoā.English: to be forward, importunate; to push, shove s.o. ors.t. to the front
totochoā.Spanish: se empuja, es muy intruso (T), lo empuja (delante delos demaŸs para que le toque regalo, etc.) (T)

tōtol-in.Comment: From its basic meaning "turkey" this has beenextended to chickens and doves.  It contrasts invowel length in the second syllable with TŌTŌ-TL"bird".

tōtolontic.Comment: M has unreduplicated tolontic "s.t. round like aball", which suggests a connection with synonymousOLOLTIC.

tōtoltecacahua-tl.Comment: M has totoltecacalli with the same sense.

tōtoltepōhu(a).Spanish: cuento huevos (C for first pers. sg. subject)
tōtoltepōhu(a).Comment: C provides a paradigm of this as an example of objectincorporation.

totomoca.English: to break out in many blisters

tōtomōch-tli.Spanish: hojas secas de la mazorca de maiŸz (M), totomoxtle,hoja de mazorca (Z)
tōtomōch-tli.Comment: T has the reflex of Ā for Ō in the thirdsyllable.

totōniā.English: to warm oneself; to heat s.t.
totōniā.Spanish: calentarse a la lumbre o al sol (M), asolear ocalentar algo al sol o a la lumbre (M)
totōniā.Comment: The reflexive use of this is synonymous withintransitive TOTŌNIY(A).

totōniy(a).English: to grow hot, to run a fever
totōniy(a).Spanish: calentarse el agua o otra cosa (M), tener ardor ocalentura (M)
totōniy(a).Comment: This contrasts with transitive TOTŌNIĀ.  T has thevariant form TOTŌNEYA.  With the prefix TLA- Zglosses this as "to be hot (weather)".

totōniyaliz-tli.Comment: T has E for I in the third syllable.

totōnqui.Comment: Z has the variant form TOTŌNIC.

tōtopēhu(a).English: to swing s.t., to rock s.t.

totopoca.English: to thunder, to make a loud cracking noise
totopoca.Spanish: truena (p.ej. cuando se oyen las vigas que quierenquebrarse) (T)

totopochtic.Spanish: cosa muy tostada, asiŸ como pan, tortillas de maiŸz,etc. (M)

totopoch-tli.English: s.t. toasted, crunchy, noisy to eat

totopotz(a).English: to make s.t. crunchy by toasting it or chewing itloudly
totopotz(a).Spanish: roer o tostar algo (M), lo mastica (haciendo ruido)(T)
totopotz(a).Comment: The sense of making or noisily eating crunchy food isat some remove from TOPŌN(I) "to make an explosivenoise, to thunder, to discharge a firearm", but thisis clearly derivationally related to TOPŌN(I) andTOTOPOCA in a morphologically unexceptional way.

tōtō-tl.Comment: This differs from related TŌTOL-IN "domestic fowl",in the length of the vowel of the second syllable.

totōtz(a).English: to hurry s.o. along, to advance s.t., to causeworsening of an illness
totōtz(a).Spanish: adelantar o aguijar el reloj (M), aguijar y darpriesa a eŸl que camina, o empeorar el meŸdico alenfermo (M), empeorar, o dar priesa a otra cualquiercosa (M)

toxāhu(i).Comment: M has transitive toxaua "to spill s.t. on theground".

toyāhu(i).English: to leak, to spill, to sprinkle water
toyāhu(i).Spanish: derramarse cosas liŸquidas o hundirse el montoŸn deharina (M), riega (Z)

tozan.Comment: M has the gloss "mole", but the animal currentlyknown in Mexican Spanish as tuza is the gopher,which is also in keeping with the rest of M's gloss.

tozcatzacu(i).English: to become hoarse, for one's throat to be constricted

tōzoā.English: to stay awake, to keep vigil

tozquihuah.Comment: C gives this without gloss as an example of thepossessor derivation.

tozqui-tl.Spanish: la voz del que canta (M), la voz y la garganta (C)

tla-.Comment: This nonspecific nonhuman prefix "something"can be absorbed into a verb stem, changing it from atransitive verb into an intransitive one.  In somecases the transitivity does not change, and theresulting verb redundantly takes another objectprefix before the fused TLA-.  With a given verb itis often difficult to determine whether the stem andprefix have been fused or not.  If the verb neverappears with a specific object or reflexive prefix,if with TLA- it has a meaning distinct from itsliteral sense, or if there is a reduplicated formthat involves the TLA- rather than the firstconsonant and vowel of the verb stem, then fusion hastaken place.  Many verbs with TLA- are ambiguous inthis respect.  TLA- also functions in two ways assomething other than an object prefix.  Withintransitive verbs it conveys an impersonal sense,while with nouns and postpositions it functions as anindefinite, nonspecific possessive prefix.  Thisparallels the use of the corresponding human objectprefix TĒ- with nouns and postpositions.

tlā.Grammar: introductory particle for clauses expressing wishes,commands, admonitions; negative form: TLĀCA =TLĀCAMŌ
tlā.Spanish: partiŸcula que se junta al imperativo y al optativo;indica maŸs cortesiŸa, maŸs insistencia que ma (S)
tlā.Comment: TLĀ may substitute for MĀ as a clauseintroductory particle and conveys greater courtesyand deference.  T and Z have TLA- "if, should it bethat, perhaps" which can be identified both with thisand with INTLĀ "if", which is abundantly attestedin B and C.

tlaahcicācaquiliz-tli.Spanish: entera y perfecta inteligencia de la cosa (M)

-tlaahcicācaquiya.Spanish: mi entendimiento (R for first pers. sg. possessor)

tlaahhuiliā.Comment: T and C have AHHUILIĀ as a simple transitive verbwhich may take specific object prefixes ornonspecific TLA-, but C also has this with a specificobject prefix preceding the TLA- implying that theTLA- has been absorbed into the stem without alteringthe verb's transitivity.  T has lost the internalglottal stop.

tlaāqu(i).English: for a fruit tree to produce
tlaāqu(i).Spanish: fruticarse el aŸrbol o cosa asiŸ (M in constructionwith ĪTECH)
tlaāqu(i).Comment: In all attestations Z marks the second vowel long.If this is correct, then the basic verb stem cannotbe AQU(I) "to enter".

tlaāquīllō-tl.Spanish: aŸrbol con fruta o cosa semejante (M)
tlaāquīllō-tl.Comment: In two attestations out of five Z marks the vowel ofthe third syllable long, and in three Z consolidatesTAĀ to TĀ.

tlaāx-tli.Comment: This appears in R without diacritics.  C specificallymarks both A's short, which would be wrong if this isderived from ĀY(I) "to do s.t.". M has tlaay,preterite onitlaax, "to work land", and C clearlyassumes that the basic verb is ĀY(I) by glossingthis noun as "s.t. accomplished, such as land plowedand cultivated".  Either C's diacritic is incorrect,or the verb for cultivation of land is not derivedfrom ĀY(I).

tlācacco.Spanish: segura y paciŸficamente, o sin sobras (M)
tlācacco.Comment: C attests this with geminate CC, while M has a singleconsonant.

tlācacconem(i).Spanish: viven con ... quietud (C for third pers. pluralsubject)

tlācachīhu(a).English: to do favors, to give help; to hold s.o. in esteem
tlācachīhu(a).Spanish: lo apoya (se encarga de ayuda), hace favor (T), loaprecia, lo adora, lo respeta (Z)
tlācachīhu(a).Comment: M also has intransitive tlacachiua "to engender, togive birth".  The prefix string nitla implies thatit is transitive, but the preterit formonitlacachiuh and the entry in theSpanish-to-Nahuatl side of M show this to be anerror.  The associated prefix string should be simplyni, not nitla.

tlacah.Spanish: asiŸ (C), palabra del que cae en la cuenta y emiendalo que dice (C)
tlacah.Comment: This is abundantly attested in C as a free form andalso bound with the particles ZO and CEH < ZO (Y)EH,all used as interjections.  It contrasts withTLĀCAH, the plural form of TLĀCA-TL "person" andwith TLAHCAH "at midday".

tlacahcāhual-li.Comment: This contrasts with TLĀCACĀHUAL-LI "widower".  Inone attestation Z marks the vowel of TLA- long, butit should not be.

tlacahceh.Grammar: expression of surprise at a discovery

tlācahuah.English: master, s.o. who owns or employs other people
tlācahuah.Spanish: sen9or o duen9o de esclavos (M), sen9or, hombre quetiene criados (R)

tlacāhualtiā.English: to abstain, to restrain oneself; to restrain, impede,delay s.o.
tlacāhualtiā.Spanish: abstenerse de algo e irse a la mano (M), ir a la manoa otro, y estorbarle algo (M), lo suspende (Z)
tlacāhualtiā.Comment: In one attestation Z marks the vowel of the thirdsyllable long, but it should not be.

tlācahuapāhu(a).English: to raise children, to be a tutor for children
tlācahuapāhu(a).Spanish: criar nin9os o ser tutor y ayo de ellos (M)

tlācahuapāhual-li.English: child raised or instructed by a tutor at home
tlācahuapāhual-li.Spanish: pupilo o nin9o criado en casa (M)

tlācahuapāhuani.Comment: M has tlacauapauhqui with the same sense.

tlacahzo.Grammar: expression of surprise at a discovery
tlacahzo.Spanish: valgame Dios, adverbio de que usa el que conadmiracioŸn cae en la cuenta de algo que no habiŸareparado, o a lo menos se confirma en aquella verdad(C)
tlacahzo.Comment: This is abundantly attested in C and also appears inR.

-tlācaicnīuh.Comment: T has lost the word-final consonant.

tlācaitta.English: to consider s.o. a human being, to acknowledge,tolerate, accept, or admit s.o.
tlācaitta.Spanish: te miramos ... como a hombre (C for first pers.plural subject, second pers. singular object), lepermite entrar, le consiente, lo admite (T)
tlācaitta.Comment: M has derivations from this involving hypocrisy anddeception.

tlacamaneloā.English: to mumble, to fail to speak clearly

tlācamat(i).Grammar: vrefl,vt; pret: TLĀCAMAH, pret. pl: TLĀCAMATQUEH
tlācamat(i).English: to be rich and prosperous; to obey s.o.
tlācamat(i).Spanish: ser rico y proŸspero (M), obedecer a otro (M)

tlācamazāteh.English: s.o. or s.t. that has rabies
tlācamazāteh.Spanish: rabia (T), perro con rabia (T for compound withCHICHI)
tlācamazāteh.Comment: T has a variant form with short A in the firstsyllable.  M has tlacamac˛atl "s.o. rabid orvicious".  Compare this compound of TLĀCA-TL"person" and MAZĀ-TL "deer" with TLĀCATECOLŌ-TL"devil" where the second element is TECOLŌ-TL "owl".

tlācamictiāni.Spanish: matador (M), el que mata a personas (C)

tlācamō.Grammar: negative form of the clause introductory particle TLĀ
tlācamō.Comment: This has a short form TLĀCA.

-tlācapoh.English: s.o. sharing the quality of being human
-tlācapoh.Spanish: uno de nosotros (C for first pers. plural possessor)
-tlācapoh.Comment: This also appears in P with the glottal stop markedbut not the long vowel.

tlacaqu(i).English: to listen, to understand, to hold a hearing
tlacaqu(i).Spanish: oir o entender o tener audiencia (M)
tlacaqu(i).Comment: This is attested in a distributive form thatreduplicates the TLA- rather than CA, indicating thatthe prefix TLA- has been fused with thestem.

tlacaquiltiā.English: to make a complaint to s.o.
tlacaquiltiā.Spanish: regan9a, lo hace sentir todas las cosas (Z)
tlacaquiltiā.Comment: In the single attestation the vowel of the thirdvowel is marked long, although by general rule itshould be short.

tlācateccō.English: residence of a member of the high nobilty, the nameof a particular temple dedicated to the godHuitzilopochtli
tlācateccō.Spanish: templo dedicado al dios Uitzilopochtli, cuyaconsagracioŸn tuvo lugar bajo el reinado del monarcaAhuitzotl (S)

tlācatecolōnōtz(a).Comment: This is implied by the derived formTLĀCATECOLŌNŌTZQUI.

tlācatecolō-tl.Comment: P gives the plural with TLAH in place of TLĀ forthe reduplication.

tlācatēm(i).English: for a crowd of people to gather
tlācatēm(i).Spanish: se congrega mucha gente, se junta mucha gente,multitud (T)

tlācatēuc-tli.Spanish: sen9or, duen9o, soberano (S), su patroŸn, su amo (Zfor possessed form)
tlācatēuc-tli.Comment: This was originally a title of high nobility.

tlācatiliā.English: to engender, give birth to s.o., for a bird to brood,to give form and shape to s.t., to treat s.o.humanely
tlācatiliā.Spanish: engendra a otro, o tratar bien y humanamente a otro(M), engendra algo, formar o reducir a cierta forma,o sacar pollos las aves (M)

tlāca-tl.Comment: The plural of this contrasts with TLACAH "that is tosay" and TLAHCAH "at midday".  TLĀCA-TL hascontradictory uses.  In older texts IN TLĀCA-TL is arespectful term of address, while the possessed form-TLĀCAUH conventionally means "slave" and is used inplace of the possessed form of TLĀCOH-TLI.

tlacatzoā.Comment: Since Z is a T-dialect, and this is attested nowhereelse, it is possible that this should be TACATZOĀ.

tlacāuh-tli.English: space, capacity, s.t. relinquished or left over
tlacāuh-tli.Spanish: espacio de lugar, o cosa dejada o sobras (M)

tlācaxināch-tli.Spanish: simiente de varoŸn o de mujer (M), el semen genital(C)
tlācaxināch-tli.Comment: M gives a derivation of this with -YŌ meaning"human generation, lineage" and a plural form with-TIN for "first human generation, progenitors of thehuman race".

tlācayō-tl.Spanish: cosa humana y piadosa o la humanidad (M), gente,multitud (Z)

tlācazcaltiā.Spanish: criar hijos o nin9os y doctrinarlos (M)

tlācazcaltiāni.Spanish: ama de nin9o, ayo o aya, o tutor (M)

tlācazcaltīl-li.English: child being raised and instructed by a tutor at home
tlācazcaltīl-li.Spanish: nin9o o pupilo criado en la casa (M)
tlācazcaltīl-li.Comment: B does not mark the vowel of the fourth syllable forlength, but it should be long.

tlācazolyō-tl.Comment: In general the sequence LY would assimilate to LL asit does in M, but in B it remains unassimilated.  Inthe Spanish-to-Nahuatl side M has vey tlacac˛olli"glutton".

tlacecēhuiliā.Spanish: aplacar al enojado (M), se reconcilia con el (T)

tlaceceltiā.English: to beg s.o.'s pardon, to calm s.o., to cool s.o.'s emotions
tlaceceltiā.Spanish: se le pide disculpas, se le ofrece algo para calme ... loconvence (T)

tlacecēy(a).Comment: Z has this with QUĒMMAN, the phrase meaning "winter,at the time when it is cold".

tlacehcēuhyoh.Comment: Because of general word-final vowel shortening andthe loss of final glottal stop in T, it cannot bedetermined whether this ends in -YOH or -YŌ, but theabsence of an absolutive suffix is evidence for -YOH.

tlacēhual-li.Comment: X also has this without the absolutive suffix as"hat".

tlaceliā.Comment: This contrasts with TLACELIY(A) "for new growth totake place".

tlaceliy(a).English: for new growth to take place, for leaves to come out

tlaceliyayān.English: verdant spot, place where new growth takes place
tlaceliyayān.Spanish: lugar fresco, asiŸ como prado verde que se estaŸriendo (M)

tlacellō-tl.Comment: M has tlaceliayan "cool, fresh place such as apleasant meadow".

tlaceltiā.Comment: This contrasts with M's tlaceltia "for a place tobe cool and refreshing", which is derivationallyrelated to TLACELIY(A).

tlacempanahuiā.English: to be superlative in some quality
tlacempanahuiā.Spanish: cosa que excede y sobrepuja a toda lo demaŸs (M)

tlacencāhual-li.Spanish: cosa aparejada, aderezada, ataviada, o adornada (M)

tlachicōmetiliā.English: to hold a novena for s.o., to make s.t. the objectof prayers for nine days for s.o.

tlachihchīhual-li.Spanish: cosa aderezada y ataviada, o cosa contrahecha,fingida, y falsificada (M)

tlachihchīhuiliā.English: to arrange one's own food, for a chicken to make itsnest
tlachihchīhuiliā.Spanish: hace su propia comida, (gallina) hace su propio nido(T)

tlachihchīuh-tli.Spanish: cosa aderezada y ataviada, o cosa fingida y falsa,asiŸ como moneda contrahecha o cosa semejante (M)

tlachīhual-li.Spanish: criatura o hechura (M), cosa hecha, obra, criatura(C)

tlachīliā.English: to keep watch, vigil; to watch or spy on s.o.
tlachīliā.Spanish: vigila (T), lo vela, lo vigila, lo espiŸa (T)

tlachipāuh-tli.Comment: This is attested in the derived forms TLACHIPĀUHYOH,TLACHIPĀUHCĀN, and TLACHIPĀUHYĀN.

tlachipāuhyoh.Comment: Because of general shortening of word-final vowelsand the loss of final glottal stop in T, it cannot bedetermined whether the final element here is -YOH or-YŌ, but the absence of an absolutive suffix isevidence for -YOH.

tlachipīn.Comment: Because of the general loss of word-final N in T, thefinal consonant here is unattested but can berestored from the related verb form.

tlachiy(a).English: to see, to look or gaze
tlachiy(a).Comment: M and C treat this as an intransitive verb resultingfrom the fusion of the nonspecific human objectprefix TLA- with the verb stem CHIY(A) "to awaits.t."  A common variation is E for A, usually writtentlachie.  The long-vowel variant preterit form isnot directly attested for this item but is abundantlyattested for basic CHIY(A).

tlachiyaliz-tli.Spanish: atalayadora o el acto de mirar o ver algo (M), vista,miradar (Z)

-tlachiyaya.Spanish: mi vista, potencia visiva (C for first pers.sg. possessor)

tlachpān(a).Comment: There is variation across sources about whether theprefix TLA- has been fused to theverb stem in this item.

tlachpānhuāz-tli.Comment: X fails to mark the vowel of the second syllablelong.

tlachpān-tli.English: a place that has been swept

tlacohcocōl-li.Spanish: herido, lastimado, o llagado de otros (M forunreduplicated tlacocolli), lastimado (Z)
tlacohcocōl-li.Comment: X has unreduplicated TLACOCŌL-LI but glosses it as"wound" rather than as "s.o. wounded".

tlācohti.English: to serve, to be a slave

tlacōhualiz-tli.English: purchase, the act of buying s.t.

tlacōlhuiā.English: to deflect s.t. from its path, to change atrajectory
tlacōlhuiā.Spanish: el corta la vuelta (una piedra, etc.) (T), se davuelta, pasa a un lado (Z)

tlacōliuhyoh.Comment: Because of the general shortening of word-finalvowels and the loss of final glottal stops in T, itcannot be determined whether this ends in -YOH or-YŌ, but the absence of an absolutive suffix isevidence for -YOH.

tlacomōl-li.English: large pit, ravine, hole in the earth
tlacomōl-li.Comment: The vowel of the last syllable is marked long in onlyone of three attestations.  M has comoloa "to makeholes, ravines".

tlaconexneloā.English: to get full of ashes; to fill or cover s.t. withashes
tlaconexneloā.Spanish: se llena de ceniza (T), lo enceniza (T)

tlacōpah-tli.Comment: R only indicates the glottal stop in PAH-TLI.Although TLACŌ-TL "staff, pole" seems more likelyfor the first element, TLĀCOH-TLI "slave" is equallypossible.

tlacopitzcān.Comment: Possibly Z has lost a glottal stop, and the firstelement of this should be TLAHCO "middle".

tlacotōnaltiā.English: to prohibit s.o. from doing s.t.

tlacpa-.Comment: This compounding element combines with kinship termsto convey the sense of indirect relationship;TLACPACONĒ-TL "stepchild", TLACPAICHPŌCH-TLI"stepdaughter", TLACPATĒLPŌCH-TLI "stepson",TLACPAICNĪUH-TLI "stepbrother, stepsister",TLACPANĀN-TLI "stepmother", TLACPATAH-TLI"stepfather".

tlacpac.Spanish: arriba, en lo alto, o encima de algo (M)

tlāc-tli.Spanish: el cuerpo de hombre desde la cinta arriba (M)

tlacuā.Comment: In the Nahuatl-to-Spanish side M gives onlytransitive CUĀ "to eat s.t.", but in theSpanish-to-Nahuatl side this is given as the glossfor intransitive comer "to eat".  C treats TLACUĀas an intransitive verb resulting from the fusion ofthe nonspecific object prefix TLA- with the stem.

tlacuāātēquiā.Comment: It is unusual that the nonspecific nonhuman objectprefix TLA- is involved here rather than its humanobject counterpart TĒ-.  Because of the specialized,nonliteral sense, it appears that TLA- is fused withthe stem in this item.  The sequence ĀĀ isgenerally written with a single letter, as it is inT.

tlacuahnāmiqu(i).English: to set oneself up in opposition
tlacuahnāmiqu(i).Comment: The prefix TLA- has been absorbedinto the compound verb stem to form an intransitiveverb.

tlacuāhua.Comment: Z has the variant TLACUĀHUAYA.
