The long vowel ofthe second syllable is attested in B, C, and Z, whichis evidence against derivational relationship toCUAUHTI "to stiffen" despite the affinity of meaning.M also has this as a transitive verb "to hardens.t.". The intransitive and transitive verbscontrast in the preterit with TLACUĀHUAC andTLACUĀUH respectively.

tlacualcān.Comment: Z has this only in negated form, AHMŌ TLACUALCĀN"hell".

tlacualchīhu(a).Comment: M has reduplicated tlaqualchichiua with the samesense.

tlacual-li.Comment: Although the verb CUĀ "to eat s.t." has a longvowel, the corresponding vowel of this derived formis short in B, C, and T.  In X and Z it isconsistently marked long.

tlacualō.Comment: The expected nonactive form of TLACUĀ "to eat"would be TLACUĀLŌ, but it is attested with a shortvowel in the second syllable except in Z.

tlacualtiā.Comment: The expected causative from TLACUĀ would have along vowel in the second syllable, but it isconsistently attested short.

tlacualtzohtzomah-tli.Comment: T has lost the internal glottal stop ofTZOHTZOMAH-TLI.

tlacuāman(a).Comment: Here the prefix TLA- appears tohave fused with the stem, converting it into anintransitive verb.

tlacuāni.English: s.o. or s.t. that eats things, glutton
tlacuāni.Comment: This contrasts with TĒCUĀNI "wild beast, maneater",in that it has the nonspecific nonhuman object prefix"something" rather than the nonspecific human objectprefix "someone".

tlacuātzin.Comment: T has a short vowel in the second syllable, while Zmarks it long, as it should be if derived from theverb CUĀ "to eat s.t."  Z gives this for "opposum" andalso for "porcupine".  M has tlaquatl "a type ofanimal".

tlacuāuh.Spanish: fuertemente, con fuerza, bien, mucho, positivamente,especialmente (S)

tlacuauhtiliā.English: to have an erection of the penis
tlacuauhtiliā.Comment: M's gloss misleadingly suggests that the penis ratherthan the person would be the grammatical subject ofthis verb.

tlacuauhtilizpah-tli.Comment: The name of this plant suggests that it is used totreat impotence.  It literally means "medicine orpotion for stiffening s.t."

tlacuāuhtlamat(i).English: to be certain, confident, firm in one's belief
tlacuāuhtlamat(i).Comment: M has this with -TECH "to depend on or haveconfidence in s.o."

tlacuāuhtlamatiliz-tli.Comment: S has this with the entirely different sense of"deception", which is apparently an error.  M hasseveral synonymous phrases with -TECH and involvingthe element tlaquauh and meaning "to haveconfidence in s.o."

-tlacuāyān.English: one's place or time for eating
-tlacuāyān.Spanish: lugar o tiempo donde o cuando como (C for firstpers. sg. possessor)

tlacuēchōl-li.English: s.t. finely ground, s.t. ground to a paste orliquid

tlacuep(a).English: to invert s.t., to regurgitate, to appeal a sentence,to engage in translation
tlacuep(a).Spanish: volver alguna cosa lo de arriba abajo, apelar desentencia, o escusarse, y no estar por lo que otrodice ... o traducir algo de una lengua en otra (M),vomita (Z)

tlacuepaliz-tli.Comment: The two senses share the literal one of "to reverse,turn back".

tlacuepōn(i).English: for things to bud and burst into bloom

tlacuep-tli.English: s.t. turned over or sent back, s.t. vaulted
tlacuep-tli.Spanish: cosa vuelta lo de arriba abajo o cosa vuelta a quienla envioŸ (M), volteado (T)
tlacuep-tli.Comment: T has C for P as in other derivations from CUEP(A)with TL and TZ.  The C persists before -MEH in theplural.

tlacuetlānhuitz-tli.Comment: M has tlacuetlaniliztli "to twist or bend wood" andtlacuetlanilli "twisted wood", which areappropriately descriptive of a briar patch.

tlacuiā.English: to borrow; to borrow for s.o.
tlacuiā.Spanish: tomar algo prestado (M), lo pide prestado por otro(M)
tlacuiā.Comment: Outside the sources for this dictionary thissometimes appears written as tlahcuia, suggestingthat T has lost an internal glottal stop.

tlacuihcui.English: to work wood or stone by chipping or planing off thesurface, to clear off a surface
tlacuihcui.Spanish: desbastar madera o limpiar el suelo quitando cosas(C), labro piedra o madera como hace el escultor (Cfor first pers. sg. subject)

tlacuihcuīliā.English: to relieve s.o. of s.t., to take s.t. away fromfrom s.t. (as in culling kernels or planing wood),to practice a type of healing in which objects saidto be causing the illness appear to be drawn from thebody.
tlacuihcuīliā.Spanish: robar alguna cosa a otros, echar granzas, o hacercierta hechiceriŸa dando a entender que sacan delcuerpo pedernales, navajas, etc., las cuales erancausas de la enfermedad del enfermo (M), alimpiarpozo, garbanzos, arroz, o cosas semejantes (M)
tlacuihcuīliā.Comment: This is abundantly attested in C where the vowel ofthe third syllable is marked long and in T where itis short.

tlacuihcuīlō-tl.Comment: In two of four attestations Z marks the vowel of thethird syllable long and in two does not.  Z lacks thereflex of a glottal stop in the second syllable, butby derivation there should be one.

tlacuihcui-tl.English: piece of worked wood or cut stone
tlacuihcui-tl.Spanish: cosa labrada o esculpida en madera o en piedra (M)
tlacuihcui-tl.Comment: R has a long vowel in the second syllable rather thana short vowel and glottal stop as C does.

tlacza.Spanish: ir muy de priesa o correr (M)
tlacza.Comment: This is implied by the derived form TLACZALIZ-TLI.

tlaczaliz-tli.English: fast marching, running, stomping, making tracks
tlaczaliz-tli.Spanish: el acto de aguijar mucho o correr (M), pisada (Z)

tlaecahuīllō-tl.Comment: M has ecauillotl "shade", reflexive ecauilia "toput oneself in the shade", and transitiveecauillotia "to shade s.t."  In T the vowel of theprefix TLA- has idiosyncratically assimilated to thevowel of the stem.

tlaēlēhuiliz-tli.Spanish: codicia o deseo de algo, apetito o antojo de algunacosa (M)
tlaēlēhuiliz-tli.Comment: In the single attestation the vowel of the secondsyllable is marked long.

-tlah.Grammar: locative compounding element conveying the sense ofabundance
-tlah.Comment: Some examples from C are TETLAH "rocky place" < TE-TL"stone", CUAUHTLAH "forest" < CUAHU(I)-TL "tree",XŌCHITLAH "garden" < XŌCHI-TL "flower".  The pluralor distributive is formed by reduplication withglottal stop of the first element, TEHTETLAH,XOHXŌCHITLAH (Cf.71v,72r).  Because of the trendthroughout Nahuatl to lose final nasal consonants andthe general rule to that effect in T, -TLAH oftenfalls together with locative -TLĀN and -TLAN.

tlahcah.Comment: M combines this in a single entry with TLĀCAH, theplural form of TLĀCA-TL "person".  TLAHCAH alsocontrasts with TLACAH "that is to say".

tlahcahti.English: to get late in the morning, towards noon
tlahcahti.Spanish: se va haciendo tarde (C for progressive construction)
tlahcahti.Comment: This contrasts with TLĀCAT(I) "to be born".

tlahcahtiliā.Comment: There appears to be an attestation of this usedintransitively but the vowel of the second syllableis difficult to make out (Bf.12r).

tlahcahtlacuā.English: to eat at midday, to dine late
tlahcahtlacuā.Comment: T has lost the glottal stop of the second syllable.

tlahcah-tli.Spanish: diŸa, desde que sale el sol hasta que se pone (C),mediodiŸa (T)
tlahcah-tli.Comment: Without the absolutive suffix TLAHCAH commonly means"at midday", while with the absolutive suffix itrefers to the middle of the day itself.

tlahcal(i).English: to lie down, to fling oneself down; to fling, cast,pitch s.t.
tlahcal(i).Spanish: se acuesta, se tira (T), lo tira, lo bota, lo tumba,lo vuelca (T)

tlahchicqui.English: s.o. who collects unfermented maguey sap (tlachique)as a beverage
tlahchicqui.Spanish: oficiales encargados de raspar el maguey y prepararel pulque que se daba a beber durante las ceremoniasreligiosas consagradas al dios (S for plural),tlachiquero (Z)

tlahco.Spanish: mediano, que ocupa el centro, que estaŸ a la mitad,en medio (S)
tlahco.Comment: The first element of this contrasts with TLĀC-TLI"torso" in vowel length as well as final consonant,despite the affinity of meaning.  M has this incompounds involving "middle" but not as anindependent entry.  It contrasts with TLACŌ-TL"staff, pole" and TLĀCOH-TLI "slave".  T also hasTLAHTLAHCO with the same sense.

tlahcol.Comment: This is only attested compounded as CENTLAHCOL "onehalf".

tlahcopāc(a).English: to bathe the upper half of one's body
tlahcopāc(a).Spanish: ban9a la mitad (de la cintura arriba) (T)

-tlahcoteyō.Comment: This implies TLAHCOTE-TL, one of many names for bodyparts with TE-TL "stone" in a completely nonliteralsense.

tlahcoyānilpiā.English: to gird oneself, to wrap one's skirt and secure itwith a sash

tlahcualquiliā.English: to curse, blaspheme; to insult s.o., to quarrel withs.o.
tlahcualquiliā.Spanish: mienta la autora de sus diŸas, mienta la madre (T),ren9ir, rifar, o contender con otro (M), lo blasfema,lo maldice (Z), le mienta la autora de sus diŸas, lemienta la madre (T)
tlahcualquiliā.Comment: Z also has two attestations of TLAHCUALTILILIĀ withthe same sense.

tlahcuiloā.Comment: M only has an entry for transitive (I)HCUILOĀ, but Ctreats this as a case where the nonspecific objectprefix TLA- has fused with the stem to form anintransitive verb.

tlahcuiloh.Comment: Z has a variant TLAHCUILOHQUI with the same sense,while M has tlacuiloani.

tlahcuilohhuiliā.English: to reply to s.o. in writing
tlahcuilohhuiliā.Comment: The glottal stop of the third syllable is notattested, and the vowel before it is unmarked forlength.  If there is no glottal stop, then the Oshould be long.

tlahcuilōliz-tli.English: the act of writing or painting
tlahcuilōliz-tli.Spanish: el acto de escribir o pintar (M)

tlahcuilōl-li.Comment: This also appears in P with the glottal stop markedbut not the long vowel.  In X the long vowel ismarked, but the glottal stop is missing.

tlahhuēltamaca.English: to cultivate land a second time

tlahmach-tli.Spanish: labor de manta labrada, o buena man9a para haceralgo, o brosladura de ropa (M)

tlahmachyoh.Spanish: manta labrada o lienzo con labores (M), bordado (Z)
tlahmachyoh.Comment: Z spells the Y as Ī, which may represent anintrusive vowel yielding the sequence IY, or it maybe some sort of hypercorrection.  M spells thistlamacho, implying assimilation of the CHY sequenceto CHCH and then degemination to CH.

tlahmah.English: physician or surgeon, s.o. competent in a specialty
tlahmah.Spanish: meŸdico o cirujano (M), el meŸdico, o oficial dehabilidad (C)
tlahmah.Comment: A variant of this is TLAHMATQUI.  R has TLAMAH "s.o.who knows s.t.", which apparently contrasts withthis.

tlahmat(i).English: to jest, to practice trickery and deception, to bequick-witted
tlahmat(i).Spanish: embaucar a otro el hechicero (M), travesear (M)
tlahmat(i).Comment: Although IHMAT(I) retains the intial I afterreflexive prefixes, it loses it with fused TLA-.This contrasts with TLAMAT(I) "to know s.t." <MAT(I).  There is a double meaning to TLAHMAT(I).On the one hand it has to do with being skillful andquick-witted and on the other with being deceptiveand tricky.  Although the preterit of IHMAT(I) isgiven by M as -MAH, the preterit of TLAHMAT(I) isgiven as -MAT.

tlahmatiliz-tli.Comment: M combines this in a single gloss with TLAMATILIZ-TLI"wisdom".

tlahmatqui.English: physician or surgeon, s.o. competent in a specialty,trickster
tlahmatqui.Spanish: embaucador (M), es el meŸdico o oficial de habilidad(C)
tlahmatqui.Comment: A variant of this is TLAHMAH.

tlahmattinem(i).English: to go about jesting and practicing trickery anddeception
tlahmattinem(i).Comment: C gives the additional gloss "to practice aspecialty" which goes back directly to IHMAT(I)rather than to TLAHMAT(I).

-tlahnecuiya.Spanish: mi olfato (C for first pers. sg. possessor)

tlahnēhuiā.English: to mistake s.t. or s.o. for another
tlahnēhuiā.Spanish: tomar una cosa por otra, pensando que era suya lacapa, siendo de otro, o pensando que hablaba conPedro, no siendo el sino otro, etc. (M)
tlahnēhuiā.Comment: M gives this gloss for tlahneuia and repeats it inbriefer form for tlaneuia.  In M this is a doubleobject verb when it involves another person, but Ctreats it as a simple transitive verb for persons andthings alike.  This contrasts with TLANĒHUIĀ "toborrow s.t."

-tlahpach.Comment: This is only attested compounded with ĪX-TLI.  M hastlapachoa "for a wall to fall on one and knock oneover".

tlahpalihuiz-tli.Comment: M has tlapaliuhcauia "to earn one's subsistence bylabor".

tlahpal-li.Comment: The possessed form of this, generally but notnecessarily with honorific -TZIN, serves as agreeting or part of a conventional salutation.TLAHPAL-LI contrasts with -TLAPAL "side" andTLAPAL-LI "dye".

tlahpaloā.English: to be forward, daring; to greet s.o.
tlahpaloā.Spanish: atreverse o osar (M), saludar a otro (M)
tlahpaloā.Comment: This contrasts with TLAPALOĀ "to sop bread in sauceor gravy".

tlahpixqui.English: caretaker, guardian, one who keeps watch
tlahpixqui.Spanish: el que guarda algo (M), vigilante, velador (T),pastor (Z)
tlahpixqui.Comment: Z has two attestations without the internal glottalstop, which may possibly contrast with TLAHPIXQUI,but this is not reflected in the attendant glosses.

tlahpixtinem(i).English: to serve as shepherd or pastor
tlahpixtinem(i).Comment: Z omits the internal glottal stop in bothattestations.  It is possible that this should beTLAPIXTINEM(I), derived directly from PIY(A).

tlahpiy(a).English: to take care of things, to stand watch
tlahpiy(a).Comment: This is attested across all sources and implies averb *(I)HPIY(A) to which the nonspecific objectprefix TLA- has become fused to form an intransitiveverb.

tlahquitīl-li.Comment: This implies a transitive verb *(I)HQUITIĀ "toweave s.t."

tlahquit-tli.Comment: Z also has TLAHQUITĪL-LI as a variant of this andglosses CUAUHTLAHQUIT-TLI as "loom".  TLAHQUIT-TLIonly appears in the Spanish-to-Nahuatl side of M,with yquittli as a synonym.

tlahtalhuiā.English: to speak in behalf of s.o.; to malign s.o.
tlahtalhuiā.Spanish: ser procurador de otros o hablar por ellos,favorecieŸndolos y ayudaŸndolos (M), lo ultraja, loinsulta (Z)
tlahtalhuiā.Comment: M and Z have contradictory senses, but both arederivable from the literal sense of IHTALHUIĀ, asthe applicative form of (I)HTOĀ.  Z omits theglottal stop.

tlahtic.Spanish: dentro de lo interior de alguna cosa (M), dentro, sindecir de que (C)

tlahtlācanequ(i).English: to pretend to be brave, to put up a brave front
tlahtlācanequ(i).Comment: M has unreduplicated reflexive tlacanequi with-TECH "to have faith in s.o."

tlahtlacaqu(i).English: to hear or listen to various things
tlahtlacaqu(i).Comment: This distributive form reduplicates the TLA- ratherthan the first consonant and vowel of CAQU(I),indicating that the prefix TLA- hasfused with the stem.

tlahtlacoā.Comment: M also includes in the entry "to damage, ruin s.t.",which is the literal sense of transitive (I)HTLACOĀwith the nonspecific object prefix TLA-.

tlahtlacōlcāhu(a).Spanish: dejares tus pecados (C for second pers. sg. subject)
tlahtlacōlcāhu(a).Comment: M has tlatlacolcaualtia, the causative of thisverb.

tlahtlacōlcuītiā.English: to confess one's sins; to lead s.o. into sin

tlahtlacōl-li.Comment: In possessed form with negation, this is a denial ofresponsibility, AHMŌ NOTLAHTLACŌL "It is not myfault".

tlahtlacōlpohpolhuiliz-tli.Comment: M has tlatlacolpopolhuia "to pardon sins, to grantabsolution".

tlahtlacōltiā.Spanish: lo envidia, le culpa, le echa la culpa (Z)

tlahtlacualtiā.Spanish: se apacienta a los animales, da de comer a losanimales (T)
tlahtlacualtiā.Comment: In this distributive form the fused prefix TLA- isreduplicated instead of the initial consonant andvowel of the verb stem CUĀ.

tlahtlahco.Comment: T does not give the glottal stop of the secondsyllable in the Nahuatl-to-Spanish side, but it doesappear in the Spanish-to-Nahuatl side.

tlahtlahcotōnal-li.Comment: In the Nahuatl-to-Spanish side of T the secondglottal stop is omitted, and in theSpanish-to-Nahuatl side the first glottal stop is.

tlahtlahcuaniā.Comment: T has E for A in the third syllable.  Here the fusedprefix TLA- is reduplicatedinstead of the verb stem itself.

tlahtlahtoā.Spanish: parlar o hablar mucho, o gorjear las aves (M)
tlahtlahtoā.Comment: This is abundantly attested in T.  This distributiveform reduplicates the fused prefixTLA- instead of the verb stem itself.

tlahtlahtzōmiā.Comment: This distributive form reduplicates the fused prefixTLA- rather than the verb stem itself.

tlahtlahuēlīlōcāt(i).English: to do evil at every turn, to be mean and cunning
tlahtlahuēlīlōcāt(i).Comment: M glosses tlatlauelilocati as a noun "s.o. who ismean and cunning".

tlahtlaihtlan(i).Comment: This is indirectly attested in T's nominalizationMOTLAHTLAIHTLANI "beggar".  M has reflexivetlaitlania and, in the Spanish-to-Nahuatl sideonly, the reduplicated form, both meaning "to beg".This distributive form reduplicates the fused prefixTLA- rather than the verb stem itself.

tlahtlāliā.English: to set various things in order, to compose music orcopy out writing
tlahtlāliā.Spanish: poner algo en orden, poner recaudo para decir misa, oponer algo en diversas partes, o poner la mesa consus manteles, pan, cuchillo, salero, etc., o componercanto, o hacer tractado de escritura (M)
tlahtlāliā.Comment: This is a distributive form and is not an instance ofa fused prefix.

tlahtlāliliā.English: to make a definite proposition; to arbitrate forothers or to lay out plans for their activities, tofix s.t.
tlahtlāliliā.Spanish: proponer de hacer alguna cosa, hacienda ley para siŸ,y obligaŸndose a ella (M), arbitrar o determinar ysentenciar entre partes o dar orden y traza de lo quelos otros han de hacer (M), remienda algo o an9adiralguna cosa a la escritura que alguno compone o a loque se cuenta (M), remendar algo o an9adir algunacosa a otra (M)

tlahtlālloh.Spanish: tiene polvo (T), tiene la cara sucia (T for compoundwith ĪX-TLI)
tlahtlālloh.Comment: Because of the general loss of final glottal stop inT, the final H is not attested in this item.

tlahtlaloā.English: for several people to run in the same direction butin an unorganized way
tlahtlaloā.Spanish: corremos hacia una parte (C for first pers. pluralsubject)
tlahtlaloā.Comment: This distributive form contrasts with TLĀTLALOĀ"to run in an orderly, sequential fashion".

tlahtlamā.English: to hunt or fish, to take captives in war
tlahtlamā.Spanish: pescar o cazar algo con redes (M), cazar o cautivaren la guerra (C)
tlahtlamā.Comment: This distributive form reduplicates the fusedprefix TLA- rather than the verbstem itself.

tlahtlamahqui.Comment: M has synonymous tlatlama in the Spanish-to-Nahuatlside only.

tlahtlamāliā.English: to hunt or fish for s.o.; to delouse s.o.
tlahtlamāliā.Spanish: cazo o pesco algo para eŸl, o le espulgo (C for firstpers. sg. subject)

tlahtlamāni.Comment: X fails to mark the glottal stop.

tlahtlamaniliā.English: This is transitive in M and X, and T's unreduplicatedTLAMANILIĀ is transitive, but T gives thisreduplicated form as intransitive.

tlahtlam(i).English: to conclude, to come to an end

tlahtlaniā.English: to examine one's own conscience, to practiceintrospection; to ask a person questions, tointerrogate s.o.
tlahtlaniā.Spanish: examinarse el pecador para se confesar algo asiŸmismo, o recurrir la memoria (M), preguntar algo aotro, e inquirir o pesquisar a alguŸn negocio (M)

tlahtlaōyoh.Comment: This seems to be missing an L before the suffix -YOH,but it is attested without one on theSpanish-to-Nahuatl side of T too, and there is no Lin the hispanized form clacloyo.

tlahtlapāc(a).English: to wash s.t. repeatedly or to do laundry in severaldifferent places
tlahtlapāc(a).Spanish: lavar alguna cosa muchas veces o lavar en diversaspartes (M)
tlahtlapāc(a).Comment: This distributive form reduplicates the fusedprefix TLA- rather than the verbstem itself.

tlahtlapaloā.English: to sip, taste a number of different beverages
tlahtlapaloā.Spanish: probar muchos vinos o cosa semejante (M), probarvarias bebidas y vinos, bebiendo poco de cada uno (C)
tlahtlapaloā.Comment: This distributive form reduplicates the fusedprefix TLA- instead of the verbstem itself.

tlahtlapoā.Comment: This distributive form contrasts with TLĀTLAPOĀ"to open and shut continuously".  M has tlatlapoa"to open s.t." which represents an unfused instanceof TLAPOĀ and the nonspecific object prefix TLA-.

tlahtlātiā.English: to hide in various places; to hide things
tlahtlātiā.Comment: This contrasts with TLAHTLATIĀ "to build a fire",although M combines them in a single entry.

tlahtlatiā.English: to burn, to be scorched; to burn or scorch s.t. ors.o.
tlahtlatiā.Spanish: se quema (gente solamente) (T), hacer fuego (M), loquema, lo chamusca (Z)
tlahtlatiā.Comment: This contrasts with TLAHTLĀTIĀ "to hide things",although M combines them in a single entry.  B has amarginal note contrasting TLAHTLATIĀ "to scorchs.o. in various places" with unreduplicated TLATIĀ"to burn s.o. up entirely".

tlahtlatzcuepōniā.English: to hit s.t. or s.o. repeatedly
tlahtlatzcuepōniā.Comment: This is attested in two compounds, one with MĀ-TE-"to hit s.o. repeatedly with one's hand", and theother with TZĪN-TE- "to hit s.o. repeatedly on thebuttocks".  TZĪNTE-TL "buttocks" is elsewhereattested, but *MĀTE-TL is not, and it is not clearwhether the -TE- here is the "body part" use of TE-TLor some sort of modifier of the verb.

tlah-tli.Spanish: tiŸo, hermano de padre o de madre (M)
tlah-tli.Comment: This displays a stem alternation of short vowel andglottal stop TLAH with long vowel TLĀ.  Theabsolutive suffix -TLI implies stem-final H, and theglottal stop is specifically marked with a diacriticin B, C, and R.  Yet C uses the possessed form meaning"my uncle" to illustrate that final syllables endingin a long vowel have low tone.  If the onlyattestation of the long vowel were in C, it might betaken for a mistake, albeit a disturbing one, sinceit would not be simply an incorrect diacritic, but anill chosen example atypical of C.  But T also givestwo possessed forms, one plural and the otherhonorific, both with a long vowel rather than a shortvowel and glottal stop.  In three attestations,however, (one from B and two from C) there is a shortvowel and glottal stop in honorific possessed forms.A case might be made for taking the long vowelvariant as basic and the vowel-shortening glottalstop as intrusive, as it is in some cases betweenstem and honorific -TZIN (ACHIHTZIN "a bit",ĪCIHUĀHUAHTZIN "his wife"), but it would not helphere, since the glottal stop precedes even theabsolutive suffix -TLI, on the one hand, and since-TZIN is preceded by the long vowel variant in oneattestation from T on the other.  TLAH-TLI "uncle"contrasts with TAH-TLI "father", which is alsoexceptional in view of the early and generalhistorical change *TA ˛ TLA which should prevent suchcontrasts.

tlahtoā.English: to speak, to issue proclamations and commands, forbirds to chatter
tlahtoā.Spanish: hablar algo o chirriar, gorjear, o cantar las aves(M)
tlahtoā.Comment: The prefix TLA- has been fusedwith the verb stem to form an intransitive verb.

tlahtoāni.English: ruler, governor, one who issues proclamations andcommands
tlahtoāni.Spanish: hablador o gran sen9or (M), el rey (C), el gobernador(C), autoridad (del pueblo), jefe, presidente (T)
tlahtoāni.Comment: Except in R and Z, which have them both in free singularform, TLAHTOĀNI and TLAHTOHQUI are suppletive, withthe former as a free singular and the latter ininflected and compounded forms.

tlahtohcāyōtiā.Comment: M has this as a transitive verb "to crown s.o. king".

tlahtohcāyō-tl.Spanish: sen9oriŸo, reino, corona real, o patrimonio (M)
tlahtohcāyō-tl.Comment: T has lost the glottal stop in the second syllable.

tlahtohqui.Spanish: sen9ores, caciques, o principales (M for plural)
tlahtohqui.Comment: This is abundantly attested but, with the exceptionof R and Z, not in the free-standing singular form,where TLAHTOĀNI is used instead.  This item appearsin the plural form TLAHTOHQUEH, the possessedsingular form -TLAHTOHCĀUH, and its compoundingforms TLAHTOHCĀ- and shortened -TLAHTOH.  TLAHTOHQUIcontrasts with TLATŌCQUI "sower".

tlahtōlchiy(a).Comment: The long-vowel preterit form is not directly attestedfor this, but is abundantly attested for theconstituent element CHIY(A).

tlahtōlcuauhtic.English: s.o. with a strong, commanding voice

tlahtōlcuep(a).English: to contradict oneself; to contradict s.o.
tlahtōlcuep(a).Spanish: desdecirse a retratarse (M), desdecir a otro,dicieŸndole que es falso lo que dice (M)

tlahtōlīxnāmiqu(i).Spanish: le contradice, lo afrenta, lo rin9e (Z)
tlahtōlīxnāmiqu(i).Comment: Z attests this as an intransitive verb "to setoneself up in opposition" where a reflexive would beexpected.

tlahtōltēncuēcuēp(a).Comment: In one attestation Z marks the vowel of the firstsyllable of CUĒCUĒP(A) long but not the second.  Inthe other neither vowel is marked long.  Elsewhere, Thas reflexive CUĒCUEP(A) "to be upset" as well astransitive CUĒCUĒP(A) "to turn things over".  Thelast element here could conceivably be a transitiveuse of CUĒCUEP(A) rather than CUĒCUĒP(A).

tlahtōltiā.English: to intercede, to speak in favor of s.o.; to causes.o. to talk or confess, to interrogate s.o., toread s.t.
tlahtōltiā.Spanish: $hablar, interceder por alguien), hacer hablar aotro, o tomar el dicho al reo o al testigo, o darletormento para que confiese la verdad (M), lo lee (T)

tlahtzomal-li.Comment: Z is inconsistent.  In one attestation the vowels ofthe second and third syllables are marked long, andin the other they are not.  By general rules ofderivation, all vowels in this item should be short.

tlahtzomalōni.Comment: Z is inconsistent.  In one attestation the vowels ofthe second, third, and fourth syllables are markedlong, and in the other the vowels of the third andfourth.  By general rules of derivation only thevowel of the fourth syllable should be long.

tlahtzōmiā.English: to snort or hiss, as in anger
tlahtzōmiā.Spanish: bufar el gato, o cosa semejante (M), dar un bufido,como caballo o persona enojada (C)
tlahtzōmiā.Comment: C gives this once in distributive form, reduplicatingthe fused prefix TLA- rather than the verb stemitself.  It contrasts with TLAHTZOMIĀ "to sew s.t.for s.o."

tlahtzomiā.English: to sew s.t. for oneself, to sew s.t. for s.o.
tlahtzomiā.Spanish: coser algo para siŸ (M), coŸsote algo (C for firstpers. sg. subject and second pers. sg. object)
tlahtzomiā.Comment: This item with fused prefix TLA- is implied by anapplicative form in C.  It contrasts with withTLAHTZŌMIĀ "to snort or hiss".  T has Z for TZ.

tlahuācqui.Comment: The vowel of the second syllable should be long butis short in T.

tlahuahhuiā.Comment: One attestation of four lacks the internal glottalstop.

tlāhuān(a).Spanish: beber vino o emborracharse templadamente (M), seemborracha, se embriaga (T)

tlāhuānaltiā.Spanish: le emborracho, le doy de beber (C for first pers. sg.subject), lo emborracha, lo embriaga (T)
tlāhuānaltiā.Comment: T is inconsistent in marking the vowel length of thesecond syllable.  T has the reflex of a long vowel inone of four attestations, and C also marks the vowellong.

tlāhuāncātequi-tl.Spanish: vuestra ocupacioŸn de borrachera (C for second pers.plural possessor)
tlāhuāncātequi-tl.Comment: This is attested as a slip of the tongue or pun onTLAHTOHCĀTEQUI-TL "occupation of governing".

tlāhuāncātzahtzi.Comment: In form this appears to be a verb "to shoutdrunkenly" rather than a nominalization.

tlahuāqu(i).English: for everything to dry up, for there to be a drought
tlahuāqu(i).Spanish: haber sequedad o agostarse todo cuanto hay (M)

tlahuehca.Comment: Z has TLAHUĒICA with virtually the same sense.

tlahuehhuelōliz-tli.Comment: In one attestation Z marks the vowel of the thirdsyllable long, but it should not be.

tlahuēica.Comment: T has TLAHUEHCA with virtually the same sense.

tlahuēlcāhu(a).English: to be irrational with anger; to forsake s.t., s.o.in anger
tlahuēlcāhu(a).Spanish: dejar de entender en lo que le es necesario por estarenojado o desesperar (M), lo deja con coraje, loabandona (T)

tlahuēlcuītiā.English: to cause s.o. to be angry or enraged
tlahuēlcuītiā.Spanish: airar a otro, o amohinarlo, y enojarlo, o provocarloa ira y embravecerlo (M)

tlahuēleh.Spanish: san9udo, iracundo, y bravo (M), muy bravo (C)

tlahuēliā.Spanish: tener enojo con otro y aborrecimiento (M)
tlahuēliā.Comment: There is a typographical error in M which substitutesh for li, but the preterit citation is spelledcorrectly, and it is correctly alphabetized.

tlahuēlīlōc.English: s.o. malicious, a villain or rogue
tlahuēlīlōc.Comment: B attests this twice with the vowel of the secondsyllable specifically marked short, and C marks thevowel long in only one of twelve attestations, butTLAHUĒL-LI definitely has the corresponding vowellong.  Possibly B and C reflect a contextualshortening of this vowel when followed by twosubsequent syllables containing long vowels, but Cdoes mark the vowel long inYŌLLOHTLAHUĒLĪLŌCĀCUEP(A).

tlahuēlīlōcāt(i).English: to become a wicked, malicious person

tlahuēlīlōcātiliā.Spanish: hacer vellaco a otro o pervertirle (M), pervertir ymalear a los otros (M)

-tlahuēliltic.Comment: The vowel of the second syllable is not marked longin the attestations.  This verb occurs only in thethird person singular preterit form and takespossessive rather than subject prefixes,NOTLAHUĒLILTIC "woe is me".

tlahuēlitta.Spanish: aborrecer y mirar con enojo a otro (M)
tlahuēlitta.Comment: In this item, but not in other derivations fromTLAHUĒL-LI, T has Y for HU.

tlahuēlīxnāmiqu(i).Comment: M has transitive TLAHUĒLNĀMIQU(I) "to set oneselfin opposition to s.o."  The intransitivity of thisitem in Z is idiosyncratic.

tlahuēl-li.Spanish: indignacioŸn, enojo o furia del que estaŸ airado ylleno de san9a (M), coraje, enojo, ira (C)
tlahuēl-li.Comment: C marks the vowel of the second syllable long in lessthan a third of the attestations, and B marks itspecifically short in two derived forms, but Tconsistently has the reflex of a long vowel and Zgenerally agrees.

tlahuēlpozōn(i).Spanish: se enfurecioŸ (C for third pers. sg. preterit)
tlahuēlpozōn(i).Comment: M has the derived form tlauelpoc˛oniliztica "withexceedingly great wrath", and S has causativetlauelpoc˛onaltia.

tlahuēltlahtlahtoā.English: to rant, to speak with anger

tlahuetzquītiā.Spanish: decir donaires y gracias para hacer reir a otros,o hacer cosa por donde se riŸan de mi (M)
tlahuetzquītiā.Comment: In Z this appears as an intransitive verb withfused TLA-.

tlāhuiā.English: to light a candle, to light the way for people withtapers or torches
tlāhuiā.Spanish: alumbrar la candela (M), alumbrar a otros con candelao hacha (M)
tlāhuiā.Comment: M also has this as a transitive verb with the prefixTLA- meaning "to redden s.t. with ochre, to turnred, to blush".  TLĀHUIĀ is apparently a reductionof TLĀUHHUIĀ < TLĀHU(I)-TL "red ochre" and-HUIĀ, and refers specifically to red light,including the light of dawn as well as firelight.

tlāhuihpoch-in.Comment: This appears only in the Spanish-to-Nahuatl side ofM.  It is conventionally paired with NĀHUAL-LI,which is a different kind of sorcerer, according toM.  This would seem to be related toTLAHUIHHUĪCALTIĀ "to curse s.o.", but there is avowel length discrepancy in the first syllable.

tlāhuiliā.English: to light one's way with a candle; to light s.o.'s waywith a candle
tlāhuiliā.Spanish: alumbrarse con candela (M), alumbrar a otro asiŸ (M)

tlāhuilicōcocotoc-tli.English: piece of pine used as a torch

tlāhuilicōcuahu(i)-tl.English: pine tree of a type used for making torches

tlāhuilicō-tl.Comment: The vowel of the second syllable is consistentlyattested short, although elsewhere in T it isattested long in TLĀHUĪL-LI "torchlight".  Thegloss implies OCO-TL "ocote, torch pine" for thesecond element, but there is I for O in one syllableand the reflex of Ō for O in the other.

tlāhuililiā.Spanish: se lo alumbra, se lo aluza (T)

tlāhuīl-li.Spanish: claridad o luz de candelas (M), laŸmpara, luz, candil(T)
tlāhuīl-li.Comment: If this is derived from TLĀHUIĀ, the vowel of thesecond syllable should be long, but B specificallymarks it short.  In T two of four attestations have along vowel, and two have the corresponding vowelshort.  In Z and X the vowel is consistently long.

tlahuiltequ(i).English: to go the shortest route, to cut corners
tlahuiltequ(i).Spanish: atajar o ir por camino maŸs breve o atravesar (M)
tlahuiltequ(i).Comment: Since B specifically marks the vowels of the firstthree syllables short, the otherwise unattested firstelement of this contrasts with TLĀHUĪL-LI"candlelight".  M has this with the directionalprefix ON-. verb.

tlahuīquiliā.English: to owe s.o., to be in debt to s.o.

tlāhu(i)-tl.Comment: This is indirectly attested in the verb TLĀHUIĀhaving to do with red firelight and TLĀHUIZCAL-LI"the rosy light of dawn".

tlahuitōn-tli.Comment: The direct derivational basis of this is M's vituma"to demolish a building or to release dammed upwater".

tlāhuizcal-li.Spanish: el alba, o el resplandor del alba (M)

tlahxīca.Spanish: haber goteras o lloverse la casa (M)
tlahxīca.Comment: T has lost either a long vowel or, more likely, aglottal stop.

tlahxillacal-li.Comment: This appears in R with no diacritics, but is attestedwith the internal glottal stop in the first syllablein a testament from Culhuacan, 1577.

tlahxi-tl.English: s.t. reached, taken hold of, seized

tlahyelitta.Spanish: aborrecer a otro (M), lo aborrece, lo odia (T)

tlahyel-li.Spanish: cosa sucia o caŸmaras de sangre (M)
tlahyel-li.Comment: M has this as tlaelli, tlahilli, and tlailli,but the glottal stop and Y are consistently attestedacross sources.  Z has Ā for E.

tlahyelmictoc.Lexical Reference: see TLAHYEL-LI, MIQU(I), the verb O

tlahyeloā.Comment: R places the diacritic on the wrong syllable.  Itappears on the second, but it belongs on the first.

tlahyeltiā.English: to suffer nausea; to make someone suffer nausea
tlahyeltiā.Spanish: tener asco de alguna cosa sucia (M), poner asco aotro (M)

tlahyōhuiā.Comment: This is abundantly attested in T and Z, whereIHĪYŌ-TL reduces to IHYŌ-TL.  The nonspecificobject prefix TLA- has been fused to the verb stem toform an intransitive verb.  M has correspondingderived forms with the full TLAIHĪYŌ- element.  Zdoes not mark the vowel of the second syllable long.

tlahyōhuih.English: s.o. long-suffering, s.o. who has suffered

tlahyōhuiliz-tli.Spanish: tormento, fatiga o pena que se padece (M fortlayhiouiliztli), afaŸn, angustia, miseria,sufrimiento (Z)

tlahyōhuiltiā.English: to torment, mistreat s.o., to make s.o. suffer
tlahyōhuiltiā.Spanish: atormentar y fatigar a otro (M for tlayhiouiltia),le tormenta, le maltrata, le angustia (Z)

tlahzanatza.English: s.o. who makes a crackling sound with s.t.
tlahzanatza.Spanish: el que hace ... ruido con hojas secas, pliegos depapel, etc. (C)

tlahzolcamac-tli.Comment: T has lost the internal glottal stop.

tlahzolhuiā.Spanish: por mirar le hace dan9o a otro (a propoŸsito), lehace mal de ojo (T for compound with ĪX-TLI)
tlahzolhuiā.Comment: T has lost the internal glottal stop.

tlahzol-li.Spanish: basura que echan en el muladar (M)
tlahzol-li.Comment: T has lost the glottal stop.

tlaī.Spanish: beber poleadas, cacao, pinolli, purga o cosasemejante (M), desayuna, toma atole en la man9ana (T)
tlaī.Comment: M gives an independent entry for this as anintransitive verb, implying that the nonspecificobject prefix TLA- has been fused with the stem.

tlaīcampa.Spanish: detraŸs de algo, allende los montes, sierras, opuertos (M)
tlaīcampa.Comment: Z also has the short variant TLAĪCAN.  In allattestations Z marks the vowel of the third syllablelong, but it is short in attestations of -ĪCAMPAacross other sources.

tlaicnēliliz-tli.Comment: Although the intial I of (I)CNĒLIĀ drops in othercontexts when preceded by a prefixal vowel, it isretained here.  M has virtually synonymousteicneliliztli.

tlaihihtōliz-tli.English: criticism, the saying of various things
tlaihihtōliz-tli.Comment: Z fails to indicate the second glottal stop.

tlaihtlapoā.Comment: T fails to mark the I short, but it must be so beforethe glottal stop.  T also gives a nonactive form ofthis appropriate to a verb ending in OHUA rather thanOĀ.

tlaīl-li.Spanish: bebida como vino, pulque, etc., bebida alcohoŸlica(T)
tlaīl-li.Comment: M has tlailli referring to dysentery, which is avariant of TLAHYEL-LI, and which contrasts with thisitem.

tlailpiliz-tli.Comment: Z also has ILPILIZ-TLI with the same sense.

tlaīuhticah.English: for there to be no one around, for a place to bedeserted
tlaīuhticah.Comment: M has c˛a iuhticac "vacant house" and under wordsfor "vacant" on the Spanish-to-Nahuatl side severalother constructions with the sequence iuhti.  Ifthis is derived from IHU(I) "to be or become in acertain way", the vowel of the second syllable shouldbe short, but T has it long.

tlaīxco.English: on the surface, in the front
tlaīxco.Spanish: en la sobrehaz, o en la delantera (M)
tlaīxco.Comment: M and C both have this in construction with the verbCĀ with the sense of "on top, first out".

tlaīxcuepani.English: hypocrite, s.o. who turns things inside out andfalsifies things
tlaīxcuepani.Spanish: el que vuelve la ropa lo de dentro afuera, o elfalsario (M), tiene dos caras, es hipoŸcrita (T)
tlaīxcuepani.Comment: T also has this in a phrase with the reflexive prefixM- < MO- rather than TLA- but with the senseremaining the same.

tlaīxnāmiquiliz-tli.Comment: M has tlaixnamictiliztli with essentially the samemeaning.

tlaīxpan.Spanish: en la delantera de alguna cosa (M), en frente (T)

tlaīxtemō.Spanish: va de bajada, baja uno en el camino, bajada de camino(T)

tlaīxtlāy(i).English: to break land with a hoe

tlaizhuatēca.Comment: T shortens the sequence TLAIZ to TLAZ.

tlālaquiā.English: for s.t. to get buried; to bury s.t., to set s.t.in the earth, to plant s.t.

tlālāx-in.Comment: The word-final nasal consonant is missing in M.  Thas the variant singular form TLĀLĀX(A).

tlālayoh-tli.Spanish: calabacilla silvestre (M), planta medicinal que llevaunas calabacillas comestibles (R)

tlālcāhu(a).English: to forsake land, to make room for s.o.
tlālcāhu(a).Comment: This is implied by B's TLĀLCĀHUILIĀ andTLĀLCĀHUALTIĀ and by C's TLĀLCĀHUIĀ.  Itcontrasts with TLA-LCĀHU(A) < (I)LCĀHU(A) "toforget s.t."  M has tlalcaualli with the glosses"s.t. forgotten" and "uncultivated land",representing derivations from (I)LCĀHU(A) andTLĀLCĀHU(A) respectively.

tlālcāhuiā.English: to relinquish one's place to s.o.
tlālcāhuiā.Spanish: dar lugar a otro, apartaŸndose de el (M)

tlalcāhuīl-li.Comment: In the Spanish-to-Nahuatl side T has the moreaccurate gloss cosa olvidada.

tlālchi.English: on or towards the ground, down
tlālchi.Spanish: en el suelo (M), en o hacia el suelo (C)
tlālchi.Comment: This is abundantly attested in C as the opposite ofAHCO.

tlālchihuīc.English: in the direction of the ground
tlālchihuīc.Comment: This is conventionally paired with AHCOHUĪC togetherwith the verb (I)TTA, the whole phrase meaning "tolook s.o. up and down", that is, to make much ofs.o. and thereby to honor that person.

tlālchipa.English: in the direction of the ground
tlālchipa.Spanish: hacia la tierra o hacia el suelo (M)

tlālchipāuhyoh.Comment: Because of general word-final vowel shortening andthe loss of final glottal stop in T, it cannot bedetermined if this item ends in -YOH or -YŌ, but theabsence of an absolutive suffix is evidence for -YOH.

tlālchiquihu(i)-tl.English: strainer for maize soaked in lime water

tlālchitlāz(a).English: to do obeisance, to prostrate oneself
tlālchitlāz(a).Spanish: humillarse y abatirse hasta el suelo (M)

tlālcuepōniā.Comment: This seems to imply making a thundering noise infalling.

tlalhua-tl.Spanish: nervio (M), su tendoŸn (Z for possessed form)
tlalhua-tl.Comment: T also has TLALHUAYŌ-TL in absolutive form.  Z hasonly possessed forms, once with -YŌ and oncewithout.

tlālhuēhuē-tl.Comment: In the absolutive form the second element appears tobe HUĒHUĒ-TL "upright drum", but the somewhatpeculiar plural form would make sense as the reflexof TLĀLHUĒHUĒN-MEH, and "old man" seems moreappropriate to a large hairy spider than "drum" inany case.

tlālhuiā.English: to get covered with dirt; to heap dirt on s.t., tocultivate s.t.
tlālhuiā.Spanish: se atierra (T), allegar o echar tierra a alguna cosa(M), echar tierra a una planta, para que crezca (C)
tlālhuiā.Comment: C contrasts this with TLALHUIĀ < (I)LHUIĀ "tosummon, advise, or warn s.o."

tlalhuiā.English: to summon or invite s.o., to advise s.o. or warns.o. to be on time
tlalhuiā.Spanish: mun9ir o apercibir a alguno para alguŸn negocio, oconvidar a otro (M), apercibir o prevenir a algunopara que haga algo a su timepo (C)
tlalhuiā.Comment: C contrasts this with TLĀLHUIĀ "to heap dirt ons.t."

tlalhuiquīz(a).English: for a fiesta to take place
tlalhuiquīz(a).Comment: M has causative tlaluiquixtia "to hold a fiesta".

tlālhuītequ(i).English: to beat s.t. or s.o. down

tlalhuiz.English: inconsiderately, without thought for the consequences
tlalhuiz.Spanish: inconsideramente, sin queŸ, ni para queŸ (C)

tlāliā.English: to sit down, to settle; to seat s.o., to put s.t.down, to set down statutes and ordinances, to setthings in order
tlāliā.Spanish: asentarse (M), dar a siento a otro (M), componer,poner algo en alguna parte, o hacer estatutos yordenanzas (M)
tlāliā.Comment: TLĀLIĀ is a high frequency verb used with a widerange of more or less figurative senses.  It alsoenters in compound constructions with other verbs ininvariant reflexive form and with the -TI- ligature,-TIMOTLĀLIĀ.  These constructions convey the senseof putting oneself in the attitude expressed by theother verb or, in the case of weather, to set in asthe type expressed by the other verb.

tlālichpān(a).English: to drag oneself along; to drag s.t.

tlalichtic.Spanish: cosa dura, como ave mal cocida o por manir (M),correoso (T)

tlālīxtlahyohuayān.English: darkness on the face of the earth
tlālīxtlahyohuayān.Comment: The internal glottal stop is not attested in Z.-ĪXTLAH and -ĪXTLAN "before, in the presence of"are synonymous, and either could be the secondconstituent of this construction.

tlāl-li.Comment: This has the full range of senses from physicalground or soil to parcels of land to the abstractidea of "earth".

tlālloh.Comment: This is conventionally paired with ZOQUIYOH, thephrase referring to one's earthly body.

tlāllōtiā.English: to get dirty; to dirty s.t.
tlāllōtiā.Spanish: se ensucia con tierra (T), echar tierra en algo (M)
tlāllōtiā.Comment: M has further glosses about separating things,perhaps in the sense of partitioning land orproviding each entity with its own location.

tlālnāmicōyān.Comment: Z fails to mark the vowel of the fourth syllablelong, but it should be.

tlalnāmictiā.Spanish: traer a la memoria, o acordar algo a otro (M),lo recuerda, le hace acordar (T)

-tlalnāmiquiya.Spanish: mi memoria (R for first pers. sg. possessor)

tlālnelhuiā.English: to mix s.t. together with dirt for s.o.

tlālneloā.English: to get dirty; to dirty s.t., to mix s.t. togetherwith dirt
tlālneloā.Spanish: se ensucia con tierra (T), lo revuelca con tierra (T)

tlālnepantlah.Spanish: en el medio de la tierra (C)

tlālnextic.English: crust of calcium carbonate and gravel on the earth
tlālnextic.Spanish: tierra caliche (barro de color de cal) (T)

tlaloā.Comment: This contrasts with TLĀLOĀ "to get soiled".

tlāloā.Spanish: se entierra, se ensucia de tierra (T)
tlāloā.Comment: M has synonymous tlalloa, forming its preterit byadding -C.

tlāloc.English: Tlaloc, the god of water and rain; the host of raingods (plural)
tlāloc.Spanish: dios del agua o de la lluvia (S), los dioses del agua(C for plural)
tlāloc.Comment: The derivation of this name is unclear.  The singularform, which is the personal name of one deity, is notrelated in a regular way to the plural form, whichrefers to the company of rain gods.  The plural formcould be based on TLĀLLOH "s.t. covered with earth"if geminate reduction were to apply, reducing the LLto L, , but the final -C of the singular would remainunaccounted for.

tlalōchtiā.English: to drive s.o., to make s.o. run
tlalōchtiā.Spanish: hacer aguijar a otro, llevando asido y hacieŸndolocorrer (M), lo empuja adelante de uno andando(lo)(como carretilla, etc.), lo arrea, le hace correr (T)

tlālocotzitzin.Comment: This is a plural form, perhaps reflecting the waythis plant branches away from its base.

tlālolīn(i).Comment: The O of the free-standing verb ŌLĪNIĀ is long,but it is attested short in derived forms in T and Z.In this item Z has the vowel short, and X has itlong.

tlālōlīniliz-tli.Comment: X retains the long vowel of the first syllable ofŌLĪNIĀ here, although elsewhere it appears shortin compounds.

tlālolīnīllō-tl.Comment: In the related verb ŌLĪNIĀ, attested in T, the Ois long.

tlālomītōn.Comment: The second element of this suggests OMI-TL "bone",but there is a vowel length discrepancy.

tlālpachihu(i).Comment: This is synonymous with the reflexive use ofTLĀLPACHOĀ.

tlālpachoā.English: to be buried; to bury s.t., s.o.
tlālpachoā.Spanish: se entierra, se sepulta (T), cubrir algo con tierra oaporcar (M), lo sepulta, lo entierra (T)

tlālpan.English: on the ground, throughout the land
tlālpan.Spanish: en el suelo (M), por toda la tierra (C)

tlalpīl-li.English: s.t. knotted or tangled, a knot, a nest, or a tangleof branches
tlalpīl-li.Spanish: cosa atada o an9udada o prisionero de otro (M),amarradijo, nudo, manojo (T)

tlalpītz(a).Comment: The nonspecific object prefix TLA- has fused with theverb stem to form an intransitive verb.  M has thederived form tlalpitzaliztli "gust, puff".

tlālpitzo-tl.English: cochineal insect (Dactylopius cacti), the bodies ofwhich produce a scarlet dye; armadillo

tlālpohpoxoā.English: to roll about in the dirt as birds do
tlālpohpoxoā.Spanish: se revuelca en la tierra (p.ej. gallina) (T)

tlālpōtz(a).English: to throw up earth, to burrow
tlālpōtz(a).Comment: Z also has what appears to be TLAPŌTZ(A) with thenominal gloss "gopher".

tlālquīxtīlōni.Comment: The vowel of the third syllable is not attested longbut should be by general rule.

tlāltataca.English: to scratch, score, dig the earth
tlāltataca.Spanish: rasca la tierra, escarba la tierra, cava la tierra(T)
tlāltataca.Comment: M has tlaltatactli "earth dug up for making adobe".

tlāltēmiā.English: to fill s.t. in with dirt

tlāltēmiliā.English: to fill s.t. in with dirt for s.o.

tlālteuh-tli.Comment: M has reflexive tlalteuhnemitia "for a sick personto turn ashen".  X has TEUC for TEUH.

tlāltiā.English: for s.o. to receive land; to give s.o. land
tlāltiā.Spanish: le dan terreno (T), le da terreno (T)
tlāltiā.Comment: There is a better gloss for the reflexive use of thisverb, recibe tierra, in the Spanish-to-Nahuatl sideof T.  M has intransitive tlaltia "to turn toearth", which probably represents TLĀLTIYA.

tlālticpac.English: the earth, on the earth, of the earth
tlālticpac.Spanish: el mundo, o en el mundo, o encima de la tierra (M)
tlālticpac.Comment: This is literally a locative construction, but C, R, andX have it as a noun with the absolutive suffix,TLĀLTICPAC-TLI.

tlālticpactlāca-tl.English: earthly being, person of this world
tlālticpactlāca-tl.Spanish: hombres de eŸste mundo (M for plural)

tlāltitechyā.Spanish: caerse o ir el edificio por tierra (M)
tlāltitechyā.Comment: M has the component tlaltitech "on the ground, tothe ground".

tlāltōca.English: to be buried; to bury, plant s.t.
tlāltōca.Spanish: enterrarse (M), enterrar a otro (M), soterrar algo(M), lo entierra, lo planta, lo sepulta (T)

tlāltzactic.Spanish: barro, estaŸ muy pegajosa la tierra (T)
tlāltzactic.Comment: M has tlaltzacutli "fuller's earth, plaster".  Thas lost the labiality of the final consonant of thesecond syllable.

tlamā.English: to go hunting, to take game, to make captives
tlamā.Comment: In the sources for this dictionary this is attestedin the reduplicated form TLAHTLAMĀ, where thereduplication demonstrates that theprefix TLA- is fused to the stem.

tlamaca.Comment: This contrasts in transitivity with TLAMACA "to serves.o. food".

tlamacazqui.English: one who served in a (preconquest) religiousestablishment, penitent
tlamacazqui.Spanish: ministros y servidores de los templos de los iŸdolos(M for plural), penitente (R)

tlamach.Comment: This is attested across sources except for Z, whichhas TLAMATCĀ, while M has both.  TLAMACH also servesas a modifying element meaning "much, many",especially in T and Z.

tlamachcui.English: to take a great deal of s.t.
tlamachcui.Comment: The idiomatic sense of Spanish coger mucho is "toengage in sexual intercourse".  In view of othersimilar constructions with CUI, this may be a calquedeuphemism.  M has tlamachcui "to imitate others, toforge s.o.'s signature or handwriting", whichprobably represents TLAHMACHCUI and has as its firstelement TLAHMAT(I) "to practice trickery anddeception".

tlamachililiz-tli.Comment: In one of two attestations Z marks the vowel of thesecond syllable long, but it should not be.

tlamachīlizpatla.English: to convince s.o., to change s.o.'s mind

tlamachīliz-tli.Comment: This is abundantly attested in Z and three times in Cwith the vowel of the third syllable marked long.

tlamachīlizyō-tl.English: wisdom, matters having to do with wisdom
tlamachīlizyō-tl.Comment: C has two variant forms, one in which the sequence ZYassimilates to ZZ and one in which it does not.

tlamāchiy(a).Comment: The long-vowel preterit form is not directly attestedfor this but is for the constituent element CHIY(A).

tlamachquītzquiā.English: to seize a great deal of s.t.
tlamachquītzquiā.Spanish: agarra mucho, agarra un gran mucho (T)
tlamachquītzquiā.Comment: In the Spanish-to-Nahuatl side T has the somewhatmore revealing gloss agarra un gran manojo.

tlamachtēnticah.English: to be piled up in a heap
tlamachtēnticah.Lexical Reference: see TLAMACH, TĒM(I), the verb CĀ

tlamachtiā.Comment: This is homphonous with transitive TLAMACHTIĀ"to enrich s.o."

tlamachtīl-li.Spanish: disciŸpulo o el que es ensen9ado de otro (M)

tlamachtlāliā.English: to pile up; to pile s.t. up
tlamachtlāliā.Spanish: se amontona (T), lo amontona, lo recoge (T)
tlamachtlāliā.Comment: M glosses this as "to set s.t. in order", whichdraws on the other sense of TLAMACH "quietly, withoutconflict".

tlamahcāhual-li.Comment: Z also has MAHCĀUHTOC as a variant of MĀCĀUHTOC"s.t. loose, separate".

tlamahcēhu(a).Comment: Transitive MAHCĒHU(A) means "to merit what onedesires", but with the fused nonspecific objectprefix TLA- it has the lexicalized sense "to dopenance".  Z has this with the entirely differentsense "to eat the first meal of the day" (perhaps insome ritual manner).

tlamahcēhualiz-tli.Spanish: penitencia, o merecimiento, o el acto de dar sacomano(M)

tlamahcēhualtiā.English: to punish s.o., to mortify the flesh
tlamahcēhualtiā.Spanish: dar afliccioŸn al cuerpo, o hacerle hacer algunascosas de abstinencia y penitencia (M), castigar (R)
tlamahcēhualtiā.Comment: R has misplaced a diacritic.  The diacritic thatbelongs to the second syllable appears on the third.

tlamahcēuhqui.Spanish: penitente, o el que hace algunos ejercicios paramerecer, hermitan9o o beata, etc. (M)

tlamahmācāhuiliā.English: to fall because one has lost one's grip on a support
tlamahmācāhuiliā.Spanish: pierde equilibrio (por no haberse cogido bien con lamano y cae) (T)

tlamāhuani.English: s.t. that spreads disease, s.o. contagious

tlamāhuihuitla.English: to pull up weeds by hand

tlamahuizoā.English: to be distracted, preoccupied, or entertained, tobehold things

tlamahuizōltiā.Comment: In both attestations the vowel before -LTIĀ ismarked long.

tlamahuizpolōliz-tli.Comment: In both attestations the vowel of the second syllableis marked long, but it should not be.

tlamalīn-tli.Spanish: torzal o cordel o soga torcida, o cosa semejante (M),torcido (T)

tlamāmā.Comment: With the prefix TLA- fused, this has thespecialized sense "to bear fruit".  Otherwise,TLA-MĀMĀ has the literal sense "to bear s.t."

tlamāmah.English: s.o. who bears a load, porter
tlamāmah.Spanish: el que lleva carga a cuestas (M)
tlamāmah.Comment: This short form is more common than Z's TLAMĀMAHQUIeven though it does not happen to be attested in thesources for this dictionary.  A common variant formis S's tlameme.

tlamāmahqui.English: s.o. who bears a load, porter
tlamāmahqui.Comment: In both attestations Z marks the vowel of the thirdsyllable long before the glottal stop, which isimpossible in terms of Nahuatl morphology.

tlamāmal-li.Spanish: la carga que lleva a cuestas el tameme (M)
tlamāmal-li.Comment: This contrasts with TLAMAMAL-LI "s.t. drilledthrough".  M combines the two items in a singleentry.  T has a variant in which the vowel of thethird syllable is long, as it is in the verb stem.  Talso has TLAMĀMAL-LI with the vowel short, whichagrees with the other sources.  X marks the vowel ofthe third syllable long instead of the second.

tlamamal-li.Spanish: cosa barrenada (M), cosa taladrada y barrenada (C)

tlamāmalōni.Comment: B specifically marks the vowel of the third syllableshort in both attestations.  This is paired incontext with CĀCĀX-TLI "packframe".

tlamāmalquīxtiā.English: to remove a burden from s.o.
tlamāmalquīxtiā.Comment: In one of two attestations Z marks the vowel of thethird syllable long.

tlamāmaltihqui.Comment: In both attestations Z marks the vowel of the thirdsyllable long.  Z also has synonymous TLAMĀMAHQUI.

tlamanchīhu(a).English: to scorn s.t., to lay s.t. aside

tlaman(i).English: for things to be a particular way
tlaman(i).Spanish: habiŸa buen orden y gobierno (C for imperfectconstruction with CUALLI ĪC)
tlaman(i).Comment: This is further attested in derived forms such asTLAMANILIĀ "to lay things out for s.o., to mends.t." (i.e. to restore s.t. to its proper state),and TLAMAN-TLI "member of a class of things".

tlamaniliā.English: to set things in order with respect to one another,to lay things out for s.o., to mend s.t.
tlamaniliā.Spanish: poner alguna cosa ante otro, o hacerle tortillas, oofrecerle alguŸn don o ofrenda (M), lo remienda (T)

tlamaniltiā.English: to make things be a certain way, to behave in acertain way
tlamaniltiā.Spanish: se portaron (C for third pers. plural preterit)
tlamaniltiā.Comment: B specifically marks the vowel of the third syllablelong, although it should be short before the suffix-LTIĀ, and C leaves the vowel unmarked for length.

tlaman-tli.English: a separate entity, a member of a class or set
tlaman-tli.Spanish: cosa (S), para contar platicas, sermones, pares dezapatos o cacles, papel, platos, escudillas, trojes,o cielos ... cuando estaŸ una cosa sobre otradoblada o cuando una cosa es diversa o diferente deotra (M)
tlaman-tli.Comment: This compounds with quantifiers for counting membersof an arbitrary class of objects that includes but isnot limited to flat things that can be folded orlayered one on top of another.  It is also an elementof other derivations and occurs in free form in Zmeaning "s.t. distinct and separate".  Zconsistently marks the vowel of the second syllablelong, but it is short across other sources.

tlamanxeloā.English: to be set aside; to separate s.t., to set s.t. aside

tlamāololōl-li.Comment: M has tlamaolololiztli "the act of gathering s.t.together with one's fingers".

tlamatcā.Comment: This is abundantly attested but only in Z.  C hassynonymous MATCĀ, and synonymous TLAMACH is attestedacross sources.  M has all three, although MATCĀappears in M only as a bound form.

tlamatcācentiliā.English: to unite, to assemble calmly, quietly
tlamatcācentiliā.Spanish: se junta con paciencia o con calma (Z)

tlamat(i).English: to be knowledgeable, to go somewhere
tlamat(i).Spanish: saber algo o ir a alguna parte (C)
tlamat(i).Comment: C and R concur that TLAMAT(I) can mean "to gosomewhere" but disagree on the verb's transitivity.C gives it as transitive, and R as intransitive.  Inaddition to independent TLAMAT(I), both C and Rillustrate this sense of going somewhere withintransitive TLAMATTĪUH, where -TĪHU(I) itselfimplies "to go to do".  In derivations includingTLAMATCĀ and TLAMACH there is the additional senseof "peace, tranquility, calm".  This contrasts withTLAHMAT(I) "to be competent, quick-witted".

tlamatiliā.English: to calm down, to grow quiet; to calm, quiet s.o.,s.t.
tlamatiliā.Spanish: se calla (Z), lo calma, le hace callar, lo pacifica,lo sosiega (Z)

tlamatiliz-tli.Comment: M combines this in a single entry withTLAHMATILIZ-TLI "deception, trickery".

tlamatqui.Comment: M has tlamatqui "s.o. deceitful, trickster", whichis derived from TLAHMAT(I) and contrasts with this.

tlamātzohual-li.Comment: B attests this both with and without hu between thethird and fourth syllables.  Since it isstem-internal and invariant, it is impossible todetermine whether there is a segmental intervocalic$w) or not.  M has matzoa and matoloa having todo with squeezing.

tlamāyahuiāni.Comment: This implies *MĀYAHUIĀ rather than MĀYAHU(I) "todash s.o. down to his death".

tlamāyahuini.English: s.o. given to throwing things down on the ground,troublemaker or killer
tlamāyahuini.Spanish: el que tira, esparce algo en el suelo (S), matoŸn (T)

tlam(i).English: to come to an end, to finish, to bring an activity toan end
tlam(i).Spanish: acabarse o consumirse y gastarse algo, o fenecer (M),acabar de hacer o de concluiŸr alguna obra (M)

tlamiā.English: to end, conclude; to conclude s.t., to finish s.t.
tlamiā.Spanish: se acaba (Z), lo termina, lo acaba, lo concluye (T),consumir o acabar toda la comida y bebida que teniŸadelante (M)
tlamiā.Comment: In construction with -TECH this has the sense "toaccuse s.o. of s.t.", hence to slander s.o.

tlamic.English: s.t. finished; a complete measure of twenty
tlamic.Spanish: veinte mazorcas de maiŸz o de cosas semejantes(M), acabado (Z)
tlamic.Comment: M has tlanqui for "s.t. finished", and tlamicas a measure of twenty, but the latter is consistentwith the sense of "s.t. (a count, a unit) completed".

tlamictiāni.Spanish: el que mata bestias, como el carnicero (C)
tlamictiāni.Comment: M glosses this as "murderer", which should beTĒMICTIĀNI, as in C.

tlamiliz-tli.English: the end of things, the close of life
tlamiliz-tli.Spanish: fin de cada cosa (M), fin de la vida (Z)
tlamiliz-tli.Comment: This appears only in the Spanish-to-Nahuatl side ofM.

tlamīn(i).English: for things like insects to bite or sting
tlamīn(i).Comment: M has tlamintli "s.t. wounded by a barbed weapon".

tlamīnini.Comment: T also has a short variant TLAMĪNI.

tlamochīhu(a).Spanish: fructificar o llevar fruta el aŸrbol (M inconstruction with ĪTECH), abunda (T)

tlamohmolōniā.English: to work land, to aerate the soil

tlamōltzin.English: stick, wooden spoon for stirring food

tlamōtlani.English: s.o. who chases s.t. or s.o. away by throwingstones; slingshot

-tlān.Comment: This commonly forms place names.  It contrasts withthe postposition -TLAN in vowel length and because-TLAN binds to other elements with the ligature -TI-in forming place names and -TLĀN does not.  Becauseof the tendency to lose final nasal consonants andglottal stops and because of the shortening of vowelswhen they come into word-final position, -TLĀN isoften indistinguishable from -TLAH "place where thereis an abundance of s.t."  -TĒCA-TL replaces -TLĀN tomean "person from" the place so named, TEPOZTĒCA-TL"s.o. from Tepoztlan" < TEPOZTLĀN.

-tlan.English: below, next to (the base of), among
-tlan.Spanish: junto a ... entre ... debajo de ... en (C)
-tlan.Comment: When used to form place names, this is bound to thepreceding element with the ligature -TI-, but inordinary postpositional constructions (includingcompound postpositions) it attaches to the precedingelement directly.  With body parts there are somedoublets with -TI-TLAN and -TLAN.  This contrasts invowel length with -TLĀN, which combines directlywithout the ligature.  Because of the tendency tolose final nasal consonants and glottal stops, -TLANcould be confused with -TLAH, but the latter does notbind to stems with the ligature -TI-.

tlanacaztecqui.English: s.o. or s.t. with an ear cut off

tlanāhuac.Spanish: en todas partes, por todos lados, enteramente, delado, alrededor, en derredor (S)
tlanāhuac.Comment: This appears in several phrases in M but not as aseparate entry.

tlanāhualahci.English: to seize things by surprise, to take s.o. bysurprise

tlanāhual-li.Comment: Z marks the vowel of the third syllable long in bothattestations, but it probably should not be.

tlanahuatīl-li.English: s.o. cited, charged, or dismissed; a notice, order,regulation, or law
tlanahuatīl-li.Spanish: citado, mandado, despedido, o licenciado (M),noticia, aviso, ley, mandamiento, mandato (Z)

tlanahu(i).English: for a sick person's condition to worsen, to beterminally ill
tlanahu(i).Spanish: estar muy enfermo (M), se pone grave, se empeora (T)
tlanahu(i).Comment: Z and X have a long vowel in the second syllable, butthe other sources have it short.  M has the derivednoun tlanauhqui "person close to death".  The basicsense of this is "to worsen, to go from bad toworse".

tlanamacac.Comment: Z has the variant form TLANAMAQUI.

tlanānquiliz-tli.Comment: Z has lost the syllable-final N of the secondsyllable.  M has synonymous tenanquiliztli.

tlancallampaquīz(a).Comment: Z has a long vowel in the third syllable, but thisappears to be the postposition -TLAN "under".

tlāncho.Comment: This is attested with a long vowel in the firstsyllable, but it seems possible to associate it withTLANCHOĀ "to chew", especially since Zidiosyncratically has a long vowel in TLAN-TLI"tooth".

tlanchoā.Spanish: remuele con los dientes (una cosa), masca (T)

tlancoch-tli.Comment: C and Z agree with M that this refers to molar teeth,but I glosses it as "eyetooth, canine tooth".

tlancuā(i)-tl.Comment: The constituent structure is not clear.  It appearsto consist of CUĀ(I)-TL "head" and either -TLAN or atruncation of -TLANI "below".  TLANCUĀ(I)-TL "knee"appears to be related to TLANĪTZ-TLI "shinbone".  Xhas apparently metathesized this, as it appears in acompound and a derived noun as TLACUĀN.

tlancuātehtequ(i).English: to get cut on the knee; to cut s.o. on the knee
tlancuātehtequ(i).Spanish: se corta la rodilla (T), le corta la rodilla (T)

tlancuitzahu(i).Comment: M has tlancuitzoa "for a dog to snarl and show itsteeth" and tlancuicuitztic "s.t. toothy".

tlanechicōl-li.Spanish: cosas ayuntadas y recogidas, o amontonadas (M),limosna (X)

tlanēc(i).English: for day to break, to get light

tlanēcitiā.Comment: This seems to be idiosyncratic to Z, which also hasTLANĒXTIĀ "to shine".

tlanehnemiliā.English: to exercise judgement, to have an opinion

tlanēhuiā.English: to borrow s.t.; to borrow s.t. for s.o.
tlanēhuiā.Spanish: tomar algo prestado para volverlo en la mismaespecie, o arrendar vin9a (M), lo pide prestado (T),lo pide prestado para otro (una cosa) (T)
tlanēhuiā.Comment: With a direct object prefix plus an oblique reflexiveprefix this has the sense "to benefit from thetransitory presence of s.o." and is so used in B torefer to one's offspring and elsewhere to the reignof a ruler.  This contrasts with TLAHNĒHUIĀ "tomistake one thing for another".

tlaneltoca.Comment: M does not have an entry for this, but C treats it asan intransitive verb with the nonspecific objectprefix TLA- fused to the verb stem.

tlaneltocaqui.Comment: M has tlaneltocac with the same sense.

tlaneltoquiliz-tli.Comment: Across sources there is inconsistency about thelength of the vowel in the fourth syllable.  B marksit long, as C does in two of five attestations.  Thas the reflex of a short vowel.  Z has the variantform TLANELTOCALIZ-TLI.

tlanemiliā.Spanish: tratar negocios de importancia, tomando consejo oconsigo o con otros sobre lo que conviene hacer, etc.(M)

tlanequiliz-tli.Spanish: voluntad o el acto de querer algo (M)

-tlanequiya.Spanish: mi voluntad con que quiero algo (C for first pers. sg.possessor)

tlanēuhtiā.English: to be for rent, to prostitute oneself; to lend orrent s.t. out
tlanēuhtiā.Spanish: se presta, se alquila (T), putan9ear la mujer (M), lopresta, lo arrienda, lo alquila, lo da prestado (T)
tlanēuhtiā.Comment: M has this with a direct object prefix plus anindirect object prefix with the sense "to lend s.o.s.t. that must be returned in kind, or to leaseproperty to s.o."

tlanēxiliā.English: to get up in the morning
tlanēxiliā.Comment: It is the gloss in the Spanish-to-Nahuatl side of Tthat distinguishes this from amanecer "to dawn".

tlanēxtiā.Comment: Z also has this as a transitive verb "to illuminates.t."

tlanēxtilīliz-tli.Comment: M has tlanextiliztli "clarity, light".  Thisimplies TLANĒXTILIĀ "to illuminate s.t. or s.o.",which appears in M and perhaps as Z's transitiveTLANĒXTIĀ if the latter is a truncated form.

-tlani.English: to order, wish, or request s.t., to aspire to s.t.,to work to bring s.t. about
-tlani.Spanish: mandar, desear, pedir ... pretender lo que elprecedente verbo significa (C)
-tlani.Comment: There is said to be a related compounding element-TLA, which according to the grammarian RincoŸn issynonymous with -TLANI.  C claims unfamiliarity withthis usage but points out that some verbs are derivedfrom nouns by a suffixed -TLA, as in YĀŌTLA "tomake war on s.o." and (I)CNĪUHTLA "to befriend s.o."

tlān(i).English: to win s.t., to defeat s.o. at gambling
tlān(i).Spanish: ganar algo en juego (M), ganar a otro jugando o enjuego (M)

tlanicāhu(a).English: to leave s.o. below as one is ascending

tlanihtoā.Comment: This is implied by TLANIHTALHUIĀ.  In light ofTLĀN(I) "to defeat s.o. at gambling", one wouldexpect a long vowel in the first syllable.TLANIHTOĀ and TLANIHTALHUIĀ are based on a singleattestation (Cf.118v) in which the vowel of the firstsyllable is not marked for length.  C may haveomitted a diacritic.

tlanipa.Spanish: hacia abajo (M), norte, lado de abajo (Z)

tlanitlāz(a).English: to hurl oneself down, to abase oneself; to hurl downor humiliate s.o.
tlanitlāz(a).Spanish: abatir asiŸ mismo y humillaŸndose (M), humillar yabatir a otro (M)

tlanītztehtecō.Comment: T gives this as the nonactive form ofTLANĪTZTEHTEQU(I) used reflexively and givesTLANĪTZTEHTEQUĪHUA for the nonactive form of thesame verb used transitively.

tlanītztehtequ(i).English: to cut one's shin bone; to cut s.o. on the shin bone
tlanītztehtequ(i).Spanish: se corta la espinilla (T), le corta la espinilla (T)

tlanītztehtequīhua.Comment: T gives this as the nonactive form ofTLANĪTZTEHTEQU(I) used transitively and givesTLANĪTZTEHTECŌ for the nonactive of the same verbused reflexively.

tlanītz-tli.Comment: This is abundantly attested but only in T.  Itappears to be related to TLANCUĀ(I)-TL "knee".

-tlannacatol.Comment: T reduces geminate NN to N.

tlanōtzal-li.Spanish: doctrinado, corregido, castigado o reprehendido deotros (M), visita, visitante (Z)

tlanōtz-tli.Comment: According to C and R this is synonymous with TLANŌTZAL-LI.

tlantzitzilca.Comment: Z has C for TZ and marks the vowel of the thirdsyllable long once.  M has tzitzilca "to shiverwith cold" and reflexive tlantzitzilitza "for one'steeth to chatter with cold".

tlantzitzilitz(a).Spanish: dar tenazadas o crujir los dientes de friŸo (M), pegadiente con diente (T)
tlantzitzilitz(a).Comment: T has E for I in the second and third syllables.

tlantzopōniā.English: to hiss, to make a sound with one's tongue againstthe back of one's teeth

tlaōcoliā.English: to be merciful to oneself; to be merciful with s.o.,to aid and benefit s.o.
tlaōcoliā.Spanish: usar de misericordia consigo mismo (M), hacermisericordia a otro (M), le regala, le obsequia, losocorre (T)
tlaōcoliā.Comment: T consistently has the reflex of a long vowel in theinitial syllable instead of the second.

tlaōcol-li.Comment: This is further attested in many derived forms.In these derivations T has the reflex of ĀOinstead of AŌ.

tlaōcoltiā.English: to feel pity; to give s.o. reason to feel pitytoward one
tlaōcoltiā.Spanish: tiene laŸstima (T), entristecer a otro o ponercompasioŸn a otro (M), dar ocasioŸn a otro para quese compadezca de miŸ (M for first pers. sg. subject)

tlaōcoy(a).Comment: Z has an intrusive glide Y between the first twosyllables in derivations from this, and so does B,although B does not indicate one in TLAŌCOY(A)itself.  In derivations from this verb T hasthe reflex of ĀO instead of AŌ.

tlaohmacaqui.Comment: In this type of derivation the QUI ending with stemsending is vowels is peculiar to Z.  Elsewhere thiswould have the form TLAOHMACAC.

tlaōlcuēchoā.Comment: Although the literal meaning of this is "to grindmaize", X apparently has generalized it to thegrinding of other things as well.

tlaolīn(i).English: for there to be an earthquake
tlaolīn(i).Comment: The literal sense of this is "things move", but inuse it is synonymous with TLĀLOLĪN(I) "for theearth to move".  The O of the free-standing verbŌLĪNIĀ is consistently long in T and Z, but thecorresponding vowel in derived forms is attestedshort.

tlaolīniliz-tli.Spanish: meneamiento de algo, o el acto de menear o mover algo(M), temblor, terremoto (T)

tlaololōliz-tli.English: the act of gathering s.t. together, heaping s.t. up
tlaololōliz-tli.Spanish: el acto de arreban9ar, ayuntar, o amontonar algo (M)

tlaōltzetzeloā.English: to separate bran from maize kernels

tlaōmepiy(a).English: to be a bigamist, to keep more than one woman

tlaōpōchcopa.Spanish: a mano izquierda o hacia la mano izquierda (M)

tlaōx-tli.English: kernels of maize removed from the cob
tlaōx-tli.Comment: O is not marked long in C or R, but R derives thisdirectly from ŌY(A) "to shell s.t.", where the vowelis attested long.

tlaōy(a).English: to remove the kernels from dried ears of maize
tlaōy(a).Comment: T appears to have the reflex of a short vowel in thisverb and in its nonactive form, but the vowel is longin basic ŌY(A) "to shell s.t." and is attested longin T in the applicative form TLAŌHUILIĀ

tlaōyal-li.English: dried kernels of maize removed from the cob
tlaōyal-li.Comment: C and R fail to mark the O long.

tlapā.Comment: In the same section C also treats the TLA- as anunfused nonspecific object prefix, TLA-PĀ "to dyes.t."

tlapāc(a).Spanish: he lavado (C for first pers. sg. subject, perfect)

tlapācalōni.Spanish: batea (Z for compounds with CUAHU(I)-TL andHUAPAL-LI)

tlapachoā.English: to cover oneself; to cover s.t., to roof s.t. over
tlapachoā.Spanish: cubrirse con algo (M), cubrir a otro (M)
tlapachoā.Comment: M also has TLAPACHOĀ as an intransitive verb "togovern, rule".  M and T both gloss TLAPACHOĀ as"for a hen to brood", while M and Z have derived formswith the sense "a setting hen".

tlapachohqui.Spanish: gallina que estaŸ sobre los huevos o la que criŸapollos (M for tlapacho), clueca (Z)

tlapachōl-li.English: subject, s.o. or s.t. which is ruled, pressed down,oppressed
tlapachōl-li.Spanish: suŸbdito, regido o gobernado, o cosa apesgada yapretada (M)

tlapac-tli.Comment: This contrasts with TLAPĀC-TLI "s.t. laundered orwashed".  It commonly compounds to form CENTLAPAC-TLI"morsel".

tlapāhuaz-tli.Comment: M also has tlapauaxtli with the same meaning.

tlāpāhuiā.Comment: This is conventionally paired with MĪXĪHUIĀ, thewhole phrase meaning "to become intoxicated".

-tlapal.Comment: When this compounds with a quantifier to form adirectional construction, as in ŌNTLAPAL "from bothsides", it does not take an absolutive suffix, but itis apparently the second element of AHTLAPAL-LI"leaf, wing" which does take one.

tlapalānaltiā.English: to cause things to rot, to suffer from venerealdisease
tlapalānaltiā.Spanish: el que tiene podrido el miembro genital (M), lo pudre(Z)

tlapalēhuiāni.Spanish: el que da favor y ayuda (M)

-tlapalezzō.Comment: This is more commonly expressed in the phrase -EZZŌ,-TLAPALLŌ "one's blood".

tlapalhuiā.Spanish: lo pinta, lo mancha, lo tin9e (Z)

tlapāliā.Spanish: tiŸn9ote algo (C for first pers. sg. subject, secondpers. sg. object)

tlapāliz-tli.Spanish: el acto de ten9ir alguna ropa (M)
tlapāliz-tli.Comment: B marks the vowels of the second and third syllablesboth long but then indicates that the diacritic overthe I is incorrect.

tlapal-li.Spanish: color para pintar o cosa ten9ida (M), tinta, pintura,tintura (T)
tlapal-li.Comment: This also metaphorically refers to blood.  TLAPAL-LIcontrasts with TLAHPAL-LI "courage", which alsoserves as a greeting.

-tlapallō.Spanish: nuestra sangre (C for first pers. plural possessor)
-tlapallō.Comment: This is conventionally paired with -EZZŌ, the wholephrase meaning "one's blood".

tlapalloh.Comment: M has tlapalloa "s.t. dyed in colors".  T has apossessed form which is ambiguous between -TLAPALYOHand -TLAPALYŌ meaning "one's color, tint, hue".The LY sequence would optionally assimilate to yieldeither -TLAPALLOH, as here, or -TLAPALLŌ, whichwould be identical to the inalienably possessed formof TLAPAL-LI "dye, ink".

tlapallōtiā.Spanish: lo tin9e, lo tinta, lo pinta (T)

tlapaloā.Spanish: mojar el pan en el potaje cuando comen (M), sopear(Z)
tlapaloā.Comment: This contrasts with TLAHPALOĀ "to greet s.o."

tlapalōl-li.Comment: M has tlapaloliztli "the act of sopping bread inbroth".

tlapaltiliā.Comment: In the Nahuatl-to-Spanish side of T this only appearsbound with YĒC- "well, good", but in theSpanish-to-Nahuatl side it occurs independently.

-tlapalyō.Comment: T has a possessed form that is ambiguous between-TLAPALYOH and -TLAPALYŌ meaning "one's color,tint, hue".  If it is the latter, then it isidentical to the inalienably possessed form ofTLAPAL-LI "dye, ink" without assimilation of LY toLL.  Otherwise it is a variant form of TLAPALLOH"s.t. painted".

tlapān(a).English: to break or split s.t. open, to break s.t. open, tohatch chicks
tlapān(a).Spanish: quebrar algo, sacar pollos las aves, o descascararmazorcas de cacao o de cosa semejante (M)

tlapanco.English: loft, storage platform under the roof

tlapān(i).English: for s.t. like pottery or eggshells to break intopieces
tlapān(i).Spanish: quebrarse algo (M), quebrarse vasijas de barro,tecomates, o otras cosas delicadas (C)
tlapān(i).Comment: M combines this verb in a single entry with TLAPĀNI"s.o. who dyes cloth".

tlapāni.Spanish: el tintero que tin9e pan9os (M), cosas de barro (C)
tlapāni.Comment: M combines this in a single gloss with the verbTLAPĀN(I) "for s.t. to break into pieces".  It isnot directly attested in the sources for thisdictionary, but the basic verb TLAPĀ is.

tlapānqui.Comment: Z has a less regular variant TLAPĀNIC.

tlapan-tli.Comment: Z marks the vowel of the second syllable long, but itis consistently short in the other sources.

tlapatiliā.English: to barter, exchange, or do business, to changeclothes
tlapatiliā.Spanish: feriar, trocar, o contratar (M), se muda de vestido(Z)

tlāpā-tl.Spanish: yerba ... que comidas trastornan la cabeza ... setoman por pulque y vino (C), quiebra-platos, plantamedicinal especie de estramonio (R), huevo de perro(X)
tlāpā-tl.Comment: This is conventionally paired with MĪXĪ-TL, anotherintoxicating plant, the whole phrase referring toinebriation.

tlapatlaliz-tli.Spanish: el acto de trocar unas cosas con otras o decambalachear (M), cambio, vuelto (Z)

tlapatlal-li.English: s.t. exchanged for s.t. else, exchange, barter
tlapatlal-li.Comment: In the same entry M has the additional gloss "s.t.dissolved, diluted", which is derived fromcontrasting PĀTLA.

tlapātzcaliz-tli.English: action of pressing s.t., expressing liquid from s.t.

tlapātzcal-li.English: juice, milk, s.t. expressed or wrung out
tlapātzcal-li.Spanish: zumo, jugo, todo lo que se exprime, leche (S)

tlapātzqui-tl.English: milk or other liquid obtained by expressing it
tlapātzqui-tl.Spanish: leche orden9ada o zumo de yerbas o de otra cosaestrujada (M)

tlapayahu(i).English: to rain gently for a long time
tlapayahu(i).Comment: X has a long vowel in the second syllable, where Thas a short one.  If the vowel were basically long,then this could be understood to contain *PĀ"water", retaining the initial P which has been lostin Ā-TL.

tlapechhuiā.English: to carry s.t. in a litter
tlapechhuiā.Spanish: llevar algo en andas o en angarillas (M)

tlapechtepehxihuiā.English: to throw s.o. out of bed onto the floor

tlapech-tli.Spanish: tablado, andamio, cama de tablas, andas de difuntos,o cosa semejante (M)

tlapehpen(a).English: to select the best from a quantity of things (such asseeds)
tlapehpen(a).Spanish: escoge semillas (lo bueno de entre todo) (T)

tlapehpenal-li.Comment: This also appears in P with the glottal stop marked.

tlapehpen-tli.Spanish: cosa escogida ... o cosas halladas que las perdierono se les cayeron a otros (M)

tlapēhu(a).English: to plow land (by driving a draft animal)

tlapēhual-li.English: trap or pit for catching animals; game that has beenflushed or livestock that can be driven; land thathas been subjugated
tlapēhual-li.Spanish: trampa para tomar y cazar animalias, o cosa ojeada, otierra conquistada, o orzuelo (M), jacal (T)

tlapetzcōltiā.English: to make s.t. come loose, slip down

tlapīc.Spanish: en vano o sin propoŸsito (M), con falsedad y mentira(C)
tlapīc.Comment: This is usually but not exclusively preceded by ZAN.

tlapihpī-tl.Comment: The vowel of the third syllable is not marked long ineither attestation.

tlapīhuiliā.English: to add s.t. above the amount purchased, to adjust orenlarge s.t.
tlapīhuiliā.Spanish: an9adir algo maŸs al peso o a la medida (M), loajusta, lo aumenta (T)
tlapīhuiliā.Comment: M has tlapiuia "for s.t. to grow, increase, ormultiply".

tlapīhuiy(a).English: for s.t. to grow, enlarge, multiply
tlapīhuiy(a).Spanish: crecer o aumentarse y multiplicarse alguna cosa (M)
tlapīhuiy(a).Comment: B attests this once and specifically marks the vowelof the second syllable short (f.9v), but it isabundantly attested in T with a long vowel, and it isalso long in T's PĪHUIC "s.t. added in over andabove what is paid for".

tlapilōliz-tli.Spanish: el acto de colgar algo de alguna cosa (M)

tlapipīnalōni.Comment: M has pipina "to suck on sweet cane".

tlapīquiā.Spanish: levantar algo a otro falsamente y con calumnia (M)

tlapī-tl.Comment: The vowel of the second syllable is not marked longin either attestation.

tlapītzaliz-tli.English: the act of playing a wind instrument or of forgingmetal with the aid of bellows
tlapītzaliz-tli.Spanish: el acto de tan9er flauta o otro instrumentosemejante, o el acto de fundir y derretir metales (M)

tlapītzal-li.Comment: Z has the abbreviated form TLAPĪTZ-TLI.

tlapītzalōni.Comment: The literal sense these share is of something workedby blowing into it.

tlapitzhuiā.English: to make a high pitched sound like an alarmed turkeyor a crying child
tlapitzhuiā.Spanish: hace ruido el guajolote al ver un gavilaŸn, lloranin9o con voz delgadita (T)

tlapitzoteyoh.Comment: The TEYOH of this is opaque.  This would make bettersense with TI-YĀN in its place.  This contrasts withTLAPITZŌTEYOH "narrow place".

tlapitzōteyoh.Comment: The TEYOH of this is opaque.  This would make bettersense with TI-YĀN in its place.  This contrasts withTLAPITZOTEYOH "ugly place".

tlapixcal-li.Comment: This appears in Z in construction with CIN-TLI withthe sense "shucked maize".

tlapiyal-li.Comment: In view of TLAHPIXTINEM(I) "to serve as shepherd", itseems that this should be TLAHPIYAL-LI, but Z has noglottal stop in any attestation.

tlapiyāzoā.Comment: The gloss is ambiguous between urination anddefecation, and moreover deponer can also mean "tovomit".  T has O for Ā in the third syllable.

tlapoā.Spanish: ser portero o desatapar, descubrir, o abrir algo (M)
tlapoā.Comment: This contrasts with intransitive TLAPŌHU(A) "tocount, to read".
