tlapōctēm(i).English: for a place to fill up with smoke
tlapōctēm(i).Spanish: se llena de humo, lleno de humo (T),humea, estaŸ lleno de humo (Z)

tlapohpōhu(a).Comment: X lacks the internal glottal stop.

tlapohpōhuiliz-tli.Comment: X fails to mark the glottal stop.

tlapohpolhuiā.Spanish: perdonar a otro, o dispensar con alguno (M)

-tlapohpolhuilōcā.Spanish: el perdoŸn con que me perdonan (C for first pers.sg. possessor)

tlapōhu(a).English: to count, to read, to pray
tlapōhu(a).Comment: M does not have a separate entry for this, but C, T,and Z treat it as an intransitive verb with thenonspecific object prefix TLA- fused to the verb stem.This contrasts with transitive TLAPOĀ "to opens.t."

tlapōhualiz-tli.Spanish: el acto de numerar o contar algo, o el acto de echarsuertes el hechicero o el agorero, o el acto de darleccioŸn el estudiante a su maestro, o el acto deleer algo (M)

tlapōhual-li.English: s.o. or s.t. counted, s.t. read
tlapōhual-li.Spanish: cosa numerada y contada o cosa leiŸda (M), cosa opersona contada (C)

tlapōhualpa.Comment: This is only attested in negated form with the sense"countless times".

tlapohu(i).Spanish: abrirse la puerta o la carta (M)

tlapōhuiā.English: to relate s.t. to s.o., to testify about s.o., tocast fortunes
tlapōhuiā.Spanish: le cuenta (un suceso) (Z), testifica (Z), echarsuertes a otro el hechicero o agorero con maiŸz (M)

tlapōhuiliz-tli.Comment: M has tlapouiliztli "opening, the act ofunfastening", which is derived from TLAPOHU(I) andcontrasts with this.

tlapolihu(i).Comment: M has this in a phrase about starvation and thirst.

tlapolōliz-tli.Spanish: el acto de perder alguna cosa (M), locura, confusioŸn(Z for compound with CUĀ(I)-TL)

tlapolōltiā.English: to become distracted or disoriented; to cause s.o.to become distracted or disoriented
tlapolōltiā.Spanish: descuidarse o desatinarse y turbarse (M), desatinar aotro asiŸ (M)

tlapōpoyāhu(i).Spanish: se obsurece (T for compound with ĪX-TLI)
tlapōpoyāhu(i).Comment: T also has POPOYACTIC "gray, dark, cloudy", and M hastlapoyahua "for night to fall".

tlapoxcahuīllō-tl.Comment: Z marks the vowel of the second syllable long, but itis not long in the related verb.  Z also has O for Ain the third syllable.

tlapoyāhua.English: for night to fall, to get dark

tlapoztec-tli.Spanish: cosa quebrada asiŸ como palo o pierna, brazo, etc. (M)

tlaquechiā.English: to support oneself on a crutch, staff
tlaquechiā.Spanish: estribar o sustentarse sobre alguŸn bordoŸn o muleta(M)

tlaquehquelōliz-tli.Comment: Z fails to mark the internal glottal stop.

tlāquēhu(a).Spanish: alquilar a otro (M), lo alquila, lo arrienda, lorenta (Z)
tlāquēhu(a).Comment: Z has apparently extended this to the hiring ofthings as well as people and services.

tlāquēhual-li.English: hired help, paid servant; s.t. rented
tlāquēhual-li.Spanish: alquilado o mercenario (M), criado, mozo, servidor,siervo, peoŸn, sirviente (Z), alquilado (Z)
tlāquēhual-li.Comment: In all but two attestations, Z marks the vowels ofthe second and third syllables long.  In one thevowels of the first and third syllables are markedlong, and in the other the vowels of the first andsecond are marked long.  This last pattern is theonly correct one if this item is derived fromTLĀQUĒHU(A), as it is according to M's gloss.

tlāquēhuiā.English: to hire s.o. to do s.t. to or for s.o.
tlāquēhuiā.Spanish: buscar o alquilar a alguno para que haga mal a otro(M), se preocupa por otra persona para llamarle a undoctor, a un curandero; le busca padrino, guiŸa, etc.(T)

tlaquēmiltiā.Spanish: hago a otro que se vista de algo, y doyle de vestir(C for first pers. sg. subject)
tlaquēmiltiā.Comment: This is synonymous with TLAQUĒNTIĀ.  They arealternative causative forms of unattested*TLAQUĒM(I).

tlaquēm(i)-tl.Comment: TLAQUĒM(I)-TL and TLAQUĒN-TLI co-occur in C, T, Z,and R with no apparent distinction in meaning.  Inpossessed form, even with honorific -TZIN, T has lostthe final nasal consonant.

tlaquēnquīxtiā.English: to get undressed; to undress s.o.
tlaquēnquīxtiā.Spanish: se desviste, se desabriga (Z), lo desnuda (Z)

tlaquēntiā.English: to get dressed; to dress s.o.
tlaquēntiā.Spanish: vestirse o arroparse (M), vestir a otro asiŸ (M)
tlaquēntiā.Comment: T has short I for Ē in the second syllable.  Thisis synonymous with TLAQUĒMILTIĀ.  They arealternative causative forms of unattested*TLAQUĒM(I).

tlaquequetz(a).English: for a male bird to copulate with the female
tlaquequetz(a).Spanish: de las aves que se toman ... del macho (C)
tlaquequetz(a).Comment: C contrasts this with TLA-QUEHQUETZ(A)"to kick out at s.t. in anger".

tlaquēzōltiā.English: to cross over s.t., to go through s.t.
tlaquēzōltiā.Comment: Z also has ĪXTLAQUĒZ "s.t. or s.o. bent".

tlaquin-tli.Comment: This is a variant of TLAQUĒM(I)-TL = TLAQUĒN-TLI inT.  Although T has possessed forms of TLAQUĒN-TLIwith the reflex of a long vowel in the secondsyllable, it also has short-vowel variantsTLAQUEN-TLI and TLAQUIN-TLI.  TLAQUINTIĀ is the Tvariant of derived TLAQUĒNTIĀ

-tlāquixcuāc.Comment: T marks the vowel of the second syllable short, whileit is long in ĪXCUĀ(I)-TL "forehead", making itquestionable whether it is a constituent of thiscompound.

tlaquīz(a).English: for the rains to end, for the weather to clear
tlaquīz(a).Spanish: acaba el temporal, se compone (el tiempo), escampa(termina el temporal, entran las secas) (T)

tlaquīzcātlah.English: profusion of fruit out of season
tlaquīzcātlah.Comment: M has tlaquizcayotl "end or conclusion of s.t."

tlaquīztoc.Spanish: hace buen tiempo, un diŸa muy claro (Z)

tlatamachīhualōni.Comment: In one of the two attestations the initial syllablehas been dropped.

tlatcōni.Comment: This is paired in context with CĀCĀX-TLI"packframe".

tlatecaltiāni.English: s.o. who fans s.t. away, drives s.t. off

tlatecōni.Spanish: hacha para cortar algo o instrumento semejante (M)
tlatecōni.Comment: This is opposite in sense from TECŌNI "s.t. in needof cutting".  C states that TLATECŌNI is not used inpossessed form but is suppletive with synonymous-TLATEQUIYA.

tlatecpānaliz-tli.English: alignment, order, the act of lining s.t. or s.o. up
tlatecpānaliz-tli.Spanish: orden y concierto de alguna cosa ... el acto deponer la gente o otra cosa en procesioŸn o por susrengleras (M)

tlatēcpanoā.Spanish: voy a palacio (C for first pers. sg. subject withdirectional ON-)

tlatecpān-tli.English: s.t. set in order, a queue, file, or tail
tlatecpān-tli.Spanish: cosa ordenada (M), alineado, cola (de gente, decosas), por turno (T for CA TLATECPĀN-TLI)

tlatec-tli.English: s.t. cut, a wound or scar
tlatec-tli.Spanish: cosa cortada (M), herida, cortadura (Z), su cicatriz(Z for possessed form)
tlatec-tli.Comment: This contrasts with TLATĒC-TLI "s.t. spread out",but M combines them in a single gloss.

tlatēc-tli.English: s.t. spread or poured out; fabric
tlatēc-tli.Spanish: guirnalda o cosa escanciada o echada en algo (M),tela (Z)
tlatēc-tli.Comment: This contrasts with TLATEC-TLI "s.t. cut", but Mcombines them in a single gloss.  M also has teteca"to warp cloth".

tlatehtec-tli.Spanish: cosa descuartizada o hecha pedazos o cosa hecharebanadas o tajadas (M), herida (T)
tlatehtec-tli.Comment: M combines the gloss for this with glosses for a formderived from TEHTĒCA "to spread out" in a singleentry.  This contrasts with TLATĒTEC-TLI"s.t. sliced".

tlatelchīhualiz-tli.English: words of scoffing or reproach, curse

tlatēmoliā.English: to examine oneself for faults, to practiceintrospection; to carry out an investigation of s.o.
tlatēmoliā.Spanish: examinarse, trayendo a la memoria sus pecados, o lohizo para se confesar (M), hacer inquisicioŸn,pesquisa, o informacioŸn contra alguno (M), loesculca (T)

tlatēntocani.English: s.o. given to answering back, s.o. disrespectful

tlateōchīhualiz-tli.English: blessing, the act of blessing s.t.
tlateōchīhualiz-tli.Spanish: el acto de consagrar o bendecir algo (M), bendicioŸn(Z)

tlateōmatiliz-tli.Comment: C marks the vowel of the fifth syllable long,although by general rule it should be short.  This isimmediately followed in context byTLATEŌTOQUILIZ-TLI, where C also marks thecorresponding vowel long.

tlateōtoquiliz-tli.Comment: C marks the vowel of the fifth syllable long,although by general rule it should not be.  This isimmediately preceded in context byTLATEŌMATILIZ-TLI, where C also marks thecorresponding vowel long.

tlatepotztocaliz-tli.Comment: Z's gloss "requirment" does not accurately convey theliteral sense of this.

tlatequiliz-tli.Spanish: el acto de cortar alguna cosa (M)

tlatequipanoh.Comment: Because of general loss of final glottal stops in T,the glottal stop in this item is not attested, but itis predicted by regular derivational rules.

tlatequipanōliztica.Comment: This conventionally pairs with CIAHUIZTICA "byfatigue", both in possessed form, the sense of thephrase being equivalent to the English phrase "by thesweat of one's brow".

tlatequipanōliz-tli.Spanish: el acto de trabajar en alguna obra (M)

-tlatequiya.Spanish: el intrumento con que yo corto algo, mi cuchillo, mihacha (C for first pers. sg. possessor)
-tlatequiya.Comment: C states that this possessed form is suppletive withthe absolutive form of synonymous TLATECŌNI.

tlatētec-tli.Comment: The literal sense of this should be "s.t. sliced inorderly fashion".  It contrasts with TLATEHTEC-TLI"s.t. hacked".

tlatetecuechiliā.English: to stamp one's feet to get attention
tlatetecuechiliā.Spanish: hago ruido con los pies, para que mire hacia acaŸ (Cfor first pers. sg. subject)

tlathui.Comment: M has this bound with YE "already" with the samemeaning.

tlathuiltiā.Comment: The applicative of this used reflexively constitutesa reverential morning greeting in B.  Once in sevenattestations B marks the vowel of the second syllablelong.

tlathuītiā.Comment: This is attested twice in B, and in both cases thevowel of the second syllable is not marked long,although by general derivational processes it shouldbe.  Like TLATHUILTIĀ, the other causative form ofTLATHUI, this is used as part of a formal morninggreeting, but it is also used to simply inquire abouts.o.'s general state upon arising, implying that thebasic verb TLATHUI "to dawn" has an extended meaning"to get up in the morning".

tlatiā.English: to burn; to burn s.o., s.t.
tlatiā.Comment: This contrasts with TLĀTIĀ "to hide s.t.", but Mcombines them in a single entry.

tlātiā.English: to hide oneself; to hide s.o., s.t., to kill s.o.
tlātiā.Spanish: esconderse (M), esconder a otro (M), lo mata (T)
tlātiā.Comment: The literal sense "to hide s.o." extendsmetaphorically to "to kill s.o." in the sense of "toput s.o. out of sight".  TLĀTIĀ contrasts withTLATIĀ "to burn s.t.", but M combines the two in asingle entry.

tlatilāniz-tli.English: the act of hauling, tugging, pulling

tlātlacalhuiā.English: to mimic s.o., to mock s.o.

tlatlācamat(i).Spanish: obedeciŸan (C for third pers. plural, imperfect)
tlatlācamat(i).Comment: The nonspecific object prefix TLA- has fused with thestem to form an intransitive verb.

tlatlācamatiliz-tli.Comment: M has tetlacamatiliztli "obedience".  Thedistinction is that M's entry representsTĒTLĀCAMATILIZ-TLI "obedience of s.o.", while thisis "obedience of s.t. (such as a rule or order)".

tlātlāca-tl.Comment: R has a short vowel and glottal stop in thereduplicated syllable instead of a long vowel.

tlātlacō-tl.Comment: M has tlacoton "boil, sore, pustule".  This appearsto be related to TLACŌ-TL "staff, stick", althoughthe common meaning is not evident.

tlātlacuāliz-tli.Comment: The vowel of the third syllable is marked long inboth attestations.

tlātlahconecuiloā.English: to twist from side to side
tlātlahconecuiloā.Spanish: se tuerce (de un lado a otro) (T)

tlatlahzoltiā.English: to pollute, to get things dirty

tlatlālchipāhua.English: for dawn to break, to get light

tlatlāliā.Spanish: poner precio a lo que se vende o hacer constitucionesy ordenanzas o poner algo en alguŸn lugar, oindustriar, fabricar, y componer algo (M)

tlatlālīl-li.Spanish: cosa industriada y fabricada o cosa establecida oordenada (M), ramillete, plazo (T)

tlātlaloā.English: to run in an orderly, sequential fashion
tlātlaloā.Spanish: corro de aquiŸ para alliŸ (C for first pers. sg.subject), corremos de la misma manera como los quecorren can9as (C)
tlātlaloā.Comment: With a singular subject this means for a person torun from a starting point in a set direction.  With aplural subject it means for people to run in anorganized manner, as in pairs or relays.  Thiscontrasts with TLAHTLALOĀ "for several people torun in the same direction but in an unorganized way".

tlātlamantic.Comment: In both attestations Z marks the vowel of the thirdsyllable long, but it should not be.  In one of twoattestations Z marks the vowel of the first syllablelong.

tlatlampa.Comment: Z has a long vowel in the postposition -TLAN, but theother sources agree that it is short.

tlātlanēc(i).Comment: The literal sense of the phrase in T is "to beluminous inside".

tlatlapaca.English: for s.t. to break into bits
tlatlapaca.Spanish: hacerse pedazos el pan o las vasijas de barro o devidrio (M)

tlatlapatz(a).Spanish: despedazar o quebrantar algo en muchas partes (M)

tlātlapoā.Spanish: aŸbrese y cerrada se vuelve a abrir continuadamente(C)
tlātlapoā.Comment: This contrasts with TLAHTLAPOĀ "for various thingsto open".

tlatlātiāni.Spanish: el que ... esconde alguna cosa (M), matoŸn (T)

tlatlatiliā.English: to build a fire to warm oneself; to burn s.t. in thecourse of laying a curse on s.o.
tlatlatiliā.Spanish: hacer lumbre para se calentar (M), lo quema (aceitepara que le caiga maldad) (T)

tlatlatiliz-tli.Comment: Z's gloss does not precisely reflect the literalsense of this item.  This contrasts withTLATLĀTILIZ-TLI "the act of hiding s.t."

tlatlātiliz-tli.Comment: Z's gloss does not precisely reflect the literalsense of this item.  This contrasts withTLATLATILIZ-TLI "the act of burning s.t."

tlatlatzīn(i).Spanish: tronar cuando llueve o cae rayo (M)

tlātlauhtiā.English: to pray; to pray to s.o. or implore s.o. for s.t.,to plead with s.o.
tlātlauhtiā.Spanish: ruega, ora (T), hacer oracioŸn o rezar (M), rogar porotro (M)
tlātlauhtiā.Comment: T's reflexive use of this is synonymous with M's useof it with the prefix TLA-.  In polite speech this isan overblown but conventional way of saying "toaddress s.o.". Z marks the A of the second syllablelong as well as that of the first, but the othersources agree that it is short.

tlatlāx-tli.English: s.t. cast or hurled down, s.t. rejected, aborted,plowed under (of land)
tlatlāx-tli.Spanish: cosa arrojada o que se le cayoŸ a alguno, o tierraarada y labrada, o criatura abortada y echada asabiendas (M)
tlatlāx-tli.Comment: C and M also have the variant TLATLĀZ-TLI, andmoreover, this is synonymous with TLATLĀZAL-LI.

tlatlāzal-li.Comment: This is synonymous with TLATLĀX-TLI andTLATLĀZ-TLI.

tlatlāz-tli.English: s.t. cast or hurled down, s.t. rejected, aborted,or plowed under (of land)
tlatlāz-tli.Spanish: cosa arrojada por hay o cosa que se le cayoŸ a algunoo criatura abortada y echada voluntariosamente (M)
tlatlāz-tli.Comment: C and M also have the variant TLATLĀX-TLI, andmoreover, this is synonymous with TLATLĀZAL-LI.

tlatlīlēuhtoc.English: for s.t. to be so far away that it appears as a darkobject
tlatlīlēuhtoc.Lexical Reference: see TLĪL-LI, ĒHU(A), the verb O

tlatōcalōni.English: staff for punching holes for sowing seed

tlatōccuahu(i)-tl.English: staff for punching holes for sowing seed, diggingstick

tlatohton-tli.Spanish: cosa desatada, desabrochada, desnudada o desenvuelta(M)

tlatquitiā.English: to make s.t. the property of s.o.
tlatquitiā.Spanish: enajenar algo o enviar alguna cosa a otro (M)
tlatquitiā.Comment: M has this with a direct object prefix plus anoblique reflexive prefix, meaning "to appropriates.t."

tlatqui-tl.Comment: This is conventionally paired with ĀXCĀ(I)-TL"property", the whole phrase referring to one'sproperty, wealth, estate.

-tlattaya.Spanish: mi vista, mi potencia visiva (C for first pers. sg.possessor)

tlatzaccān.English: at the end, conclusion, last of all
tlatzaccān.Spanish: al cabo, a fin, o a la postre (M)

tlatzacu(a).English: to close, to make restitution, to suffer punishmentfor s.t.
tlatzacu(a).Spanish: cierro, o pago y lasto algo (C for first pers. sg.subject), pagar por otro, expiar la falta de alguien(S)

tlatzcan.Comment: This is abundantly attested in C.  It also appears inZ with the absolutive suffix -TLI, but this isidiosyncratic to Z.

tlatzcancayō-tl.Spanish: lo concerniente a los cipreses (S for TLATZCANYŌ-TL)
tlatzcancayō-tl.Comment: This appears in C as an example of a derivationalprocess and without a gloss, but according to C it issynonymous with with TLATZCANYŌ-TL, which is glossedin S.

tlatzcaneh.English: s.o. who possesses a cypress tree

tlatzcotōn(a).Spanish: quebrar hilo, cordel o soga (M), lo revienta, lorompe (T)

tlatzcuepōniliā.English: to beat s.t. or s.o. hard

tlatzetzeloliz-tli.Comment: In one of two attestations the vowel of the fourthsyllable is marked long.

tlatzihuiliā.English: for s.t. to make s.o. apathetic or disgusted

tlatzilhuiā.English: to be weary of s.t. or s.o., to be apathetic aboutor disgusted by s.t.
tlatzilhuiā.Spanish: aborrecer a otro (M), aborrecer algo que de enrostro, como la comida el enfermo (C)

tlatzilīn.Comment: M has tlatzilinilli referring to a bell.

tlatzīn(i).English: to make an explosive sound, to thunder, to sizzle
tlatzīn(i).Spanish: sonar algo reventado asiŸ como huevo cuando lo asan ocosa semejante (M), truena (Z)
tlatzīn(i).Comment: Z also has impersonal TLATLATZĪN(I) with the sense"to thunder".

tlatzīniā.Spanish: le pega, le da sus nalgadas (T)

tlatzīntlan.Comment: T has the additional gloss "in the south", reflectinglocal geography, since Tetelcingo is situated on landthat drops away to lower altitudes to the south.

tlatziuhcāmāhu(a).English: to infect s.o. with one's laziness
tlatziuhcāmāhu(a).Spanish: lo entretiene, contagia a otro con la pereza (T)

tlatzohyāyaliz-tli.Comment: M has tzoyayaliztli "smell of burnt feathers orcloth".

tlatzotzonaliz-tli.English: the act of making music by striking or plucking aninstrument, the act of striking s.t.
tlatzotzonaliz-tli.Spanish: el acto de tan9er atabales, oŸrganos, harpa, etc., oel acto de dar golpes con alguna cosa (M)

tlatzotzonanih.Comment: This nonstandard plural form implies TLATZOTZONANI"musician", the regular plural form of which would beformed by adding -MEH.

tlatzotzonqui.Spanish: atabalero o tan9edor de oŸrganos (M), muŸsico (Z)

tlatzotzon-tli.English: s.t., s.o. beaten upon; a type of drum
tlatzotzon-tli.Spanish: atabal tan9ido, o persona apun9eada, o cosa golpeada,o cosa tupida y apretada (M), instrumento (demuŸsica) (Z)
tlatzotzon-tli.Comment: In both attestations Z marks the vowel of the thirdsyllable long, but it should not be.

tlatzoyōnīl-li.Comment: Z also has a short form TLATZOYŌN.  Bothattestations mark the vowel of the second syllablelong, but it should not be.

tlāuhquechōl.English: rich red plumage; bird of such plumage, roseatespoonbill or flamingo
tlāuhquechōl.Spanish: pluma rica y bermeja (M) ave acuaŸtica muy parecidaal pato y notable por el esplandor de sus plumasrojas (S)

tlaxamānīl-li.English: s.t. cracked or splintered, or s.t. split (such asa shingle)
tlaxamānīl-li.Spanish: cabeza machucada, etc., tablas menudas, o astillaslargas (M), tejamanil (Z)
tlaxamānīl-li.Comment: Under influence from Spanish teja "roof tile", Zhas the variant TEXAMĀNĪL-LI.

tlaxcalchīhualōyān.Spanish: lugar donde se hace pan, panaderiŸa (C)

tlaxcalhuiā.Spanish: hacer tortillas de maiŸz para otro (M)

tlaxcalīxchīlloh.English: enchilada, tortilla covered with chili-seasoned sauce

tlaxcallān.Comment: This is implied by TLAXCALTĒCA-TL "person fromTlaxcala".

tlaxcal-li.Spanish: tortillas de maiŸz, o pan generalmente (M)
tlaxcal-li.Comment: In older texts TLAXCAL-LI often refers to bread ingeneral; more recently it has increasingly been usedto distinguish maize tortillas from raised wheatbread.

tlaxcalpōpozōn.English: dish of shredded tortillas boiled in broth
tlaxcalpōpozōn.Comment: Because of the general loss of final N in T, thefinal one here is not attested but can be restoredfrom the related verb.

tlaxcalzol-li.Comment: T is missing the internal L in the Nahuatl-to-Spanishside of the dictionary but has it in theSpanish-to-Nahuatl side.

tlaxēloā.English: for a chicken to scratch, scattering earth around

tlaxelōliz-tli.Spanish: el acto de dividir y partir alguna cosa o partija(M), separacioŸn, divisioŸn (Z)

tlaxhuiz-tli.Comment: In two of five attestations Z marks the vowel of thesecond syllable long.

tlaxīcōliz-tli.Comment: This seems to be related to XĪCOĀ, but the onlysense they have in common would seem to be one ofendurance or tolerance of a burden.

tlāxiliā.English: to abort, to cast s.t. off; to throw s.t. away froms.o., to cause s.o. to abort
tlāxiliā.Spanish: abortar, deshacerse de algo, dimitar de un cargo (S),hacer abortar a una mujer (S)

tlaxīpēhual-li.English: s.t. peeled, the bark or shell of s.t.
tlaxīpēhual-li.Spanish: cosa desollada o descortezada, mazorca de maiŸzdeshojada, o cortezas de pino y de oyametl para hacerbuena brasa (M), caŸscara de encino (Z)

tlaxocoliā.English: to make things go sour, curdle, ferment
tlaxocoliā.Spanish: el que aceda o hace agria alguna cosa (M) lo haceacedo (T)

tlaxocoltilōni.Comment: In one of two attestations Z marks the vowel of thesecond syllable long.

tlaxonēpalhuiā.English: to braid one's hair; to braid s.o.'s hair
tlaxonēpalhuiā.Spanish: se hace trenzas (T), le hace sus trenzas (T)

tlaxopoch-tli.Comment: This specifically refers to a nest made in adepression on the ground.

tlaxoxōhuiya.English: for things to get green, for leaves to come out
tlaxoxōhuiya.Spanish: verdeguear el prado que se estaŸ riendo (M)

tlaxqui-tl.Spanish: cosa asada en las brasas o en el rescoldo (M)

tlaxtlāhualiz-tli.Spanish: el acto de pagar o restituir algo (M)

tlaxtlāhuiā.English: to be self-satisfied; to pay for s.t.
tlaxtlāhuiā.Spanish: pagarse, o satisfacer asiŸ mismo (M), galardonar orestituir lo que debo a otro (M), lo paga, lorecompensa (Z)
tlaxtlāhuiā.Comment: X gives the truncated form TLAXTLĀHUI as anexpression of thanks.

tlaxtlāhuīl-li.Spanish: paga, jornal, soldada, restitucioŸn, o galardoŸn (M)

tlaxxīm(a).Comment: M has this with a single x, but B has xx,which makes it contrast with TLA-XĪM(A)"to plane s.t." < XĪM(A).

tlayacac.Comment: M has several items with tlayaca as an elementsharing the sense of "to go first".

tlayacānaliz-tli.Spanish: primado o ventaja (M), poder, autoridad,gobernacioŸn, reino (Z)

tlayacānquetz(a).English: to advance, to take the lead

tlayacānqui.Spanish: autoridad, mayor, jefe, patroŸn, superior, gobernador(Z)
tlayacānqui.Comment: M has synonymous teyacanqui.  T gives areduplicated plural rather than the regular -QUEHplural for this type of derived noun.  The finalglottal stop is given here by analogy with otherreduplicated plurals.  Because of T's general loss ofglottal stops in word-final position, it is notdirectly attested.

tlayahualoā.English: to go in a procession around s.t.
tlayahualoā.Spanish: rodear algo andando alrededor de el (C)

tlayehyecōliz-tli.Spanish: ensaye o prueba del que se impone o ensaya (M)

tlāy(i).Comment: This is attested as an element of the synonymouscompound TLAĪXTLĀY(I).

tlayohuac.Comment: In both attestations Z marks the vowel of the secondsyllable long, but it should not be.

tlayohuaquiliā.English: to get dark, for night to fall

tlayohuayāntiā.English: to get dark, for night to fall

tlayōlēhualiz-tli.Comment: M has teyoleualiztli with the somewhat differentgloss "the incitement or provocation of s.o."

tlayōlloh-tli.Spanish: corazoŸn, centro del maiŸz o madero (T), centro deuna cosa (aŸrbol, etc.) (T for possessed form)

tlāz(a).English: to fling oneself down; to cast or hurl s.o. down, toput s.o. out of office, to evict s.o., to throw s.t.aside, for a chicken to lay eggs
tlāz(a).Spanish: echarse por esos suelos o de alto abajodespen9aŸndose (M), echar a otro en el suelo oderribarlo, o deponer y privar a alguno del oficio osen9oriŸo que tiene (M), tirar tiro, o arrojar algo,o poner huevos la gallina (M)
tlāz(a).Comment: In the case of "to lay eggs", the nonspecific objectprefix TLA- can be seen as fused with the verb stemforming an intransitive verb TLATLĀZ(A)

tlazāl-li.English: s.t. sticky such as bird lime; clothing, cloth

tlazāl-li.Comment: This is abundantly attested in Z with the sense of"clothing, cloth".  M has only the "bird lime" sense,which in the sources for this dictionary aresupported by derivations from ZĀLOĀ "to glue, joins.t."

tlazālōliz-tli.English: act of joining or glueing two things together, mosaicwork

tlazohcāmachiliā.Spanish: recompensa un favor, le da gracias (Z)

tlazohcāmat(i).Spanish: ser agradecido o agradecer algo a otro (M)

tlazohcāmati.Comment: In Z this has a final -C.

tlazohti.English: for s.t. to be rare, precious, for merchandise to behigh priced

tlazohtlanqui.Spanish: muy linda (C for compound with HUEL)

tlazohtlapōloā.English: to love s.o. out of the depths of one's unworthiness

tlecāhuiā.Comment: This contrasts with TLEHCAHUIĀ "to ascend s.t."

tlecuīltiā.English: to set s.t. afire, to light s.t.

tle(h).Comment: According to C, this has a final glottal stop inphrases when the following word begins with aconsonant and drops the glottal stop elsewhere.  Insome contexts it does not sustain its interrogativesense.  With negation it means "nothing".

tlehcō.Comment: In abundant attestation across sources the vowel ofthe second syllable is marked long only in twopreterit forms in X.  By form and meaning TLEHCŌwould seem to belong to a group of verbs ending in Ōsuch as PANŌ "to cross a river" and TEMŌ "todescend".

tzahtzacu(a).Spanish: encerrarse en alguna caŸmara o en otra parte (M),encerrar o encarcelar y recoger a otro (M), cerrarlas puertas o las ventanas, o ensilar o encerrarmaiŸz o trigo (M)

tzana-tl.Spanish: paŸjaro negro de pico encorvado, de taman9o delestornino; su carne no sirve para comer (S)

tzīcuēhu(a).Comment: This is only attested paired with TLAPĀN(I), thesense of the phrase being "for children to be born".The construction also appears in the grammar of Olmoswith the same sense.  TLAPĀN(I) alone can mean "foreggs to hatch", and TZĪCUĒHU(A) probably has asimilar meaning.  M has tentzicueua "to nick therim of a container" and quauhtziceualli "large splintersof wood", suggesting that the basic meaning ofthe verb is "to chip or splinter off".  It mayalso be related to TZITZĪCA,having to do with becoming full.  In threeout of four attestations in B the vowel of the firstsyllable is marked long.  In the fourth it isspecifically marked short.

tzicuīnaltiā.English: to make s.o., s.t. leap, run
tzicuīnaltiā.Spanish: le hace brincarlo, lo salta (T), lo lleva corriendo,le hace correr (T)

tzicuīn(i).Spanish: corre, brinca, salta (T), salpicar cualquier cosaliŸquida (M)

tzicuīnīhua.Comment: T gives this as the nonactive form of the loan blendcruz-TZICUĪN(I) "to jump in a cross" (Tp.180).Elsewhere the nonactive of TZICUĪN(I) isTZICUĪNOHUA.

tzihtzicnoā.Comment: X lacks the internal glottal stop.

-tzinco.Comment: The honorific of postpositions is formed by addingnot simply -TZIN but -TZINCO.

tzīncuētiā.Spanish: le pone una cosa abajo (adobe o chinaŸmil a una casa,pan9al a un nin9o, etc.) (T)

tzīncuitlahuiy(a).English: for a plant to rot at the base

tzīnēhu(a).Comment: M has this as a transitive verb with the sense of "tohurl down from a high place, defeat, destroy s.t.,s.o." and indicates that the sense is metaphorical.The sense in Z is synonymous with TZĪNTI in C.

-tzinoā.Grammar: compounding verbal element used to form the honorificof reflexive verbs
-tzinoā.Comment: The same vowel length problems across sourcesdiscussed under -TZIN-TLI apply to -TZINOĀ, sincethe latter is a derivation of the former.  See thediscussion under -TZIN-TLI.

-tzīnpan.Comment: T has characteristically lost the final N.

tzīnquīxtiā.Spanish: desistir, separarse, retroceder por miedo, ceder ...(disminuir, desgravar un impuesto), cortar, cercenar,rebajar, disminuir una cosa (S)
tzīnquīxtiā.Comment: M has several more extended senses.

tzīnquīz(a).English: to retire, to retreat, for a price to drop
tzīnquīz(a).Spanish: retrocede para atraŸs, se abarata, se rebaja (elprecio) (T)

-tzīntech.English: next to the base of s.t.
-tzīntech.Spanish: junto a la base de, al tronco de (T)

tzīntelaquiā.English: to sit down hard; to make s.o. sit downhard
tzīntelaquiā.Spanish: se da un sentoŸn (T), le da un sentoŸn (T)
tzīntelaquiā.Comment: M has tzintelaquitihuetzi "to slip and fall onone's rump" and several verbs witl tel as the firstelement with the sense of kicking or shoving.

tzīntemō.English: for a price to decline; to descend s.t. steep
tzīntemō.Spanish: se rebaja (el precio); baja en declive (T)

tzīnte-tl.Comment: T has this incorporated into a verb, the wholeconstruction meaning "to spank".  It also occursin X referring to the contents of a pot.

tzīntetlahtlatzcuepōniā.Spanish: le pega en las nalgas, le da nalgadas (T)

tzīnti.Spanish: tener comienzo o principio de ser (M)

tzīntiliz-tli.English: the beginning or foundation of s.t.
tzīntiliz-tli.Spanish: principio, comienzo o fundamento de alguna cosa (M)

tzīntlan-tli.Spanish: nalga (M), su nalga, su cadera, sus asentaderas, sucimiento (Z)

tzīn-tli.Spanish: el ojo del salvohonor (M), ano, colon, cimiento, base(S)
tzīn-tli.Comment: In the sources for this dictionary this appears onlyin compounds, but it is given as a free form in M.

-tzin-tli.Grammar: compounding element with honorific or diminutivesense; pl: -TZITZINTIN; vocative -TZINE = -TZE(stress on E)
-tzin-tli.Comment: Although necessarily bound, this behaves as in amanner distinct from suffixes and postpositions.  Ithas its own absolutive suffix, and it forms theplural by reduplication of itself plus the additionof the plural suffix -TIN; ICHCA-TL "sheep",ICHCATZIN-TLI, ICHCATZITZIN-TIN "sheep (pl.)".  Ifthe item it compounds with does not take anabsolutive suffix, then the compound does not either,and -TIN is omitted in the plural; ILAMA "old woman",ILAMATZIN, ILAMATZITZIN "old women" (Cf.8r).Personal names with -TZIN often do not take theabsolutive suffix.  C is consistent in contrastingthis bound -TZIN-TLI with the noun TZĪN-TLI "base,foundation, buttocks" by vowel length.  T, Z, and Xall have long vowels in both, and this seems to begenerally true of modern Nahuatl.  B, with only asingle attestation of TZĪN-TLI, has a complex andpossibly transitional pattern for -TZIN-TLI.  In Bword-final -TZIN (in possessed forms and whereabsolutive -TLI is omitted) is never attested with along vowel.  It is as though the general rule whichshortens word-final long vowels was extended to thevowel of -TZIN in spite of the final -N.  Where -TLIis present, the vowel of -TZIN is marked long inabout half the attestations.  The I of the fullvocative -TZINE is never attested with a long vowel,and in the special possessed honorific formNOPILTZINTZINE "my lord", the vowel of the secondTZIN is specifically marked short twice, while thevowel of the first TZIN is marked long in four out ofsix attestations.  In all other constructions,including -TZINCO, -TZINHUĀN, -TZITZINTIN, and-TZINTLE, the vowel if -TZIN is marked long in morethan half the attestations and unmarked for length inthe others.  Aside from the special case ofNOPILTZINTZINE, the vowel of -TZIN is neverspecifically marked short.  This suggests that-TZIN-TLI and TZĪN-TLI were originally homophonousand that differentiation of them has been a localphenomenon.  In C the differentiation is lexical;-TZIN-TLI has a short vowel and TZĪN-TLI has a longone.  In B it appears that shortening applies to-TZIN exceptionlessly in word-final position, whilethe length of the vowel is ambiguous if it carriesstress itself or precedes the main stressed syllable.A glottal stop is sometimes attested between -TZINand the element with which it compounds, as inACHIHTZIN < ACHI.  This is generally true when -TZINis added to possessed forms of kinship terms, as inĪCIHUĀHUAHTZIN "his wife" < CIHUĀ-TL "woman, wife"plus the possessive suffix -HU(A).

tzīnyahualtiā.English: to encircle the base of s.t.

tzīnyahualtiā.Comment: T characteristically has YE for YA.

tziqui.Spanish: poquito, chiquito, chaparrito, pequen9o, bajo (deestatura) (T for reduplicated form)
tziqui.Comment: This is only attested bound to the additionaldiminutives -TZIN and -TŌN.  The form TZIQUITŌN isso close to Spanish chiquito that it suggests aloan formation, but this is not necessarily the case.

tziquil.Comment: Two of these attestations are as part of the name forthe chilacayote squash.

tziquiloā.English: to cut s.t. off for s.o.

tzitzīca.English: to stuff s.t. tight, to compress s.t. in a container
tzitzīca.Spanish: atorar o meter algo muy apretado en alguŸn agujero(M)
