tzītziqui-.Comment: According to C, reduplication of diminutives witha long vowel in the reduplicated syllable rendersthem even more diminutive (f.125v).

tzītzquiā.English: to grip s.o. or s.t. with the hand, to take hold ofs.t.
tzītzquiā.Spanish: asir o tener algo en la mano (M), asir de algunapersona (M)

tziucnoā.Comment: Z and X have reduplicated TZIHTZICNOĀ "to sob orto sigh".

tzoco.Comment: All attestations of this are with one or the other ofthe additional diminutives -TZIN, -TŌN.  It may berelated to XŌCOH, XŌCOYŌ-TL "youngest (smallest)child".  It only appears in the Spanish-to-Nahuatlside of M.

tzohtzocoltic.Spanish: botonudo, palo que tiene tronquitos de ramas (T)

tzohtzoltic.English: s.t. thick and sticky like cooked oatmeal
tzohtzoltic.Comment: T has variants of this with and without the internalglottal stop.

tzohtzomah-tli.Spanish: trapo o andrajo (M), ropa, tela, trapo, velo (T)
tzohtzomah-tli.Comment: T lacks the internal glottal stop, and it is notmarked in the attestations in B and R, but it doesappear in C.

tzohtzon(a).Spanish: dar palmadita con la mano, alagando a un muchachoo a un caballo (C)
tzohtzon(a).Comment: C contrasts this with TZOTZON(A) "to strike s.t.,to play an instrument".

tzohuahcal-li.Comment: M has tzoacati meaning among other things for asquash to become damaged by mildew and tzoacatl, afruit so damaged.  The Z attestations lack anabsolutive suffix.  One attestation is spelled withmedial -HU-, the other without.

tzōlaqu(i).Comment: Only one of the attestations marks the vowel of thefirst syllable long.

tzōl-li.Comment: This is an element in a number of compounds with thesense "narrow".

tzōloā.Comment: This is indirectly attested in the sources for thisdictionary.  Although the vowel of the first syllableof this item is not marked long in the attestationsof TZOTZŌLOĀ, it is supported by the formsTLATZŌLIHUI, TLATZŌLCĀN "constricted place" andTZŌLTIC "s.t. narrow, constricted".

tzom(a).Spanish: coser algo, o cubrir de paja el bohio (M)
tzom(a).Comment: This verb is only attested in the sources for thisdictionary in derived forms.  M has it as a freeform, but in view of M's entries chpana.nitla for(I)CHPĀN(A) "to sweep s.t." and cuiloa.nitla for(I)HCUILOĀ "to write s.t.", M's tzoma.nitla mayrepresent (I)HTZOM(A).  On the other hand, thederived form TZOHTZOMAH-TLI implies TZOM(A).

tzom(i)-tl.Comment: TZOM(I)-TL is a variant of TZON-TLI.  The form of thesingle attestation is ambiguous between TZOM(I)-TLand TZON-TLI.  It is in the possessed constructionĪQUECHTETZON "his shawl, his neck protection".  Ifthere is semantic differentiation between TZOM(I)-TLand TZON-TLI "head of hair", then TZOM(I)-TL isslightly more appropriate.  Otherwise, this does notconstitute a genuine attestation of TZOM(I)-TL, asdistinct from TZON-TLI.

tzomoc.Spanish: cosa rota y rasgada, o persona soliŸcita y diligente,recia y fuerte (M for tzomoctic)
tzomoc.Comment: M has several compounds with TZOMOC as an elementwith the sense of working hard at something, scrapingaway at it.  TZOMOCNEM(I) has the sense of "to scrapealong in life".

tzomōn(i).Comment: X has this as a transitive verb.

tzompām(i)-tl.Comment: A common variant of this is TZOMPĀN-TLI.  The lengthof the vowel in the second syllable distinguishes itfrom tzompantli "skull rack", which is aconstruction of TZON-TLI and locative -PAN.

tzompīlihu(i).Spanish: tener romadizo (M), se pega el catarro, tiene catarro(T)

tzompol-li.English: plant that produces seeds used in making mole
tzompol-li.Spanish: chompola que da semillas para mole (T)

tzonāca-tl.Comment: This is peculiar to T; elsewhere it is TZINĀCAN-TLI.

tzoncayāhu(a).English: to muss one's hair; to groom s.o.
tzoncayāhu(a).Spanish: despeina el cabello (T), lo peina (al otro) (T)
tzoncayāhu(a).Comment: The senses of the reflexive and transitive uses ofthis verb appear to be opposite.

tzoncuēloā.English: for a snake or worm to coil

tzoncuep(a).English: to turn somersaults; to turn s.t. upside down

tzoncui.English: to avenge oneself, to take vengeance

tzonica-.Spanish: cabeza abajo (M from gloss for tzonicpilcac "tohang head down")
tzonica-.Comment: This element is abundantly attested in Z where thefinal vowel is marked long in twoattestations.  It appears in a number ofconstructions in M without the final vowel.

tzonicaihcatoc.Comment: M has tzonicquicac "to hang by the feet" withIHCA as the second element but without the verbO.
tzonicaihcatoc.Lexical Reference: see TZONICA-, IHCA, the verb O

tzonicaquep(a).Comment: One of the two attestations has a final -C.

tzonicaquetz(a).English: to turn s.t., s.o. upside down, to throw s.o. outheadlong
tzonicaquetz(a).Spanish: vaciar el caŸntaro de agua en la tinaja, o poner bocabajo la vasija, o volver maderos o cestos lo dearriba abajo, o echar a otro de cabeza en el agua odespen9arlo (M for tzonicquetza), echar a empujones aalguno de casa aunque le pese (M for tzonicquetza)

tzonicza.English: to tread on s.t., trample s.t.

tzonmācāuhtoc.Comment: In MĀCĀHU(A) Z has MAH for MĀ, but in the singleattestation of this item, the vowel is not markedlong or followed by a glottal stop either.
tzonmācāuhtoc.Lexical Reference: see TZON-TLI, MĀCĀHU(A), the verb O

tzonquīxtiā.English: to finish doing s.t. or to shave
tzonquīxtiā.Spanish: acabar de hacer o de concluir algo (M), rasura, seafeita (Z)

tzonquīz(a).English: for s.t. to conclude, end, or to grow hair
tzonquīz(a).Spanish: acabarse y concluirse la obra (M), nacerme el cabelloo el pelo, o fenecer la vida (M), ya se acaboŸ (C forpreterit)

tzontecom(a)-tl.Spanish: cabeza cortada y apartada del cuerpo (M), cabeza (C),craŸneo (T)
tzontecom(a)-tl.Comment: Z has an idiosyncratic possessed form -TZONTECOMATwhere the absolutive suffix appears to be present.  Zalso has another possessed form ending in -TECŌN,where the absolutive is not present, but the longvowel of the final syllable makes it appear to bederived from CŌM(I)-TL rather than COM(A)-TL.

tzontecomeh.Comment: For both C and R this is just one unglossed example in a listillustrating the possessor construction.  R hasN for M.

tzontecompanoā.English: to carry s.t. on one's head
tzontecompanoā.Comment: T has lost the final M of the first element.  Theexpected form of the second element would bePANŌLTIĀ from the verb PANŌ, which T haselsewhere.

tzontecontlapān(a).Spanish: yo te quiebro la cabeza (C for first pers. sg. subject)

tzontecontlapān(i).Spanish: tiene dolor de cabeza, punza la cabeza (T)

tzontequ(i).Comment: The attestation in B is partially illegible.  It appearsto be part of TLATZONTEC-TLI "judgement".

tzonte-tl.English: s.o. stubborn and defiant, a piece of s.t. thatsticks up
tzonte-tl.Spanish: rebelde y pertinaz (M), pedazo (T), hormiga arriera (X)
tzonte-tl.Comment: T and X have this compounded with CUAHU(I)-TL"tree" to mean "stump".  X also has this as thename of a type of ant.

tzontlam(i).Comment: This is attested in the phrase CĀMPA TZONTLAMI "end,terminus", literally "at the place where it ends".

-tzontlan.English: at the head of one's bed
-tzontlan.Spanish: a la cabecera de la cama (M)

tzon-tli.Comment: Z has TZŌN, while all other sourceshave a short vowel.  There is a variant TZOM(I)-TLrecorded in S of which there is a possible, butambiguous attestation in the sources for thisdictionary.   In compounds this sometimes hasthe sense of "hair" and sometimes the sense of"head".

tzontzapo-tl.English: a type of sapota with narcotic qualities (Lucumasalicifolia), a name also used for a member of theplum family

tzop(a).English: to finish weaving s.t., to finish constructings.t.
tzop(a).Spanish: acabar y concluir de tejer la tela o la boveda,el maderamiento de la casa, o cosa semejante (M)
tzop(a).Comment: This is implied by TZŌTZOPĀZ-TLI "weaver's reed".

tzop(i).English: for a piece of weaving or other construction toget finished

tzopēliā.Comment: This contrasts with intransitive TZOPĒLIY(A)"to become sweet".

tzopēlicxihu(i)-tl.English: verbena, a plant with fragrant leaves

tzopēliy(a).Comment: This contrasts with transitive TZOPĒLIĀ "tosweeten s.t."

tzopīlō-tl.Spanish: aura (M), zopilote, aŸguila (T), zopilote de cabezanegra (X)

tzopīniā.English: to prick, jab, puncture s.t. or s.o.
tzopīniā.Spanish: punzar, picar, o dar herronada (M), punzar a otroasiŸ (M)
tzopīniā.Comment: This is synonymous with CHOPĪNIĀ, both beingdescriptive of the puncturing action of beak, fangs,or talons.

tzopitiā.Comment: This seems to be a Z variant of TZOPĪNIĀ.  Z alsohas TZOPŌNIĀ, which M glosses as synonymous withTZOPĪNIĀ

tzopōniā.Spanish: punzar, picar, o dar herronada (M), punzar a otroasiŸ (M), lo pica (Z)

tzo-tl.Spanish: sudor espeso del cuerpo (M), sudor, suciedad,inmundicia (S)
tzo-tl.Comment: In the sources for this dictionary this is found onlyas an element of compounds, and with the sense of"foulness, rottenness", but M has it as a free form.

tzotzoca-tl.Spanish: verruga, o persona lacerada, apretada y escasa (M),mezquino, verruga, grano que no tiene pus (T)
tzotzoca-tl.Comment: There is a gender distinction in current Spanishverrugo "miser" and verruga "pimple".  The lattercan also be a disparaging term for a person.  T seemsto use TZOTZOCA-TL both ways.  M also hasunreduplicated tzocatl.

tzotzōltic.Comment: The vowel of the second syllable is not given long inany attestation, but it should be if TZOTZŌLOĀ iscorrect and if this is related to TZŌLTIC.

tzotzomahtatapah-tli.Comment: T has lost the glottal stop of the third syllableand possibly one from the initial syllable as well.

tzotzomahtiā.Comment: T may have lost a glottal stop from the intitial syllable.

tzotzomoca.Spanish: partirse, henderse, estallar, hablando de un objeto(S)
tzotzomoca.Comment: This is implied by TZOTZOMOTZ(A) and TZOMŌN(I).

tzotzomotz(a).English: to tear s.t. like cloth or paper
tzotzomotz(a).Comment: M has tzotzomoni, the reduplicated form ofTZOMŌN(I) with the same sense.

tzotzon(a).English: to strike s.o., to beat s.t., to play an instrument
tzotzon(a).Spanish: golpear algo, o tan9er instrumento (C), tan9eratabales, o oŸrganos, dar golpes o batir oro (M),apun9ear o dar golpe a otro (M), lo toca(un instrumento de muŸsica) (T)
tzotzon(a).Comment: C contrasts TZOTZON(A) with TZOHTZON(A) "to beats.t., s.o. with repeated blows.

tzotzoncuēloā.English: to wriggle, move in a serpentine manner
tzotzoncuēloā.Comment: This seems to be a reduplicated form of TZONCUĒLOĀ,but the N is missing from both attestations.

tzōtzopāz-tli.English: weaver's reed, stick to push down and tighten theweft
tzōtzopāz-tli.Spanish: palo ancho como cuchilla con que tupen y aprietan latela que se teje (M)
tzōtzopāz-tli.Comment: One of the two attestations in B has the vowel of thefirst syllable specifically marked short, but theother attestation in B has it marked long, as it isin T and Z.  This implies the verbs TZOP(A) "tofinish weaving s.t." and intransitive TZOP(I)"for a piece of weaving to get finished", bothof which are in M.

tzotzopoca.Comment: Z has CHOCHOPOCA with the sense of "to boilfuriously".

tzoyōn(i).English: to fry, for water to boil away
tzoyōn(i).Spanish: freiŸrse (M), se consume (el agua) por tanto hervir(T), se friŸe (T)

xacualoā.English: to rub, mash or grind s.t., to cook s.t.
xacualoā.Spanish: desgranar semillas o cosa semejante, estregaŸndolascon las manos, o sobar masa o cosa asiŸ (M), lofrota, lo friega, lo restriega, lo cocina (T)

xahcal-li.English: jacal, house of poles and thatch
xahcal-li.Spanish: choza, bohiŸo o casa de paja (M)

xahcalmōyō-tl.Comment: This literal meaning of this is "jacal-fly".

xahuān(i).English: for water or other liquid to fall in a mass
xahuān(i).Spanish: caer golpe de agua, u otras cosas liŸquidas (C)

xahuāniā.English: to empty out water or other liquids
xahuāniā.Comment: This is indirectly attested by XAHUĀN(I)

xāhuiā.Comment: This is probably from XĀNHUIĀ with loss of thesyllable-final N.

xālmōyō-tl.Comment: The literal meaning of this is "sand fly".

xālocuil-in.Spanish: gusano que come la can9a del maiŸz (T)

xālte-tl.Spanish: piedra arenosa (para filar), poma (T), su molleja(Z for possessed form), piedra poma (Z)

xāltohtopoca.English: for s.t. to be crunchy, to have sand in it
xāltohtopoca.Spanish: estaŸ arenoso, tiene arena (p.ej. una comida) (T)
xāltohtopoca.Comment: This attested form implies *TOHTOPOCA, but theregular form associated with TOPŌN(I) is TOTOPOCAwith no glottal stop.  TOPŌN(I), TOTOPOCA, andassociated forms all involve crunchiness.

xāltoma-tl.Comment: The literal meaning of this is "sand tomato".

xālxoco-tl.Comment: X has lost the internal L.  The literal meaning ofthis is "sand fruit".

xamān(i).English: for certain brittle things to break
xamān(i).Spanish: quebrarse huevos, tecomates, guitarras, etc., y nocosas de barro (C)

xamāniā.Comment: This is not directly attested but is implied byXAMĀN(I) and TLAXAMĀNĪL-LI.
xamāniā.English: to crack, break s.o.'s head or a gourd vessel
xamāniā.Spanish: cascar o quebrantar cabeza o vaso de jical (M)

xāncotoc-tli.Spanish: pedazo de adobe o de tabique (T)

xaxahuaca.English: for water or other liquid to fall in great quantity

xaxahuatz(a).English: to cause water or other liquid to fall in greatquantity
xaxahuatz(a).Spanish: hacerlas caer de esta manera (C referring to XAXAHUACA)

xaxaltic.English: s.t. loosely or thinly interwoven, as inopen-textured weaving
xaxaltic.Spanish: cosa rala, asiŸ como manta, estera, o cosa semejante(M), tejido abierto (de tela, ayate, etc.) (T)

xaxamaca.English: for numbers of certain brittle things to breaknoisily
xaxamaca.Spanish: quebrarse muchas de estas cosas (huevos, tecomates,guitarras, etc., y no cosas de barro) con ruido (C)

xaxamatz(a).English: to break certain brittle things into pieces; to routeone's enemies, inflicting great casualties
xaxamatz(a).Spanish: quebrar y hacer pedazos estas cosas (huevos,tecomates, guitarras, etc.) (C), hacer pedazos a losenemigos, haciendo gran estrago en ellos (M)

xāyac(a)-tl.Spanish: cara o rostro, caraŸtula o maŸscara (M)
xāyac(a)-tl.Comment: Z has the variant XĀYAC-TLI, while X has areduplicated form with the same sense.  When -TZIN isadded to this reduplicated form in X, it is used tomean "horsefly".

xāyacaxolochahu(i).English: to have a wrinkled face, to frown

xehxeloā.English: to divide s.t. up into portions
xehxeloā.Spanish: repartir, dividir, o partir en partes (M)
xehxeloā.Comment: C contrasts this with XEHXĒLOĀ, the correspondingreduplicated form of XĒLOĀ "to scatter s.t."

xehxēloā.English: to scatter s.t. in various different directions andinto different piles
xehxēloā.Spanish: extiendo (el maiŸz) en varias partes, y de variosmontones (C)
xehxēloā.Comment: C contrasts this with XEHXELOĀ, the correspondingreduplicated form of XELOĀ "to divide s.t."

xelhuāz-tli.Comment: Z has XIL for XEL, and X has XĀL.  The vowel ofinstrumental -(HU)ĀZ-TLI is long, as Z and X haveit, but T has it short in this item.

xelhuiā.English: to divide s.t. with s.o., to relieve s.o. by takingpart of his burden
xelhuiā.Spanish: partir con otro alguna cosa, o aliviar quitando partede la carga o del tributo (M)

xēlhuiā.English: to tousle s.o.'s hair, to rake grass for s.o., toscatter s.t. for s.o.
xēlhuiā.Spanish: le abre (el cabello, la yerba, etc.), lo derrama(como gallina el maiŸz) (T)

xeliuhtoc.Comment: X has this glossed as "s.t. empty".

xeloā.Comment: This contrasts with XĒLOĀ "to scatter s.t."  Theyare easily confused because of the proximity of theirsenses.

xēloā.English: to scatter s.t., to spread s.t. out
xēloā.Spanish: extender algo, como maiŸz o trigo en paja, para quese seque (C)
xēloā.Comment: This contrasts with XELOĀ "to divide s.t."  They areeasily confused because of the proximity of theirsenses.

*xēlōlō.Comment: This is not attested in the sources for thisdictionary but is predicted by general rule.  Itcontrasts with XELŌLŌ, the nonactive form of XELOĀ

xeltic.English: change from currency of a larger denomination

xēxeloā.English: to slice s.t., to carve s.t. up
xēxeloā.Comment: C contrasts XĒXELOĀ "to slice s.t." and XEHXELOĀ"to divide s.t. up into discrete portions".  This isone of the clearest contrastive uses of long-vowelreduplication versus vowel-glottal stopreduplication.  C also contrasts XĒXELOĀ withXĒXĒLOĀ, the corresponding reduplicated form ofthe verb XĒLOĀ "to scatter s.t."

xēxēloā.English: to scatter s.t. or to spread s.t. out continuouslyin a single direction
xēxēloā.Spanish: extiendo (el maiŸz) continuadamente en una parte (C),desparramar paja maiŸz (C)
xēxēloā.Comment: C contrasts XĒXĒLOĀ "to scatter, spread things inone continuous direction" with XEHXĒLOĀ "toscatter, spread s.t. in several directions".  Thisis one of the clearest contrastive uses of long-vowelreduplication versus vowel-glottal stopreduplication.  XĒXĒLOĀ also contrasts withXĒXELOĀ, the corresponding reduplicated form of theverb XELOĀ "to divide s.t."

xīcalēhu(i).English: for s.t. to be peeled, shelled

xīcal-li.Spanish: vaso de calabaza (M), recipiente para guardartortillas (Z)

xīcaltic.Spanish: calvo, peloŸn, cabeza de jiŸcara (T), desnudo (Z)

xīcama-tl.English: jicama, a type of edible root (Pachyrhizus angulatus)
xīcama-tl.Spanish: cierta raiŸz que se come cruda y es muy dulce (M)
xīcama-tl.Comment: M gives this both with an absolutive suffix andwithout.  The T attestation is without.

xiccāhu(a).English: to be neglectful of oneself, to lose out through neglect,not to take oneself seriously; to abandon s.o. indisgust, to lose s.t. through neglect
xiccāhu(a).Spanish: perder algo por descuido y negligencia, o no curar desu persona, o no hacer cuenta de siŸ (M), desamparara otro con desdeŸn y enojo, perder algo por su culpay negligencia (M)

xīcoā.English: to feel envy; to suffer, endure s.t., to deceive s.o.
xīcoā.Spanish: tener envidia o enojo, o agraviarse de algo (M), loaguanta, lo soporta (T), engan9ar o burlar a otro (M)

xīcohcuitlapīloā.Spanish: del sastre o zapatero, que encera el hilo, se dice(C)

xīcoh-tli.Spanish: abeja grande de miel que horada los aŸrboles, oabejoŸn (M), abejorro, abejarroŸn (Z)

xīcōl.Spanish: es desconsiderado, uno que no quiere hacer un favor,egoiŸsta (T)
xīcōl.Comment: This is not attested with an absolutive suffix.

xīctiā.English: to hold s.o. in low esteem, to make bold with s.o.
xīctiā.Spanish: tenerme otro en poco, o atreveŸrseme (M for firstpers. sg. object)

xīc-tli.Spanish: ombligo o bruŸjula para tirar derecho (M)

xihu(i)-tl.Comment: XIHU(I)-TL in its "turquoise" sense sometimes appearsas TEŌXIHU(I)-TL, but the simple form XIUH is usedin compounds to convey the sense of greenness.  Italso serves as a modifier for heat, indicatingintensity, as white and blue do in English.According to C, this item differs from XIHU(I)-TL"year" in that it forms the abstract derivationXIUHYŌ-TL, while the "year" item is associated withthe abstract form -XIUHCAYŌ-TL (which is alwaysprefixed with a number).  M combines both in asingle entry with XĪHU(I)-TL "comet".

xīhu(i)-tl.Comment: C and R contrast XĪHU(I)-TL with XIHU(I)-TL "grass;turquoise; year".  M combines them in a single entry.

xihxicuin.English: glutton, big eater or self-centered person

xihxicuinoā.Comment: B does not attest the glottal stop, but C does in therelated noun XIHXICUINYŌ-TL "gluttony".

xihxicuinyō-tl.Comment: M lacks the final N of CUIN.

xihxil(i).English: to trample s.t., to tamp s.t. down
xihxil(i).Spanish: pisar con pisoŸn, o henchir recalcando (M)

xihxipintic.Comment: All attestations have a long vowel in the thirdsyllable, but see the note under XIPIN-TLI.

xillānpīqu(i).English: to tuck s.t. away in one's bosom

xillān-tli.Comment: There is disagreement across sources on vowel-lengthpatterning for this item.  It is attested twice in B,both times with the vowel of the second syllablemarked long, once with the first vowel specificallymarked short.  C follows suit once in marking thevowel of the second syllable long but in four otherattestations leaves both vowels of the stem unmarked.T consistently has the reflex of a long vowel in thefirst syllable and a short vowel in the second,XĪLLAN-TLI.  If the second element is the postposition-TLAN "beneath", the A should be short.

xīlō-tl.English: tender ear of green maize before it solidifies
xīlō-tl.Spanish: mazorca de maiŸz tierna y por cuajar (M)
xīlō-tl.Comment: This contrasts with ĒLŌ-TL, which is the ear afterthe kernels form.

xīlōtzon-tli.Spanish: raspa de espiga (M), cabello de elote (T)
xīlōtzon-tli.Comment: T and X have the variant form XĪLŌMOTZON-TLI.

xīlōxōchi-tl.Spanish: ciertas flores grandes y hermosas formadas de hilos oestambres semejantes a las garzotas de vidrio (R),$pochote)
xīlōxōchi-tl.Comment: This appears in R without diacritics, but the componentparts are elsewhere attested with them.

xīm(a).English: to smooth, shave, plane wood or stone; to docarpentry

ximmīl-li.Comment: The first element of this is probably XIHU(I)-TL"grass" with assimilation of UH to M.

xīmōhuayān.English: place of the dead, realm where the human body isshaved free of flesh

xīniā.Comment: M has xini "to fall down", and S has that and alsoxinia "to knock down, demolish, unravel s.t.".This is possibly the same verb by some extremeextension of meaning.  The verbs in M and S aresynonymous with XITĪN(I) and XITĪNIĀ.

*xīp-.Comment: This is an element in numerous compounds andderivations and refers to peeling, flaying, shaving,etc.  It appears to have a variant form *XĪ-in some words.

xīpēhu(a).Spanish: desollar, o descortezar, o mondar habas, etc. (M)

xīpēhu(i).English: for s.t. to peel, to come off

xīpetzoā.English: to strip; to take off clothes
xīpetzoā.Spanish: se desviste, se quita la ropa, se desnuda (T), loencuera, lo desviste (T)

xipinquetz(a).English: to break out in pimples, pumps

xipintic.Comment: In one attestation the vowels of the second and thirdsyllables are marked long.  In the other none of thevowels are so marked.

xipin-tli.Comment: This is only attested in compounds and derived forms,all sharing the sense of "bump, protrusion".  Theattestations are divided between marking the vowelsof the first and second syllables long or leavingthem unmarked.  The most common pattern is with ashort vowel in the first syllable and a long vowel inthe second.

xipipi.Comment: In one of the attestations the vowel of the firstsyllable is marked long, and in the other it is not.

xiquipil-li.Comment: This is used symbolically in the vigesimal countingsystem to represent the unit "eight thousand".

xitīn(i).English: for s.t. to collapse (of a concrete object or anagreement)
xitīn(i).Spanish: caerse o deshacerse la pared o sierra, o cosasemejante, o desbaratarse la gente (M)
xitīn(i).Comment: M has a typographical error and gives xitmi forxitini.  XITĪN(I) implies that M's xitinia "toknock down a wall, abrogate an agreement, etc." isXITĪNIĀ.

xitīniā.English: to knock down a wall, to destroy s.t., to decimatethe encampment of one's enemies
xitīniā.Spanish: derrocar o deshacer pared, etc., o destruir algo (M),desbaratar real de enemigos (M)
xitīniā.Comment: This is indirectly attested in the sources for thisdictionary.

xītom(a).English: to scrape s.t., to remove the skin of s.t.
xītom(a).Comment: This appears to be synonymous with XĪPĒHU(A).

xītoma-tl.English: large red or yellow tomato (as contrasted with thegreen husk tomato)
xītoma-tl.Spanish: tomates grandes colorados, amarillos, y blancos (M),jitomate (T)

xitōniā.Spanish: lo desenvuelve, lo descompone, lo desbarata (T)

xittomōn(i).English: to make a sound on bursting; to form a blister
xittomōn(i).Spanish: reventando sonar (M), se ampolla (T in constructionwith "hand")
xittomōn(i).Comment: This is attested in the sources for this dictionaryonly in the compound MĀXITTOMŌN(I).  Thecorresponding transitive verb in M would beXITTOMŌNIĀ

xittomōniā.English: to make an explosive sound; to cause s.t. to make anexplosive sound
xittomōniā.Spanish: hacer rueda el gallo de la tierra, etc. (M), hacersonar algo reventando (M)
xittomōniā.Comment: This is indirectly attested by XITTOMŌN(I).  Mattests the unusual medial TT.

xiuhcāhuāl-li.Comment: One of the attestations has the vowel-length valuesreversed.

xiuhcal-li.Comment: One of the attestations has the vowel of the firstsyllable marked long.

-xiuhcayō-tl.English: a matter of a certain number of years

xiuheh.English: to be of a certain age
xiuheh.Comment: The literal sense is "possessor of years".  Z hasan intrusive Y before the possessor suffix -EH.

xiuhmātēca.English: to pull up plants, to clear ground

xiuhocuil-in.Comment: The literal meaning of this is "grass-worm".

-xiuhtiā.Grammar: necessarily prefixed with a number, the whole acts asan intransitive verb
-xiuhtiā.English: to attain a certain age (number of years)
-xiuhtiā.Spanish: debiŸa yo de tener hasta diez an9os (C for firstpers. sg. subject imperfect with the number ten prefixedto the verb)

xiuhtic.Comment: In one of the attestations the vowel of the firstsyllable is marked long.

xiuhtlatiā.English: to tire, to get impatient; to irritate s.o.
xiuhtlatiā.Spanish: enfadarse o cansarse (M), enfadar a otro conimportunidades (M)

xiuhtlatla.English: to be hot, to be burning with hunger

xiuhyō-tl.Comment: This is from XIHU(I)-TL "grass" and contrasts withthe abstract derivation from XIHU(I)-TL "year", whichis -XIUHCAYŌ-TL.

xiuhzālōliz-tli.English: the art of mosaic work, sticking together greenstones

xīx(a).Spanish: proveerse o hacer caŸmara (M), cagar (M), orina (T)
xīx(a).Comment: When this is compounded with Ā-TL "water", it stillcan mean to defecate as well as to urinate.

xixīcoā.English: to deceive s.o., win out over s.o., to defeat s.o.
xixīcoā.Spanish: enganar y burlar a otro (M), le gana, le persuade, lovence (T)

xixihcuepōn(i).English: to blister, break out in sores

xixitica.English: for all of something (such as a wall) to crumble,come apart
xixitica.Spanish: desmoronarse, o deshacerse alguna cosa (M), cuando sedesmorona y desbarata todo (C)

xixititz(a).English: to cause all of something (such as a wall) to crumble

xixittomōn(i).English: to blister, to break out in sores
xixittomōn(i).Comment: M has xittomonalli "blister".  M also hasxittomoni with the sense of "to make an explosivenoise".

xixīx(a).Comment: In both attestations the vowel of the first syllableis short.

*xo-.English: element with the sense "foot" in many compounds
*xo-.Comment: This is an element of XOCPAL-LI and XOPIL-LI.  Thereare many XO- compounds in M.

*xō-.English: element with the sense "green" in many compounds; seeXŌPAN, XŌTLA, etc.  XOXOCTIC also contains a XOelement and the sense "green" but has a short ratherthan a long vowel.

xocatetlāliā.English: to swell, for a raised swelling to form
xocatetlāliā.Spanish: se hincha (en forma de bola -- como el piquete deabeja) (T)
xocatetlāliā.Comment: Despite the different vowel in the second syllable,this may be related to XOCOTETIC "s.t. with a round shape".

xōchiaquiā.Comment: There is no attested gloss of this, but it isparallel to M's quauhaquia "to plant trees".

xōchicuauhtōpīl-li.Spanish: cruz floreada (que usan en el casamiento) (T)

xōchicuepōn(i).English: to bloom in the manner of a flower

xōchihcual-li.Comment: In C and Z this is abundantly attested andconsistently with a glottal stop between the twocomponent elements.  In T it is attested only onceand without the glottal stop, but the loss ofinternal glottal stops is characteristic of T.  Thespecific sense "banana" is common to Z and Nahuatl ofthe Huasteca, areas where bananas are intensivelycultivated.

-xōchihcuallō.English: the crop of fruit (of a tree)

xōchipehpen(a).English: to gather s.t. as one would gather flowers.
xōchipehpen(a).Spanish: busco y escojo (algo) como las rosas (C)
xōchipehpen(a).Comment: See the discussion under XŌCHIPEHPEN(A) withincorporated object.

xōchipoloā.Comment: M has the variant xochpoloa.  In this constructionXŌCHI has the extended sense of "s.t. precious,delicate" rather than its literal sense of "flower".

xōchitēmoā.English: to seek s.t. as one seeks flowers
xōchitēmoā.Spanish: busco y escojo (algo) como flores (C for first pers.sg. subject)
xōchitēmoā.Comment: See the discussion under XŌCHITĒMOĀ withincorporated object.

xōchitiā.English: to utter witticisms and bons mots; to make peoplelaugh
xōchitiā.Spanish: decir gracias o donaires para hacer reir (M)
xōchitiā.Comment: M has the variant xochtia.  XŌCHI here has ametaphorical sense of s.t. delicate, precious ratherthan its literal sense.

xōchi-tl.Comment: As a modifier this has the sense "s.t. precious,delicate".  It is also conventionally paired withCUĪCA-TL "song" to refer to poetry.

xōchitlah.Comment: M also gives the reduplicated form of this, XOHXŌCHITLAH,with the same gloss.

xōchiyoā.Comment: It is not clear whether this is the general form or aT variant.  In T the preterit is formed regularlyafter the pattern of -OĀ verbs, but the Z formsuggests it may be a -HUA verb forming the preteritas -HUAC.  In this case, one would expect thestem-final O to be long.  M gives the verb once asxochyoua and once as xuchioa with no preteritform.

xōchiyōtiā.Spanish: enrosar o adornar algo con flores (M)

xōchiyō-tl.English: the essence or being of flowers, matters having to dowith flowers

xōcoā.English: to hurl s.t. or s.o. down in scorn
xōcoā.Spanish: echar por ahiŸ a otro con menosprecio (M)
xōcoā.Comment: This is indirectly attested inXŌCŌLTITOC "bruised" and XŌCŌLIĀ "to damages.t."

xocoātōl-li.Spanish: atole de ciruela (T), atole agrio que beben en TodosSantos (Z)

xococ.Comment: In both attestations in Z the vowel of the secondsyllable is marked long, but it is short in T.

xōcōltitoc.Comment: Z does not mark the vowels of the first two syllableslong.

xocopaltic.Comment: In one of the attestations the vowel of the secondsyllable is marked long, and the other is not.

xocotetic.English: s.t. with a round shape, s.t. shaped like a plum

xocote-tl.Spanish: fruta muy verde y por sazonar (M), ciruela (T)

xoco-tl.Comment: This appears to be used as a more generic term forfruit, while XOCOTE-TL is specifically "plum".Most derivations from XOCO-TL have to do withsourness, unripeness, or immaturity.

xocoya.English: for s.t. to sour, ferment, spoil
xocoya.Spanish: acedarse o avinagrarse (M), fermenta, agria, se echaa perder (comida) (T)

xōcoyō-tl.Spanish: hijo o hija menor o postrera (M)
xōcoyō-tl.Comment: This frequently occurs as a possessed plural,NOXŌCOYŌHUĀNE "my children" (vocative) meaningliterally "my youngest children".

xocpal-li.Comment: In T this is used as the name of a red wasp.

xoc-tli.Comment: Z glosses this as "babosa, caracol", "slug, snail".This may be the same item in some extended sense, orit may be a loan extension involving XONAC(A)-TL,since Spanish babosa has both the sense of "slug"and of "green onion".

xohuil-in.Spanish: pescado de a palmo que parece trucha (M), badre,bagre (X)

xohxōchitlah.Comment: This is the distributive of XŌCHITLAH, which has thesame sense.

xōicpōxihu(i)-tl.Comment: the XŌ- here probably has the same "green" sense ithas in XŌTLA "to bud", XŌPANTLAH "green time of theyear", etc.  The second element may be derivedfrom (I)CPOĀ "to reseed s.t."

xolāhu(a).English: to slip; to make s.t. slip

xolēhu(a).English: to get skinned up by a blow; to peel s.t.
xolēhu(a).Spanish: rozarse o desollarse con golpe (M), lo pela (T)

xōlēpitzāhuac.English: a type of mushroom that is long and thin in shape

xoloā.English: to slip; to make s.t. slip

xolopihti.English: to be foolish, to joke and lie like a fool

xōlō-tl.Comment: This has the same form as the second element ofĀXŌLŌ-TL "edible salamander" and HUEHXŌLŌ-TL"turkey cock", but there is no obvious connection insense.  It is distinct in vowel-length patterningfrom the first two syllables of XOLOPIH-TLI "fool".

xōmil-in.Comment: T has variants XOHMIL-IN and XOMIL-IN.

xonacapilōl-li.English: small pitcher with handle for hanging
xonacapilōl-li.Spanish: cantarito que se cuelga de su propia oreja (T)

xonac(a)-tl.Comment: This invites analysis into XO- "foot" and NAC(A)-TL"flesh".

xonecuil-li.English: staff used in offerings; a type of cactus
xonecuil-li.Spanish: palo como bordoŸn con muescas que ofreciŸan a losiŸdolos (M), nopal de monte (flor) (Z)

xōpantlah.English: green time of the year, rainy season, summer
xōpantlah.Spanish: temporal, temporada, tiempo de las aguas, las aguas(T)

xopepe.Comment: The shape of this item suggests it is a loanword, butZ also has XIPIPI "wart, pimple", which does appearto be of native lexical stock.

xopilcui.Comment: The literal sense of this seems to be "to take withone's toes".  The Spanish gloss is a euphemism forengaging in intercourse, and M has a reduplicatedform of the verb CUI with that sense.  This may beyet another euphemism.

xopitza.Comment: M has xopitzactli "shank", literally "thin leg".Possibly this refers to a mushroom that has a long,slender stalk.

xōtla.English: to burn, to catch fire, to run a fever; for flowersto burst into bloom
xōtla.Spanish: abrasarse la tierra, o encenderse los carbones obrotar las flores (M), tener gran calentura (M)
xōtla.Comment: Nahuatl also associates blooming with giving offa glow or exploding in CUEPŌN(I).

-xōtlaca.Comment: M has xotlac "flowers already full blown, open".

xōtlaltiā.English: to burn s.t., to set fire to s.t.
xōtlaltiā.Spanish: encender carbones (M), lo quema, lo enciende, loprende (T)

xōx(a).English: to give s.o. the evil eye, to bewitch s.o.
xōx(a).Spanish: aojar o hechizar o ojear a otro (M)

xoxoctic.Spanish: cosa verde o descolorida por enfermedad, o cosa cruda(M), verde, azul (T), verde (no maduro) (T)
xoxoctic.Comment: Although the vowels of the first two syllables hereare short, this is related to other constructionsinvolving XŌ- with a sense of "green".

xoxōhuic.Comment: X has the variant form XOXŌUHQUI.

xoxōhuiya.Spanish: pararse verdinegro de enfermedad, o descolorido, opararse algo verde (M)
xoxōhuiya.Comment: In both attestations C specifically marks the vowelof the first syllable short and that of the secondsyllable long.

xoxōtlani.Comment: X has MĒTZ for NI and adds final -TZIN.

ya.Comment: This is a variant of YE "already".

yā.Grammar: suppletive verb; sing. pres: YAUH; pret: YAH
yā.Comment: This verb is suppletive with HU(I).  In the dialectson which classical grammars were based, HU(I) is usedfor the present plural, the imperfect, the optativeplural and the nonactive.  It is also an element ofthe present progressive construction -TI-HU(I).  Thereare variant forms of the imperfect and the nonactivebased on YĀ.  YĀ and HU(I), which are elsewheresuppletive, are compounded for the present tensesingular, and many dialects have some reflex of YĀand HU(I) in the present plural as well.  Wheneverthey are compounded, the vowel of YĀ is shortened.The paradigm of YĀ is otherwise regular in thepattern of verbs that alternate a long final vowelwith vowel plus glottal stop.

yacacuep(a).Spanish: da media vuelta y regresa (T), le cambia ladireccioŸn en que va (T)

yacamomoyoca.Spanish: le hace cosquillas en la nariz (T)

yacān(a).English: to govern s.o., to lead s.o.
yacān(a).Spanish: guiar a otro, o gobernar pueblo, o adiestrar al ciego(M)

yacapantlatqui-tl.English: estate of the eldest, entailed estate

yacapan-tli.Comment: This appears in C only as an element of two compounds.T only has it prefixed with TĒ-, but M has it bothwithout the prefix and as tiacapan with the vowelof TĒ- reduced.

yacapīloā.English: to draw s.t. out into a point
yacapīloā.Spanish: le adelgazo la punta, torcieŸndole (C referring tothreading a needle)

yacapitztic.Comment: M has yacapitzauac "s.t. slender".  Z hasinconsistency of vowel length marking betweenattestations, but all vowels should be short.

yacapitz-tli.Comment: This is only attested in alternative possessed formswithout the absolutive suffix.

yac(a)-tl.Comment: T and X have YE for YA.

yacatzacu(a).English: for one's nose to get obstructed; to obstruct s.o.'snose
yacatzacu(a).Spanish: se le tapan las narices (T), le tapa la nariz (T)

yacatzōlcoyoc.Comment: In one attestation no vowels are marked long, and inthe other the vowels of the first and fourthsyllables are marked long.

yacatzōl-li.Comment: If the second element of this is TZŌL-LI "s.t.narrow", then the vowel should be long, as it is inX, but it is abundantly attested with the reflex of ashort vowel in T and inconsistently attested in Z.

yacaxolochoā.English: to wrinkle one's nose; to crease s.o.'s nose
yacaxolochoā.Spanish: arruga la nariz (T); le arruga la nariz (T)

yacaztemohmolōniā.English: to hit one's nose so that one has a nosebleed
yacaztemohmolōniā.Spanish: se trompea, se golpea en las narices y sale sangre(T)

yahualoā.English: to go around s.t., to go in procession
yahualoā.Spanish: cercar a otros, o irse a quejar primero que otros(M), andar en procesioŸn o alrededor, o rodear (M)
yahualoā.Comment: T has the variant YEHUALOĀ and Z YOHUALOĀ, but Cagrees with M on YAHUALOĀ (f.95r).  In the 1892reprinting of C, however, the attestation is printedwith e rather than a.  R has a reduplicated formYAHYAHUALOĀ.  R also has alternative causativesformed with -LTIĀ and -CHTIĀ but does notindicate the vowel length of the vowel precedingthem.

yahualtiā.Spanish: lo pone alrededor de la base de una cosa (T forTZĪNYAHUALTIĀ)

yahualtic.Spanish: cosa redonda como luna o rodela (M)
yahualtic.Comment: Z has YO for YA, while T has YE.

yahui.English: s.o. who has been on a long journey
yahui.Spanish: peregrino de largo tiempo (M), "va (de ir), viaja,asiste (Z)
yahui.Comment: YA and HU(I) "to go" are generally suppletive.  Herethere seems to be a compound of the two.  In Z it isglossed as a verb, but M glosses it as a nominal.Z has O for A.

yāhui-tl.English: a type of maize with dark-colored kernels
yāhui-tl.Spanish: maiŸz moreno o negro (M), maiŸz azul (Z)
yāhui-tl.Comment: T has the reduplicated form YĀYĀHUI-TL

yahyā.Comment: C uses this as an example of reduplication with adistributive sense; inchachan Ōya

yamāncāyō-tl.Spanish: blandura, y per metaphoram quiere decir riqueza yprosperidad (M)

yamāniā.Spanish: ablandar o adobar cueros, o entibiar lo que estaŸ muycaliente, o ablandar cera o cosa semejante al fuego(M)
yamāniā.Comment: This is indirectly attested by the applicative formYAMĀNILIĀ.  T has YE for YA.

yamāniliā.English: for s.t. to soften; to soften s.t.
yamāniliā.Spanish: se ablanda, se suaviza (T), amollentar algo, o entibiarlo (M)

yamāniy(a).English: for one's body to be neither warm nor cold; for s.t.to soften, become smooth
yamāniy(a).Spanish: estar templado el cuerpo (M), se ablanda, se suaviza(T)

yamānqui.Comment: T has YE for YA.  Z has a variant form YEMĀNIC.

-yān.English: place where s.t. is habitually done
-yān.Spanish: el lugar y a veces el tiempo donde uno ejercita laaccioŸn del verbo (C)
-yān.Comment: This suffixed element occurs in many setconstructions with extended senses of place andduration.  C analyzes it into suffixal -N added todeverbal instrumental nouns ending in -YĀ (f.50r).These nouns are otherwise identical in form withimperfects, and this in turn suggests that theimperfect suffix is -YĀ with a long vowel, althoughthe vowel is shortened in the singular imperfect byvirtue of being word-final and in the plural becauseit precedes a glottal stop.

yancuiy(a).English: for s.t. to be renovated, restored

yāōnāmiqu(i).Spanish: les saldremos al encuentro de pelea (C for firstpers. plural subject)

yāō-tl.Comment: In compounds YĀŌ also means "war, battle", but asa free form "war" is YĀŌYŌ-TL, contrasting withYĀŌ-TL "enemy".

yāōtla.Comment: C gives as one example a reduplicated form used whenmany are involved in the fighting or by children atplay when there are two opposing sidesmoyayĀŌtla.

yāōxōchi-tl.Comment: In one set of attestations X fails to mark the vowelof the first syllable long, but it is so markedelsewhere in X.  The literal meaning of this is"enemy flower" or "war flower".

yāōyō-tl.Comment: In compounds this drops the -YŌ and appears simplyas YĀŌ.

yayāctic.Comment: This is probably related to (I)HYĀYA "to stink"and -IHYĀCA "the stench of s.t."

yāyatihu(i).English: to walk, go along a bit at a time
yāyatihu(i).Spanish: andar o ir andando poco a poco (M)
yāyatihu(i).Comment: In one of the two attestations the vowel of thethird syllable is marked long as though this wereformed with purposive -TĪHU(I).

ye.Comment: This particle combines with many other particles,sometimes written solid and sometimes spaced apart.Among these combinations where YE is initial are YECUĒL "already, soon", YE IMMAN "a while ago", YE IUH(often written yeyuh) "afterwards", YE NECHCA"formerly", YE NĒPA "formerly", YE HUEHCĀUH "on theother side", YE ĪC "ready".

yecāhuiā.English: for s.t. to be rinsed out, dried
yecāhuiā.Comment: Diphthongization of Ē and initial glide-formationleads to an ambiguity in T.  The single attestationmay have a reflex of a long vowel in the initialsyllable.

yecapaxihu(i)-tl.Comment: The name of this fragrant flower may be derived fromYAC(A)-TL "nose" or -IHYĀCA "the stench of s.t."  Anothername in T for the same tree is IHYĀCXIHU(I)-TL.

yecapixtlān.Comment: The name of this town is spelled in many differentways in Nahuatl and Spanish sources.  It is possiblyderived from YAC(A)-TL "nose, point, ridge" andPIY(A) "to have", but it is not certain.  Such aderivation would be consistent with T's consistent YEfor YA, but in the single attestation T drops thefirst syllable altogether.

yēccān.Spanish: lugar bueno y abrigado (M), a buen tiempo (M)

yēcchīhu(a).English: for s.t. to set itself aright, to be in good order;to order, arrange, correct s.t.
yēcchīhu(a).Spanish: se arreglar, se compone, se corrige (T), lo arregla,lo compone, lo corrige, lo repara (T)
yēcchīhu(a).Comment: M has the reduplicated form yecchichiua "to adorn,bedeck".

yēccuauhneloā.English: for s.t. to be beaten or scrambled well

yēccuēchoā.English: to grind s.t. a second time, to grind s.t. veryfine

yēceh.Comment: In C this is attested equally often with the vowel ofthe first syllable marked long and unmarked.Considering C's tendency to omit vowel-length markingin frequently used words when they are not central tothe example, YĒCEH is probably correct.

yēchuicxitiā.Spanish: lo coce bien, lo cocina bien (T)

-yēcmācopa.English: to or on one's right-hand side

yēcmelāhuac.Comment: Z characteristically lacks the final -C, as it doesin several other similar items.  Z also has fourattestations of YĒC MELĀN with the same sense(p.28,114,128,230) with -N replacing -HUAC.

yēcnem(i).Spanish: vives bien (C for second pers. sg. subject), honrado (Z)
yēcnem(i).Comment: M has derivations from YĒCNEM(I) but not the verbitself.  Z treats this as a substantive "s.o.honorable".

yēcnōtz(a).English: for s.t. to be said respectfully; to speak to s.o.properly, respectfully

yecō.Comment: The long final vowel is not attested and ishypothesized here on the pattern of other verbs suchas TEMŌ "to descend".

yecoā.English: to taste, sample food or drink; to copulate with s.o.
yecoā.Spanish: probar el manjar (M), hacerlo a eŸl o a ella (M)
yecoā.Comment: M has the "taste" gloss of YECOĀ combined with thegloss of YĒCOĀ "to conclude s.t." in a singleentry.  C points out that the "taste" sense of YECOĀis generally expressed with the reduplicated form ofthe verb YEHYECOĀ (f.127r).

yēcoā.Comment: M combines this with YECOĀ "to sample food ordrink" in a single entry.

yēcohmacaliz-tli.Comment: The literal sense of this is "good road-giving".

yēcpiy(a).English: to take good care of s.t.

yēcquīz(a).Spanish: si ... tengamos buena cosecha (C in phrase referringto crops)

yectel.Spanish: diŸas ha (M for hace diŸas), los diŸas pasados (C),el otro diŸa (C)
yectel.Comment: Although this would appear to be a compound ofYĒC-TLI and TĒL, the vowels are unmarked for lengthin all attestations.

yecteltlamatqui.Comment: If the vowel length pattern is correct, this has theliteral sense of "knower of the things of old", but Zin one attestation marks the vowel of the firstsyllable long and in the other the vowels of thefirst and second syllables long.  Z also hasQUITĒLMATI "s.o. competent", and this may interactwith YĒC-TLI "s.t. good, pure, clean" in someway.

yēctēmiā.Spanish: lo llena bien, lo empaca bien lleno (T)

yēctēnēhu(a).Spanish: alabar a otro (M), alabar alguna cosa (M)

yēctēnēhualizpan.Comment: This seems to be a locative despite itsgloss in T.

yēctlāliā.English: to arrange, prepare, order oneself, s.o., s.t.
yēctlāliā.Spanish: se compone, se prepara, se arregla, se corrige, semejora (T), lo compone, lo prepara, lo arregla, locorrige, lo mejora, lo repara (T), guarda (Z)

yēctlamachiliz-tli.Comment: In both attestations Z marks the vowel of CHI long,but it should be short.

yēctlamatcāyetōliz-tli.Comment: The element YETŌLIZ appears to be equivalent to M'syeliztli "state of being".  M has the constructiontlamatcayeliztli "peace and quiet".
yēctlamatcāyetōliz-tli.Lexical Reference: see YĒC-TLI, TLAMATCĀ, the verb YE

yēctlapaltiliā.English: to get soaked; to soak s.t.

yēctzicaticah.English: for s.t. to be secure, permanent

yecuēl.Comment: This is more often written as two words.

yēcxacualihu(i).English: to cook through, to become well-cooked

(y)eh.Comment: This particle has alternate forms YEH = EH (Cf.88r)and is a constituent of several types ofconstruction.  As a free element it serves as aminimal third person pronoun and as a grammaticalreferent standing for a whole proposition (as it,what, and that do in various Englishconstructions).  This same particle seems to be aconstituent of the Nahuatl pronominal system, NEH,NEHHUĀ-TL, etc., being derived from the personalprefixes plus EH; N-EH, N-EH-HUĀ-TL "I", etc.  Athird use of (Y)EH is as a sort of anchor at the endof particle clusters; NŌCUĒLYEH "on the otherhand", QUĒNOCYEH "all the more", MĀNOCEH < MĀ NOZO (Y)EH "nor even, if only", CUIXAHZOYEH "I don'tknow whether".  These clusters are sometimes writtenspaced as separate words and sometimes solid withinternal assimilation, but the entitive sense of(Y)EH remains plausible in even the most lexicalizedof them.

(y)ehhuā-tl.English: he, she, it, they, etc. (independent third personpronoun)
(y)ehhuā-tl.Comment: This is the long form of the third person referentYEH = EH.  It sometimes appears as EHHUĀ-TL, butYEHHUĀ-TL is more common.  This also appears withoutthe absolutive, and when honorific -TZIN is attached,the absolutive is not used.

yēhua.Spanish: denantes o ahora poco ha (M), endenantes (C), hacebuen rato (C)
yēhua.Comment: The form YEYĒHUA indicates a longer space of time,YECUĒL YĒHUA even longer, and YEHUEL YĒHUA stilllonger (Cf.96v).

yehyecoā.English: to experience s.t.; to test, sample, taste s.t.
yehyecoā.Spanish: ensayarse o esgrimir (M), probar o experimentar algo(M)

(y)ehyēilhuitica.Comment: In attestations of this construction with othernumbers the reduplication is of the long vowel type,not the vowel glottal stop type.  Perhaps the glottalstop here is a reflex of stem-final Y.  R marksthe glottal stop on the secondsyllable instead of the first.

yeīconya.Comment: The component parts of this cluster are YE, ĪC, andONYA.  The last part is not readily analyzable, butit appears to be the directional prefix ON- and averb, possibly some reduction of YAUH < YĀ.

yeliz-tli.Spanish: ser o estado de cada cosa (M)

yeōhuīptla.Comment: This is constructed of YE "already", antecessive Ōand HUĪPTLA, which alone has the sense of "day aftertomorrow".

yēppa.Spanish: de antes, o antes de ahora (M)
yēppa.Comment: Of eleven attestations of this, only three have thevowel of the first syllable marked long.  In theothers it is unmarked, but the apparent relationshipof YĒPPA and YĒHUA adds support for the vowel beinglong.

yēqueneh.Spanish: y maŸs, y tambieŸn (M), finalmente, ultimamente (C)

yēquihtoā.English: to praise s.o. or s.t., to declare s.t., to explains.t.
yēquihtoā.Spanish: alabar a otro (M), lo afirma, lo declara, lo explica(T)

yēquīmpa.Spanish: hace poco, poco tiempo, recieŸn, reciente (Z)

yēquīn.Comment: This Z form seems related to YE and QUIN and also toYĒQUENEH "finally, moreover", although the vowellength and and quality do not agree.  Z consistentlyhas the vowel of the second syllable long in YĒQUĪNand YĒQUĪMPA and marks the vowel of the firstsyllable long half the time.

yetoc.Comment: This is a characteristic Z progressive constructionof the verb YE and the verb O.

yetzticah.Comment: This compound verb construction involving both YE andCĀ of the suppletive complex meaning "to be" isused in formal speech in place of the simple verb.

yeyēhua.Comment: This may be a reduplicated form of YĒHUA or thephrase YE YĒHUA "already a while ago".

(y)ēy(i).Comment: This has a variant ĒY(I).  In some constructions theinternal Y spirantizes, yielding YĒX.  In othercompounds this has the form YĒ with no finalconsonant.

yezōtla.Comment: This is a variant of IHZŌTLA

-yō.Comment: This suffix is pervasive in Nahuatl.  In addition toits sense of "abstract quality", it is used with manypossessed nouns to indicate inalienable possession;NAC(A)-TL "flesh", NONAC "my flesh, meat" (from themarket, for the table), NONACAYŌ "the flesh of mybody" (Cf.82r).  Membership in the class of nouns thattake -YŌ in the possessed form is arbitrary andextends to nonliteral cases such as TĒUC-TLI "lord",NOTĒUCYŌ = NOTĒCUIYŌ "my lord, my lordship".The Y assimilates to preceding L and Z to producesuch forms as YŌLLŌ-TL "heart, life, spirit" <YOL-YŌ and MAHUIZZŌ-TL "honor" < MAHUIZ-YŌ.Derivations with -YŌ take the absolutive suffix-TL.

yocci.Spanish: madurarse la fruta o cocerse algo (M)
yocci.Comment: Z has reorganized the first syllable of this itemfrom IUC to YOC.  The CC sequence here represents$ks), not $kk).

yōcoxcā.Comment: This is derived from YŌCOY(A) with considerableextension of meaning.

yocxitiā.Comment: This Z variant corresponds to M's IUCXITIĀ and T'sHUICXITIĀ, both with specifically marked shortvowels in the second syllable where a long vowel isto be expected.  Z does not mark the vowel long,although X has a long vowel in its variant of thiscausative form.

-yoh.Comment: There is a relationship between the abstractderivational suffix -YŌ and this suffix, which isnot incompatible with deriving -YOH by adding thepossessor suffix -HUAH to -YŌ and reducing the result.In general -YŌ refers to a quality and -YOH to aconcrete thing invested with or embodying thatquality.  In the case of contrasting YŌLLŌ-TL andYŌLLOH-TLI, both < YŌL-LI "heart" by -YŌ and -YOHrespectively, there seems to have been a confusion ofthe two derivations which has led to a suppletiverelationship.  -YŌLLŌ is used in simple possessedforms and YŌLLOH when followed by -TZIN and -TŌN(Cf.83v).  The Y of -YOH assimilates to preceding Land Z to produce such forms as YŌLLOH-TLI "heart(s.t. filled with life)" < YŌL-YOH and MAHUIZZOH"person replete with honor" < MAHUIZ-YOH.  Aside fromYŌLLOH-TLI "heart" and ĪXTELOLOH-TLI "eyeball",-YOH derivations in general do not take an absolutivesuffix.

-yohcāuh.English: one's possession, s.t. for oneself alone
-yohcāuh.Spanish: cosa miŸa (M for first pers. sg. possessor)
-yohcāuh.Comment: This is related to M's yocatia "to take possessionof, appropriate s.t."  T has YŌ in place of YOH.

yohua.English: to get dark, for night to fall

yohualnepantlah.Spanish: media noche, o a media noche (M)

yohuatiman(i).English: for night to fall, to be night

yohuatzinco.English: in the morning, early in the morning
yohuatzinco.Spanish: de man9ana, o por la man9ana, o man9ana, o demadrugada (M)

yohyohuac.English: to be dark in several places, everywhere

yohyohuatoc.English: to be dark in several places, everywhere

yōl-.Grammar: modifying element incorporated in verbs and referringto volition, emotions
yōl-.Comment: Although attestation of the noun YŌL-LI "heart" islimited to X, this related modifying element ishighly productive.  With transitive verbs there canbe ambiguity between YŌL-LI as an incorporatedobject and modifying YŌL-.  The ambiguity parallelsthat discussed under XŌCHITĒMOĀ andXŌCHIPEHPEN(A).  YŌL-, YŌLLŌ-TL, and YŌLLOH-TLIseem to have largely fallen together so thatdistinction among them is more functional thansemantic, with YŌL- used adverbially, -YŌLLŌ insimple possessed forms, and YŌLLOH elsewhere, allwith an extended sense that encompasses emotion,volition, strength, valor, and heart.  Thisdistribution is by no means exceptionless, asdemonstrated by such doublets as YŌLCĒHUIĀ =TLAYŌLLOHCĒHUIĀ both with the sense of "toplacate, satisfy s.o."

-yōlcā.Comment: This occurs as part of the phrase -YŌLCĀ -NENCĀ(both possessed) with "sustenance" as the sense ofthe whole construction.  It is a different item fromM's yolcatl "vermin".  The long vowel of the secondsyllable is not directly attested, but it is impliedby the related item YŌLCĀYŌ-TL.

-yōlcān.Spanish: patria o tierra natural de alguno (M)

yōlcāyō-tl.English: one's sustenance, that by which one lives
yōlcāyō-tl.Spanish: el mantenimiento y sustento con que vivimos (C)
yōlcāyō-tl.Comment: This is a different item from M's yolcayotl "snail,slug", which is related to M's yolcatl "vermin".

yōlcēhu(i).Comment: This is indirectly attested in YŌLCĒHUIĀ.

yōlcēhuiā.English: to calm down; to calm, placate, satisfy s.o.
yōlcēhuiā.Comment: This implies intransitive YŌLCĒHU(I).  Z hasTLAYŌLLOHCĒHUIĀ with the same sense.

yōlchicāhu(a).English: to take courage, to incite oneself to bravery; toincite s.o. to bravery
yōlchicāhu(a).Spanish: animarse y esforzarse (M), animar a otro de estamanera (M)

yōlcocoā.English: to be in pain, to grieve, to suffer envy; to feelsorry for s.o.
yōlcocoā.Spanish: tener pena o arrepentimiento, o tener envidia de algo(M), tiene duelo, tiene laŸstima, tiene tristeza,tiene sentimiento (T), le da laŸstima (T)

yōlcocoliā.English: to aggravate s.o., to hurt s.o.'s feelings
yōlcocoliā.Comment: Both attestations are short one CO syllable.

yōlcuep(a).English: to change one's mind; to change s.o. else's mind
yōlcuep(a).Spanish: mudar el parecer y propoŸsito que teniŸa (M), hacer aotro que mude el propoŸsito o parecer que teniŸa (M)

yōlcuītiā.English: to confess, make confession; to confess s.o.

yōlēhu(a).English: for one's emotions to be stirred, to fall in love; toexcite s.o.
yōlēhu(a).Spanish: provocarse o incitarse a algo, o enamorarse (M),provocar asiŸ a otro (M)
yōlēhu(a).Comment: Z has this with the sense "to invite s.o."

yōl(i).English: to live; to come to life, to hatch
yōl(i).Spanish: vivir, resucitar, avivar, o empollarse el huevo (M)

-yōlīcahtzin.English: polite phrase for greeting or passing
-yōlīcahtzin.Comment: The literal sense of this is very close to "take iteasy".

yōlicnīuh-tli.Comment: Z only gives this in the plural, M only in possessedform.

yōlihtlacoā.English: to suffer; to hurt or offend others
yōlihtlacoā.Spanish: recibir pena (M), dar pena o ofender a otro (M)

yōlīhuani.Spanish: instrumento para vivir (C), que da vida (C)

yōlihuītiā.Comment: There is a simpler causative derivation YŌLĪTIĀ <YŌL(I).

yōlīpantiā.English: to give notice, to announce; to announce, proclaims.t.
yōlīpantiā.Spanish: avisa, anuncia (T), le avisa, le advierte, le anuncia(T)
yōlīpantiā.Comment: T specifically marks the vowel of the first syllableof ĪPANTIĀ short, but ĪPANTILIĀ in C has itmarked long.

yōllāliā.English: to be consoled, content, happy; to console, cheers.o.

yōl-li.Comment: This is abundantly attested as a free form in X butnot elsewhere.  M has only yoli, yuli "livingthing", which is a different word.  Therelated verb-modifying element YŌL-, which impliesvolition or emotional involvement, is highlyproductive, and there is potential ambiguity betweenit and YŌL-LI as an incorporated object.  YŌL-LI,YŌLLŌ-TL, and YŌLLOH-TLI are virtually synonymousbut tend to different grammatical functions.

yōllohtlahuēlīlōcācuep(a).Spanish: os enfurece (C for first pers. plural object)

yōllohtzetzeloā.English: to empty out, cleanse s.o.'s heart
yōllohtzetzeloā.Spanish: le sacude el corazoŸn, le limpia el corazoŸn (T)
yōllohtzetzeloā.Comment: T has characteristically lost a glottal stop in the secondsyllable but leaves evidence of it in the syllable's short O.If YŌLLŌ-TL were the initial component, there would bethe reflex of Ō instead.

yōllohxōchi-tl.Spanish: flor muy olorosa de hechura de corazoŸn (M), $flor decorazoŸn)

yōllōtiā.English: to confide in a friend; to inspire s.o.
yōllōtiā.Spanish: descubrir algo al amigo (M), inspirar algo a otro (M)

yōllō-tl.Spanish: corazoŸn o meollo de fruta seca (M), su corazoŸn, sualma, su aŸnima (Z)
yōllō-tl.Comment: This is almost always possessed.  -YŌLLŌ seems toserve as the possessed form of both the abstractionhere and the more concrete YŌLLOH-TLI, except whenthe latter is suffixed with -TZIN or -TŌN.  This isdiscussed in C on f.83v.

yōlmalacachoā.English: to lose one's bearings, to change one's mind; toconfuse, deceive, bewitch s.o.
yōlmalacachoā.Spanish: desatinarse o volverse de otro parecer (M), desatinara otro, o traerlo al retortero, o ligarlo conhechizos (M)

yōlmelāhuac.Comment: This is different in sense from M's yolmelaua,which has to do with confession.

yōlmictoc.Comment: M has yolmiqui "one who has fainted" with a similarderivation.  Both are from YŌLMIQU(I) "to be faintof heart, dispirited, depressed".

yōlmiqu(i).English: to be faint of heart, dispirited, depressed
yōlmiqu(i).Spanish: desmayarse o amortecerse, o tener comezoŸn, oespantarse (M)
yōlmiqu(i).Comment: This is indirectly attested in YŌLMICTOC.

yōlnēntoc.Lexical Reference: see YŌL-LI, NĒN, the verb O

yōlpahzoloā.Spanish: se aflige (de molestia), se molesta (T), lo molesta(T)

yōlpāquic.Comment: Only one of three attestations has the final -C.

yōlquetz(a).Comment: The gloss of this item seems contrary to the sense ofits constituent parts.

yōlqui.English: a living thing, s.t. brought to life
yōlqui.Spanish: animal bruto, o cosa viva, o huevo empollado, o elresucitado de muerte a vida (M)
yōlqui.Comment: B forms the plural in regular fashion, YŌLQUEH,while X adds -MEH.

yōlquīzac.Comment: This is opposite in sense from M's verb yolquixtia"to annoy s.o. very much".  Of five attestations,three have final -C and two do not.  On Zp.232 bothforms are given as separate entries, although theglosses do not contrast.

yōltequipachoā.English: to become sad, to be regretful
yōltequipachoā.Spanish: tener pesar de lo que hizo (M)

yōltihticuīn(i).Comment: This is only attested once; TI should probably beTZI.

yōltotomocatoc.Lexical Reference: see YŌL-, TOTOMOCA, the verb O

yōltzacuīz-tli.English: for s.o.'s breathing to be cut off
yōltzacuīz-tli.Comment: The second element of this is a contraction of*TZACUILIZ-TLI < TZACUILIĀ "to impede s.t."

yōlyamānic.Spanish: justo, benigno, beneŸvolo, manso, suave, tierno (Z)

yōlyamāniliz-tli.Comment: Z has YE for YA and NAL for NIL.

yōmohtlan-tli.Spanish: costado de persona o de sierra (M)

zā.Comment: C distinguishes ZĀ from ZAN, which appearssynonymous.  According to C, ZĀ implies that thematter in question was not always as it is but hascome to be so, whereas ZAN carries no suchpresupposition (Cf.110r).  In T the reflex of ZĀalternates in about equal numbers with ZA with ashort vowel, which is the reflex of ZAN by T'sregular loss of word-final nasals.  Z alternatesbetween ZĀ and ZAH.

zacamoā.Spanish: abrir o labrar de nuevo la tierra, rozar la yerba (M)

zacatetez-tli.Comment: This may refer to chopped or ground up hay.

zāceh.Comment: This is a contraction of the sequence ZĀ ZO (Y)EH.

zahcanohpal-li.Comment: T has variants with and without the glottal stop inthe third syllable.  T also has a stem-final I, whichin turn takes the -TL form of the absolutive suffix,-NOHPALI-TL, but elsewhere NOHPAL-LI is the conventionalform.

zahuacoco-tl.Comment: This is attested only in plural form.

zahualiz-tli.Comment: Z marks the vowel of the second syllable long, but itshould not be.  This is attested eight times as anelement of personal names in B, always with both stemvowels short.

zahuanitiā.Comment: The vowel of the third syllable of this form shouldbe long but is specifically marked short.

zahua-tl.Spanish: ron9a, tin9a, viruelas (S), grano, llaga, erupcioŸn,sarpullido, viruela (T)
zahua-tl.Comment: C specifically marks the vowel of the first syllableshort, while T and Z have it long, hence contrastingwith the verb ZAHU(A) "to fast".  C contrasts this withthe place name ZĀHUĀ-TL, where both vowels are long.

zāhuā-tl.English: the name of a river in Tlaxcala
zāhuā-tl.Comment: C contrasts this with ZAHUA-TL "pox, itch".

zahzaca.English: to transport s.t. from various places
zahzaca.Spanish: acarrear algo (M), darse priesa en acarrear de variaspartes (C)

zahzāliuhyān-tli.Spanish: coyunturas de los miembros del cuerpo (M)
zahzāliuhyān-tli.Comment: This is the distributive form of ZĀLIUHYĀN-TLI"joint".

zahzāloā.English: to align s.t., to patch s.t. together

zāliuhyān-tli.English: place where things fit properly, joint
zāliuhyān-tli.Spanish: coyunturas de los miembros del cuerpo (M), en sulugar y en caja (C)
zāliuhyān-tli.Comment: Z has the variant form ZĀLIHUIYĀN.

zāloā.English: to glue, solder s.t., to make s.t. stick to s.t.else
zāloā.Spanish: pegar algo, engrudar, hacer pared, o soldar conplomo, etc. (M)

-zāzālōl.Comment: T has O for the reflex of Ā here.

-zāzāliuhyō.Comment: T has O for the reflex of Ā here.

zancuēl.Spanish: un momento, un pequen9o instante; frecuentemente, muya menudo (S)
zancuēl.Comment: This is often written as two words.

zānēn.English: I wonder if ... (with respect to something expectedor desired)
zānēn.Comment: C contrasts ZĀNĒN with ZANNĒN, the latter being anemphatic expression of NĒN "in vain" (Cf.112v,113r).

zānīl-li.Spanish: consejuelas para hacer reiŸr (M for reduplicatedform), cuento, plaŸtica, conversacioŸn (Z)
zānīl-li.Comment: This is commonly found in reduplicated form, butthere are no attestations of it in the sources forthis dictionary which would show whether thereduplication is of the short-vowel, long-vowel, orvowel-glottal stop type.

zānīloā.Comment: M has the applicative form of this verb inreduplicated form c˛ac˛anilhuia.

zānīpan.Spanish: cosa manual o mediana, o alguŸn tanto, o en algunamanera (M), medianamente, de buena manera (C)
zānīpan.Comment: Of eight attestations C marks the vowel of the firstsyllable long five times and leaves three unmarked.Apparently this is not a compound of ZAN and ĪPAN.It is often found in the phrases ZĀNĪPAN CUAL-LIand ZĀNĪPAN YĒC-TLI, both of which appear in Mwith the same sense of ZĀNĪPAN alone.

zaniyoh.Comment: Other elements can intervene between ZAN and IYOH.In Z this is reduced to ZĀYOH.

zannēn.Lexical Reference: see ZAN, NĒN, note under ZĀNĒN

zannō.English: likewise, also, by the same token (often indicatingidentity of time or place)
zannō.Spanish: identidad de lugar o tiempo (C), el mismo o los mismo(M for c˛annoye)

zanyenō.English: particle indicating identity of time or place

zātēpan.Spanish: despueŸs, a la postre, o al cabo (M), despueŸs, maŸstarde, luego (T)

zātēpanyahui.Comment: The literal sense of this is "to go afterwards".  Tcharacteristically drops word-final nasals, and whensuch an element compounds, the nasal sometimes doesnot appear, even though it is no longer in word-finalposition, and this is the case with this item.

zāyōl-in.Comment: C uses ZĀYŌL-IN as an example of how nouns with the-IN absolutive suffix can form the possessorderivation with -EH or -HUAH in free variation,ZĀYŌLEH = ZĀYŌLHUAH "one who has flies".

zāyōltēn-tli.Spanish: grano de mosco, piquete de mosco (T)

zāzahuatic.Spanish: estar ronco o zumbar, o follar las fuelles (M forc˛ac˛auaca), ronco (Z)

zazālic.Spanish: cosa pegajosa, como engrudo o cosa semejante (M)

zazāltic.Spanish: cosa pegajosa como engrudo, o cosa semejante (M)
zazāltic.Comment: M gives as synonymns c˛ac˛altic and c˛ac˛alic.T has a short vowelin ZAL despite the clear relationship to ZĀLIHU(I)and ZĀLOĀ.  In one of three attestations Z marksthe vowel long.

zāzan.English: any which way, without coherence or sense
zāzan.Comment: C has a discussion of this with repeated examples(f.115v).  T has ZĀZAN-TLI with an absolutive suffixand the sense "many things".

zazcemi.English: at one and the same time
zazcemi.Comment: M has c˛a cemi as a phrase glossed as "finally,just this once, or something said upon departure".

zāzo.Comment: This particle placed before an interrogative particlereplaces its interrogative sense with the sense of-ever constructions in English; whatever, whenever,whoever, etc.

-zo.Comment: This is a necessarily bound particle that adheres toother particles without any overt sense of its own.The vowel is often lost in particle clusters.

zō.English: to pierce oneself; to draw blood by piercing s.o.
zō.Spanish: sangrarse (M), punzar y sangrar (C), pinchar, sangrara alguien (S)

zōhu(a).English: to stretch or spread out; to extend, spread out,open s.t.
zōhu(a).Spanish: se estira (ropa, etc.), se tiende (T), tender odesplegar ropa, o abrir libro (M)

zohuaehēca-tl.Spanish: llorona, mal aire que se cambia en forma de mujer (T)

zohuahtiā.English: for a man to marry a woman
zohuahtiā.Comment: Here a glottal stop intervenes between ZOHUA and theverbal suffix -TIĀ.

zohuāhuah.English: one who has a wife, a married man
zohuāhuah.Comment: This is the only instance in T in which the vowel ofthe second syllable of ZOHUA-TL is given as thereflex of a long vowel.  The short vowel of the otherattestations of ZOHUA-TL contrasts with that ofCIHUĀ-TL, which is consistently attested long.

zohuahuehxōlō-tl.Comment: This is contradictory, since HUEHXŌLŌ-TL in generalspecifically means "turkey cock".

zohuamōn-tli.Comment: In the Spanish-to-Nahuatl side, T gives this as agloss for nuera "daughter-in-law".  In terms pertaining toin-law relationships the vowel of the MŌN element isconsistently short in T and consistently longelsewhere.

zohua-tl.Comment: Although CIHUĀ-TL is the standard form for theValley of Mexico, M also gives c˛ouatl.  ZOHUA-TLis the standard form in T and is widely spread inmodern Nahuatl.  Although the vowel of the secondsyllable of CIHUĀ-TL is long, T does not have thereflex of a long vowel in ZOHUA-TL or in any of itsderivations with the exception of ZOHUĀHUAH "one whohas a wife".

zohuatōtol.Comment: This is only attested without an absolutive prefix.

zohzō.English: to string things together by piercing and threadingthem.
zohzō.Spanish: ensartar cuentas, ajiŸ, flores, o cosas semejantes(M)
zohzō.Comment: In T there has been characteristic loss of theinternal glottal stop.

zohzōhu(a).English: to spread open one's arms; to spread s.t. out
zohzōhu(a).Spanish: $abrir los brazos); tender o desplegar mantas, oabrir libros (M)

zohzōhua.English: to nail s.t., to pierce s.t.

zohzōlhuiā.Comment: T has the reflex of a short vowel in the secondsyllable where a long vowel is to be expected.

zohzoquihuiā.Comment: T is missing the glottal stop of the initialreduplicated syllable, but short vowel reduplicationis unlikely here.

zohzōtiman(i).English: to touch and pierce s.t. such as the sky
zohzōtiman(i).Comment: This is derived from ZŌ, but C does not mark thevowel of the second syllable long in one attestationand in the other marks it short.

-zol-li.Comment: Unlike -TZIN-TLI, -TŌN-TLI, etc., this has noreduplicated plural, since it is only used withinanimate objects (Cf.8r).

zoloā.English: to exhaust oneself; to wear s.t. out
zoloā.Comment: Z has one attestation of ZOLHUIĀ and two of ZOLOĀ,all with the sense of "to exhaust, tire s.o."

zolōn(i).English: for s.t. to rush along with a great noise
zolōn(i).Spanish: ir con gran iŸmpetu y ruiŸdo el riŸo (M)

zōmā.Spanish: yo tengo cen9o como enojado (C for first pers. sg.subject)

zōmāliā.English: to become angry, to work oneself into a rage
zōmāliā.Comment: The vowel of the second syllable should be long butis not so marked in the two attestations.

zōnēhu(a).English: for s.t. to swell, puff up; to make s.t. swell orpuff up
zōnēhu(a).Spanish: azorarse el ave (M), alterar o alborotar la gente(M), apitonarse o azorarse o crecer mucho el agua deriŸo, o azorarse el perro o el gato, etc. (M), seinfla, se esponja (T)

zōnēhualtiā.English: to cause s.t. to swell; to suffocate

zoquiaquiā.English: to bury oneself in mud; to bury s.o. or s.t. in mud
zoquiaquiā.Spanish: se entierra en lodo (T), lo mete al lodo (piedra,etc.) (T)

zoquichīhu(a).English: to mix mud for foundations and adobe
zoquichīhu(a).Spanish: hacer barro para edificar pared o para hacer adobes,etc. (M)
zoquichīhu(a).Comment: This is indirectly attested by ZOQUICHĪUHQUI.

zoquichīuhqui.Comment: According to M, this is "one who makes said clay"for foundations and adobe.

zoquihuiā.English: to get soiled with mud; to soil s.t. with mud

zoquineloā.English: to soil oneself, s.o. with mud

zoquipachoā.English: to sink into mud; to spread mud over s.t.
zoquipachoā.Spanish: se entierra dentro del lodo (T), estercolar la tierraen cierta manera (M)

zoquiti.Spanish: mojarse, hacerse una sopa de agua (M), volver cieno(C)

zoquitlah.Comment: The vowels of the second and third syllables are marked longin one of the attestations in Z, but they should all beshort.

zoquitōca.English: to stick s.t. in mud, to bury s.t. in mud
zoquitōca.Spanish: se atasca, se entierra en lodo (T), lo entierradentro el lodo (T)

zoquiyoh.Comment: This conventionally pairs with TLĀLLOH, bothpossessed, to refer to one's earthly body.

zōtoc.Comment: In one of the attestations both vowels are markedlong and in the other neither.

zōtōl-in.Spanish: palma (M); planta para hacer tenates, canasta (Z)

zōyā-tl.Comment: T has this with a short vowel in the first syllableand the reflex of Ō in the second.

zozolca.Comment: This seems to be a truncated variant of ZOZOLOCA "tomake a rumbling noise".

zozolcahuiā.Comment: One of the attestations marks the vowels of thesecond and third syllables long, but they should notbe.

zozoloca.English: to make a rumbling or roaring noise
zozoloca.Spanish: follar o zumbar las fuelles, o anhelar el que estaŸmuriendo (M), hace ruido (como frijol hirviendo) (T)

zozolocatihu(i).Spanish: de la piedra tirada con fuerza o de la codorniz quese levanta y vuela se dice (C)

zozolotz(a).English: to cause s.t. to make a rumbling, roaring sound
zozolotz(a).Spanish: hacer ruido el chorro de agua que cae sobre otra agua(M)
